review_body: I stayed in one of the luxury mature double rooms on the fifteen floor. This was a great room for Tokyo with quite a bit of space. This hotel has rooms for every budget and the cheaper rooms are of course smaller and very much in line with your average Tokyo hotel room. I really enjoyed this location as there were many great places to eat within a comfortable walking distance and while there are love hotels near this location it is a very safe place and I was never uncomfortable walking the streets of Tokyo. All the staff spoke English well and I had no communication issues. All the staff were very helpful and I very much enjoyed my stay.

We love the room..every day they will replenish complimentary coke and green tea and 1 bottle of water in the bar fridge on top of the usual 2 bottle of water will be at the bar counter as usual.This room come with access to lvl 13 club lounges area where there is free flow of beer and wine during 5pm to 7pm. And the view of the club lounge area is amazing too. There is coffee,juice snacks at the club lounge area too so my 6 years old daughter really likes to go there and relax.Location is really quite easy to walk to the train station

Review is for the Deluxe Designer Double - Casual. Amazing views, we were on the 16th floor and wouldn't have had it any other way. The room, while small, was accommodating for two. The bathroom was definitely the a really nice feature in the room, definitely used the tub almost every night of our 7 night stay. Price is affordable for Tokyo, but for someone coming from America, it's a considerable shock having to pay per person. We added the daily breakfast buffet, which I looked forward to every morning. A lot of the reviewers on here complain about the selection, but I was more than happy with the Asian options of curry, mackerel, and kimchi (great way to start the day, smelly breath and all!) Unfortunately, by our 5th day, the impending threat of the coronavirus turned the buffet into a standard 3-course, western breakfast, which I was less than interested in (why travel to another country to eat what you're accustomed to??)The hotel is in a very convenient location that may seem far on the map from other spots in Shinjuku, but you won't even notice it with how densely packed everything is and all the lights and sounds. Safety was never a concern for us, besides from some very aggressive taxi drivers who seem as if they're on a mission to hit you. In the mornings, you can see groups of young, drunk kids walking around, but that's about it. Overall, our trip to Tokyo was greatly benefitted from our stay here and we'll consider it again when we return.

Stayed twice here; the hotel is located not too close to the centre of Shinjuku but is still very convenient to anywhere; the vibe is great and there are lots of entertainment nearby, including a place where you can play baseball. The staff are friendly and I will stay again if i go Tokyo next time.

The hotel is just 5 minutes walk from Higashi-Shinjuku Station (subway). Staffs were really friendly and helpful during check in process. The hotel rooms are quite small but it's understandable since it's hard to find bigger room with similar price in Tokyo. Overall, we really had great stay there!

This place felt good from the moment we walked in. Well located (you hardly even notice it's in the red light district), with an attractive lobby, friendly staff and a cool roof bar, which did good margaritas! We splashed out on a spacious Deluxe Design Double room on the 13th floor with great city views, handy to the club lounge, breakfast restaurant and bar. The room was stylishly designed with a comfortable king bed and good TV. The only down sides were the bathroom: the shower flooded the floor; there were no hooks to hang the towels; and the handheld shower was in a non-adjustable holder. There was also a lack of space for our suitcases. The western breakfast options were also a bit limited if you were staying a few days. But I'd definitely stay here again.

First time staying here and would recommend it to anyone who’s looking to stay in Tokyo, very central area and you will be proud when you realize your hotel is the biggest and looks the best in the area. The rooftop bar has a great pizza and even greater view with heaters and blankets provided if it’s chilly. The front desk staff are very knowledgeable and provide free umbrellas to guests if it rains. We paid 1,700 yen each for the breakfast when we were in a crunch for time and it’s pretty pricey (unless you pick breakfast included) however did not disappoint - a good variety of western , chinese and japanese food to pick from. Only con is that we did get a room that was not the one we selected in the photo, considered a downgrade with the smaller size and more basic decor but had a great view. An FYI for more high maintenance travellers: there is only a few hangers for clothing storage in the room we were given and a small counter in the bathroom for toiletries. A reviving positive: there were full bottles of shampoo/conditioner and body wash and the toilet is heated :) Thanks Granbell! Please give us an extra nice room next time to make up for it :) ahaha

The highlight of the hotel is its excellent location. It is right in the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku bar and dining precinct, making dinner and a few drink out at night super easy.In saying this, there are no noisy restaurants or club next door to the hotel so you can head back there at night time and enjoy absolute peace.It’s about a 10 minute walk to the Shinjuku train station, which open up access to the entirety of Tokyo. The hotel rooms themselves are quite small, just big enough for a queen bed and bench storage plus a bathroom. This is standard for Tokyo so you won’t find many larger rooms for a reasonable price. The room was tidy and liveable. Staff were friendly and helpful at all times, and the included breakfast was always good. Overall we enjoyed our stay at the Shinjuku Granbell hotel as it allowed us to explore Shinjuku and the greater Tokyo region with easy. Would recommend to family and friends.

Hotel is large and modern, in a great location for walking and catching public transport. Rooms are comfortable and stylish. Coffee on sight is good (but expensive as we are finding all good coffee in Tokyo to be). Bar upstairs is nice also. Would definitely recommend and are staying again next week.

My husband and I travelled together, we are in our late 30's and early 40s. We usually like to stay in boutique style hotels, and we were in Tokyo for 4 nights. In doing a ton of research, this hotel ticked all the boxes in terms of the modern vibe we were looking for and the price point. Yes, true to all the other reviews, the room is small. However, if you get creative with space (I put one suitcase under the desk and used it as a shelf for clothing and we placed another suitcase on the rack), it wasn't bad! I liked the location, the shower was strong, the bed was comfortable and they provided pajamas! It has a full length mirror. The heater worked well, we had a nice view. The staff was polite and we found the vending machines and money changer machine inside the hotel to be really convenient. I honestly have no complaints and would stay here again, as well as recommend to friends and family!

We stayed here for the first few nights of our honeymoon in January 2020 to explore the Shinjuku/Golden Gai area of Tokyo before moving on to other neighborhoods. Though the location of the hotel is very central and easily accessible, the hotel itself was disappointing. We paid a lot for a “suite” that was barely suite level, and felt deceived by the misleading pictures online (clearly a common problem based on other reviews). The bathroom sink was huge, which resulted in not much counter space for toiletries or for a woman to do her makeup. There was not much closet space for 2 guests, either. But what bothered me the most was that the staff did absolutely nothing to make us feel special or extra welcome for being there for the start of our honeymoon. My husband had noted that our stay would be for exactly that reason, which also coincided with New Year’s Eve and our first time in Japan overall. No chocolates or champagne in the room, no welcome drink at any point, not even an acknowledgement upon checking in. The Granbell staff should be trained a little better on paying attention to those details and going above and beyond for guests paying good money to be there.

Our stay at Granbell was great, perfect location close to all entertainment in shinjuku, robot cafe is less than 10 mins away. Station close by with easy access to whole of Tokyo. The hotel gives you great amenities for your stay- everything you need they have. Only complaint would be the room was tiny however this is common in Tokyo.

This is my third time staying at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel - however, it would be my last time after a very unpleasant experience.I booked a double room for 31 Jan to 2 Feb for my vacation. As it is a double room, it was my expectation that the room will be able to be occupied by 2 persons. After checking in, I invited my friend to come to the room and chill a bit before dinner. However, the reception told us to pay extra 5,500 yen if my friend wanted to "enter the room." This is extremely unreasonable and confusing. As I have checked in the room, why I would have to pay extra for a short visit from my friend?While I was trying to discuss the situation with the staff at the front desk, the staffs were extremely impolite with a discriminating tone. Sakura Miyata (the manager at the front desk) was very rude and even shouted "Just pay!" in our face. When we requested to speak to the hotel manager, she claimed herself as the "only manager" and rejected to further discuss with us.The disrespectful and discriminating tone has made our trip very unpleasant and I would not return to Granbell Hotel again because of Sakura!

We stayed here in April 2018 on our first visit to Tokyo.The hotel was comfortable, clean and very easy to find. The room was a decent size considering it was in Tokyo. The bed was comfortable.The staff were wonderful and were very helpful when we were struggling to find out our pick-up time for our airport transfer. They contacted the company for us and got all the information we needed!Great, central and safe location. It was perfect for us.We got engaged while staying here, and have just booked to go back this April for our honeymoon!

Located in the nightlife part of Tokyo...Shinjuku. Very pleasant and helpful staff at reception. First impressions were not great as the reception/ lobby area is very small and probably needs refreshing. There’s a small cafe in the lobby and also vending machines for drinks and snacks. For the week we stayed the restaurant was not open in the evening however bar snacks were available in the terraced bar...which does have a spectacular view at night. The staff in the bar were very attentive and helpful. We stayed in a Hollywood twin room. The rooms are small but the space is used very well. Rooms were modern, very clean and have Wi-fi which worked well. There’s a few nice touches such as free toiletries, bottles of water etc. There is only one English speaking channel on the tv which was CNN, which was disappointing. In summary a pleasant stay for the price range.

It was our first time in Tokyo and our honeymoon, and we couldn’t be happier with Shinjuku Granbell! We stayed here for a week and it proved to be the perfect spot - great walking distance to Golden Gai and nearby train stations. We especially loved coming back to happy hour at the rooftop bar to rest our tired feet before heading out again for the evening. It was never too crowded and felt like a hidden gem. I liked how the hotel was quite discreet and hidden by a garden, in amongst love hotels. Never felt unsafe in the area either, and great nightlife all around. The room was quite spacious by Japan standards I believe. A nice bath and pretty view of the city! I would definitely stay here again, a lovely home base in this incredible city. They also gave us a little gift for our honeymoon and the staff were wonderful.

Lovely place to stay with a fabulous rooftop bar. Fantastic location with lots of great restaurants nearby. Good breakfast and helpful staff also fabulous views of the city to enjoy while you eat. Would highly recommend this hotel.

Decent room size for a Tokyo hotel. What we didn’t like was the very strict check-in and check-out protocol. They ring your room on the dot to tell you to check out. In our hurry, we left a newly purchased sake wood ware box set in the room.After checking out we went back to the hotel to get it but they only gave back the 2 sake cups while the carafe was missing from the box set! Dishonest staff. Very disappointing. We left the hotel giving them a chance to complete the set by asking them to mail us the box set once they “find” the carafe. They never did.

Bit of a walk from the train station, but very nice. Accommodating staff when requests were made (pillows, water, bedding), good bar facility, fair spread for buffet breakfast. A very comfortable stay. 8th-14th jan, room 1552.

Having stayed here a couple of times before, we won’t be coming back after this last time. Over the years the hotel has aged fairly fast and what I thought were teething problems is actually complete apathy from the staff. The staff actually couldn’t be more unhelpful. You really just feel like a number going in and then out. On rope of everything they made it very hard to make a restaurant reservation, and we were charged over au$100 cause of 1/4 nip of whisky spilt on a sheet.

Stayed here from 28th Dec - 3rd Jan in a mature designer double room on one of the executive floors. While the room was lovely and clean the breakfast and executive lounge fell very short of what I'd expect in a 4 star hotel.The breakfast lacked choices and the quality was poor. I've attached pictures, but there was no fresh fruit, only the tinned type in liquid. The bread for toast was the most basic sliced bread. The fruit juices came straight from cartons, I saw the cartons being emptied into the jugs on two mornings. The scrambled egg didn't look appetizing as it was radioactive yellow in colour. There were 3 types of pastries on offer, again considering the quality of bakery offerings we saw in Tokyo these were basic. As a vegetarian who wanted a western breakfast my choices were extremely limited. On our first morning I asked the gentleman in charge if there was any possibility I could get 2 fried eggs and his response was an abrupt no, he was the rudest person we encountered in Tokyo during our whole stay. He didn't even enquire why I was asking, allergy aware he definitely wasn't! You had to self serve your drinks when 4 star hotels always serve you. There was no black tea or English breakfast tea. The hotel was busy while we were there and the breakfast spread clearly couldn't cope, people were stepping round each other and in general it felt like a slight step up from school canteen or food hall. Definitely not a relaxing pleasant start to the day. In 6 days we skipped breakfast 3 times it was that bad! A tip if you're looking for a good western breakfast go to Bakery and Restaurant Sawamura round the corner from the expressway bus terminal at Shinjuku station.The executive lounge lacked choices, the beer and wine offered between 5-7pm was Chardonnay or Malbec with 1 or 2 choices of beer. The nibbles were 3 types of savoury snacks from little jars on the side or dried fruit with tea and coffe or soft drinks. In most hotels if you're staying on the executive floor you can opt to have breakfast in the executive lounge but that's not possible here. One evening there were a few people in the lounge but staff weren't present so I had to go to the bar across the hallway to ask for the beer to be replenished. Overall the executive lounge felt very sub standard with the food and drink offerings, although the views are lovely. Given it's on the same floor as the bar why isn't the choice better? We needed to print our boarding passes (wasn't clear if our airline would accept mobile ones) we asked somebody in the executive lounge but no we had to go to reception downstairs. Last picture shows executive lounge offering.The mature designer double room we had, (room 1603) was spacious, clean and very nice, reasonably comfortable beds, shower worked well but wifi was dropping out/was slow at points, in the executive lounge the wifi was good.Location of the hotel was good, yes it's a 15min walk to Shinjuku station but we liked that and we found the area immediately around the hotel (kabukicho and Golden Gai) great for evenings out.Overall I can't recommend this hotel as there are better options around Shinjuku. If we come back to Tokyo I'd definitely stay around Shinjuku but in another hotel. Also to put my breakfast moan(!) above inti context we're currently staying in a 4 star hotel on a Philippines island and the breakfast and wifi is far superior!

I just needed a place to sleep overnight but I didn’t want to stay at cheap hotel. The hotel itself is very nice and clean! Shinjuku station is walking distance. If you are thinking about staying here, just note it’s located in the middle of red light district.

Great location for sight seeing and ideal for the Golden Gai however we left the bus at Shinjuku station and couldnt get a taxi to agree to be dropped off so had to find the hotel which wasnt easy.Breakfast was very good and the room was clean.

Clean and welcoming big hotel with 24/7 hours reception service. The breakfast was very japanese and they could not arrange breakfast pack for our early travels. 10-15 min walk from Shinjuku Station. Almost like a red light district outside but didnt do much, did not hear any sounds. Small but nice rooms. Breakfast and restaurant on top floors with great view

It's a shame that we were here during the typhoon; we felt like the staff were not prepared as the only restaurant had ran out of food and the vending machines were quickly emptied of snacks as well; it's a good thing that we loaded up at the 7-11 earlier in the morning. We had a 'larger' room which was really nice and having the 'happy hour' perk during the typhoon was nice in the business lounge; it was unfortunate, however, that they didn't give us access to that on the first night of our stay.The hotel is really clean and the staff are very courteous.

Booked this hotel on a recommendation. Good location, and was close to The Samurai Museum, and shopping and the train station. Nice serviceNice hotel (beds are a little firm) Good value for money Room quite small but pretty good for Tokyo

The bustling metropolis of Tokyo gives way to the serenity of this inner city hotel. Service was terrific, breakfast hot and varied and rooms with views amazing. Our room was supplied with a mobile phone to use around the city, including free calls to Australia. Good location with walking distance to train stations, restaurants, pub, shops and temples. Heated dunny seats gives new meaning to a warm toilet seat.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for 5 nights. The hotel was in a convenient location, about a 10-15 min walk to the station. It is near the seedy area as others point out, but it’s not bad at all - few drunken business men and that’s about it. We also did find a route completely avoiding it too if it bothered you. We stayed in one of the larger rooms on the 15th floor. The room was nice, good size and had a great view. The only thing we could really criticise was there was basically no where to put clothes (about 4 hangers and no draw space) so we lived out of suitcases. The breakfast was good, loads of choice and lots of western options which was good for us. We always felt full and didn’t need to eat again until mid afternoon.I would recommend this hotel for anyone staying to Tokyo for the first time. It’s also convenient for getting to Hakone which was one of our highlights!

The hotel is perfectly placed in the vibrant area of shinjuku near many restaurants and bars. The hotel itself is very nice and offers a great roof top terrace overlooking the local area with great transport links to central Tokyo

Yep, I'd call it the red light district but it was still a great location. Easy access to restaurants, shops, Robot show. Small rooms but clean. We were traveling with our own and they did not have a triple so they put us in two rooms. The Japanese have it going on when it comes to toilets!

Stayed for 3 nights, end of November 2019.As soon as we confirmed our accommodation at the hotel, we were pleasantly contacted via email for our arrival details, with a polite note that we could leave our luggages for safe keeping in case we arrive early before the check-in time of 3pm.The hotel is easily accessible via the Shinjuku Station (about 15-20 minutes walk), the Shinjuku-Sanchome station (7-10 minutes walk) and the Higashi Shinjuku station (4-5 minutes walk) depending on how fast you walk. Our preference is via the Higashi Shinjuku station as it is the easiest and the fastest amongst the three routes. As you arrive by the subway train, head for gate A1. Fortunately, there are escalators going up from the underground to the upper levels of the station and therefore, it is a welcoming help, especially when you are tired, having travelled over a long period of time, tugging your luggages. As you exit the Higashi Shinjuku station, turn left and walked for about 30-35 metres. Turn left at the first road and the tall white building at a distance of about 120-130 metres on your right is the Granbell Hotel. You can enter/exit the hotel through the side sliding door. However, you will need your room access card to open this door at night. If you need to enter through the main door, it is just round the corner of the building.The reception is manned by 3-4 personnel and they are capable of conversing in English, therefore, it should not be a problem to bombard them with any of your questions or asking for directions. They are very friendly, genuinely polite and most helpful.The rooms are of standard sizes as you can find in any Japanese hotels but the one we had, had a compact bathroom with a bathtub and a modern WC that features heated seats with electronic gadgets for buttock washings, etc. It is equipped with the necessary toiletries, bedroom slippers, bathrobes, hairdryer, coffee making facilities, a safe deposit box and even a pair of pyjamas. There is a small work table with a table lamp next to the semi double bed. A 20in LED TV hangs on the wall fronting the bed. Two bottles of mineral water (500ml each) are supplied FOC daily.Breakfast is served between 7am to 10.30am at the 12th floor restaurant and there is a fairly good selection of food served, ranging from simple Western to Japanese/Chinese dishes, fruits (pineapple cutlets & grapefruits), fruit juices, fresh milk, soya milk, cereals, bread, porridge, salads, teas and coffee. There is a ‘Return Point” shelf where one needs to bring back used plates and cutleries for the kitchen staffs to wash later.The rooms and the surrounding access areas within the hotel are clean. They even have a few air purifiers placed along the corridors leading to the rooms. Another plus factor is that there are many restaurants and convenience shops located within short walking distance from the hotel which one may find it useful. This is a fine hotel, strategically located near to the subway train stations, served by friendly, helpful personnels and not overly expensive to stay. It is a highly recommended place to stay if you intend to visit Shinjuku, Tokyo.

An Economy Double at 15 sq m is the smallest room I’ve ever stayed in. For a single person, it was functionally designed well with some trendy touches. I would stay in such a small room if it was more than one person. For example, the bathroom shelf only had enough room for my own toiletries. Not far from Metro subway stations but not close either. If being really close to a station is important, you should find another. We could not find really good close restaurant and coffee shop. Anything really good seem to be a ten minute walk, except a 7-11 around the corner. Lobby space seemed crowded most days. Not the biggest factor, but lack up comfortable places to sit and wait.Visited roof top bar a couple of times because of nice view and pleasant service. Nothing really negative about hotel, but nothing sticks out for a reason to stay again. This is in contrast to other Tokyo hotels I have reviewed.

Excellent hotel, within a couple of minutes walk of the centre of Shinjuku, and 5 minutes from the train station.Room was on the smaller side, but pretty standard by Tokyo standards. Bathroom was modern and clean.Hotel bar on the top floor was very good, with great views out over the city on the terrace - would recommend there for a good view in the evening.Overall would recommend this hotel and stay again.

The hotel looks much better in pictures. I found the room wasn’t very clean - dirt on walls (the kind that can be wiped off) and our bed had a brown mark on it. We had to ask for more pillows because the pillows have massive hard lumps (like a stuck together bean bag) and killed our necks.The food is average - what you’d expect on an aeroplane. LOCATION:This hotel is smack bang in the centre of the red light district in Tokyo. I thoroughly researched this hotel and Shinjuku and not once did I read an honest review about the specifics of the location of the hotel. There are prostitutes on street corners throughout the evenings with signs around the neck detailing their prices, there is rubbish and garbage everywhere and the most horrible smells (we bought masks for when walking back to the hotel) and the Japanese Mafia own a number of restaurants within 10 meters. Further - we saw a drunk man in a suit fighting with a woman and man in the early hours of the morning (evidence of their escapades from their night before). The hotel is in the same side street as a number of love hotels (hotels used for a few hours by brothels that organise “blind dates”)... you get the picture.All in all, had the hotel been in a different location, the hotel would be just okay.

I really enjoyed staying at this fabulous hotel, it is well set up with clean and safe and comfortable rooms including excellent bathroom amenities. The staff are friendly and helpful, there is a restaurant and bar within the hotel as well as a cafe - even vending machines which sell hot and cold drinks. Right in the fun heart of Shinjuku and an easy walk to see Godzilla and the robot restaurant. This was my first trip to Japan and I felt comfortable and relaxed right away with the excellent facilities and service. Highly recommended - I actually stayed in August of 2018, but I can't select that date

This was my 4th stay at the Shinjuku Granbell. I have stayed in the regular economy rooms, the "Delux" ones and this time decided to splurge for a Luxury Design Double on the 15th floor. In my opinion it was definitely worth it. Plenty of room, a huge window overlooking the city, a roomy bathroom with a great shower and a separate bathtub. The staff were helpful and attentive and when I mentioned that the shower was only "warm" and not as hot as I like it, they sent someone up and had it fixed before my next shower.Working in the hospitality industry myself, I realise that you will never please everyone with breakfast, but I think there could be improvements made. While the Asian offerings of miso soup and kimchi, etc. were excellent, the Western offerings were not great. The scrambled eggs were so runny you had to eat them with a spoon and the bacon so raw you could barely call it ham. As I mentioned above, the room was great, but there does need to be something additional for hanging clothes, or jackets, etc as there was only a tiny rack next to the entrance that could fit 2 winter coats and that was it. There wasn't even a spot to hang and dry used towels in the bathroom so we had to drape them over a chair.

Once I managed to find the hotel I was very happy with it. A great bed in a nice sized room for Tokyo, view of suburban Tokyo (I would have preferred the other side looking toward the busier part of town), a deep bath and so nicely decorated. It was a great place to recover from long days exploring Tokyo. The smoking area at the front of the hotel was a lovely place to sit and listen to the sounds of Tokyo's Jungle Crows and passing crowds. A very nice roof top bar/restaurant had commanding views toward Shinjuku. The staff were lovely too. The only downer was late at night running the gauntlet of many African high pressure hawkers trying to entice one into shady bars in Kabukicho (The police broadcast loudspeaker messages about hawkers BUT do nothing about them...why?). My solution? Don't even acknowledge their existence and walk on by. One extra dryer in the self service laundry would be nice too. Would I stay again? Yes totally now I know how to get there easily, a 9min walk from Shinjuku station's East exit.Very close to the micro-bars of Golden Gai and the dazzling lights of Kabukicho.

The staff was great and helpful, they are able to converse in english, not a problem. Booked Superior Designer room, ample space for solo traveller, enough space to open my large luggage. I like the room, it has a huge window, the room design was nice, bathroom toiletries provided was great, have facial care lotion provided. The location wise was okay. It will be a long walk from Shinjuku station around 15 to 20 minutes (with luggage), nearest station is Higashi-Shinjuku metro station (brown line), will take around 5 minutes walk to reach the station entrance.I like the vending machines area at the ground level, always went there every night to buy drink and snack. There is a sign board at the counter where it will show some of the famous locations (Hakone, etc) temperature and weather for the day.The down side was the breakfast, although the breakfast was good, but the variety wise was not that great, stayed for few nights and saw the same type of dishes, it was like they have the same menu for odd day and same menu for even day. They provided the same dishes everyday. Should have more variety on the breakfast portion. Another issue is with the wifi connection, on and off when surfing internet and video, can improve more on the wifi connection.

Selected the Hotel mainly on price and what we hoped a manageable room size.Hotel staff were friendly and helpful, the reception staff spoke good English and provided helpful suggestions.Location 400 meters from a metro station and 1.5 klm from the main Shinjuku station.No problems wandering around the area and checking out some of the sites.We noted the tips around the room size and booked the Deluxe double. The room was small as expected but we were able to work things so we could open both suitcases. Shower, toilet and bath were fine although it was difference having the sink outside the bathroom and the bed hard up against the wall.The room was a little worn and tired but clean enough.All in all what you would expect for the price in Tokyo.

Once we got over the size of the rooms this became a great location and hotel for a weekend with friends. This isn’t an area I would bring the family though.The general area was a fantastic gateway to Tokyo though!

We spent 4 nights in the hotel at the start of our trip. The staff were helpful and gave us a small gift as it was our honeymoon. The hotel is well located, it is about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station which is a main hub station. There are a few roads leading up to the hotel, one of which is quite seedy in the evening, we found out afterwards that it was through the red light district. The room itself was pretty small, it had a narrow desk and a double bed and that was pretty much it, apart from the bathroom. We know that the majority of the hotels in Tokyo are like this so it wasn’t a surprise but is the reason why we aren’t giving it 5*They do supply a good selection of toiletries which were replenished daily, this was from a toothbrush to razor blades and hair bands. The hotel did have a couple of restaurants in house as well as a sky bar on the 13th floor. We didn’t visit any of these though.

This hotel is hardly what I’d expect for a 4 star hotel and I’ve stayed at better 3 star hotels in Japan. The room was old and dirty. The walls in the corridors. There was even some dry blood on my room door. The space behind the toilet seat was disgustingly dirty with hair, dust and whatever else. The furniture was dated and worn. The room doors would slam loudly and the walls would shake, so I could hear other guests coming and going. The location wasn’t the best either. It was too far from Shinjuku JR station, about 15-20 mins walk, which is difficult if you have luggage. Shinjuku is a great area to stay in but the area where this hotel is wasn’t very pleasant, with a number of “love hotels” nearby. There wasn’t the typical Japanese hospital with front desk staff not as friendly as they are in other hotels and shops in Japan and wouldn’t even acknowledge you as you walk in. I even heard one of them yell at a difficult customer in the front desk. Definitely wouldn’t stay here again.

Rooms are small yet comfortable with great blinds to block out the morning sun. The bathroom and toilet are fine. We enjoyed the roof top bar. No breakfast included in the price but there's a Subway three minutes walk away plus a few Family Marts. There are restaurants close by and you can be in the thick of the action within about 10 minutes walk. They did try to charge 450 yen to call us a taxi at check out but just walk down the street and they are everywhere. The Samuri Museum close by is worth a visit. You are close to large shopping centres here so take your Passport to get the Tax waived. Also Spirits at the local bottle shops here are far cheaper than the Duty Free at the Tokyo airport so if you can pack a bottle save your money and buy near the hotel.

This was a reasonably priced hotel recommended by the travel agent. It was well located, although it did take me a while to find it using google maps, from the train station. The room was very small, and it was hard to fit my case. But it was clean and had everything needed, including pjs. I would stay again if l stay in Shinjuku.

The Shinjuku Granbell is a large hotel with tiny (and I mean tiny) rooms. So if you have much luggage, beware! Receptionists were friendly and helpful, but always queues and over busy. The room as acceptable, although probably could do with a facelift. The restaurant staff were unfriendly and service disappointing. Food quality was okay, but not special. Location is good and near to a subway.

This hotel is perfect for staying in Tokyo. It's close to the Shinjuku station (approx 10 min by foot or metro) and in the middle of Shinjuku Nightlife, Restaurants etc.The (economy) rooms got a decent size for a Tokyo comparison (still small but ok!).As we arrived in the morning we couldn't check in yet but we could easily store our luggage there and come back later.The rooms are clean comfy and have a good bed. You got all the amenities in your room!There is also a nice rooftop bar, but they'll charge a 500 yen table charge (I can understand that in a small bar but not at the hotel bar you're staying...)Some other reviews said that the hotel is in the middle of the red light district, this might be true but we didn't got/saw any of it. The area is really safe so don't worry!

My husband and I stayed for a few nights on our honeymoon. All the staff were very kind and helpful & the room was very clean and comfortable. The rooftop bar is also fun! Located in the fun neighborhood of Kabuki-cho, we were about a 15 minute walk to Shinjuku station, and 5 minutes to Golden Gain or robot restaurant. Lots of good eats close by! We’d stay again!

The Shinjuku Granbell hotel is a clean and modern hotel with a good location within Shinjuku. Staff at reception were very friendly on arrival and we were even able to check in a bit early (greatly appreciated after a long flight). Rooms are on the small side but had everything we needed for a few nights. Bathroom was starting to show signs of fatigue but the room was otherwise clean and modern. Location within Shinjuku was very convinient with lots of shops, bars and restaurants within walking distance but the walk to Shinjuku station (10-15 minutes) may be an issue for some. Overall a very good stay but it was on the expensive side for what you get.

The hotel is in a slightly seedier part of Shinjuku, but we never felt unsafe. It is reasonably close to the train station (750m) and there are many bats clubs and eateries nearby. We stayed in single compact rooms which were perfectly suited to singles who didn't plan on staying inside much

We stayed three nights at the Granbelle Hotel, it is in a good location, about 10 minutes walk from the Shinjuku Railway Station. There are plenty of good restaurants in the area and it is close to the Golden Gai. It is only a short walk to the main shopping area. The staff and friendly and efficent and speak English. The rooms are smallish as are most in Japan compared to western standards but were very comfortable and adequate in size. The buffet breakfast was great and catered for most tastes.

Great hotel, great staff, and super clean. 5 min walk to golden gai and super close to the main areas. However a little far from main station, like 15 min walk which was a hassle with luggage. Room was small but we still made it work with 2 large luggage. Would recommend for the cleanliness and overall location. We definitely got our steps in.

We only stayed for 2 nights but this hotel had good service a rooftop bar with great views and easy access to shinjuku shops and restaurants Great value for moneyOnly downside was that we paid extra for a lodt room which didnt add any value and was very small that we were constantly falling over each other and had no where to put anything. You couldn't stay in this room for any more than 1 or 2 nights

Great location, close enough to the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku (10-15 min walk) but far enough away to be a little quieter in the immediate vicinity of the hotel. Good helpful staff. Rooftop terrace was lovely, drink and food prices were also pretty good for central Tokyo. Good variety at breakfast. Hotel was generally of a good standard and the Room was a reasonable size for Tokyo / Japan. Loads to do around Shinjuku area and easy enough to get around the rest of Tokyo via subway (nearest station just 5 mins away).
user_name:
Jay and Andrea W
Rhymney, S. Wales

review_body: Decent view, good but not amazing, really just a good place to drop in for a few drinks and a snack, good service, excellent drinks, bring a jacket. If you don’t they have blankets, of course you can also sit inside.

Stayed here for our final 2 nights in Tokyo. Was supposed to be 3 but the Typhoon had other plans. The facilities are nice and clean with lots of other English speakers staying which was nice when we went to the bar for drinks. I will say the on-site amenities have the most bizarre hours. The cafe doesn’t open til 10am (Atleast during the week) which if I’m getting up at 10am coffee isn’t needed any longer. The restaurant seemed to select its own days to be open and lucky us— none of them were the days we were there. I also wished the bar was open prior to 5pm but I digress. The front desk staff was nice and had excellent English, which I appreciated. They even checked us in 3 hours early! I will also say when the maids were cleaning there was a very thick stench of body odor, as well as cleaning supplies strewn about the hall. I can deal with body odor pretty well but this was enough to make me gag a bit. Truly hope they’re compensating all their staff well! All in all a solid place to stay within walking distance of Robot Restaurant and Shinjuku station.

Lovely hotel in an interesting area, did not have any problems with the Love Hotels. Staff friendly, helpful and polite, hotel clean. Restaurant wasn't open in the evenings, but had a fantastic roof snack and drink bar, great for watching the sun go down. They wouldn't check us in until 2.00pm, having flown overnight it would have been appreciated

we stayed here for 8 nights. the hotel is in a great location in kabukicho in shinjuku right by the godzilla head, sega arcade, golden gai, plenty of restaurants, the government building, easy access to transport and plenty of night life. the hotel is very clean, some of the rooms are small depending on what room you get but its great for what you need it for. the restaurant has an all you can eat breakfast buffet which is a great deal. they do lunch and dinner too but we didnt try those as there is so much around the area. the rooftop bar is amazing the drinks are reasonably priced and the views amazing the cherry blossom gin i had was very tasty.i highly recommend this hotel as its in the centre of everything and is well run, clean and the staff are very polite and helpful not a bad word to say about it.

The room was small and compact but well set out with two windows so didn’t seem claustrophobic. Nice bathroom with good shower place was spotless.Roof top bar - not a bar more of a restaurant so didn’t find it as relaxing as other roof top bars Nice reception areaGood location for Shinkuku and loved the feel of the area with plenty of bars and restaurants even though red light district felt perfectly safe and didn’t feel it was in your face Arrived at train station during rush hour and place was manic. Read on here that it was easy to find as it was the tallest building with blue flashing lights but this is not the case. It’s about a 10 min walk and we used the app maps.me which is a great app as don’t need WiFi to use as long as you down load the map before hand.Excellent free WiFi

Although the motel was in the middle of the red light district in shinjuku we felt very safe. The room was clean if a little small but this is Japan. The bed was comfortable the pillows slightly hard but OK. The ensuite was small but practical. The service was impeccable. Location close to shinjuku station. The breakfast was very good and variety was excellent. Western food as well as Japanese food was available. The toilet like all over Japanese fantastic and a novelty in itself. Heated toilet and music playing made for a nice relaxing time lol. Very good price wise. Very happy with motel although wouldn't stay there with young children just because of the adult entertainment area.

Firstly the hotel is 15 minute walk from main station. Hotel is not in the best part of Tokyo, bang in the middle of red light. Whilst this is not an issue the surrounding area is not the cleanest compared to other parts of Tokyo. Lobby is busy basic and worn. The rooms are average Japan size with many scuffs and whilst clean could do with a refurb. Hotel reminds me of a well used UK premier innThe hotel however has a real gem, the roof top bar was great and a nice way to start or end the night.

Clean and comfortable and perfectly located, easy walking distance to shinjuku sites and train. Staff was friendly and very helpful. We rented a premier studio and if had a great view, enough space so weren’t cramped, and the most amazing shower:) would defy go back and recommend

Very nice hotel with beautiful views. Staff at reception are very welcoming. Great location.A nice rooftop bar and no cover charge for customers that are staying at the Granbell. Food is not the greatest but the view is amazing.

The room was bigger than expected, clean and well equipped. The area has a lot going on and it's easy to get to all the sights on the metro/subway. The rooftop bar was great for happy hour. Staff friendly, all in all a great stay.

We booked this as it was close to Shinjuku train station. I was expecting a mediocre hotel given its located in downtown. Instead it was super nice, very clean, well maintained and superb bathroom. Regular rooms are very small but per tokyo standards so pls be prepared for that. People are very helpful and have all information readily available at front desk about tourist spots, veg options etc. Breakfast was very good with lot of options and worth the price. We didn't buy breakfast with the room as there wasn't any additional discount for prepay. it worked convenient as couple of days we had to venture out really early.Great place for the price.

We booked this hotel as it was so close to Shinjuku station and the price was great. We booked an economy room so knew it would be a standard Japanese sized hotel room however it was exceptionally clean and has everything you need in it. 5 minute walk from Shinjuku statio and stumbling distance from golden gai. Plus the rooftop bar is stunning in the evening if you can get a table (it’s very popular so gets busy quickly) . Brilliant find will defiantly stay there again.

Newer hotel in the nightlife district of Shinjuku. Our room was spacious however we did opt for a larger room. Only disadvantage was it’s proximity to its nearest station but I’d recommend this hotel.

The location of the hotel was really good for us as it is close to Higashi-Shinjuku and Shinjuku-sanchome subway stations and the JR and subway stations for Shinjuku making travel around Tokyo and wider area easy from here. The hotel staff we’re friendly and helpful and check in was easy, our room was ready at 12 and we were able to have the room even though check in was supposed to be from 3pm which was great after a long flight. The rooms are a lot smaller than other hotels we’ve previously stayed in and for the length of our stay this was frustrating as there was no wardrobe just a rail and 4 coat hangers so we had to use the small seating area to store folded clothes. Also as the double bed is up against the wall so I had to shuffle down the bed to get out in the night for the bathroom rather than just getting out normally which was not ideal. The room was immaculately clean and the facilities provided included a safe, a fridge, tea and coffee making facilities and a hairdryer. There were also nightshirts and slippers available in the room.The bathroom had a bath and shower and a wide array of toiletries. The roof top bar is lovely and gives a great view over part of Shinjuku. Ideal for a few nights stay but not ideal for a longer stay due to the small room.

Whilst this hotel is located in the center of a lively district it really is not up to scratch. The staff try their best but it just doesn’t get there, especially for the price you are paying. The rooms are “compact” and the cleanliness, housekeeping, is just not up to scratch. The breakfast room has the feel of a canteen were you bus your own plates away. The breakfast is on the other hand very good in terms of the options offered. Be aware that housekeeping does not clean rooms after 14:00hrs but does leave new towels and ameinaties. That’s quite shocking for a hotel of this so called stars and something that I have never come across before. The washing facilities that they provide are quite poor and dirty, to the point that I’d rather pack my soiled clothes to take home and wash. This place falls down on a number of important customer touch points.

We stayed for 3 days in this hotel, and we were aware that the room size would be small.Bag storage is limited to a space near a large window that overlooked the lights and sights of Shinjuku (level 16). Storage was available for hanging but its quite limited. The bed is a standard double and situated with one side up against a wall making it awkward for access for a couple at times.  The shower is located in the bathtub, so you need to be able to step up/in to this. Staff were friendly and accommodating with ability to communicate in limited english. There is a large terrace bar/restaurant which overlooked the city.Pro's We stayed during a typhoon and we were not aware of movement or noise beyond a whistle from the wind at times. Easy walk to town and areas of interest. Less than 1km to the main station. The views from the room overlooking the city were a bonus we didn't expect for the price we paid.Cons Smoke and chlorine smell at times in the foyer when walking to the lift (not a huge issue)Be aware you need to walk through what is considered a 'red light" district to get here, we didn't find this an issue and if anything it was interesting and added another "highlight" to our stay.

The hotel is ok. Located near a subway station, although it’s not the main Shinjuku station. The room was very very small. I couldn’t even open my luggage. The staff was helpful, although their English was not very good.

Don’t get me wrong, I know most hotel rooms in Japan are small, but the rooms at the Granbell are next level. We booked this hotel for our last night in Tokyo and I wouldn’t stay again. The hotel is worn out, has seen better days and our room was claustrophobic. It smelt like chlorine and we had to keep the bathroom door shut the whole time. The rooms would probably be ok for a single backpacker, not a couple as there is not room for suitcases and you have to climb over each other. We stayed in the economy double as that was the only room type available at the time of booking. The hotel is also located in the seedy district of Shinjuku, Kabukicho. I didn’t find the staff to be as warm as the other reception staff in other Tokyo hotels.

Nice hotel in a good location and an exelcent breakfast. However do not unpack as there is no where to put anything. There isn't even a towel rail in the bathoom. You have to live out of your suitcases. Top price rooms (ie exec level) are also on the small size for the price you are paying.

Granbell is pretty tall, a great feature when you're wandering around Shinjuku without being able to trust Google maps. (eyeroll)But really, it is tall, and offers a rooftop bar (cover charge is waived for guests) that has outstanding views, especially at night. Loved having a drink out there after a long day of walking. We were able to get any and everywhere in Tokyo because of the proximity to subway and JR stations. There is no shortage of stuff to do in the neighborhood. It does seem a little red light district-y, but it's Japan, so it's not overly offensive, and it is still super clean. The hotel also has a cafe that serves breakfast, and a little outdoor space with patio furniture - we grabbed beers from the convenience store and drank them out there one night while planning our next day. We weren't the only ones with that idea...The room was incredibly small. My only gripe is there wasn't a great space to put luggage for two people with carry-on size without dipping into the window seat real estate. The bed was comfy, and the bathroom was modern with all amenities we needed for our stay - toothbrush, hairbrush, hair tie, razor, cotton swabs, toiletries...you name it. The hotel also had lots of tourist info in the lobby, and we had no issues during our stay. I think for the price and location, it was a fantastic value.

Location:The hotel is around 800 metres from Shinjuku station. However, it is rather painful to push your luggage through the huge crowd of people in the sweltering heat. Instead, you could take a subway from Shinjuku by transferring to the Shinjuku Nishiguchi Station on the Toei line and alighting at the next stop which is Higashi Shinjuku station followed by a 150 metres walk to the hotel.Do note there are numerous love hotels (short-stay hotels) and host/hostress clubs around Granbell. Room:Stayed in a triple bedder loft room. The room was clean and well laid out. Beds were large for japanese standards. I would give it top marks for the many power sockets that were dotted around the room. It came in very handy when we had to charge out numerous electronic device.Service:The staff were mostly professional and polite. The staff at the front desk spoke excellent english and they were very helpful in giving guidance and advice on transport options when the public transport system was badly impacted due to Typhoon Faxai. The small notice board which provided updates on the status of the trains and buses were very helpful.All in all, I would definitely come back for subsequent stays if I'm back in the Shinjuku area.

My partner and I stayed here for 3 nights. The hotel was lovely. The accommodation is within a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku train station and there were a number of restaurants and convenience stores nearby. The room was comfortable and reasonably bigger than some of the other rooms we had stayed in previously in Tokyo. The hotel had all the amenities we required (which for us wasn’t a great deal) and the bed was comfortable. I would happily stay here again.

I stayed in Tokio for 4 days on my way to Bangkok. The Ganbell hotel is very well located at shinjuku near to several transportation options. The hotel has a lot of movement due to several foreigners arrive there but the service is within the aceptable bases (higher due Japanese culture). I was on a single room which was considerable small but cozy and clean. Caught my attention that the rooms are very quiet which allow me to get a very nice rest at night. I would definitely use this hotel option on any other Tokio visit

My favorite hotel in japan! This hotel got everything. A great bar and dining room, perfect to get a breakfast in the morning. The staff is so friendly, they helping you when ever you need them. The rooms are so clean and not to small. We had a great time, thank you all for the service!

We stayed here for 3 days. All transportations were in walking distance. Convenience stores are just few meters away. The hotel lobby is kinda hipster-like vibes wherein you can just sit their look at the sky or better yet sit outside they have set wherein you can enjoy the relaxing vibe of the neighborhood.

This hotel is in a great location if you are staying in the Shinjuku area. Although it's about a 12ish minute walk from Shinjuku station (pretty far when you are walking in extreme humidity), you have easy access to every other line by way of metro entrances. It's about a 7 minute walk to the main Shinjuku bar/nightlife/restaurants area, which was great because we were close enough to all the great restaurants but still considered in the quieter parts of Shinjuku and so we missed the noise and red-light district hustle and bustle.Staff are friendly and helpful. Check in and check out were a breeze. The room (we booked a standard room) was very clean and efficient. Although it is a smaller room, it felt pretty standard for Tokyo's standards. The design and layout were efficient, and made living in a very small space doable. The bathroom was also efficient, and always stocked with amenities like disposable toothbrushes, disposable wash cloths, shampoo, conditioner (not the mini bottles), etc. However, during the middle of our stay (we stayed a total of 6 nights), our toilet started to smell like subway station urine (EW). It was a faint odor, but still offensive. Perhaps it was a plumbing issue. Overall, we had a great stay at this hotel minus the bathroom/toilet issue. I would recommend this hotel and consider staying here again when i'm back in the Shinjuku area.

This hotel is reasonably priced for Shinjuku ! It is a long walk from Shinjuku station but much closer from Higashi Shinjuku on the Oedo line.The area is somewhat seedy! But the hotel is modern and clean.Our room was very small but that was expected. They manage to fit a lot into a little space. Tea and coffee making, frig, 3 seat lounge, desk, and AC etc. The bathroom was well equipped with enough bits and pieces for one person for at least a month!!The wifi was excellent.The rooftop bar is great and has wonderful views. Happy hour is from 5.00pm to 7.00pm. Cover charge if not a guest!The restaurant was not open for dinner and that was disappointing as we had organised for guests to join us.Overall a 3-4 rate

This hotel is seriously rundown, the photos are from many years ago. My room (not the cheapest option) had a dirty toilet, stains on the chair, a smell in the shower, stained grout, damaged furniture and dusty. Poor management that sent an inexperienced manager to deal with my concerns on the 2nd day. My worst hotel experience in Japan ever. I was shown other rooms and they were almost as bad. I had booked for 3 nights but left prior and found a much better hotel for less $ nearby. I rarely complain about hotels online, I go on holidays to have fun and not spend time explaining how deficient a hotel is!

PROS.1. It has a bidet.2. Three blocks away from the subway Shijuku Higashi.3. Two streets away from the primary activities in Shinjuku4. Price for regular room is reasonable.5. Instead of bathrobes, it provides a kimono style pajamas with buttons in the front for male and female.CONS:1. Regular room (non suite) is small (Superior Double 17-18m2 and Deluxe Hollywood Twin 23m2) 2. It is therefore, you will not find a closet.3. There are so many room's configuration.s The different "online travel agency (i.e. Expedia, Trip.com, etc.) may not have the same selection of rooms. Make sure you double check w/ Granbell directly if you select the room that you want.4. Found a tiny bug hoping around in the bathroom.5. It comes with a basic Wi-Fi connection - which was quite slow. It is probably okay for sending text only.6. Rooms needs maintenance

Since this is our first Japanese hotel visit we can’t compare. We found it to be perfectly clean and neat and the staff satisfied our very few needs. Is the room small? Yes it is, but I hazard a guess this is the norm for a very cramped and overpopulated city. We absolutely loved our free Handy Android device. It was an absolute life saver and we were saddened to read that this service is being discontinued starting Aug 22. We weren’t expecting to have it ( it was not advertised) but it saved as many $$ by not having to activate international service on our own phones. Again we enjoyed our stay in this very conveniently located hotel.

The prices were in range for hotels in the area, the rooms were clean. However the room was very small so just be wary when you book . However this is consistent with room sizes in tokyo. Remember to use the mobile phone provided by the hotel. Its for free with unlimited data and free local phone calls.The roof top garden is a nice place to relax with a drink in evenings

Location of the hotel is so far so good. Bad attitude of Front Desk staff, no smile no eye contact, just feel that staff wanna finish his work quickly and didn't welcome me. When I entered the room, the room is small but which is acceptable for me as I'm a single traveller. However, the furniture is old and the cleanliness of the room is extremely worst. it is not acceptable!! I would not recommend and must not visit this hotel again!

We stayed in Tokyo for 5 nights at Granbell. 2 of us. Stayed in a standard double/lead in room type the first 3 nights just as a place to sleep and shower. Then moved it one of the suites our remaining 2 nights which was totally worth it. The first room was small as expected (and most rooms in Japan) but was new, modern, clean etc. Then the Granbell suite was well worth the money. 5 times the size of original room, with washing machine, large bathtub, large shower, separate living and bedroom. 150% worth the money and will be back. Breakfast included with the suite good for hotel breakfast. Location was great as well. Not as central to Shinjuku station however still a short 5-10 minute walk (depending on how slow/many distractions you find along the way). Definitely felt safe walking back to the hotel at early hours of the morning although located within the red light district & love hotels. Staff were great as well. There was a good baseball batting cage across the road, 7/11's on every corner and some smaller train stations nearby. No issue staying here whatsoever will be back.

The check in process was okay but we arrived early and the first person wasn’t particularly friendly. She seemed a bit cold but let us store our bags there so we could come back a few hours later. Our room was really small, but it had a loft bed which made it seem more spacious. Lots of amenities such as coffee, tea, tooth brushes, body towel, qtips, organic shampoo, conditioner, body wash, and nightgowns. I found it odd that there was a mirror on top of the bed. The location of the hotel was seedy so if you come back late, try to take the main roads or take a cab.
user_name:
SportTrekker
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in a standard double in August. The room was fine- cosy, but big enough for two of us and all our luggage. The aircon was excellent- if anything a bit too cold. We didn’t have amazing views on the sixth floor, but they were good enough. The big plus of Granbell is the rooftop bar, and we frequented it for local beer and cocktails every night. This is where you can get your views :)Breakfast was fine, Spaghetti and noodles were excellent.If I came back to Shinjuku, I wouldn’t hesitate to stay here again

We got the basic room so it was expectedly small, cramped even. Though we didn't really mind as we're out exploring almost the entire day and would only return to our room to shower and sleep. On the upside, the room is kept immaculately clean and we always get a fresh supply of towels, pajamas, toiletries, and water. The wifi is good and accessible everywhere in the hotel. The downside, I feel, is the breakfast spread which is by no means impressive. I thought it was rather basic and you'd find better options outside. And you will because the location is super convenient - there's a ton of restaurants and cafes in the area and walking distance to the Shinjuku train station. Speaking of location, one would actually say that it's kind of a red light area as there are short-time hotels (love motels) nearby and some night clubs, too. But despite that, you don't really feel unsafe. Not at all. We went up the rooftop bar which gives you an awesome view of the urban landscape below, but sadly, we find the cocktail drinks not up to par. The hotel staff is friendly and accommodating and there is a brochure/magazine stand at the lobby where you can get maps, leaflets, and magazines to help you navigate the city, especially if visiting for the first time. Also, they have a currency converter cash machine (I dunno what it's called, okay? hahaha) at the lobby where you can exchange your foreign currency with JPN yen if you are ever in need of quick cash. Though there's ATM aplenty located inside the Family Marts and 7-11s in the area, so withdrawing cash is also not a problem.

Very good hotel. I think the price is really high. The breakfast was very good for salty thinks, less for sweet (in short, just small croissants and two jams). You'll do breakfast with love songs so that after you'll want to go to bed again. They have two old washing machines and one almost broken dryer, all inside a really really hot room. For that price I was expecting much more attention to details.

Travelling around Japan and this was our first stop. Was disappointed by the room on arrival as it was unbelievably small. Information on our itinerary from our travel agent described the room as superior double and I would say that was not right. Rooms was comfortable clean and tidy however. Staff were a little abrupt and not as friendly as I’ve found in other places and hotels across Japan so far. Never asked if we needed anything or any questions. Did not like that the bathroom was frosted glass facing onto the room when using the toilet in the night when the light came on it shone into the bedroom and woke disturbed my partner. Not sure what it’s not just a wall to save this. Ok for a few nights but couldn’t have coped with longer as too small. Probably wouldn’t stay here again when we return. Area is not the best pet of Tokyo. If you approach the hotel from the front at night lots of people trying to get you into bars. Coming from behind you avoided this.

The staff here are despicable.They overcharged us by $250 AUD, we continuously had to tell them and the man on reception was so arrogant, argumentative and rude, until we got booking.com on the phone to his manager. He demanded we pay $600AUD and he would refund the $850AUD in full. 10 days later we have paid both and still not had the $850 refunded. We’ve emailed and called every single day and had no response. DO NOT STAY HERE.

Staying in Shinjuku most lively part of Tokyo. Well located hotel with relatively big room - for standard in Tokyo. Not in the main road and only few minutes from metro station in quiet part. English speaking staff. Surrounded by many restaurants, entertainment places, karaoke bars and shopping options.

This hotel was reasonably comfortable for the week that I stayed there. I was in an economy single which was obviously small which I had expected. The only issue there was I was not able to open my suitcase unless I put it on the bed. I was travelling with family but had my own room and the hotel was able to accommodate us all to be in rooms close together. Pretty clean however the decor was a little bit worn/outdated but not bad. The location was convenient being only a short walk from underground and metro stations. It was also easy to find great places to eat, not far from the hotel. I didn’t realise before booking that this hotel was in the “red light district” of Shinjuku, however it was not really an issue, didn’t not seem unsafe, only kind of seedy and some of the streets were obviously less than picturesque. Overall I was happy with the hotel and found the price to be fairly reasonable for my experience with the hotel.

Hotel is located in one of the best spots in shinjuku, with the golden Gai bar district only a few minutes walk away and the hotel being centrally located within a short walk to busy shopping districts and great food. Hotel is clean, rooms are good value for money and buffet breakfast with good selection of American/Asian food. Hotel lobby staff could be a little more accommodating but other than that would definitely stay again. Was not any issue being close to many love hotels in the area - wouldn’t really call it a “red light district” as never saw any workers etc.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights at the start of our honeymoon to Japan. It’s is well located in the city with easy access for the Shinkansen from the main Shinjuku station, as well as other stations servicing the Tokyo transport network! Only thing to note is that my family (who are from Tokyo) did remark this was not in the best area (lots of love hotels In close proximity). TBH, this didn’t phase us at all coming from East London and found the whole area fascinating (from night to day there’s a great contrast!!!).We didn’t want to pay heaps for a room given we would be out most days exploring, and managed to get a good deal on the room rate. The room was pretty cosy (that’s standard for Tokyo and other cities such as Osaka) but really clean and well organised. Hotel facilities were great too: Colin laundry a bit small but good, vending machines offering snacks and drinks, and a cafe serving good coffee and cakes. Rooms made up every day to a good standard!The view from the roof top bar was awesome and service was good: they served a good range of drinks both international and local brands.Staff on reception all spoke great English and were super helpful. It was the perfect place for a quick city break, and matched our expectations perfectly!

We’ve stayed here for 4 nights. It’s really convenient because you can walk to Train station for 10-15 minutes or less than 5 minutes with Taxi. This hotel surrounds by night clubs, shopping malls and restaurants. The staffs are friendly, the Bar upstair is great, the room is clean and not too small but the breakfast is not many varieties.

I recently stayed here for my holiday. It is situated about 14 minute walk from Shinjuku station. It is a decent enough holiday. Here are my positives or negatives are said hotel-it is very convenient location for travelling in and around Tokyo. -the staff with whom I met seem to speak decent English for the limited or non speaking Japanese foreign tourist.- the receptionists/ hotel clerks are professional and attentive to your needs.-as a guess you have access to a mobile device called handy which is free to use &, I used it extensively for Google maps to navigate in & around Tokyo. You can make Free phone calls & internet use to find places to visit & browsing. It seemed to last the full day.On the negative side these are what I found:-The internet/ WiFi connections/speed is variable & therefore there is not at a consistent level that one can watch YouTube videos without a lag. I highlighted this to the staff and they provided and set up a free Ethernet connection which helped but still did not fix this issue.- there is no laundry service. The hotel guest has access to 2 washing machines & 2 tumble dryer which cost ¥300 & another ¥100 for detergent that can be purchased at the reception desk. -there seems to be a queue to use the laundry self service. -bed sheets are very thin so if you are prone to coldness this may be a problematic issue
user_name:
stan7lee
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: The hotel is in a great location right in the heart of Shinjuku although it’s right bang in the middle of the red light district this didn’t bother us. Found the hotel staff not to be the friendliest.. perhaps because we were a young couple. When checking in, we were given a room that had a terrible view and looked nothing like the photos when booking. Room was tired and not what we expected. Requested to be changed to a better room with some kind of view and after a few minutes being told there were none available she eventually gave in and gave us a better room... strange!Room was MUCH nicer, bathroom nicer too although tiny it was well thought out. Although he warned there is NO WHERE to store your belongings so suitcases had to be left unpacked on the floor which meant there was no space to walk. I also found the hotel lobby very scruffy, the corridors also had dirty towels and maids trolleys everywhere any time of day. Breakfast was also a disappointment although the view was great it felt like a school canteen rather than an luxury buffet. Overall a decent stay but make sure you’re not given an old and tired room and be prepared that the lobby is not as shown in photos.. it’s more like a waiting room filled with suitcases.

We booked a 1 night stay at Granbell Shinjuku. it was fuss free, value for money and has an excellent location. The room is small but packs all you need for a few night stay in the city. You will be out most of the time anyway. The furnishings are modern and well maintained. Amenities were thoughtful and overall a really good experience. The location is a 10-15mins walk to Shinjuku station, which was no problem for us. It’s surrounded by all the hustle and bustle you expect of Shinjuku, with food and shopping right at the doorstep.

All hotels in Japan have small rooms, this one clean and easy to use. For a basic room you don’t get an iron, so remember that when packing. The wifi was the worst out of all the places we stayed, patchy and rarely connected. The rooftop bar doesn’t look like the pictures, just tables to eat at. Still a fabulous view. The cafe doesn’t open till 10am so for tourists who are use to morning coffee with breakfast, you have to go elsewhere if you’re planning on already being out and about by 10am.

The hotel is very modern although the single room is very small like other typical Japanese hotel rooms. Although small, the rooms are full of amenities and any basic things you need for your stay. The hotel is about 10 mins walk away from the main Shinjuku station and 2 mins to another line. Follow me for the full review

Having stayed at the Granbell in Kyoto, I was really looking forward to staying at their Shinjuku hotel however it wasn’t as great. The room, although clean and with plenty of amenities, was a little tired and in need of some TLC (thumbs up for coffee in the room however, which appears not to be common in Japan). The hotel is also located practically in Kabuki-cho, which means if you’re walking from Shinjuku station, then you have to walk through the main streets of the red light district and love hotels. I was a little nervous of this at first, but it was actually pretty tame and there was no hassle. You may want to select another location however if travelling with children

My room was on the 10th floor, and we had a great view of Shinjuku. The room was super clean and not as small as others had described. The staff were friendly and really helpful, they helped us out with travel queries i.e how to use the JR pass etc. I would highly recommend the location is great right next to the shops and the subway. Will visit again if in Tokyo in the future.

->Area and Surroundings:The hotel is a 15 mins walk from Shinjuku station, and the route is also not a straight line (use of google maps is a must). The area looked to me very shady with few black people around which made me feel unsecure.There are convino stores nearby (that’s all over Tokyo anyhow). I was not able to find good English speaking restaurant in the area. That way Shibuya was much better to deal with.->Room:We opted for a Luxury Designer Double Room with Kitchen and the room was decent sized compared to the rooms in Tokyo. The price for the room was way high compared to what is offered. The room was a open layout with kitchenette on one side and bathing tub on the other side. The room had a very small table chair setup and all things were placed in a cramp up manner.The flooring was some sort of thumping effect when we walked on it. The placement of TV in the room was nice and the room also had surround sound speakers to the room facing to the bed.->Bathroom and Bathing experience:I liked the bathroom most, it was made of glass and stainless steel. The rain shower was huge in size (one of my favorites), there was a separate Toilet with electric toilet seat 9which is very common all over in Japan).The water pressure and temperature was favorable for a pleasant bathing experience. The hotel provides all toiletries to the room and also has a blow dryer if one needs.->Hotel StaffThe hotel staff was not upto the mark in English skills. The have a very strict checkin policy. When I arrived they told me that the room was not ready, and then when I told that I am ready to pay extra for early checkin, the room got ready immediately as I paid Yen 4500 upfront (1500 Yen per hour of early checkin than 3 PM) . The room wifi was often disconnecting.->Breakfast:I did not opted for breakfast with the hotel and I did not had any hopes from them.->Swimming Pool / Gym / Spa:The hotel does not have a swim pool or gym.Special mention:We requested hotel to provide us with “Bottle Sterlizer” and “Baby Cot”. They had Baby cot but they failed to provide a bottle sterilizer.The kitchenette in the room was very very basic and had almost no utensils. If talked on phone, they had no clue what I was asking for.

The rooms are small and cramped. I was staying with one other person and we couldn't open our large luggage and had to do it on top of our bed. The hotel does not have a key-operated elevator so any one can come up to the floors. This was a problem for us as a drunk, random stranger started banging on our door in the middle of the night and when we ignored him he just started banging and screaming even louder. Turned out he was looking for his friend and he thought our room was his friends. As two girls who were staying in the room, this was quite frightening. We told the front desk this incident and they did not even apologise or empathise. I wouldn't stay here again because of that incident and also there are many other hotels that are not so out of the way for the same price and size.

我剛剛從東京回來 入住的記憶猶新 房間老實說真的沒有驚艷到 空間小 只夠打開一個24吋行李箱 還好我們只帶Handcarry酒店配備Handy phone 可以讓客人帶著出門上網 雖然我大部分時間還是偏向用自己的手機（畢竟在公眾的Device開自己的帳戶還是會不放心）但用它來導航真的很不錯 Google map 和定位都很準自助式洗衣沒用到但感覺有這服務挺好的地理位置方便 可因為離歌舞伎町很近 所以人流也比較複雜 女生真的要小心點因為這次住到2樓 比較近街道 敏感的人會覺得吵 也建議最好關窗簾睡不過可能是有了比較 入住的前兩個晚上都住在大一倍可價格只需一半的酒店 所以對比之下這酒店並沒有任何一個地方給到我驚喜或是達到高CP值的水準標四星的酒店來說 它好像服務水平需要再提高一下如果再去東京，我可能也會選擇某幾天住這區域 可是不太會回頭住這家了*Hotel room is small but the hotel location is great. Typical Japanese hotel I would say*

The hotel is fine. My only compliant is the slow WiFi. Websites download at a crawl and VPNing into a corporate server is almost impossible. I would recommend staying elsewhere because access to the internet these days is a basic utility.

We had a comfortable stay in a twin standard room... rooms on the small side but very clean... area is a bit seedy is staying with family. I wouldn’t let my teenage children walk around the streets as adult district on the doorstep... Service has been great with plenty of helpful staff who speak English

I've stayed here twice now and thoroughly enjoyed it both times. The location is convenient and the rooms are nice and a good value. I will definitely stay at this hotel again on my next trip to Tokyo.

Room - basic room in Tokyo, pretty affordable and spacious enough to open two large luggage for my week-long trip to Japan Service - could be improved, definitely, the front desk staff helped us check in quickly but wasn't very helpful in identifying the amenities we needed such as a hot water kettle which we though we didn't have until we called to enquire about it the next day (stayed there for 3 nights and they told us impatiently that it was in the extreme left cabinet) Location - 15 minutes walk from the various metro/ JR stations, bumpy roads, not recommended for people who can't walk long distance or have heavy baggageAmenities - didn't explore the hotel, the room was a litlte dim as well, will not return

My family and I were hoping to spend a nice time in a hotel that claims to be a 4 star hotel. First off , the hotel is closer to 2 stars. The second you open the doors you arrive to a run down hotel. The rooms are cramped, not even a space to open a briefcase. The biggest issue being that the management treats you with zero respect around here, and I will make sure to spread the word on every possible site so everyone is aware. Will never stay here again.

Our first hotel in Japan. The rooms are not large but are clean and have decent facilities. The roof terrace bar is a nice way to start or end the evening. Location is not the best if you are wheeling cases but actually it wasn’t a problem. That area of town has lively nightlife but seemed fairly safe. Desk service was formal and a little austere and the reception area looks ‘tired’. If you want a clean practical base and don’t expect to spend any time using the hotel facilities or spending time in the hotel this is fine. Didn’t use any of the restaurant facilities.

Booked 2 rooms for our family of 4 persons. Rooms are small but expected. Bed was a bit of a squeeze but bearable; you can only get on bed from one side and the pitcher side is backed / lined up against a wall.
