It's a bit of trek to the Shinjuku train station with baggage, but otherwise in reasonable proximity by foot to Station to see most of Tokyo’s attractions by train. The single room is very small, but that’s expected for Japan. The only disappointments for this hotel no where to put your bag in room but the floor, the blind didn't quite cover the window so a lots of ambient light came through and the Wi-Fi connected but didn't work at all. The rooftop bar and restaurant is probably the best aspect of this hotel. Breakfast 3.5 out of 5 stars.

We found the Shinjuku Granbell to a reasonably comfortable hotel within walking distance of the local underground station (where we received good help on the platform for finding interesting places to travel to}. We were caught out by the lack of help from the staff on any of the tour and travel brochures on display in the foyer and were also caught out by the fact that the full day we had in Tokyo was a holiday Monday. This also meant any of the facilities in the hotel like bars and restaurants for lunch were closed for the day. There was no notices or information provided by staff when we arrived the previous evening that the holiday would curtail hotel services.

So pleased with our choice in staying here. Superb hotel. Great location for nightlife and easy access for sightseeing. The rooftop bar on 13F was a lovely plus. Best hotel we stayed in during our 3 weeks in Japan. We booked a Superior Designer Double, lots of space on 16F! Coffee, water and some complimentary soft drinks provided. Some extra complimentary his and hers toiletries, in addition to the standard items normally provided. Its located 5 min walk from the Metro and about 10 min from the JR Shinjuku station. The hotel is above the price point we would normally aim for but as it was our last stop, and we had a 5 nights, we wanted some space and comfort and it delivered. Well worth it.

We checked in to a room that we couldnt fit our luggage. The size of the room was 12 square meters and it had a tiny rectangle window and a small desk. We complained to the front desk lady and asked to upgrade our room. We had to pay almost double the price for a 22 square meter room. Not good value for your money.
user_name:
adig398
New York City, New York

review_body: I loved the location of this hotel. Walking distance to many great places to visit. The rooms were tiny AF. But for Tokyo, I heard the rooms were larger than most. Hmmm, well we were using our suitcases as seats. The service was great and the hotel was clean. I loved Tokyo, the people were friendly, and the city is the cleanest city i've ever visited. We didn't spend much time in the hotel, so it really didn't matter much. They have a nice top floor outdoor area where we had drinks while taking in the view of the city. Breakfast was decent. If you're looking for a western style breakfast, not gonna happen. They have cereal, bread, and eggs. But you best get used to Asian breakfast if you're going to stay in a non-US chain hotel. I really liked our neighborhood. It was quiet. Though it was close to their so-called red light district, you really couldn't tell imo. I'd recommend staying here for the location.

We stayed in this hotel for 4 night during our honey moon.The hotel is very good located, close to the metro station and to Golden Gai, a very particular area with very small streets full of bars with good vibe in evening time.The staff is friendly and ready to help if required.The only problem is the size of the room, very small but as I know in Tokyo all hotel are like that.Cleaning is good and breakfast with good selection.Suggested!

We just spent our first three nights in Japan at the Granbell Hotel in Shinjuku. I am so happy that we chose this hotel! It really was a fantastic experience. I did not know what to expect given the reviews. However, i think that the hotel rooms may vary quite a bit in this hotel. We stayed in room 1605 which was a Luxury Designer Double Room (the one with the shower and flat screen TV in the middle of the room and a large tub in front of a floor to ceiling window overlooking the city - see pics on website). The website photos did not do this room justice. It was really so beautiful! The shower is spacious, with a handheld spray nozzle and rain shower head. There is a his/her trough sink, with a toilet in a separate enclosed area. The soaker tub was amazing. There are two sliding frosted glass doors on either side of the shower/TV block that can separate bath/bed if you want more privacy. The bed was great, pillows comfortable, and there was a decent size table with comfortable chairs at the other floor to ceiling window by the bedroom (with a lovely view of the city and the rooftop bar and patio down to the right on the 13th floor). The room was nicely stocked with anything you would want, robe, slippers, red wine, teas, disposable drip coffee (which I had never seen before), and all toiletries and supplies you might need. The lighting in this room is also incredible, with dimmers on many lights, and the pot lights nicely placed with warm light as opposed to a cool light. The staff were extremely friendly and service was great, both on the rooftop bar and when we called for anything we might need, such as extra coffee, wine, calling for a taxi, or help with our Handy that would not charge. The room comes with a "Handy" which is basically an android phone with google maps, internet etc. . It was a life saver when it came to navigating our way around Shinjuku and beyond, both by foot, and subway. Great perk!We loved the location of the hotel. It is situated facing a quiet street in Shinjuku, with a nice deck and seating area outside the front door and some greenery. You can buy coffee, beer, snack items and other drinks at the lobby bistro and take them outside. We did not do this but opted for the rooftop patio and bar a few times. Amazing views and great staff, the food up there, however, will not be the reason to go. The main restaurant is closed, and the rooftop patio has limited food choices. I had hoped for some grilled chicken, sushi, miso soup, some healthy yet what you might expect in Japan type of food. Nope. Deep fried breaded chicken tenders, french fries, pizza, french onion soup. However, there was a great prosciutto and parmesan green salad with sherry dressing (most healthy item on the menu, I think). They need to step up the food in order to bring it into line with the quality of the service and the rooms. However, overall the rooftop patio was a great experience and we did return every night, at least for a glass of wine and a snack. The internet was spotty as other reviews have mentioned so keep that in mind, and rely more on the supplied "Handy". We did use our cell phone data from home to surf the net for some information on attractions, etc. a few times. As far as the location being in the "red light district", this did not present any problems in terms of us feeling uncomfortable or uneasy. We walked many blocks through this area without incident on a couple of nights. We also went to two restaurants and the Robot Restaurant Show in this area. We are both in our 40's from a rural area in Ontario, Canada, so not like home, but nothing daunting. Five stars for this hotel. We will definitely return to stay here on our next trip to Tokyo!

First visit to Japan. Granbell was lovely. Very welcoming staff and nice room [ although small ] All rooms in Japan are small! Very comfortable bed. Shower only but fab heated toilet seat that could wash and dry your nether regions! Received lovely birthday cake and chopsticks from hotel. Breakfast was quite good. Lots of people so food disappeared fast, but replacement was on hand. Coffee ok. In general a great hotel in the heart of Tokyo. Easy access to trains and decent tourist venues within walking distance.

My teenage daughter and I stayed 6 nights in a Economy double with breakfast. We throughly enjoyed our stay at this hotel. It was well located to several railway stations making it easy to commute around Tokyo. Our room was small but this was made very clear even when we booked the room - we managed to find a workable solution for our luggage. The room was clean and well serviced and quiet. Room service was fast and affordable and we enjoyed our ordered meals. Breakfast was buffet style. The staff were very helpful and friendly and many spoke English quiet well. The rooftop bar has a lovely view for sunset drinks and served dinner. The wi-fi was intermittent but I had a data package with my service provider (don’t rely on the hotel wi-fi). Our luggage was held until our departure on our last day. We would definitely choose to stay at this hotel again if returning to Shinjuku but would possibly choose a larger room on our return.

The hotel is nice with clean rooms, the room size was small, but the hotel is located in a very good location, in the heart of Shinjuku. There was a problem with the Internet in the room but the staff were very helpful and provided us with Extra internet modem.
Wifi is free, but Wifi doesn't work. So No wifi, no network, the Wifi router doesn't work.Only 40ko/sec for download, but 40 Mo for upload !!! What does that mean ?Impossible to work from guest room.

So we decided on this hotel as other hotel rooms in Tokyo were much smaller for the same price. Location - this hotel is not really near to a train station (although walking distance around 600m). But it is away from the busy nightlife of Shinjuku, which is a plus.Room - We took the Luxury Designer Double room, for the space. Everything was clean and bathroom was huge. TV selection however is disappointing. There were no English channels other than CNN. Also, wifi connection was horrible. We stayed 5 days, and only on the last day did we find out we can get a router from the front desk for stable connection. This should have been mentioned to us upon check-in.Breakfast - Breakfast is nothing compared to any other hotel for this price, outside of Japan. Really lacking in selection and taste.There are not much facilities, and the so called "lounge" is just a small room with some biscuits and coffee. All in all, I would choose another hotel if I do visit Tokyo again.

Stayed two nights and this place didn't disappoint. It is a larger hotel, but the rooms don't feel mass produces and are all very different (choosing which one is exhausting!). We selected the 'Deluxe Designer Double / Casual' (yes, really that's the name) and were very impressed. Even the bathroom had a great view out over Tokyo. The breakfast was included and buffet style with a big selection. Wifi was less-than-ideal and the walk from the JR line with luggage is a little too long, but still would strongly recommend.

The hotel is in the heart of Shinjuku and walking distance to many famous area, abit far from Shinjuku Stn around 20mins. We have a comfortable stay here. Price we pay is abit too expensive for a hotel like this and the room handyphone and radio is not working at all. Anyway, nothing impressive but for 1 night is just ok.

The hotel is on a small street, pretty quiet at night. Staff speaks little English but very polite and helpful. Room is so compact, you hardly have any room to walk. However, it is well designed, everything is neatly placed. You have almost everything in the room, a small table, a bench, a tiny fridge, a kettle, TV, radio..Nice adapter also available so you don’t need to bring one from home. Washroom small but clean, good quality shampoo and soap are provided. Bed is so so.Plenty of restaurants within walking distance. Metro ans train stations around 10minutes away depending on which exit you take.The only unpleasant thing is their wifi. It was so slow even in the lobby. The best free wifi is at the Shinjuku metro station.

Stayed 4 nights at The Granbell. Found it well located (10 minute walk to main shopping area) very clean room. Good size bathroom, room size was good for Tokyo area. Bed comfortable. Shampoo, conditioner, body wash, razor, toothbrush supplied. Complimentary bottled water.

The room was very nice and clean. Nothing bad about the hotel facilities. But what i remember is, one of the receptionists was very rude. I stayed there with 6 friends. We had big luggages and we asked if we can leave those at the hotel coz we have to go to kawaguchiko first, for 1 night. Then we're gonna stay at their hotel for 2 nights. They allowed it. But on the day we checked in, one of the receptionist was very rude. I asked her very politely to bring out our luggages, but she said "it was too many" and unhappy facial expression. Of course it was too many. There were 7 people. And we booked 4 rooms. So please don't complain. We're not stay there for free, sister. Unfortunately, I forgot to write down her name

...but like everyone else said, their internet service is the worst I've ever seen in a chain hotel. Literally couldn't connect to it.Otherwise room was great I got the cheapest available and it had a double bed and a cool loft area with another single sleeping area, would be great if traveling with a pal. Bathroom has every amenity you could think of (razor, toothbrush, etc.)It is in the red light district as other people have mentioned, which is definitely seedy but I didn't find it at all dangerous and walked through every night without issue. Just ignore the touts bugging you walking through and you'll be fine!

Very friendly and helpful staff. Could be a nice place, but in today's world there is no excuse for such shoddy internet service, not only in the room but everywhere in the hotel. This is really a differentiator when considering similarly priced hotels.

Location is convenient but it is in the red light district. Rooms are extremely small with no closets or drawers. Don't let the pictures fool you. They only show pictures of their deluxe suites which are way pricier and usually booked. the difference between the deluxe suites are drastically different

Stayed in one of their pimped out rooms - The Villa Suite - for 2 nights. Great views and the room had outdoor shower and open air garden (although we went in winter and it was too cold to use). The suite is 62sqm in total so quite large. Views were amazing from the large glass windows but in this room they are not looking towards the main part of the city. Family travelling with us had a different suite (the penthouse suite I think) which didn't have the outdoor shower/garden but had better city views and if I was staying here again I think I would try and book this room.Location easy 3-5min walking distance to Shinjuku's famous alleyways, nightlife and shopping areas. Overall a really nice room and well priced for this level of quality in Tokyo. would stay again.

Stayed for five days while exploring Tokyo, hotel is in the middle of three stations, walkable but not particularly convenient either. Situated in the centre of the red light district it can be a bit confronting walking back to the hotel after dark, and I wouldn’t want to walk around there if travelling with kids. Having said that, lots of cool bars and restaurants in the area, which was fun. Room wise... we had a deluxe Hollywood twin room. It was quite small, and the pillows were horribly uncomfortable. Wifi was pretty bad, but they did provide a ‘handy’ phone with internet access that we used a lot for google maps when out and about - really helpful and the main perk of the room for me. Vending machines all around the hotel, and a restaurant, bar and cafe. We didn’t eat in any of them so not sure how they are.Staff are approachable but service was a little haphazard. We requested extra pillows that didn’t arrive until we asked again the next day, and unfortunately had an issue with the hotel not accepting NAB bank cards. We had to pay on arrival but with none of our cards being accepted we had to pay in cash which was really inconvenient. This could have been handled much better than it was and left a bit of a sour taste for us.There is a small laundry at the hotel, but limited facilities if the hotel is busy so we had to go around the corner to do washing. In summary, clean and serviceable for a short stay, location was okay provided you’re not a family, small rooms and uncomfortable bed. Wanted to like it more but didn’t quite get there for me considering the cost, not too expensive for Tokyo really but I’ve paid less and had better experiences for sure. Give it a try, but maybe take your own pillow!

We booked a Suite Room and it was fantastic. It was huge and luxurious. One of the best hotel rooms we have ever stayed in.However the wifi in the hotel is just terrible. They even have a sign on the front desk admitting that it is terrible. Just fix it. They advertise that they have a French/Italian themed restaurant. They don't. It is closed. This could be one of the great hotels in Tokyo but it appears that they just don't care.We booked online with the hotel. That was an experience but we finally made it. We received a price and I confirmed the booking. When we arrived I found out that the price was per person and not a room rate. Be careful. I think this is a ripoff.

The Hotel is in a perfect location to start everything off. Is right next to the buzz of Shinjuku yet far enough away to be quiet in the night. I stayed here in February and will be going back this September for my second time this year and my second ever time in Japan! That will show you how happy I was with the service. Cleaning ladies are superb and extremely friendly. Rooms are small but so are most in Japan.

Very good hotel : the rooms are not that small for Tokyo, they are very clean, the staff is very nice, and above all, the hotel is very well located (Shinjuku, 5 minutes away from the metro station (Higashi Shinjuku). Just one downside : the wifi connection is very badAnother thing I would like to draw your attention : I firstly booked a room in this hotel via the website "Gala Hotel" and one day after, they sent me an email indicating that the hotel was fully booked and I was relocated to another one, which was located in an area not convenient for me and which was of a lower standing. I called the first hotel i initially booked which confirmed me that they still had rooms available for this period! I requested Gala Hotel to reimburse me but they never refund me. That kind of situation never happened to me because i am usually watchful, I try not to book via agents, and I usually do deep researches when I dont know the agent. I have not done it this time because i was lacking of time but I regret! Dont book via this website, this is a huge FRAUD!!

It seems like the hotel is in the middle of a clubby area but we were never disturbed by any outside noise. The check in staff were so lovely and polite, we had emailed about a special occasion and they gave us a welcome gift. How lovely! The room was just big enough but was made up for by daily replenished toiletries and a clean nightshirt. Most floors had a vending machine and there was a guest laundry available. The biggest asset was the free use of a smart phone during our stay.I would stay here again.

I stayed there on a brief (5 day) holiday, my first experience of Japan. The hotel seems reasonably new, its certainly very clean and well maintained, the little origami figures on the reception desk (changed daily) were nice - liked the Pikachu, especially. I booked on line and had to extend by a day - this was no problem but they advised me to book on line again as it was cheaper than the front desk rate (it was!) which was nice. The room, supposedly a double, was quite small. Fine for one person but I would have struggled if my wife were with me. Partly I think this is a Japan thing, but also because space is at a premium in Shinjuku. I was amused by the high tech toilet (heated seat, adjustable sprays!) and liked the provision of a free mobile phone (no data but free calls including some international). The minibar was empty - actually a good thing. The surrounding area is infested with small 7/11 type shops so its cheaper and more convenient to buy your own.The TV channel selection is quite limited and only has CNN in English. AC was arctic-effective, handy in the humid Tokyo Summer. No Gym but I wouldnt have used it anyway after a day's touristing. The restaurant is no longer open, though there is a lobby cafe and a penthouse bar. Again there are many restaurants in the immediate area.A few words on Shinjuku - it is a hub for the metro and Japan Railways services, with several stations within 10 mins walk of each other. A bit of a tourist trap at times, with hostess bars and guys trying to lure you into strip clubs, but also food, shops and other attractions and plenty of native Japanese were also there. The area is a real 24 hour zone even for an old geezer like me!

Really convenient location as it is just walking distance to the centre of Shinjuku. Also close to restaurants and a batting cage. Service was good, room could be a bit cleaner, and reception area was fairly hot and needs airconditioning.

I had a great stay at this hotel. The rooms are very clean and modern. The hotel provides you with a FREE cellphone to use during your stay with data so you can find your way around the city. Which in my opinion makes up for the lack of wifi. About 15 mins walk to train station.

Firstly, yes the WIFI is basically non-existent. It has always been this way and will continue to be like this I would suspect. That is why they give you a "Handy" smartphone that you can take with you to help with navigation etc. You cannot turn it into a hotspot, you will just have to put up with not using your own device(s) while you are there. Yes the rooms are small, that is Japan. The bed was very hard, we found this difficult on our backs but if you do some stretches in the morning, you will be fine. The location is spot on, heaps of things to do in the area and close to several stations. Don't bring kids here if you don't want them to see the love hotels and the red light district stuff. Do your research first, and don't complain about it later. Buffet breakfast was really nice, however the music is on high rotation of the same songs, which must drive the staff nuts. This hotel is clean and tidy, and ticked most of the boxes.

We recently stayed in this hotel. The room was small, clean and we had a nice view, however no cupboards to hang your clothes. My major issue with the hotel was the Free Wi-Fi. It DOES NOT WORK. Which is a problem when you wish to locate places on maps and look at different restaurants on Trip Advisor for dinner. We felt so frustrated the whole stay. If they fixed the Wi-Fi I’d consider it in the future.

I have seen a lot of small rooms but this is really the worst!! How they managed to get the amount of stars the say they have? Never again. I dont even dit under the shower. They call is a bath but you have to be a child to fit in.

Don't book this if you want to book popular restaurants ahead of time. We have booked one of the most expensive rooms for a 4 night stay in Tokyo next month. Unfortunately, the hotel concierge wasn't willing to help us to book some Michelin starred restaurants ahead of time, stating that they only can help when we arrive. This is rather disappointing as most other hotels have a concierge service that will help us with something like that ahead of your stay.

We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of July. I loved it! Very good location, all transport points within walking distance. Plenty of restaurants and coffee shops nearby. We happened to be there when a very exciting street festival was going on. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Yes, the rooms are small, but you should know that when you book. It does show the floor space. We had the loft room and used this for our luggage, so didn't have any problems. Breakfast was nice and the staff helpful. Would recommend this hotel without hesitation.

Would stay here again! Fairly small room but I think that is pretty typical in Tokyo. The room was clean and sleek. We had a loft room which seemed like such a cool feature...and then never used the space. Whoops. Nice view but a better one from the rooftop bar. Sadly their beer vending machine was out of order during our 3 day stay. Other vending options were good though. Staff extremely friendly and helpful.

Stayed last year for 4 nights in the hollywood suite and it was great. service is good and staff was great. breakfast was a bit bland tho. its a bit of a walk from JR shinjuku station but the area around it is great for food and entertainment. Looking forward to my stay here again this weekend in a different room. one thing that did bother me was the clutter of people and suitcases in the lobby... i understand travelers are tired and specially this summer is quite hot but i think that should be sorted out..

Been there with a big group of friends (12 peoples). The room is nice and clean, size is at Japanese standard for this price. The hotel is near to public transport and 10 mins walk to Shinjuku JR station. Will be there again for sure!

This hotel has gained good reviews in Tripadvisor and generally it deserves them. The staff were very friendly and although the room was small (typical of Japan, I believe) it was comfortable and the shower was very good. It has an upstairs bar/restaurant, which was good value and we ate there both nights of our stay, mainly because we found no restaurant nearby that appealed to us. One problem was that the restaurant only served European food. It was very good and good value for money, but it would have been good on our first visit to Japan to have an early chance to try Japanese food. The other problem is that the area is clearly a red light area, and although we felt safe, it was a bit seedy.

We stayed in the Granbell in July for the first leg of our honeymoon. The location is fantastic, a short walk to the Golden Gai, Shinjuku and the train/metro - a great base for exploring Tokyo. The hotel itself is clean and the staff were helpful. Our room was quite small and the window was tiny but we slept well and it was a comfy stay. There is a rooftop bar but really, it's not that great. I'd recommend instead, to visit one of the smaller bars in the Golden Gai for atmosphere. Basically, this hotel is perfectly good if like us, you will be busy out and about during the daytime and just want somewhere clean and comfy to sleep at night. If you like to spend more time in your hotel room, it may feel a bit cramped. The hotel also had a device in our room called a 'Handy' that you can use for free to access the internet and you can bring it with you off the premises. This was so so good to help us get our bearings as we had to use Google maps several times!

This is a decent hotel located in a busy section of the city. However, our double bedroom was very small with only one bed. We were two friends traveling but they provided us with one bed which was very inconvenient. Also, the lobby was always crowded and not very spacious for such a big hotel.

I found the rooms at this property to be quite small although clean and I had a comfortable sleep. There was no safe or ironing facility and overall I thought the price was excessive. The station is a 15m walk and the metro around 10m. For the price paid, I think it's better to consider options closer to the trains.

I was having trouble with my Cellular Network provider,but the hotel offers a temporary free phone to use,el even outside the hotel.it helped us navigate around the city, and it offers a 24/7 concierge live chat as well. I travel often and this has got to be the most amazing amenity offered. Definitely staying here on my next trip.

Excellent Hotel - close to all the action in Shinjuku but far enough away to be reasonably quiet. Rooms are well maintained and cleaned - some a bit small - for our second stay we upgraded to a bigger Room - much better.Staff can't do enough to help - highlight is Roof-Top Bar / Lounge on 13th Floor - amazing Views of the City at Night.

Positive: very central location in lively Shinjuku, fair price for Tokyo.Why below expectations? Pictures of rooms on web create an expectation which doesn't match with reality - below the obvious promotional efforts of hotel pictures on web. Small and no special design at all. Simply conventional in a "mass hotel". Room not clean (waste of previous guest under bed), bathroom smelly. Staff at check-in neither friendly nor helpful at all. Not at all the Japanese standard experienced at the other places on our trip.Too much focus on efficiency instead of service?
user_name:
Eric H
Canton of Zurich, Switzerland

review_body: We stayed here for 2 nights. Hotel is trendy , clean and staff is very friendly. Our room was super small. However, it was super clean and the bed was comfortable. It is strategically located, it’s near the busy part of the neighborhood, but far enough that the noise won’t bother you. There is a train station a couple minutes away from the hotel. The hotel has a rooftop bar which has very nice views of Tokyo.
user_name:
EmFama
New York City, New York

review_body: The location is perfect for Shinjuku - it is around 10 mins walk to the main station which is very convenient. Although the red light district is in the next road so you end up being pressured by intimidating men if walking back late at night but it wasn't too bad. It is a few minutes walk from Golden Gai if you wanted to try the tiny but heavily overpriced and touristy bars. The room was much much smaller than I expected but was very clean. One incredibly useful thing was the 'Handy' device that you can use for the duration of your stay which means you have a sat nav, internet, and phone without picking up roaming charges. This is a huge advantage and well worth considering for this alone. The bar on the top floor has great views of Shinjuku and normal expensive prices for a hotel bar but very enjoyable for a relaxing drink. I got a cheap deal for £76 on Expedia and then for the 2nd part of the trip £79 on Hotwire which was good value for the location. There are plenty of places where you can eat for 500 Yen within a few minutes walk, plus there is a Seven Eleven 1 minute away which is always handy for snacks and drinks.

Bad experience when checked out. We need a taxi to JR train station. A female reception just pretend to make a call and hung up said to me that you can call a cab at the main road and walk away. No explanation. Such a rude manner. So i and my mom miss the train. Have to catch the next round. Never again for this hotel.

Just love how convenient this hotel is & eatery is plenty. Walking distance to most complexes nearby or you can take the underground train stations which are connected with plenty of exit with a walking up stairs. Stayed there for 5days. Only hope they change their breakfast menu every few days else you will be eating the same variety of breakfast everyday.

Hotel is in a great location, I highly reccommend staying in Shinjuku when in Tokyo. Service was outstanding, typical to Japanese culture. Only con would be the breakfast which was far from spectacular.

This hotel is located on a side street in the very busy Shinjuku district. Although the economy room was small. it was efficient. The breakfast was plentiful and since it is on the 14th floor, there is a good view of the City. Shinjuku Station is a 10-15 minute walk. Included with the room was a Handy device which is like a cell phone and proved invaluable for navigation and activity suggedtions. The hotel also has a little bar by the lobby and a restaurant open at night.

This was our first stop of our trip in Japan, We spent 2 nights here before heading to Kyoto. Now the hotel itself is a little bit of a walk from Shinjuku station and tiresome when you have to push, drag your bags from the station. so either think about getting a cab or uber. When we checked into our room the first thing that we noticed about the rooms was the size of Tokyo rooms, they are tiny. with minimal walking space around the base and one side of the bed. The bathrooms are also tight. however the room wasn't the reason that we flew to Japan. A nice touch that the Granbell Hotel offers is a 'handy' travel buddy. This was a small mobile phone that I presume was in each room that had mobile data and allowed you to make local calls. You could take this beauty out on your day trips and use the navigation / maps to get around. Search for local hotspots and restaurants to visit and then also ring to make reservations without having to use your mobile and associated costs. The breakfast that we had included in our room rate was serviceable also, offering a range of different western / Japanese dishes. The location of this hotel is in a fairly quiet area of Shinjuku with not to much traffic around the streets. They also have a rooftop bar that is nice to get a nightcap at the end of a long day and take in the lights of Shinjuku. Would stay here again.

This hotel has a great location. Shinjuku is the place to stay. There is so much to do and so many places to eat. The hotel has some great maps with recommendations for food. The one downside of this hotel was that the Wi-Fi did not work well. A minor note is the bed was too firm for our liking but I think this is common for Asia. I’ve spent about 4 months in Asia and I’m still in search of a comfortable bed. Some have mentioned the size of the rooms; they are typical for the price and area. It is enough room to get some sleep and clean-up for another day of adventure. Some travel tips:-Buy a tourist subway card (very affordable and gets you everywhere in Tokyo)-Checkout the Robot Show; only a few blocks from the hotel. It is a riot. -Cat Cafe Mocha is a wonderful way to relax for an entire day. -Take some risks and walk into a restaurant that looks popular with locals. My favorite sushi was one that was not recommended.

Rooms are quite small, you can barely fit there with only one bag, not much more space for anything else... area: not a nice area specially at night !!!! Surrounded you other type of hotels .... during day area is ok .

This hotel has everything you need but be prepared for small rooms (typical of everywhere in Tokyo). No frills (pool and those sorts of things) but a great rooftop bar and super friendly staff. Just what you need for all the fast pace of Tokyo.

Unless you are staying in one of the top floor executive rooms, this lovely hotels' rooms are tiny. Yet, the room was extremly clean, have all the amenities, and we still had a great view from the hotel room. Staff are very friendly and there is free WiFi.

We stayed in Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for 4 nights and we had a pleasant stay in this modern establishment. The location was a little off the central of Kabukicho Shinjuku (which was a 5 min walk away), with the nearest subway station at Higashi-Shinjuku Exit A1 (3 min walk). There were several convenience stores around the hotel and Tully Coffee (cafe) and Macdonalds nearby. We stayed in a Economy Double which had a smaller Queen size bed (120cm width) than regular Queen (140cm width) hence recommend to stay in Deluxe Double if you wish to have more bed space. The room was small in comparison to regular hotel size but it was common in Japan to have rooms of such size. It was furnished with a small lying couch and small side table by the window. The bathroom also had all the toiletries you need hence you could stay in without bringing any toiletries. The hotel was comfortable, modern and fuss free, will recommend to couples.

this place is impeccable! also I am in love with the breath taking views, make sure to check the terrace lounge on the 12F and have a perfect balance cocktail by the friendly bartender Arai! Very convenient location for public transportation.

I can honestly say that this hotel is one of the best hotels that I have stayed at ever. The staff is very polite, the rooms are clean and comfortable, and they offer a wonderful breakfast comprised of different foods. This hotel is perfect for guest, who want to explore one of the busiest cities in Tokyo.

Granbell is situated in an excellent location, walking distance to Kabki-cho and Golden Gai. Many good restaurants close by. Very functional hotel with a nice roof top bar. Very friendly and professional staff. Clean rooms. All what you need for a Tokyo holiday in Shinjuku area.

In my room, I had a plastic bag full of gifts for friends and family (stationery, candy, toys, etc.) worth around 5000 yen in total. When I left one morning, this bag was out in the open because I had not yet packed it in my suitcase. When I returned at the end of the day, the bag was gone. I searched the entire room and our suitcases with no luck. I thought perhaps the bag had been placed in the hallway during cleaning and someone had accidentally tossed it out, or maybe someone stole it. I went to the front desk and asked if they could find it. They told me that I would be contacted if they discovered what happened, but I heard nothing else. Two days later I went to the desk again and was told that they hadn't found it. And the day after I went again and was told the same. I asked if there was anyway they could help me remedy this problem and they replied with lame excuses. I even suspect that my complaint was not taken seriously and no one actually searched for my stuff. My time and money has been wasted by the actions of the staff at this hotel.

I complained several times about the issue of not having WIFI in the room although it was very much advertised. Management seem no to care. People at the front desk appeared unable to give you a good reason for this.

We stayed in the double economy room. Though small, we were still able to move around comfortably and everything was very clean. We were initially worried about staying on the fringe of the red light district because of previous reviews but it was completely safe. There were love hotels surrounding the area but it was not obvious and we hardly saw anyone entering/exiting the hotels. The hotel is in a good area, a short walk to the train station and attractions such as the robot restaurant. For the price which we paid it was good value.
user_name:
tract003
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: My husband and I stayed here after having our Airbnb cancelled the week before our wedding for our honeymoon. We've been married a week and there are NO SECRETS. The room is small, which is standard for Tokyo, but it fits a queen bed and barely room for a person to walk on 2 sides of. The bathroom is decently sized, but there's a frosted glass wall and no sound proofing. So its a little traumatizing for my relationship. The room is clean, comes with a cell phone you can bring around the city with you, and a television that is only in Japanese, even though it looks like there is an English option (can't click it). The power does cut out when you leave the room, so don't plan on your stuff to charge or for the AC to stay on (it does cool down fast though). All in all, it's a fine room.

Loved this place. Have stayed here twice now. The rooms are tiny but you shouldn't be spending any time in the hotel in Tokyo anyway. It's super clean and the check in / out is very efficient. I loved how close it is to everything as well.

Superior room was slightly small as we expected when booking was made but comfortable enough for two and the room was clean with all amenities provided. In Japan, most hotel provide Japanese style of pyjamas and I really love this one provided by Granbell and its available for sale so I purchased 2 sets during check out.Café/restaurant/vending machines are all available so it gives extra conveniences to the guests who decided to stay in rather than exploring the Shinjuku area as it is situated more to the side but everywhere in this area is within walking distance.Apart from all the good things, there was only one thing which I really wouldn't give point to is the attitude and unfriendliness of the receptionist at the reception counter which I happened to encounter a few of them to be this way during room check in except for a guy who was quite friendly when I checked out of the room. Improvement is definitely required on this as they do not greet or even say goodbye when I leave compared to other places I stayed in Japan.

The hotel itself is average (neither good nor bad) - the rooms are tiny but clean and functional, and the service is ok. It represents fair value for money. The buffet breakfast was consistently quite good, but it was the Rooftop Bar that made us glad we had chosen the Granbell.It's not very close but is close enough to the main Shinjuku train station, and a host of dining and shopping options.

Cons: Tiny room for the expensive price tag. Staff seem genuinely depressed to be working here. Terrible bedding (even if you don’t have to replace it - see below for full rant). Not close enough to the JR line for the cons to be worth it. Staff are too busy to help with luggage or concerns outside of check-in/check-out. Pros: You’ll still be awake at 3am because you’re sleeping arrangement is so uncomfortable which means you’ll have time to give the hotel a very prompt review. Save your time and money. Stay at the Ibis. I’m currently staying at the Shinjuku Grandbell on night 1 of 4 and my experience has been pretty awful so far. This is not a 4 star hotel by any means - 3 stars is a stretch. My partner is allergic to feathers. This has never been a problem anywhere else in the world. Tonight, when I realised the (rock solid) pillows were feather I phoned to have them swapped. The hotel had to phone me back and say they didn’t have any so we made do with the throw cushions on the couch. They would see if they had other pillows in the morning. Every Japanese person we have met up until today has been incredibly kind and polite so even though I was wrapping throw cushions in clothing so I could sleep on them, I was very polite. I later realised the doona is also feather so phoned again and apologised for the second call and asked for a different blanket. The desk attendant told me to come get it myself because they were short staffed. So at 1.30am I opened my suitcase in the smallest room in the world, got dressed and went down to the front desk to find THREE attendants standing around with nothing to do. After noting how abhorrent the service was, the desk attendant blamed me for not requesting the bedding for a good 20 minutes while we argued about his terrible service (which I might add, wouldn’t have happened if he’d just nicely asked me to come get the blanket, rather than demanding me over the phone. I’m not even going to play the ‘paying guest’ card and say he had every capacity to bring the basic bedding to our room). I told the desk attendant I would have my travel agent phone to have a refund issued so I could leave this terrible hotel. He told me he didn’t care, fetched the tiny blanket and came back to yell at me some more. I think the blanket he gave me is a single so my partner and I are huddled in the middle of the rock solid bed because the blanket doesn’t fit across. It’s probably a good thing because the throw pillow is only the size of my head. If I were to roll over I’ll face plant onto a solid stone mattress. Two good lessons here: 1. Stay somewhere else; 2. Make sure you annoy the desk clerk AFTER you get your bedding supplies.

Best Booking.com offer in Tokyo for me and my wife for our first travel to Japan.Things to know:- Small room, but this is standard for Japan. If you’re very tall ask for a twin.- No wardrobe in the room. That’s ok for a short stay, not the best for a week.- Reception personnel nice but not excellent.Great features: - in the room there was a mobile phone that can be used as personal assistant, phone and MOBILE ROUTER (discovered too late, shame on me) Definitely to advertise.- great top roof bar/restaurant- good breakfast also for European customers

Booked 3 rooms for 3 nights for the beginning part of our Japan tour. The hotel was modern and clean. While the rooms are small (we had 2 twin bed rooms and 1 economy double), that's to be expected of most Japanese business hotels, especially within Tokyo proper. There was a built in bench that could accommodate two carry-on size suitcases comfortably, but if you have larger luggage, it may be difficult. The economy double room didn't have an in-room safe if that is important to you (the 2 twin bed rooms did). Although this place offers great rates for Shinjuku, it was a 10-15 minute walk from Shinjuku Station (where JR and shinkansen trains stop), so beware if you are walking on foot from the station with luggage, as it can be a weary trip after a long international flight. Other than that, it was close to the Higashi-Shinjuku Tokyo Metro station as well as Golden Gai and the rest of Kabukicho. We stayed in 6 other hotels throughout the country during our trip, and this was one of the better ones in the going price range.

Staff was very helpful and spoke English rather well. Hotel is neat and clean. We had an economy room, so it was small, but we knew this when we booked. We were there for 9 days and managed fine.It was a very pleasant stay.

Great location if a red light district and room rental by the hour is your thing. Highlight has to be the roof top bar, reasonably priced and a fantastic refuge from the madness that is Shinjuku. Usual half size bath and space age toilet but room size is the biggest negative. We didn’t even have enough space to open a suitcase on the floor.
user_name:
Paul T
County Durham, United Kingdom

review_body: The room was ok. Clean, but very small with nowhere to hang your clothes. We booked a twin room with two small doubles next to each other making a super king bed. The breakfast was 6/10. Better than nothing. The worse bit was the lack of working WiFi. Really not cool and there’s no option to pay for a proper connection either. Yes, you have a Travel Buddy in the room, but it won’t have your personal apps. We spent lot of time in Starbucks. The hotel has some lovely views from the roof terrace. The location is not bad for sightseeing.

Rooms were superclean and the staff was very friendly. The best thing in this hotel was a "Travel buddy", a smartphone with internet and google maps. So convinient! We had pasta at the roof top restaurant and it is not worth to try so I recommend any other restaurant near by.

This was our first time in Tokyo and were aware that the standard room size we booked would be very small; which it was. The room was also clean and relatively quite for the area, which is situated in the middle of busy Shinjuku, just around the corner from the red light district. However, while we felt that the price of this hotel was reflective of a 4 star hotel, the hotel did not live up to this expectation and was more like a 3 star hotel. While this hotel is new the lobby already looks old and there are disgruntled guests sleeping on the couches with their suitcases everywhere! The smoking room is located next to the lobby making it smell like smoke! We often had to wait in line in the smoke filled lobby for the elevator up to our room! The room itself also already feels old with scuff Marks all over the walls. Our room on the 10th floor was very dark with minimal light and was very stuffy! The bed wasn’t particularly comfortable and your pillow choice was either what felt like a sandbag or a pancake! We booked this hotel after reading several excellent reviews and felt it necessary to put it out there that standard rooms are not very nice and do not live up to a “4star” rating

The hotel is not close to the metro/ train station but is really comfortable and convenient. The rooms are quite small but well decorated and with nice views. The staff is correct and with good English.Nice bar in the rooftop with nice views from the Shinjuku area.

I had never been to Japan before and I am so glad I found this hotel. I was with 2 other people so we got a room with 3 single beds. The room was very small but the ceilings were very high! My bed was up a ladder on a really comfortable mattress and my friends were at the bottom. Where I was sleeping there was a projector that I could connect my laptop to, so my friends and I watched movies on the big screen at night in our room! Super cool! The hotel is walking distance to the Robot Resturant and many cat cafes, shops and the train station if you are up for a bit of walking.They have a beautiful rooftop bar with amazing views that we visited many times.The staff at the desk had very good English so it wasn't difficult to ask them questions and they were very helpful, friendly and accommodating. My friend I stayed with is going back to Japan again and staying here once again because we all loved it so much.If I go back to Tokyo, I will be staying here again.

We had a great stay at this hotel. In a great location for restaurants and bars. Only a 10 minute walk to the Shinjuku main subway station. Front desk is friendly and helpful. Nice bathrooms. Decently comfortable bed. Very quiet.

Great place, we upgraded to bigger room was great clean sheets and quilt cover everyday, room nice and tidy. Bathroom was great with separate shower to bath I loved the warm toilet seats lol... buffet breakfast was good only thing wrong is food could of been warmer. Stayed 10 days had no problems at all.

This was our first hotel when we arrived in Japan and I'm glad we choose it. The staff were very helpful and could be reached 24/7 easily, they even went out in a storm to see if they could get a taxi for us. We stayed in the penthouse suite and had stunning views of Shinjuku and the room was beautiful and had a lot of space. The bathroom was stunning also being able to take a bath while looking out over the skyline at night was fantastic. The hotel is a short distance walk from everything Shinjuku has to offer with its nightlife and just a couple of minutes from Higashi-Shinjuku on the Oedo & Fukutoshin lines.

The location was central to all the main attractions in the area. Only a couple of blocks walk to Golden Gai which is a hoot, 5 minute walk to two different subway stations and a ten minute walk to Shinjuku Station. The buffet breakfast was substantial with a large variety of western and Asian food, and the rooftop bar was a great place for a pre-dinner drink or a nightcap. The rooms were the quietest I've ever stayed in with no noise from street (I was on 8th floor), and no toilet or shower noises from adjoining rooms or from above. All staff members were very professional and friendly as well as being able to speak English.

Small but well appointed rooms that were stylish and clean. Hotel quite despite being 5 minutes from the hustle of Shinjuku. Reasonably priced. Would use again when in Tokyo. Bar with city view also, sadly didn’t get time to visit. Happy to provide iron etc

Don't worry about all the pearl clutchers gasping that this area is "seedy" or "scary". It's absolutely fine. Yes Kabuki-cho is a bit of a "red light" district - in the mornings you might see a few people stumbling worse for wear from the night before, and at night there are touts on the corners spruiking strip clubs - but if you're not looking for that sort of action they'll largely leave you alone. The Granbell is located on a quiet street on the edge of that district anyway, so you can avoid it altogether if you really want to. It's a short 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station, which is a great hub for lots of JR lines, and there are lots of great and affordable restaurants and bars within walking distance. The room we had was very small (I think that's just Tokyo, though) but very comfortable and came with some really handy extras such as an internet connected mobile phone you could take with you for free, complete with Google maps and a Tokyo city guide. Really handy, especially if you're travelling without a data capable phone. The rooftop bar had great views, and the staff were very friendly.
user_name:
SystemE
New York City, New York

review_body: Would 100% recommend this hotel. Location was fantastic, easy to walk in to the center of it all & it walk-able distances to underground stations & bus stops. The hotel was really clean & modern. Our room was tiny so if you can afford to get one of the bigger rooms would defiantly recommend that. The room comes with your own handy phone which is great to take out and use the google maps which makes getting around the city so much easier.

It's not especially near the metro but the surrounding area is interesting. Rooms are small but fine. Staff seemed friendly. Bar is ok but if you go for one drink bear in mind you'll have to pay 500 yen per person on top of your drink - seems unnecessary to me. There's a late night baseball batting cage about 30 seconds away FYI.

For our last two nights in Tokyo, we wanted to spoil ourselves and decided to spend $275CAD per night on a "4-star" hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. This hotel warrants 2-stars at best and was a huge let down.The room was much smaller than what was advertised when we booked (through Booking.com), with absolutely nowhere to unpack a suitcase. There were so many funky looking rooms on the booking.com site but not one of them accurately depicted the bland and compact room that we had. There was just enough room for the bed and a couple of feet of space to manoeuver around it. However I cannot fault the hotel for this since I should have done my due diligence and read the TripAdvisor reviews prior to booking, and it is quite common for hotel rooms in Tokyo to be small. To the hotel's credit, the rooms were incredibly clean, the beds were comfortable, and there were plenty of toiletries provided in the bathroom.That being said, it takes more than just a clean hotel room and some free slippers to label yourself as a 4-star hotel. Booking.com describes the room and hotel as being "Fitted with an air of urban sophistication." What would be more appropriate is saying that this hotel tries to be sophisticated but fails spectacularly. From the moment you walk in the hotel, rows upon rows of luggage clutter the lobby (undoubtedly people travelling who have left their luggage in the lobby for the day). Dozens of disgruntled looking guests are hanging around on the couches and there were so many people that we had to line up to get into the elevators. The lobby was in this state every single time we went through it, whether it be at check-in time, in the evening, or at 1AM. It was impossible to appreciate any "air of urban sophistication" in this hotel because of it's inefficient layout resulting in unpleasant clutter and crowds in the common spaces at all hours of the day.Although the bathrooms in the hotel room were sleek, the room itself was not what I would describe as urban sophistication. There were bare white walls that were covered in scuffs and stains (which comes as no surprise given how small the rooms are), and furniture that looked a little on the worn out side. What's worse is that the sliding door to the bathroom was so flimsy and devoid of sound-proofing that you can literally hear everything that goes on in there (not recommended for romantic getaways if you get where I'm coming from).The service at the front desk was average at best. Despite there being many people working there, no one seemed particularly warm and friendly. I had a stressful experience trying to coordinate forwarding my luggage with one front desk employee who didn't seem to know what he was doing (although he was trying and he was friendlier than the other staff members). I did not have full confidence that my luggage was going to arrive at the right place at the right time but thankfully it did.We did not eat at any of the restaurants though we did order coffee and a matcha latte from the café in the lobby. The matcha latte was exorbitantly expensive and incredibly small... you can get much better for much cheaper in Tokyo. The coffee took about a half hour to arrive (no exaggeration). After about 10 minutes of waiting, we reminded the two barristas who seemed to have forgotten about the order (note that there were not more than 5 other customers in the café area at the time, so it was not a busy period). It took another 20 minutes before we got the coffee, because the two workers looked flustered/annoyed and seemed to be having a disagreement with one another. It was very underwhelming service in comparison with what we had grown accustomed to receiving elsewhere all over Japan.Lastly, while the hotel is located within a 3 minute walk to the Higashi Shinjuku subway station (Fukutoshin and Oedo lines), it is still about a 15 minute walk to the main Shinjuku JR station (which connects to well over 10 different lines including the JR Yamanote loop) so the location isn't as ideal as it could be. It is located in the Kabukicho district (aka love hotel district) however I did not find this to be sketchy in any way. The hotels advertised hourly rates on the outside but anything that was going on in or around the hotels was done in such a discrete way that it goes mostly unnoticed. The hotel rooms that were advertised actually looked pretty cool and we wondered if we would have gotten a better value staying in one of those instead of the Granbell.Overall, the cleanliness was appreciated but everything else about this hotel was a disappointment. For a lower price you can get a much larger Airbnb (for our first week in Tokyo, we stayed about 5 minutes from Shibuya Crossing in an Airbnb twice the size of our hotel room for significantly cheaper). In fact, if you're okay with small hotel rooms there are much better options for half the price in Shinjuku (i.e Ibis - small but efficiently laid out, chic, and 3 minutes away from Shinjuku JR station). Save your money and find a better place to stay. Avoid the Granbell if you can!!

Stayed in this hotel for one week in the economy single room. Yes, it was tiny but I was alone. The room was clean, quiet and the bed large and comfortable. I cannot complain for Tokyo and $89USD a night. I did my research and would like to know where those who complain can find a modern, secure, clean hotel in a great location for that money in Tokyo. Those who read this review, you get what you pay for, this is Tokyo, not Hanoi. I was not willing to pay over $100 USD for a place to simply sleep. That said, the neighborhood is fine, these wild stories of stumbling, s-crazed people in brothel like hotels is nonsense. I felt completely safe no matter when I returned to the hotel. The location is close to the JR Shinjuku Station which is convenient to anyplace in Tokyo. I will say the hotel bar is expensive and I canceled a mixed drink and ordered a beer when I saw the thimble sized glass the mixed drink was going to be served in. I also would like a better selection of TV channels, that said I would definitely return to this hotel if the price is right again.

This was my first visit to Japan we heard a lot about Tokyo but it was far beyond our imagination you have to come and see how nice and clean,polite people they are. We went to Fuji mountain and Hakone lake .National museum of Tokyo , sky tree , use the under ground and pullet train.went to fish market,zoo, eat they fantastic food.Imperial palace .i would like to come back to Japan magic.

Hotel is new and with roof top bar which is rare in Shinjuku. The walk from JR to hotel is much further that I expect. After a whole day of shopping or carrying luggage, this 12 mins walk looks forever.Location is far from JR, Room is small, price is not a budget hotel price, check in is slow, bed is not so comfortable. But Hotel is new and clean.So it is not my cup of tea. I would rather spend same amount of money and have a hotel with bigger room and next by JR (although 3-4 stops further from Shinjuku). Or spent a little bit more money to go for a real 4/5 stars hotel next time.

Just checked from it today , the location is perfect in middle of Shinjuku area which is very amusing, full of restaurants and stores. The room was very small which was inconvenient 15 square meter but everything was available in the room . The breakfast was average . The WiFi was perfect and available except in the restaurant and speed was rapid. The nearest metro station is Higashi Shinjuku which is five minutes walk from hotel back door . Very convenient hotel.

We stayed here for four nights for our trip to Tokyo, and it was a solid choice. We found the staff very helpful and everything very clean. Not all of the staff are fluent in English, but enough of them are.Served on the 12th floor with a nice view of the city, the included breakfast was a nice bonus. It's promoted as "western-style," but keep in mind that is a pretty loose descriptor. Don't expect all of your comfort foods or even those foods they include to be familiar. But you're in Tokyo! Be adventurous!And it turns out, miso soup for breakfast is actually really good.On the topic of breakfast, there's a small coffee shop on the ground floor; however, like all coffee shops in Tokyo, it seems, it doesn't open until 11. So if you're like me and need coffee in the morning, hit it up at breakfast (which you should make sure your booking includes) or make other plans.You will read other reviews about the small room size, and yes, our room was small, but it's Tokyo. Know what to expect. Focus on the positives, like the comfortable bed (which is 99% of the reason you get a hotel room) and the greatest toilet you'll probably ever sit on. Also, the smaller size means this hotel is affordable. A big plus, each room is supplied with a Handy phone, which is a smartphone you can take with you on your travels. The hotel should really do more to promote this because it's a huge bonus if you're traveling without an international data plan. I gather this isn't uncommon anymore, but it's nice that the Shinjuku Granbell has them.And be aware that this is in Tokyo's Red Light District, Kabukicho. In the immediate area, you'll find love hotels, clubs, and some potentially shady looking places for Shinjuku. But again, you're in Tokyo. That means you're still relatively safe, and you're not coming here to not experience the city and culture. And, this might actually be a plus for you. For instance, Golden Gai is a very short walk away. For that matter, Shinjuku station isn't far.Is this the best place to stay in Tokyo? No, but it's a solid choice that, if you temper your expectations, you probably won't regret. We didn't.
user_name:
Timbalabim
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I stayed here for 3 nights with my husband and we enjoyed our stay. The rooms are small by Western standards but the hotel has basic amenities and is clean and comfortable. The staff were friendly and helpful and the hotel is close to many restaurants and bars in Shinjuku. It’s also just a several minute walk to the subway stations. We would stay here again.

Stayed at Shinjuku Granbell with family. The hotel lobby is clean and the rooms are neat and well maintained. The room we had was double but it was very tiny. There was no closet and no space for luggage. Also, the hotel's location is not very ideal as it was a bit of a walk to the commercial area and the subway station. Lastly, some of the staff at the front desk behaves as if they don't want to help you. This clearly isn't an ideal hotel for families with small children.

Had to stay some where in Shinjuku as shuttle was needed in early morning so checked in at night. A lady with a badly done face was very ansty and curt when we checked in. Perhaps it was a busy night at the reception. We wanted to enquire about upgrading with payment to a bigger room after seeing what type of location is property was at. She cut us out saying we were booked at economy room. Well this is Tokyo central ...almost all room is economy to me! Try Sapporo ..even standard rooms was much bigger. We let it slide as we were already very tired travelling cities to cities.Room ECONOMY is super small and window view faces the other cheap love hotels or motels screaming 3900 yen for 3hrs stay.It's located among many dodgy love hotels and neon light bars that even at 7-8am still have dwellers rushing for cabs off the little roads. So there is competition for getting one. Wont recommend it for families with small toddlers. Location was at least two -three blocks from main road. And having so many hotels or motels nearby. This is not a place I would recommend. There are better ones on the main road towards the Kabuki-cho.

Hotel is located very conveniently. Easy to find. Obviously well recommended as both friends and us booked the hotel completely separately. The staff at check in were nice. The rooms were tiny, really small and if we were staying more than one night I think my partner and I would have called it quits. The bar on the top floor was underwhelming and had little atmosphere.

We stayed here for 4 nights in an economy double. Room was small but we werent surprised - as we had read all the information before we booked. It was a base to rest our head thats it! Would have liked more coat hangers as only 2 but im sure if we had asked we could have had some more. Bed was comfy, bathroom clean. Toilettries in room. Free bottles of water provided each day. Slippers and bed dress provided.15/20 minutes walk from shinjuku station. 5 minutes to golden gai. Felt was a good location and good place to base ourselves from to explore tokyo! Went to bar one night - great views, reasonable prices and cover charge waivered for guests of hotel! Would recommend to anyone staying in Tokyo!

For 2 nights stay it was ok. Breakfast was alright. The room was compact but not any smaller than some that we've stayed. Wifi was relatively fast. Convenience stores close by for those late night noodle snacks. We had good rest after walking all day.

Quite a small room but had everything in it. Just very compact. Not much room for luggage.The window was very small as well. No parking out front of hotel and a bit of a walk. Very obliging staff. Very clean room.

I’ve traveled to over 30 countries and stayed in over a hundred hotels. This was by far my worst experience ever. I woke up after my first night at the hotel and was covered in bed bug bites. I asked to speak to the manager privately since any hotel- including four star hotels, can have bed bugs tracked in. The manager was contemptuous and rude. He simply offered to have the sheets changed which demonstrates a complete disregard for this issue. After significant pushback he agreed to change me into a new room- the same room type and category, and at my insistence, launder my clothes since the rooms are very small and my clothes were in close proximity to the bed (bed bugs lay eggs in clothing or hitchhike). The manager was super difficult to deal with, totally unapologetic, initially refusing to launder my clothes, although he ultimately relented. During my discussion with him he was more concerned about ensuring I did not receive a benefit as a result of my terrible experience, continuously saying to me “no benefit for you”. The hotel took my clothes to launder them. I was later informed that they would not be ready until the next day. When my clothes were ready I was not notified. The manager never followed up with me and was not concerned about service, or the fact that I had a terrible experience and basically lost a day in Tokyo waiting for my clothes to be laundered, or that I had been subjected to a bed bug infestation. I would avoid this hotel at all costs as the manager was right about one thing, there is no benefit to staying there.私は30カ国以上に旅行し、100以上のホテルに滞在しました。これまでのところ私の最悪の経験でした。私はホテルで最初の夜の後に目を覚まし、ベッドのバグの咬傷で覆われた。私は4つ星のホテルを含むどのホテルも追跡したベッドバグを持つことができるので、個人的にマネージャーに話すように頼んだ。マネージャーは軽蔑的で無礼だった。彼は単にシートを変更してこの問題の完全な無視を示すように提案しました。大きなプッシュバックの後、彼は私を新しい部屋に変更することに同意しました - 同じ部屋のタイプとカテゴリ、そして私の主張で、部屋は非常に小さく、私の服はベッドのすぐ近くにありました。服やヒッチハイク）。彼は結局服を洗濯することを拒否していましたが、彼は最終的には服従しました。彼との私の議論の中で、彼は私のひどい経験の結果として私が利益を受けなかったことを確実にすることに、私にとって「あなたには何の利益もない」と絶えず言いました。ホテルは私の服を洗濯した。私は後日、彼らが翌日まで準備ができていないと知らされました。私の服が準備ができたら、私は知らされなかった。マネージャーは私に追いついたことはありませんでした。サービスについて心配していませんでした。あるいは、私は恐ろしい経験をしていて、基本的に東京で服を洗濯するのを待っていた、またはベッドバグの被害を受けました。私はこのホテルを絶対に避けるだろう！

i will recommend this hotel if you visit tokyo. affordable price with quality hotel in the central of shinjuku area.location wise very convenient n close to shopping area n train station.Breakfast standard but the taste is good.

Fantastic 3 night stay. Very convenient location just 5mins from subway station and 20mins Shinjuku station. Check in and out very efficient and quick. Rooms good size for Japan. Kettle and tea/coffee. Clean bathroom and toilet. Very comfy beds. Lots of useful tourist info in foyer and vending machines for late drinks. Stunning rooftop bar - highly recommended to visit. Lunchtime buffet at restaurant is really good value.

Hotel is right on the fringe of the red light district but is quiet when your in your room. Good walking distance to the “sights”Definitely one of the busier places in Tokyo and wouldn’t recommend for more than a few nights. Shibuya is much better.Hotel rooms are VERY small even by Japanese standards.Breakfast can be hectic with many tour groups staying at this hotel.I would opt for a different area to stay if just in Tokyo for a few days.

I stayed 4 nights during my trip to Tokyo. The hotel is about 10-15 mins walk to Shinjuku station, so it's not that close. The big plus is to be walking distance to all the action without the noise. Front desk staff were helpfull and spoke English. Lobby is modern with a coffee shop and maps available for free with suggestions of restaurants and store. I was travelling alone and booked a standard single room. As expected the room was tiny! You can't even have your suitcase open! The bathroom was well equiped, the double bed very comfy and good wifi. There is a free cellphone to use and you can bring with you everywhere in Tokyo including internet.... googlemap will be your best friend! I didn't book with breakfast but I went one morning. It is extremely busy with line up for the dining room. The selection is ok, nothing spectacular. The front desk staff can take care shipping your suitcase to your next hotel is you want ($) and it's totally worth it. Tokyo station is 30 mins away by walking and metro.

Wow, what a location? Everything about this hotel was great. The staff at front desk were fabulous, checked us in, put our bags aside, so we could go and explore and eat till our room was ready. Our room was compact, but had everything. Bed was super comfortable, pillows. All amenities supplied, and the best dripper coffee. I would definitely stay there on my next visit to Tokyo

Located close to subways and the JR line, this was a pretty easy hotel to access from Haneda when we flew in on. Sunday evening, having taken the monorail and Yamanote line to within a 10 min walk of the hotel. Checking in was polite, quick, and our few questions answered in understandable English. Rooms are typical Japanese small, but very clean and efficiently laid out. Slight challenges with the climate controls and futuristic toilet as instructions were only in Japanese, but overall everything worked well. Decent sized lobby and hotel. Good blackout shades and quiet space surroundings. Nice to be able to step outside though and be quickly immersed in the vibe of the area. Tons of restaurants nearby.

I booked this hotel without the greatest of expectations as it was a lot cheaper then similar hotels. From the moment we arrived the staff were friendly and welcoming and checking in was easy. The room was small as but bigger then other reviews made me think it would be and was very clean and well stocked with toiletries. My wife and i stayed for 8 nights and with 2 suitcases it was quite crowded but as we were out and about all the time it did not matter. The hotel is in a good location. Walking distance for a lot of good attractions and restaurants and has convenience stores very close by. Was an easy 10 minute walk from shinjuku train station which connects straight to narita airport so was really easy and cheap to get to and from hotel and airport. I would not hesitate to stay here again.

This hotel is located near enough to but far enough away from the lively streets of Shinjuku. We didn't hear any noise from our hotel room and commented that it must definitely be sound proofed. The room itself was small but had everything we needed - toiletries, fresh towels, a smartphone you could take with you while travelling around the city! It was a little cramped though for 2 people and 2 backpacks. The hotel was clean and provided ample breakfast options with views overlooking Shinjuku. The roof top bar also boasts nice views. We were a 7 minute walk from the subway so could easily access the city. Would stay again!

Just checked out after staying 3 nights. I arrived early at around 07:00. Before arriving I had asked whether I can have a early check in after a 12 hour flight. I was informed this was not possible as check in time is 15:00. However they did say book a night before to ensure early check in. Therefore I booked a extra night knowing I would arrive on the morning. I checked in and got some sleep. Though I was woken up at 11:30 and told I had to checkout at 12:00 and wait for checkin for 15:00. As the room type was different. I was furious. However on my final day they again rang the room telling me to check out at 12:00 and anytime beyond 12:20 I will be charged. This is the first time after travelling extensively I had this type of experience. Just based on this I would say avoid this hotel. Customer service is terrible! I will be staying at their branch in Kyoto. Hope they are better.

This hotel is ideal if you want to be close to Tokyo's night life but was a LONG journey by taxi from Tokyo station. The room was yet another designed for very small people! At least our room at the back of the hotel was quiet. When we,stayed, the restaurant was closed, they didn't say why. A TINY cafe in reception opened at 10am for drinks and snacks and the lovely roof top bar served food at night. The staff were not the most friendly but were efficient. We would not stay there again but if you are travelling light and enjoy going out at night into crowded, noisy streets, this will do.

Fully aware that isn’t quite the saying but to call this hotel anything other than perfectly adequate wouldn’t be right. Before you visit Japan, Tokyo particularly, you are of course aware that space is a commodity in major demand but this room was fairly small even by those standards and two of us struggled managed to navigate the room, let alone with two suitcases. If you need a reference, did you or a friend ever get your first double bed as a child/teenager and despite you having a box room, you were going for the king-size. All your visitors and your poor mother simply had to stumble around the foot-wide moat surrounding your bed. Cute kimono pyjamas were a lovely touch and the vending machines on ground floor were a great punch of Tokyo. Staff were friendly and of course the anticipated/dreaded Japanese toilet was great. We always say this but location is so important, so fo us, next to two metro lines and the monumental Shinjuki station certainly made for a great base. Also being tucked a way a little from the high streets made leaving and returning comfortable. Only other negative would be that the panoramic lounge they boast about was closed. I think this was because it was ‘cold’ but even still, for all the fuss they made over it, would have been good to have visited it. Particularly as we were there around New Years. Overall, a great little base for a proper Tokyo city break.

Good location, Great roof top bar, Room was clean, tidy and well serviced. It was a little cramped for me, and it was a shame that the small window wouldn't open either. Overall hotel felt safe and secure. Restaurant on 12F was undergoing renovations when I was here, so could only have bar snacks. Surprised that smoking was allowed inside the bar after 10pm.... Bar service was prompt, yet junior. Cafe in lobby was good, but only opened at 10am, not good for getting a takeway on the way to work.Disappointed that there were no gym facilities. VOD (video on demand) was not working when there, and WiFi was also intermittent and under maintenance too. Wired internet at desk was very fast. Working space at desk was very limited with little space to put legs. Overall, would probably not stay here again, and instead try another hotel, probably a larger one with more facilities.

My wife and I stayed here for six nights. Overall it was okay as we spent limited time at the hotel but be warned, this is possibly he smallest room you’ll ever get - basically two people can’t move around at the same time without tripping over each other and there’s hardly enough space to leave a suitcase open. Despite this (and the slow useless internet connection) we found it okay and bearable. Location is convenient enough (about 10 mins from main Shinjuku Station) and tons of good food etc not too far away. If the hotel will just be somewhere to sleep it’s worth a look, otherwise search elsewhere.

This is a great Hotel in a great location. The lunch buffet at Restaurant G located on the 12 floor is a must and also happy hour at the roof top outdoor area can not be skipped. the var tender Mr Arai really knows his drinks! All the staff are friendly and most can speak basic English.

The room we had was of a very good size, fine bath room and a very good bed. Good view to the city.Need more wardroom space, hardly nothing. In general good service in reception and restaurant, however, the hotel has not real restaurant facilities. Mainly only breakfast and bar.

We booked 4 nights in one of their top floor rooms. Our room had a magnificent view of the city and an outdoor bath. The room was enormous, we loved the luxury of it and having some space to unpack after our previous very small rooms elsewhere in Tokyo. The bed was amazingly comfortable and the amenities are second to none. We had a drink at the rooftop terrace which was nice, but it was a bit chilly so we didn’t stay long. The hotel is fairly central to the subway and a little bit of a walk to Shinjuku JR station. Closest subway is less than 5 minutes away. Close to a multitude of restaurants and the front desk staff have lists by food type of restaurants suggestions within walking distance - they put us onto a fantastic Sushi restaurant just up the road - we went there twice!! The only disappointment was the breakfast which came with our room rate - it was very standard fare, not what you’d expect from a hotel of this caliber. We ended up going out for breakfast instead on the last 2 days.

Travelled with my wife and 1 year old son. The room was really small, a struggle with suitcases (you simply cannot pack really lightly with a baby) that was made palatable only because we stayed just the 1 night.Concerns about this being the red light district are overblown. Yes there are hotels in the vicinity that rent their rooms 'by the hour', but it's not overly obvious and I would not have concerns of that nature in making a booking here.For a single traveller this hotel would be brilliant.
