We had a group of 6 stay at this hotel during the cherry blossom season and overall, this is a solid hotel. Rooms - decently sized compared to other hotels in japan. We got water every day, the restroom was clean and functional and not too tight and the room even came with a phone you can use during your stay. Location - 10-15 minute walk from shinjuku, but closer to the local stations 5-10 mins. You do have to walk through some interesting and spotty streets depending on where you are coming from, but overall, a manageable walk. Concierge - I tried their Bebot (web chat) concierge and was able to get a reservation to a sushi restaurant that I otherwise wouldn’t have been able to during the busy cherry blossom season. 5/5 for their bebot concierge experience.

The room is bigger than the rooms in many other hotels in Tokyo, but not big. No facilities. The restaurant was closed. Wi-fi doesn’t exist. It was clean, staff was nice and let us check in a little bit earlier. They provide you with a smartphone (and internet) for your explorations. Comfortable overall but not great

I enjoyed my stay here. The WiFi worked very well and the room was comfortable and quiet. The location is great as it’s close to Shinjuku station and a short walk to many shops and restaurants. The room also included a smartphone with unlimited data and WiFi. This was a pleasant surprise and something I hope to see included at more hotels!

The WiFi in our room rarely worked and when it did it was so slow it wasn’t worth waiting around all day just to check ones email. Needless to say, at the room rate, something this basic needs to be much better. It’s 2018. Come on.

We spent 7 nights in this hotel, the room was tiny but Nice and clean, we had breakfast there, not bad but it was the same every single day. Would have love it if they changed fruits or have some pancakes or hot chocolate. The rooftop is nice! It is well located, near from shinjuku area !

Room rates for tourists are twice more expensive than for locals. Hotel has no facilities, no gym, no pool. Packed with groups from China. Very small rooms in busy district with night clubs and cheap eateries

First things first, unless you pay for it, your room will be small. You can't fit big luggage, a baby bed, a crib or your portable piano in this room. Not happening. Your room will also be charming, clean and perfectly usable with thoughtful, charming amenities like a toothbrush, cotton balls, hair ties and Japanese pajamas (!)Your room will also be in the midst of it all but also far enough away not to be overwhelming. This hotel is about an 8-10 minute walk away from the JR metro station, 15 minutes walk from the massive Shinjuku train station, 5 minutes from Golden Gai drinking/noshing area, 10 minutes from the Shinjuku Gyoen Park and 10 minutes away from Kabukicho nightlife area (that didn't seem as 'seedy' as they make it out to be at all).... it was perfect for a first time stay in Tokyo. The bar upstairs has a gorgeous view of the city at night and the fee is reimbursed if you are staying at the hotel. Drinks were quite good and the outdoor area has blankets and heaters. The desk clerks were most helpful but not obsequious. There were lots of tourists from all over during our stay.The area felt very extremely safe. Totally ok to walk around at any hour of the day or night.Another fun detail is that this hotel is in the midst of the love hotel area. So nearly every hotel around this one has posted rates for sections of hours, rather than full nights. A pretty fun cultural difference that can be entertaining.To get there, we took the limo bus from Narita and then a $20 cab from Shinjuku station to the hotel. On the way back, we took the train and after riding the subway system for a while and getting the hang of it, the train back was quite easy but it might have been a tad overwhelming first thing off the plane. If you take the train or limo bus to Shinjuku station, the hotel is still a 15-20 minute walk from there down very meandering streets. Print a map or ensure you have wifi if you go this route and are not familiar with the rail lines.

The location of this hotel is great, the rooms are small (no dresser or anywhere to put your clothes), but the bed is comfortable. However, the front desk was so bad I would never stay here again. First, they would not give us a baby bed for my niece because the room was too small, but this was never mentioned when I booked it. That was bad enough, but the worst was when we were trying to book a steak dinner. The woman at the desk spent 5 minutes looking for a restaurant to recommend and the one she chose was not even open that day. So we found one on our own and a different woman (the one who wouldn’t help with the baby bed) refused to call them for us until we tried first to see if they spoke English. After calling and finding out they did not, she was finally willing to make the reservation for us. My family lives in 3 different countries, so we travel a lot to get together, and none of us had ever dealt with a front desk who was so difficult. The restaurant staff were great, but they couldn’t make us for the terrible service at the front desk.

We have stayed in this hotel 3 times already and we really like it. Even it is slightly aware from the subway or JR station, but it is under the walking distance (around 10-15 minutes). It just like 5 minutes away from the Toyota Car Rental shop, if you are planning to rent a car for travel the area outside of Tokyo, it is very convenient. We have booked a very special room this time and it is very spacious. The room is really modern and have the jacuzzi outdoor. It is difficult to find a such a huge size of room in Tokyo with such nice/modern design. It's worth to try !

Stayed in this hotel for 5 nights.The room and adjoining bathroom were small.Well positioned to the train station and eateries.Choose if 4 types of breakfast in 2 locations within the hotel. Staff spoke English and were helpful.Close to the JR Booking Office.

The hotel is quite new for Tokyo’s standard. The rooms are nicely designed with some great city view.The bar is lovely for a chill at night and planning your next day adventures.However again in my opinion is quite expensive for what’s offering. The breakfast is very basic except the croissant is as good is in Paris:)

Check in is slow as front desk offer a trainee to service us for a group of 7 people. She spent 10 min and only processed two rooms for us. Still the manager complained us blocking the way for rest of guest to check-in in not so nice way which is rare in Japan. We are so pissed off and responded to her in that case why dont they speed up our check in process with rest of the front desk staff that is in fact free and got nothing to do but just standing there. As a guest, we have no time to stand for over 10 mins snd let them train their staff and waste our time.But anyway, hotel is clean with reasonable price. Room size as small as any other Shinjuku budget hotel.Downside of the hotel other than service is it is just too far away from JR. We overestimated our buying power, after shopping for few days and take all of our luggage and goods to walk back to JR to take the Narita Express to airport becomes tough. If you dont plan for too much shopping. This hotel location is still ok consider the price. If you are a good shoppers, just to stay closer to the station.

The hotel is probably a 5-10 minute walk from the nearest JR Station. The hotel is also a 10 minute walk from the centre of Shinjuku where you can find The Robot Restaurant, the Golden Gai or The Godzilla Head.The rooms are very small! There's barely enough room to unpack, we had to live out of our suitcases. The windows would not open (or at least ours didn't) and we found the room to be quite claustrophobic through the night, as it became so hot, even the windows would steam!
user_name:
Georgi18
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is a very good hotel located within the Shinjuku area.It is about 10mins walk from the main red-light and entertainment districts (Kabukicho / Shinjuku). The hotel is close to Higashi-Shinjuku station (~5mins walk) and Shinjuku Sanchome station (~7mins walk). The hotel can be a bit tricky to find however given it is located in the back streets off the main road, and you can get confused coming to and from or back to the hotel after a long day. Pros:- close to the Shinjuku area- courteous staff- free umbrellas on a raining day;Cons:- rooms are quite small (10-12sqm), however this is Tokyo so this is all relative;- can be tricky to find / navigate at times

Stayed 3 nights and was very happy with this European/boutique style hotel as my base for a first time exploring Tokyo. Great central location; pleasant staff, modern compact room (firm bed/pillows as in all of Japan); good varied breakfast buffet to set you up for the day.

This hotel appears fairly new with modern/contemporary feel. We had the economy room which was very small but was clean and funky looking. It’s a close walk to the main JR station via a 15 minute walk.

We got the economy double which is pretty small but clean. The hotel is in a great location, about 5-10 minutes to the nearest subway station. WiFi is good except for at night, when a lot of people are using it. We didn’t get breakfast so we could explore the city. I would recommend you do the same.

Even though the hotel is located in the middle of the Kabukicho district the area around the hotel is nice and quiet. We had a great view over the city from our room. Walking distance to Shinjuku Station (5 minute walk).Rooms are small but well planned (as everything is in Japan), nice amenities and rooftop bar.

Average service/ food not Good/ location is in the middle of red light area (full of cons) roof top bar very nice view, tiny room/ very uncomfortable pillow. In japan most people wear mask to hide their identity (pls don’t trust people in red light area / n jap police are the worse very slow)

Our stay here was great. Everything went very smooth from check in to check out. The staff were friendly and very helpful. Everything we needed was in the room, and the bed was comfortable. The room with one double bed was very small. This was my first trip to Japan, and I have heard all rooms are on the small side, so we just went with it. I would prefer a toilet that is more than a meter from the head of the bed I suppose. I still like the place, might just try for a larger room next time.

Located in the Kabuchiko area of Shinjuku. It’s about a 15-20min walk from Shinjuku station. Surrounding area has a few girly bars and there may be a few touts along the way, but all very harmless. Lawson’s/711 nearby. Breakfast at 1,500 Yen per head. Rooms are new, clean. With a space for a writing desk and chair. Bath is slightly bigger than normal Japanese standard. Will stay here again next time.

This hotel is in my opinion perfectly situated within the heart of Shinjuku. Just on first night taking a walk, I stumbled across the famous Golden Gai area within minutes (and the love hotels). The hotel is within walking distance to most things within Shinjuku. The only issue I have with the hotel is that there is no guidance or directions available for walking from Shinjuku Station (which is the route most would take), which makes it extremely difficult to navigate through bustling Shinjuku, especially of you don't have Wi-Fi. The hotel itself was sophisticated without being grand. The rooms are well kept and the staff are nice without being great. One issue with the room however is the TV. The channels are all understandably Japanese, however, the only English channel is an American news channel. Now that maybe okay for some, however it would be great if the likes of NHK English, Al Jazeera, the BBC and others alike would be included, and potentially a standard channel that plays English content (given that Japan has a large array of entertainments option available on TV). However, this hotel is a solid choice for those who want to be right in the heart of Tokyo and get a feel for Japan (especially the room sizes haha).

Located in the Shinjuku area and close to many other shopping areas and eateries. Service staff were very helpful in rendering tourists to get around Tokyo. Overall an excellent hospitality and worth checking it out!

Great location in Shinjuku, close to public transportation, yet in a quieter neighborhood. The bathroom amenities were great, as were the shower products available. An extra plus for clean and crisp PJ's in the room.The economy double room, that we had initially booked, had a bed that was too small for two persons. At least two persons of Scandinavian height. We upgraded the room to a superior room with a slightly bigger bed. The service was not what one would expect of a four star property in Tokyo, however. The staff were curt, and difficult to communicate with, partially due to the fact that they hardly spoke English. They were unable to help out with dinner reservations at restaurants or book taxis unless you were personally present in the lobby. This was a bit unpractical, as most restaurants open later in the day. On one of the days we stayed, we received an e-mail that due to electrical tests, we could not access our hotel room between 12:00 and 17:00. This was fine. On our last day, when we requested a later check-out of one hour, the front office required that we pay a fee for this. We thought this was a bit unflexible, seen as we had not been able to access the room for five hours the previous day. They would not budge on this, and were quite unfriendly about it.I would not recommend the hotel breakfast, which seems to have been outsourced. It only costs ¥ 1300 per person, and has a varied buffet with a rather odd selection. Watery, uncooked scrambled eggs, green eggs, tasteless miso soup and orange juice marked "freshly squeezed" even though it was from concentrate, unfortunately pulled down the experience for us.

We hv visited between Feb 21-24, were told we can ask front desk to book restaurants for us(even Michelin stars barely anyone speaks English) & we hv got brochure abt Bebot, basically English & Chinese you can ask for all type of favour including booking all type of services require Japanese, definitely makes my trip much easier, perfect for tourists.

I celebrated my Mums 80 th birthday in Tokyo and we had the best trip ever. The best discovery was a service Granbell provided Bebot.io. The next best thing to slice bread . Restuarant reservations , recommendations and all enquiries through bebot on WeChat . Prompt , responsive and amazing service . Anyone visiting Japan will need to stay with hotels that provide a bebot service ...

Second time at Granbell Shinjuku. In terms of proximity, a 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku Station but possibly only a 3 minutes walk from Higashi Shinjuku Station. Very clean and comfortable hotel. Well stocked with bathroom amenities which I really liked. If I should nit pick, there is no housekeeping service after 2pm. A note will be provided mentioning that the housekeeping service hours have passed and you'll have to pop by the front desk to collect the towels. I do accept the cut-off timings but suggest that the housekeeping staff could minimally put in new towels and replenish bottled water. It will make me happier and would have accorded a 5 stars rating for this review. Overall a good hotel.

Unless you know Tokyo very well or speak Japanese, this is not the hotel for you. The rates are good but there is no concierge service. You are pretty much on your own. Wouldn’t even help my 84 year old mother with her bag. Forget about getting a restaurant recommendation. Won’t happen. Just about everything about the stay was a disappointment. The rooms are teeny. The twin room has two beds but it may as well be one. They are crammed into a small space with zero space between them. There is nowhere to put a suitcase, no closet for clothes. Bath products and shower are good. The rooftop lounge is nice but was empty most of the time. The breakfast buffet is very mediocre, not like most hotels we’ve stayed at in Asia. I’d skip booking the breakfast option and go elsewhere. Not worth the money. The neighborhood is dicey; our local contacts were shocked we were staying in this area. So hard to get a cab in the morning that our group missed their already paid for Mt. Fuji Tour, unable to get transportation from the hotel to connect with their group. No good option offered for airport transfers (we paid $255 plus a service charge to the hotel for ordering the taxi). Next time in Tokyo I will stay elsewhere.

This hotel was excellent, rooms are cleaned every day, the rooms where a little bit small but this is not an issue, the staff are excellent, location was excellent only a 15min walk to Shinjuku Station and a 5 min walk to the train metro, coffee is excellent from the cafe down stairs, the roof top bar has a nice view of Shinjuku, would stay here again

We left our room before 12nn today, and put signal “please clean up the room” However, NO housekeeping clean up the room, they only put a note said that no more staff on duty after 14:00, we only can provide clean towels to you! When I went down Front desk to check what happen, they also only said no more housekeeping staffs today, we only can clean your room in tomorrow. I ask why, they only reply we will check in tomorrow....What kind of the service???

Super small room but for this central it's all about the same size just be prepared to trip over your luggage in the middle of the night.Really helpful staff and good roof top bar with great views and a reasonable price.Best thing is everything is pretty much walkable including Shinjuku train station to get you anywhere you can't walk.

I stayed here twice in February in two different rooms (one at the beginning of my Japan trim then at the end as we came back to tokyo). First room was so tiny, unbelievably tiny, but clean. We were surprised to find it near lots of seedy love hotels and gentleman clubs!! The second room we booked was a two single bed room and it was bigger, nice bath tub too. We found on our second visit that it's really close to Shinjuku station (lots of food and shops), and Korea town. The big downside that lost points is the poor wifi, staying on the 9th floor the wifi is basically non existent. It's pretty annoying when you want to use it when at the hotel. Restaurant looked average and so we didn't eat there, there was lots of options if you walk toward the station. Staff were pretty nice and decent enough English. House keeping was good, and we enjoyed the drip coffee too.

We stayed here on our last night in Japan. It was clean and nice. There was a lot of noise in the room. It sounded like fans and compressors from the air conditioning. It’s close enough to restaurants, but I wouldn’t say it’s right in the middle of everything.

The room was comfortable and the hotel was near to a few different train stations and good eating options. The bathroom was great with toiletries and a shower bath. As is the norm in Tokyo, the room was tiny. Of the two different rooms shown in the photos before we booked, we ended up with the smaller one with barely enough space to lie down and open one suitcase. We probably wouldn't stay again as I feel we could do better for the price.

This is a comfortable hotel, conveniently located in Shinjuku about 15 minutes walk from the train station. The rooms are slightly larger than the Tokyo average which is a plus. The restaurant has a great view of Shinjuku.

Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is about 5mins walk away from Shinjuku train station and very close to many pubs and sushi bar. There are also plenty of family mart and lawson that you can get snacks, drink and etc.Best part about this hotel is that it offers plenty of space in your room, there is a place for me to sit and have my breakfast. Been travelling around Tokyo hotel and realised most hotel are very small. In additional to the plenty of space Shinjuku Granbell Hotel offer, it comes with really great bathroom.The Hotel is new and within walking distance of many places of interest with Shinjuku, the rest are like hidden gems awaiting for your to discover when you are staying there. Definitely the one to choose if you're looking for a good for money hotel in Tokyo.

We booked one of their luxury club rooms for one night recently, and although the room itself was nice, we were not happy with a few other things about the hotel. We had booked this room because part of the description said that it included access to a lounge with free food and drinks. Upon check in they told us this lounge would be open until 22:00, so around 19:30 we went up there. However, upon arrival we were told that we were too late for alcoholic drinks since that stopped at 19:00 (we were eventually given one glass of wine each, however it took quite a bit of arguing to get it). This would have been nice information to know when we checked in, and it is also a poor policy. If people are willing to pay extra for the luxury rooms then they should have access to the club with free drinks whenever they like, or at least later than 19:00 when maybe people are just recovering from sight seeing all day. The hotel just was not relaxing and I wouldn't book a room here again.

We stayed at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for 7 days to explore Tokyo, the location is in quite area and is excellent to go the Robot Restaurant and Golden Gai area, The stuff of the hotel was really helpful and the beds are comfy and clean.

We loved our stay here, the hotel is really well taken care of, clean and new.The beds are really comfortable, rooms are a good size (we had a Deluxe Hollywood twin room), and amenities include everything, even a kettle with tea and coffee.The breakfast selection is really good, with options of japanese style breakfast or western. The views from the restaurant are incredible.The neighbourhood is incredible, hectic at all times, but the exact location of the hotel is pure peace, and away from the noise but two steps away from anything handy.The neighbourhood is full of restaurants that offer really good food for a good price.It's also not far from Shinjuku station, you can easily walk there in 10-15 minutes, which makes it really easy to move around Tokyo.We will definitely stay here when we come back!Thank you for everything!

The hotel is in a great location in Shinjuku. It’s close the the Golden Gai and Robot Restaraunt. However it is quite expensive and the rooms are very small. The breakfast is unimpressive with no options, apart from what is set out; i.e. If you dont like the powdered scrambled eggs you cant get custom eggs.My biggest complaints are: 1. the ¥500 per person table charge to sit in the lounge. Considering that we are drinking premium priced drinks that seemed too much; and 2. We couldn’t share a pizza in the restaraunt- we both needed to order a meal to sit in the restaraunt.

Stayed here 3 nights and I was very pleased with my stay. The hotel is a fine boutique hotel within walking distance all over Shinjuku. Close by is the famous eat-street packed with bars, restaurants and izakaya’s. The room was good, a bit small, but hey, it’s Tokyo. WiFi was fast so that’s a plus. I’ll definitely stay here again when I’m back in Tokyo, I think this might be my new favorite hotel in Shinjuku!

The staff are friendly helpful and efficient. Rooms are strangely (to westerners) small but well organized and cute....The breakfast in the level 14 resonant with great views is well worth paying for.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights during our trip through Japan. It was such a lovely space, and we loved the cool modern touches in the room; from the open floor plan, the sliding glass doors, the views! We loved being in such close proximity to shopping, restaurants, transit, and ofcourse the bars of Golden Gai. Our only negative was that they only gave us two small waters at night and there was nowhere else to get fresh water (I think we looked in the vending machine but only saw beer? then again we don't read Japanese).

Great breakfast :) :) :) , nice hotel; great moment ; small room;;;;;;but what else we are in japan , nearest Shinjuku station; nearest attractions , was a nice moment in this hotel , for 3 nights , verry secure zone

Stayed at the Granbell for 7 nights across new year. We had a great time! We stayed in a deluxe double room, which was a decent size for a Tokyo hotel.Good location, about 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station and just round the corner from both Golden Gai and Kabukichō area. Lots to see and take in.The breakfast view and the breakfast were amazing, really enjoyed it, especially the the Japanese options. Coffee not great though.The roof top bar was great for New Years Eve, looking out over the city. Nice cocktails and lots of drinks options.

I thought the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel was an excellent property. We booked a deluxe luxory room for our stay which was quite lovely and spacious. It also provided a nice view of Shinjuku which we enjoyed. The hotel was in a great location with walking distances from two subway stations (which is very important when getting around Tokyo). It's also nearby Golden Gai which is great for you night owls looking for a good bar.On mornings/nights you feel like staying in, the hotel offers a nice breakfast buffet where you can explore some decent eats. There's also a rooftop bar to lounge at.Overall, our stay at the Shinjuku Granbell was a wonderful experience. Looking forward to our next visit.

Well Tokyo is really impressive and enjoying my stay, there are a few things about the hotel that are really bugging me.. the staff are lovely... but..... our room has no wardrobe, no where to put any clothing so living out of a suitcase, one bedside table has not even a drawer! The tv has one English Channel, well if you can call CNN (American) English... and the internet is terrible so I cannot even watch anything on my phone or properly FaceTime my family. There needs to be a tiny bit more storage, room to put your suitcase, hang clothes maybe a few shelves! A few more channels on the TV and internet that works.As I said the staff are lovely but the whole thing is very over priced and the food expensive for the size of the portions. The only hood thing is the heated toilet seat!!!!Tokyo has been a lovely clean interesting city but I know I definitely wouldn’t recommend this hotel to friends at home.

Hotel is based in the Shinjuku area and center of Tokyo. Right by Goldengai and the red light district of Tokyo. There nothing than love hotels and hotels on hour basis around it. So I wouldn't recommend to take your kids here. But for younger people who wants to party and see the town by night. The hotel is perfect. Breakfast isn't that good, but on the other side it's not that expensive.

Room is quite small (but not bad for Tokyo standard) with good interior design. The rooftop bar is a nice spot for early dinner drinks or late night tipple. Location in Kabukicho near the subway. Service is quite spotty. Some of the front staff not friendly and helpful at all, while some are very nice.

It was the first time my boyfriend and I have ever been in Tokyo and this hotel was the perfect spot! It took about an hour and a half to get here from Narita airport during the afternoon traffic (3pm) but the views leading to the hotel are worthwhile. This hotel is centralized to restaurants, karaoke bars, Metro, Yokochos and convenience stores like Lawson and Family Mart.Check-in was a breeze. The staff was very polite and speedy to get us our room. We must have looked so tired from the airport. The room we choose was the Deluxe Designer Room Mature, Non-Smoking on the 14th floor. Room was spacious, quiet and had a great view of the city and outdoor bar. A huge flat screen TV was provided and the drinks (coke, green tea and water) are free! On top of this, I recommend trying the imported bath salts they provide for your tired and aching body or feet.We had breakfast included with our reservation, which was an unnecessary but a great extra perk ie: American and Japanese assorted breakfast.The vending machines they have on the first floor (beer, ice cream, snacks) also has a great, inexpensive selection.Would definitely recommend this hotel for travelers who love to be in a centralized location and want to experience Shinjuku city life first hand. Would definitely stay here again!

This hotel is very brand new and quite spacious compared to other hotels in Tokyo. The big window in a room and a beautiful view is a big plus. The bathroom is amazing, spacious and clean. We were amazed by the exterior of the hotel when we arrived at night. It deserves 4 or 5 stars from our first glance. However, the location might be quite a problem, as it is quite far away from the main Shinjuku station, you have to walk around 20 minutes, and have to walk pass through the notorious district of love hotels. However, you can manage to walk to the closest metro/subway station, in just about 3 min. The internet connection was not strong as well, we always lost it while in the room. One last thing that they could improve is about the staff. We used to travel in Japan several times, and we have experienced many impeccable services from Japanese personnel all across the country. This time, it let us down a bit, as they were less reluctant to help us and a lack of smile on their faces.

We got the loft room, queen sized bed with a tiny ladder that goes up to a second floor with a single bed. High ceilings with a large projector for watching movies. It was clean, modern and felt spacious because of the 1.5 floors and high ceiling. Not much space to open our luggage but it was cozy enough.

This was the smallest room i've ever stayed in... but it was clean. Location was ideal, didn't mind the surrounding love hotels (the couples stumbling home in the morning were hilarious). Biggest issue was that the tiny window didn't open - major problem after my partner and I got gastro and we couldn't ever air out the cramped, poo-smelling room. The wall between the bed and the toilet was very thin.. Food/breakfast was all good - however disappointed that the rooftop bar required a 500yen entry fee of all guests/visitors. Doesn't make grabbing a casual quick drink easy. I'd stay in this room again only if I was traveling alone.

Really nice hotel, great rooms and amenities. Not a bad location, pretty close to action without being in the middle of it. Food is okay at the cafe and restaurant.Some small issues (take them how you will) - cover charge per person for entering the bar and restaurant, even as a guest of the hotel. Not a fan of that. - at the downstairs cafe we had an order forgotten and then the wrong order brought out (not a language issue, it was on the receipt.Not bad but could and should be better for the price.

We stayed for six nights and not put off by the location which was certainly lively at night. We didn’t have breakfast but dinner one evening on the top floor was delicious. Went to roof top bar during happy hour but only a handful of drinks were available at reduced price and we had to pay 500 yen just to sit down in the bar. This is not uncommon in Japan apparently. The rooms were certainly smaller than we were used to but we knew this before so we packed lightly. Good WiFi in rooms. Not so good in reception area. Lots of info and maps in reception area. Good hotel. Good location. Staff friendly and courteous.

My travel mates and I enjoyed our stay at the Granbell hotel very much. The rooms and amenities were modern. The location is central to the downtown shops, eateries, and other attractions. And the location is less than 1 mile from Shinjuku train and rail station. Very pleased with the property and all it has to offer.The room sizes were typical of Asian hotel standards. Toiletries were complimentary: slippers, toothbrush and toothpaste, hairbrush, and other daily necessities. They also offer loaner pajamas. You could almost travel without luggage there.
user_name:
JoseiH
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here as part of a family holiday. The hotel is within walking distance to multiple stations as well as the centre of Shinjuku itself. We had a pair of small, and I mean small rooms for the family that were comfortable with lots of small touches that made a difference (loved the heated mirror in the bathroom that didn’t fog up). Would definitely stay here again!!

This hotel was highly rated in TA and the stay did not disappoint. The hotel was new and equipped with modern furnishings. We picked the “Luxury Designer Room (Casual)” and this was located on the 16th floor, with a view of the skyscrapers around the hotel. The room was very clean, quite spacious (by Tokyo standards) and comfortable (although I will not term it luxury).Breakfast was served on the 12th floor with a basic buffet spread of both Japanese and Western. There was also parking available at the hotel for 2,000 yen per night, the parking lots were located on the side of the hotel. Each time we had to park/ move our car, we had to press the intercom for the Hotel parking attendant to come to help facilitate. The reception staff was very friendly, efficient and spoke good English. We had our skis sent over via Takyubin from Hokkaido (even before we reached Granbell Hotel), and the reception was most efficient in managing that and storing the skis for us.While the location of the hotel had access to many izakaya and soba restaurants (walking distance), it also had many night clubs, entertainment outlets and love hotels surrounding it, as such I did not find it to be family friendly (i.e. we saw drunk men and women in the area trying to hail a cab). Should Granbell be located in another part of Shinjuku (without the love hotels), we will definitely be back the next time we are in Tokyo.

the location is good, close to all Shinjuku subway stations. the building is high enough for preventing get lost in Shinjuku area. the staff were friendly. the room would be too small if there were really two people stayed.

Granbell Shinjuku is a good hotel with a nice location in Shinjuku. It’s a great startingpoint not only to explore Shinjuku, but whole of Tokyo, much thanks to the closeness to the subway and Shinjuku station. Staff was friendly and spoke enough English to manage standard tasks. Breakfast was ok, not more. There is a nice bar on 14th(?) floor, which is recommended at evening with a great view over Tokyo. Our rooms were very small, certainly a drawback, but we did go for economy.

Rooms are small but that’s Japan standards for you. Very clean and breakfast is great. Location is central also. Service is ok also :) will stay here again next time I go to Tokyo. Very near uniqlo, bic camera, train station and metro.

This is a large hotel situated on the outskirts of Shinjuku's nightlife area. Having said that, it is pretty quiet and there are great views from the roof top bar.Our room was tiny. I mean really small. But it is Tokyo and that's what you have to deal with. The room was very clean and the service was great.Breakfast was okay. Nothing brilliant but it filled the spot before we got out and about. If it is included then take it, if you have to pay extra, then head out of the hotel and explore better options outside.As for the location, it is a fair walk from Shinjuku station. A long way to drag the bags. The best option is to change trains and get off at Higashi-Shinjuku Station. From there it is a very easy walk. If you use this station, the hotel is a great place from which to explore Tokyo. There are lots and lots of restaurants within a very easy walk of the hotel. We'll review on of our favourites 'Black Hole' Wagu barbecue separately.Happy to recommend this hotel.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for three nights and was a great place to get acquainted with Tokyo. The room was pretty modern and we were on the 16th floor with views overlooking the city. The room was a little on the small side but that is to be expected I think in Tokyo. Absolutely loved the shower / bathroom. A lot of times I find it hard to find a hotel with great water pressure and a good shower. The shower was amazing! Also, the bed was pretty comfortable if you like firm mattresses. Additionally, the staff was very friendly and the breakfast every morning was great. Full spread of various eastern / western style dishes. Definitely enough food to hold you over for a full day of touring the city. Over the course of the time we were there we really loved the location and proximity to various spots throughout the city. Shinjuku is popular for nightlife and the hotel was steps away from a wide array of bars / local hangouts. Cons I would say is some of the room classes can be a bit expensive and the size of the room can be a bit small if you have a lot of luggage.
user_name:
chrisfrede
New York City, New York

review_body: The Granbell is a hip and cool hotel and wants you to know it by playing asian rap in the elevator. Everytime you go up, and everytime you go down.The reception's people are cool as well, and will prove it to you by being slightly alloof and somewhat distant. Not too much for you to complaint but enough for you to notice.We had a comfortable room on the upper floors, one floor up from the club lounge and its patrons whom you could see very well by the room window, and them see you as well as you have no sheer curtain but only a night curtain in the room. All or nothing.The sound system was well thought of, asian rap on it is optional. The bathroom was spacious and well arranged, with a freestanding tub by the second window for long soaks while looking at the Shinjuku landscape, as well as a large shower with glass walls. Amenities were good, and the cleaning crew and its supervisor, on that floor, friendly and efficient.Breakfast was sufficient, in a bright upper room.I am stiill wondering if the phone call telling us check out time is in ten minutes was a warning or a reminder.Location is good, one can walk everywhere in Shinjuku and around.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for 3 nights at the end of our Japan Trip and loved it! Our check in was smooth and the gentleman spoke good English, we very much appreciate the chopsticks gifted to us for our anniversary. We stayed in a Superior Hollywood Twin Suite and it was spacious, very clean and suited my partner and I perfectly. We were very impressed with the amenities provided especially the hairbrushes, razors and bottled water. We unfortunately didn’t get a chance to check out the rooftop bar. Location could be seen as seedy due to the love hotels surrounding but it didn’t bother us in the slightest, nobody is really around during the day, we felt safe at all times. Only a short walk to Shinjuku station was a bonus. Thanks for making our final nights in Japan great - highly recommend!

We picked this hotel based on location and availability - when reading through some reviews, I really had doubts about my choice. I was therefore pleasantly surprised about the hotel. Granted, the rooms are small but when out sightseeing the whole day, I don't need a big hotel room! We managed to fit our stuff (2 small suitcases, 2 backpacks) into the room, didn't have to shuffle around too much and felt it the room had really everything you need.The room was very light and bright which made it feel bigger; the bed was very comfortable but on the smaller side. I really liked the bath tub - perfect to have a soak at night, after spending the whole day outside in the cold.We really liked the convenient location (check out the map on the hotel for directions from Higashi Shinjuku - they are great and include pictures!) to get snacks from nearby convenient stores, stop for meal at the end of the day or grab breakfast.We didn't really go and explore the hotel further (rooftop terrace etc) and didn't have breakfast or coffee at the coffee shop. Would definitely stay again and tempted to try the other Granbell hotel next time!

Stayed here for 5 nights at the start of our Japanese tour, during my research for this trip the recurring message was that hotels can be quite small. Our room was an 'Economy Double' to be honest I don't think it even qualified as a single!Bathroom was ok, breakfast buffet was good with excellent views. We stayed 2 floors below the breakfast/restaurant but had to take the lift as the doors to the staircase were locked, one day we spent almost 10 minutes waiting for the lifts. Staircase locked - fire hazard? There is a rooftop bar but you are charged to use it? Non residents, yes but hotel residents?

Clean and comfortable hotel in Shinjuku. Very small but to be expected for Tokyo. Very close to shops and amenities. Concierge very friendly and helpful. Hotel smells a bit stale though. Would stay here again if staying in Tokyo for a night

Cool hotel with a decent lobby, many vending machines on the lobby floor. Room is not really spacious, and might be cramped if you're travelling with another companion. Nearest train station is Higashi-Shinjuku (about 5 mins walk), and the best part about staying at this hotel is that its near Golden-Gai (place with many small drinking bars). I'd be drinking almost every night at Golden-Gai before heading back to the hotel :-)

The hotel is a 5 min walk to the metro and the main area's of interest in Shinjuku. It's modern clean and accessible. For me there were a few things i didn't really like. The rooms are tiny, the pictures are very well engineered. There was no space to either side of the bed in our room and you literally have to climb in and out of bed from the bottom, not fun at 3am.Breakfast is vile, the food could not be more random or more disgusting, from fish to rice, to smelly hams, it was a struggle.The club lounge is 4 seats, a few jars of nuts and few soft drinks, don't have high hopes.Checked in, given keys, up 16 floors and they didn't work at the room door (the most annoying thing in the world) when i came back down to correct they laughed amongst themselves.The rooftop bar is nice, they charge 500 yen to be seated even though you are a guest in the hotel with is greedy and the bar is half empty, perhaps this is why.Would i stay here again... wouldn't be my first choice.
user_name:
Tim O
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Start with the positives:1.) convenient to the train station2.) convenient to golden gai 3.) Room is fine with comfortable bed4.) Breakfast was serviceable Issues:1.) extras are few and far between - no clothing iron nor availability unless on the 5th or 9th floor 2.) no gym or partnership with a gym3.) no Wi-Fi - not ideal for business4.) house keeping was iffy - random Japanese panties left in our room?

Decent place, nice room and the surrounding will suit those who wanna party, as just a walk a way streets of night clubs and night life are aplenty. Breakfast is not that great, well its Japan so enjoy the street food, its brilliant.

This hotel had a great location near three different metro lines and a lovely tree-lined pedestrian walkway. The hotel was very clean, and though our standard double room was quite small, we managed just fine. I loved that the hotel had a basket full of items in the bathroom - razors, cotton swabs, hair ties, compact brushes, shoe wipes. There was also a bottle of fabric freshener spray in the closet. The front desk staff was very helpful and spoke great English. One staff member even called a restaurant for me to make a reservation because they didn't take calls from non-local numbers/my cell phone. We had a great stay here and we'd stay again.Note: If you're out and about in the area between 6 and 8am, you may see local young adults stumbling home drunk. It is in the love hotel area, after all.

It looks like it is a fairly new hotel. It has a modern look. They have a lot of vending machines on the lobby floor. It is well located in the Shinjuku district. There are a lot of stores nearby and you are close to public transportation.

Internet is free but unstable and super slow. If you need it for work or just dependent on it, consider an alternative. Hotel is centrally located in red light district between multiple love hotels.Interior is modern. Staff is friendly. Prices are reasonable. Everything is clean.Good for singles in their standard rooms. Perhaps a bit too cozy for couples. Unless you just fell in love.

The Shinjuku Granbell Hotel was very nice, clean rooms, good amenities, yummy buffet breakfast and the rooftop bar was lovely too! Staff were always helpful and friendly. Would recommend and stay again.

Very nice hotel, check in staff friendly and helpful. Room was small as expected in Japan, but clean and welcoming. Just needed better ventilation in bathroom due to steam from shower. Breakfast had a decent selection of food. Has 4 or 5 vending machines in the lobby for any late night hunger or thirst needs. Hotel is in the red light district, has many as they are called love hotels (no issue even if you travel with kids) in the area and clubs down the road. Less than 5 min walk from closest train station exit and about 5-10min walk to the robot restaurant. Would stay here again.

My wife and I just got married and decided to have our honeymoon in Tokyo.Since I wanted to keep my stay going for seven nights, the suites were unfortunately fully booked. I ended up choosing the "Luxury Designer Double with Kitchen/Mature" and I'm quite glad I did.The Room: Very spacious and well thought-out with an excellent view of the city which can be enjoyed either at the breakfast nook or in the tub. It also comes with an electric stove which is pretty simple to figure out even if your Japanese isn't exemplary. The microwave and other appliances were also quite powerful despite Japan's wattage differences. The room was always kept clean and room service even washed any dishes you may have forgotten to take care of (there's some basic utensils, plates, and even a santoku knife stored and covered on the underside sink compartment).The Food: We ordered room service once and the food came almost as fast as I'd ordered it. This gave me some high expectations for the breakfast buffet that was an option I'd added on in the reservation. Unfortunately, the food was ice cold and the warming units really didn't do their job and therefore my wife and I both got sick. Nothing a few Seirogan pills couldn't fix, but it definitely stopped us from utilizing the rest of our meal vouchers.Enjoying good food elsewhere wasn't an issue since all the best restaurants and cafes are a 4~10 minute walk away.The Service: Rough start, but definitely got better at the end.My wife and I wanted to wash our clothes but were unsure how to use the washer, so we asked a woman at the front desk to make sure we didn't end up flooding the floor.I have native speaker level Japanese abilities as a 2nd Gen Japanese American, so conversing with the staff was not an issue at all. Anyway, I asked the woman how to utilize both the washer and dryer functions properly since there was no instruction manual at the room and the labeling was in vague English. She advised me that both washing and drying was done on the blue marked cycles and to simply add the Dryer timer function to the right to ensure everything worked well. By utilizing the red markers, I'd end up only using hot water to wash the garments. I thanked her for the information and retreated to my quarters where my wife and I spent 5 hrs (default timer setting). After the time had passed, we realized our clothes were completely damp. Fidgeting with the controls a bit, we kept to the woman's advice in blue cycle since she'd expressly warned me to not use the red. I decided to go back downstairs with a photo of the dial just to make sure that it wasn't a miscommunication error on my part. She then looked over my photo and assured me her information was correct. Going back, we spent a good bit of time again with only damp clothes to speak of. Not wanting to wait another 5 hours, I went down again to the front desk and requested her assistance. She went up to our room and began making adjustments. .....it was at this point we realized that she didn't know how to use this machine either. Eventually she found a set of instructions online and sent them to me in English via email & realized that the red markers are indeed for DRYING. This upset us quite a bit as we've now lost a whole night's worth of sleep over her misinformation that could've been solved had she simply said she didn't know how to work the item and can ask someone else. Even if we were to get our clothes to dry right now, practically a whole day would be wiped out just in our room. Looks like my plans to go early to Nikko flew right out the window. We asked to speak to a manager and were informed he would be in at 9am. The time stamp on the email the woman sent for when she found the instructions? 5:44am. The laundry we had was in the wash for so long we had suspicions that even on the max heat settings we'd be looking at the clothes still being moist at that time (and indeed we were regrettably correct). Nevertheless we made the attempt. About 15 minutes before 9, I called the front desk and a man answered. He already was informed of the situation and stated we could come down to the front desk once the manager had arrived. I asked if the manager could come to our room instead due to us being in either dirty clothing or robes, to which he cut me off stating it's not possible at all. Now, I'm the type that wouldn't mind wearing clothing a couple days used, but I definitely wouldn't want that of my wife on our honeymoon!Thankfully the manager did end up calling us and came up to the room within a matter of seconds.I explained to him the situation once more and he immediately sprung into action by taking all of our laundry needing attention and having it professionally cleaned at no cost to us. This was a nice jesture, but even he informed us that dry times may take just as many hours to complete. ...may as well have told my wife we were under house arrest. I demanded some form of compensation as due to his employee's ego we'd literally lost an entire night's worth of sleep & now were abandoning an entire day of our honeymoon. I wasn't demanding anything crazy like my whole stay refunded, but I definitely wasn't going to settle for a laundry service and a bar tab discount.He warned me loosely that getting a cash accommodation is far above his level and he'd need time to get that sorted out. I'm quite familiar with Japan's comp system and know very well that most Japanese give up out of frustration when stalled, so right after he'd taken his leave to deliver the laundry to the cleaners I'd already found the Granbell CEO's information. Thankfully the manager saved the day. He personally delivered each bag of clean laundry as it'd finished including some of my wife's highly delicate items. Any communication I had with the front desk in terms of requests or inquiries were transferred immediately to him. Amazing customer service, but again the issue of comps were up in the air. This didn't get resolved until the next morning.We ended up getting the night's stay refunded!!! Hallelujah he came through on his promise to do all he could. Couldn't have been happier. I then asked if he wanted me to remove this incident from my review as a courtesy since I didn't want my story to cause people to try demanding comps left and right from him (because I assure you this is NOT customary in Japan-- 9 out of 10 times you will get NOTHING, and that's everywhere). He told me to go ahead and write the review anyway as it can be a learning experience for the rest of his staff. It's hard to find managers dedicated to helping the customer in a fair way like this. I truly hope he will continue to remain in charge of the Shinjuku Granbell for a few more years as my friends and family are already gearing up to make reservations next year and thereafter.Final Note:This hotel is everything my wife and I could've asked for from start to finish. There was indeed a rough patch of misinformation regarding the washer, but the manager was able to fix the issue and take us seriously every step of the way. Room service cuisine was tasty, the room was absolutely breathtaking, and any craving from a shopping fix to local restaurants are accessed with a brisk walk.I highly recommend the Luxury Designer Double Kitchen/Mature (especially if you're concerned of other patrons' reviews regarding the general laundry room or space of the lofts) & look forward to returning there again soon. I rarely bring local souvenirs to hotel staff & management, but the Shinjuku Granbell can definitely hold me to that promise in the future!

Stayed here for one night whilst in transit. The room was on the small side and nothing special. However it was clean. Also considering the decent nightly rate, I was not expecting anything else. The hotel itself is located on a quiet back road in what is a very busy area of Tokyo. If you are exiting from a metro station then it is approximately 10mins to the nearest one, it might be a struggle if you have luggage, this is due to the fact that the surrounding area gets very busy and is not at all fun negotiating your way through that crowd!In terms of location for me it was perfect; staff were friendly and you have got good value for money. Why the 3*? There was nothing for me about the hotel that really stood out.

Modern hotel with averaged sized rooms. Not too far from the Station and conveniently located near lots of restaurants. Pros: Easy check in/out process. Decent hotel ammenities provided including disposable slippers. Fridge worked ok with good room temp controls. Room felt clean and modern. Good value overall. Cons: Can be noisy at night if you’re on the lower levels given the zone. Bathroom was ok, shower curtain constantly has a slight smell.

The Shinjuku "entertainment" area in Tokyo can get be quite loud and boisterous, however this hotel is on a relatively quieter street but walking distance to attractions, bars of Shinjuku and the huge train station. The hotel is clean, good value, small typical Japanese rooms. Nice restaurant and bar on top floors with an outside deck.

Stayed here with friends for a couple of nights in October. OK, nothing amazing and nothing too bad to say about it. Cafe downstairs sometimes open, didn't use it, they have vending machines for crisps, beer etc Rooms average size for Tokyo, smaller than most are used to, no wardrobe ... just a "wall-drobe" i.e. a rack on the wall with some hangers. OK location in terms of being able to walk to places.

Really good hotel for what we paid!Rooms are small but they all are in Tokyo. We were very pleasantly greeted and it was in a great location for all of Shinjuku and around. Easy to find and close to some very fun batting cages and arcades!Lovely rooftop bar and would definitely stay again

Firstly the Granbelle is well located just minutes from the entertainment areas. The surrounding streets are a little tacky but if you want to stay in Shinjuku which is where some of the best nightlife is centred then that's to be expected. Its certainly not scary or intimidating as some reviewers have stated.There's nothing really to love about the place- its a bland high rise corporate sort of place which would be fine if the rooms weren't so tiny- seriously small- no where to store luggage and just a coat rack - no wardrobe or drawer space and a uncomfortable bathroom. Its gets three stars because of the awesome roof terrace- heated with great views and the best G and T in Japan

As other reviewers have stated, this hotel just isn’t worth the money. For the same amount or slightly more, you can get something much better. It’s quite a long walk with luggage through less than ideal neighborhood from the metro. The location plus the wear and tear on the place are major red flags. We stayed in Ginza in the first part of our trip and it’s MUCH better, cleaner, safer, and quieter.

About 10mins walk from Shinjuku station, the Granbell is modern hotel offering rooms with European inspired décor. We booked one of the suites on the top floor which featured floor to ceiling window wall overlooking downtown Shinkuku. The rooftop terrace bar offers a happy hour between 5-7pm everyday which we enjoyed sipping our drinks while watching the sun set over Tokyo. Breakfast was an interesting mix of just about anything you can thinkof having for breakfast. From cereals, fruit, pastries, Full English even dauphinoise potatoes and chicken nuggets. Good selection of vending machines in the lobby and plenty of 7-11 around the local area which is a nightlife hotspot so the location is perfect for stumbling home after a night of Sake and Karaoke. Overall this hotel offers some real quality and considering how low the price is compared to most hotels in Tokyo it’s definitely worth considering.

We were here for three nights and were very pleased. I heard hotel rooms are small in Tokyo but the economy room is ok! Bed is firm but really comfortable even though I love a soft bed. The whole room was super clean and had everything we need. Hotel shampoo usually makes my hair feel awful but they had pretty great products. They give you two free bottles of water every day and the in-room coffee is actually pretty good for hotel coffee! Staff is super nice and helpful. We had an issue with our Robot Restaurant reservation and they called for us to clear it up and also gave us restaurant recommendations. The location is about a 7 minute walk from the subway and 15 min walk from train station. There aren’t too many restaurants right next to the hotel but not a long walk from the more busy area of Shinjuku. That being said, it’s a quieter area. We were on the third floor and didn’t hear the outside noise at all! I felt totally safe walking around the area at night. We had drinks at the rooftop restaurant at night and they gave us blankets and turned on the heat lamp. The downstairs cafe has pretty great espresso and wine. A fantastic stay!

We stayed here for 3 days and then left for 3 nights and returned before heading home. The rooms were small but very well designed with all the usual amenities - try not to get a corner room as our second room was extremely snug!. the breakfasts were great, service fine and the location was terrific. it was a quirky neighbourhood but safe with plenty of options for eating, drinking and socializing. we would stay there again.

Loved the hotel. Rooms were a bit larger than most Tokyo hotel. Relatively new. The only drawback was that it was not in the most desirable part of Shinjuku. However it was close to the action and the neighborhood was not dangerous or anything (just a few men's clubs and love hotels in the mix). We were also not impressed at all with the rooftop lounge. the prices were very high, the food was not very good and the portions were very small and they charged a fee to get into the lounge. At a minimum, hotel guests should not have to pay a cover charge to have a drink and eat in their own hotel.

Don’t stay here. Sink water tastes and smells like sewer lines. Front desk service is only willing to help those who are just checking in or paying money. We just checked out today and asked for a taxi at the front desk. The staff lady asked us to wait while she finished typing something before assisting us. Once she was done she called a Taxi for us and asked us to pay an extra 450¥ service charge for the hotel to call a taxi. We have no choice so we say OK, then she told us to wait 10-15 minutes. We waited for over 15 minutes and noticed other people got Taxis before us. We ask the front desk again and now we see the staff lady run outside to try to call us ANOTHER Taxi - meaning they let other people take our Taxi even though we reserved first. We ended up walking to the train station with all our luggage because the staff here is incapable of calling a taxi and because we are late to the airport for our flight. Best part of the hotel is the rooftop where you can see the city skyline and not see the front desk staff.

This is my third time to stay in Granbell. Location is great, rooms are nice and tidy. There is a live chat service which you can connect with staff immediately to get help in traffic, making reservations in restaurants… etc. the staff in live chat is very friendly and good in English, and replies promptly even in mid night.

I love this hotel! Been staying in this hotel for at least 3 times. Although it's small but it's cosy! Quite convenient to the station which is about 8 mins walk. The only negative point is that they forget requests. Wanted to surprise my friend cause it's her birthday but they didn't do anything. So I was quite disappointed.I will still stay in this hotel whenever I'm in Tokyo!

Stayed here fir 6 nights. Got the twin room (not double room) which is bitter. Although room was not big, but this is Japan, every space counts. Free breakfast at the 12 floor is good. Took the Narita express (NEX) at 4000 yen round trip. From station took the taxi @ 1000 yen, because we were carrying bags. Make sure you buy suica card for traveling. When we travel, we used Higashi-shinjuku station which is only 350m walk instead of shinjuku station. There are so many restaurant around this area and the staff were so accommodating and helpful. we took the uber to the jr station on our way back at 1200 yen.

We stayed here for 7 nights on our first visit to Japan. It was a perfect location for everything we wanted to do, very close to Shinjuku station and lots of restaurants and bars. It’s also very close to Golden Gai, which we randomly discovered walking around the neighborhood on our first night.The room was very small, with no closets, but luckily we packed pretty light. The staff were very nice and helpful, and they provided complementary coffee and water every day. We also had sleeping shirts that were refreshed every day as well.There were tons of tourist groups coming and going almost everyday, but that’s Tokyo! There was also a nice rooftop bar with a decent happy hour, but note that there is a cover charge! The breakfast was extensive with lots of options, but we only ate there one morning so that we could explore other restaurAnts around. They also have vending machines with lots of snacks, drinks (including beer), and other things at decent prices.Big bonus for a long stay is that they have a laundry room, and sell detergent at the front desk.

Excelllent location and good staf... wonderful breakfast from the 12th floor...Only you must pay attention to the size of the rooms...Well trained staff/...you can easily reach to the train station Shinjuku and from there to Narita and back//

A hotel which focuses on tourist groups from S.E Asia and China at the expense of the quality of services provided to individual travellers who pay international prices without getting international services. Having breakfast at 12/F restaurant is a nightmare. Put it simply - money spent is not worth it.

Stayed here for 2 nights dying Oct 2017. Had a 12th Floor Loft Room with projector and city view. I enjoyed my stay here, and here are my pros/cons.Pros:-Good Location, Clean Room and Hotel.-Was given Free Breakfast Vouchers. Nice food, wide variety, Excellent view-Inclusive Wi Fi. Free Water Bottle.-Friendly Staff, let us leave luggage after checkout for over 5 hours.Cons:-Price was a bit steep for a 3 to 4 star hotel.-No wellness centers-HAD 2 WASHER AND 1 DRYER. WHY NOT 2 TO 2?Overall? I had a pleasant stay, it was fun, for 2 nights I get to live in a decent size hotel room and enjoy the night.

Great for first time visitors, since the proximity to Higashi Shinjuku station means you have access to convenient transportation without dealing with the madness that's Shinjuku station. Shinjuku's shopping and dining areas still within walking distance. At night (even weekends) the area's buzzing but never too busy or crowded.Rooms are expectedly small, but was never too inconvenient despite 3 luggages. Super clean, and having control over AC/Heat was great. Would definitely stay here again.24 hour supermarket a 5 min walk away is an added bonus.Wifi great during the day, but slows to a crawl at night due to the full occupancy.
user_name:
CS H
Kew Gardens, New York

review_body: Just an ok hotel... and for the price probably expected a bit more. Clean yes. Very small rooms.. yes.. but as the general thread of a lot of the comments here .. the reception staff leave a lot to be desired. I remember thinking.. if you don't like your job.. leave. Not sure I got one smile the entire time I was there. Also .. I didn't check but there are no wellness facilities at all. No gym. No sauna.. pool.. nothing. So whilst that was my fault for not checking.. I was disappointed that I couldn't relax after a long day out. Breakfast... same... same everyday.Rooftop bar .. expensive and drinks nothing special and no wifi for some reason. All in all ... just ok.. next time I won't stay there.Also I note that the hotel management don't seem to respond at all with any comments... again .. quite poor really.

We enjoyed our stay here for 6 nights but would reconsider staying again due to the location. Pros:-Beautiful view from the room and breakfast table. The front desk offers a range of free guidance on local foods and attractions.- We stayed in one of the suite rooms so the Club lounge was included in our stay. It has a wonderful view and free snacks/happy hour. Great place to pit stop after a long day, the coffee is also great in the morning if the foyer cafe isnt open. We found the concierge desk was only stationed after 4pm however, so if you needed advice or to check-in, you had to go downstairs to the main reception. - Great facial products, our room had all shiseido mens and womens facial cleaning products and moisturisers. - The cafe in the foyer was the best coffee we had in Tokyo. Proper barista coffee. It doesnt open until 10am however, which was inconvenient if you wanted to grab one on the way out each morning. - Plentiful and free umbrella's! We unfortunately stayed during Typhoon Lan, which caused rain all week long during our stay. The hotel had an uncountable number of umbrella's for guests which were a blessing during the downpour. We found other accommodations across japan dont provide this as standard, so were happy in hindsight for this. - Vending machines in the foyer provide every food item you may need, hot drinks, cold drinks, savoury and sweet snacks at cheaper prices than 7 Eleven.Cons: - The long walk to the station becomes arduous with tired legs after roaming Tokyo all day or when you have luggage. Save yourself the hassle and get a taxi if arriving from the station, the ground is very uneven. Taxi is only 800Y. - Consider whether the hotel is the right location for you. It is not overly close to any restaurants (with the exception of an amazing ramen restaurant around the corner), so we found ourselves eating the local 7 Eleven delicacies many evenings as we were simply too exhausted to head back out to the main shinjuku area. We discovered on the final night that Uber Eats works terrifically however, so this may assist if we stay again. - Shinjuku station is a very very complex train station to navigate, simply figuring out which exit to take, or taking the wrong one can add 20mins to the journey, then you have the 15mins to walk back to the hotel. Higashi station is closer/more straightforward, but still a 10min walk away. - A little too much effort has gone into the visual design of the rooms but not the practical, strange tinted glass doors cutting off the bath from the room, but no blind on the giant bathroom window which meant light streamed in each morning. We asked if the front desk could put up a makeshift sheet etc, they said no. Not sure if this was lost in translation or simply too hard but it ruined our ability to sleep in/very well as the bright city lights at night are equally harsh. - No shower cap in the bathroom, we requested one but were told they couldn't provide it. For the price of this room you would think this a standard inclusion. 7Eleven also doesn't sell them. - Breakfast - one day would be okay of their offerings, but nothing is rotated so we found ourselves heading out after the second day for coffee and bakery foods instead. There are some western options - dried out tiny breads and croissants, scrambled eggs swimming in so much butter one mouthful is enough and some yoghurt. Sometimes pineapple. The rest is all traditional Japanese breakfast (eg: miso, pickles, fresh fish) which was also okay for one morning, but not everyday. - There are only 3 lifts for the whole hotel, which given its size was surprising, so the wait can be long.

The smaller rooms are great for one person. Very clean and modern. The beds are comfortable and the heated toilet seats are EVERYTHING!!! The water pressure in the shower is strong and gets really hot. You also can’t beat the location of this hotel. It’s in walking distance to the train. However, it’s best to take a taxi from the train station upon arrival until you get your bearings together. This will cost you about $6 USD. The streets aren’t paved so traveling with luggage is a task. I’d definitely recommend this hotel as I really enjoyed my stay.

Poor housekeeping for my 6 nights stay.There's cockroach!Front desk staff is not friendly and helpful. room is ready for check in but she insisted to ask us wait till 3pm or pay extra $100 if we will to check in at 2pm

This hotel is perfectly located to the night life of Shinjuku just a five minute walk and your surrounded by endless things to do. Hotel was clean, front desk greeters we're super friendly and helpful. The rooms are much smaller that pictured for one couldn't get into the bed from right or left had to crawl up from the bottom to get in. No space for placing luggage out of the way so sits in the middle of the room or blocking the bathroom entry. Two things that could use improvement is the in hotel dining service personal. Free breakfast YAY but was awful food and service service just made the food unbearable which took me by surprise. One other item, don't ask the front desk to call you a taxi as the fee they charge and time of arrival is ridiculous I stood out front for two minutes tops got a taxi in less than the 15mins quoted and no fee! WiFi was awful throughout the hotel.

Nice hotel in the exiting Shinjuku area. The room was small, but the bed was comfy and the bathroom was nice and clean. Amazing view from the skybar. Lovely staff :-) And the breakfast was great!I enjoyed myself very much!

This was my second time i had visited Grandbell in 10 months. The reason why i chose to go back was because i had such a positive experience the first time. This time around my experience was average, with this being the service i was given. It seemed like every request was an effort for the staff, never smiling and just in general being unpleasant. It is such a shame because i love the area and the hotel rooms are clean and nice and the location is soo good.

The stay was part of my first travel to Japan.The staffs were very helpfull and attentive.The rooms are very clean (we occupy 2 rooms) and the coffee as part of the room is excelent (not instant - real blended and filtered coffee)As most Japan hotel offer smoking rooms you must select Non Smoking if you want a non smoking.The hotel is far from the buzz of Shinjuku night life but convenient walk to the night life should you wish to be part of.We took dinner at one of the best 24hour Sushi and it was only 5 minutes walk from the hotel

Stayed here for 4 nights whilst in Tokyo; the room is very small for the money but that’s pretty standard in Tokyo. It was cleaned & made daily to a high standard. The location is only 5 minutes walk from the heart of Shinjuku so very convenient. It’s in Kabukicho (red light district) though so may not be ideal for families?!The restaurant is French/Italian so sadly not much in the way of traditional Japanese fare but it’s not bad. Breakfast has quite a large choice and was very tasty. Check in and check out were very easy and the staff speak a good level of English. They were also kindly able to arrange for our luggage to be forwarded to our next hotel in Kyoto (via Takkyubin) which makes life so much easier!Overall, would recommend.

We stayed here for 3 nights and can not fault the hotel or staff! We had an economy double room which was clean and comfortable. It was spacious enough for the amount of time spent in the room. Also it is in a brilliant area, close to Shinjuku Station for easy access to metro and rail. Would definitely recommend Tokyo and the Granbell Hotel to anyone.

We stayed in the Villa Suite for 3 days. It has a gorgeous outdoor shower, huge bed, very spacious, and well worth the price! Location is good. It's a short walk through some tiny streets, but then you are right in the heart of Shinjuku. Club lounge was small, but a nice area if you are looking to kill some time with snacks and a view. Staff did a fantastic job of cleaning the room and offering assistance if needed. My only real complaint is about the checkout time. Checkout time was 12:00pm, but DO NOT TRUST CHECKOUT TIME!!! The day of checkout we were packing the last of our things around 11am (about an hour before checkout). We had the "Do not disturb" sign on our door to make sure that housekeeping didn't come in while we were still packing. A little after 11am someone used a key card to enter our room. He saw us in the room, and looked a little confused, and then left. Not sure why this man entered our room. We even talked to staff earlier in the morning to confirm the checkout time, so they knew we were still in the room. Either way, it made us very uneasy that someone would enter our room, before our checkout time, with our Do Not Disturb sign on the door. Had it not been for the rude way in which we left the hotel, I would have given it 5 out of 5.

The room was by far the biggest and best we stayed in during 5 weeks travelling Japan. We also got breakfast included and free soft drinks in the room bar as well as access to the lounge. The price usd160 was cheaper than a lot of other hotels we stayed and which had much smaller rooms .Bed comfortable.. bathroom huge and nice. The restaurant on the other hand has a cafeteria feel to it and no class. Dinner was expensive and poor. Breakfast was average but someone should show them how to cook scrambled eggs. Not really that close to metro stops. The area is full of bars and restaurants but not much else.To be honest i prefer the Asakusa area better. The room was great ( not the standard room) but the rest of the hotel is just average.

The rooms are so small you felt like you were staying on a boat! The hotel is extremely busy but very convenient for the metro and some nice restaurants nearby! We paid 1300 yen each for breakfast and it definitely wasn't worth it, if it isn't included in your room go outside as it is mainly catering for the Chinese market very little western options. All in all average hotel, good location.

This hotel is great. We did however upgrade to the Club Level rooms which are much more spacious and include more as a result. The room location and views were great and the proximity to the roof top lounge was perfect. The room was spacious, with upgraded bath amenities. We were in the center of Shinjuku which is a great area to be in as a tourist however quite far from city center Tokyo. We loved everything about our hotel for the short stay we had in Tokyo.
user_name:
Shane R
Medford, New York, United States

review_body: With three of us we ordered the triple room with mezzanine, which worked well. This place is 3 minutes from Golden Gai, the Ninja museum, Robot Restaurant etc. and about 7 minutes from Shinjinku Station on the east side. It is surrounded by activity, but it’s very quiet and comfortable. The cafe near reception has brilliant espresso take away as well as sit in. The bar has great views, but no real vibe. The restaurant is really reasonable for breakfast with a range of US, European and Asiatic choices. Coffee is filtered stuff which is strong but not nearly as good as the espresso! Bathrooms are well appointed. Like all Japanese rooms, squeezing suitcases in can be a challenge! Highly recommended.

This hotel has a good rooftop bar that is open until 3am and as many of the hotel rooftop bars in Shinjuku only open until 11 or 12 is a great option. Staff are friendly and is in a quiet part of Shinjuku. The hotel just looks like it has had some fixtures updated to try and make it look stylish however some of the fixtures are still old. Also, I would suggest that vegetarians do not opt for breakfast as my only options were undercooked scrambled eggs and potato gratin!

This is a tastefully decorated hotel. The room was smallish but we expected that for Tokyo. The Shinjuku Granbell is close to the main railway station, Shinjuku, and is located in the Kabukicho area. This is really interesting. Very quiet by day but it comes alive at night - bright lights, restaurants, Golden Gai - really interesting alleyways and even Godzilla. We always felt safe together. The hotel restaurant has a great view of the surrounding area. Value for money breakfast buffet.

The hotel is near to station, it took me about 5 minutes to reach the hotel. I checked in hotel at around 12am but there were still a lot of staff at the front desk to help the guests to check in. The check in process was pretty fast and totally hassle-free. The staff spoke good English and showed leaflets of hotel area information and Bebot online assistance AI chatbot. Bebot provided me area information and recommendations for restaurants which greatly help me to explore the area around the hotel. It was a great city view from my room through the window. The room is well-decorated with artistic painting and beautiful lightings. Hotel provided full set of amenities such as shaver, comb, toothbrush, toothpaste - basically everything I need. The room space was perfect for me. TV can be viewed in English language which makes perfect sense for the guest who doesn’t know Japanese to function TV well. Hotel staff called and reminded me of check out time so that I wouldn’t be charged extra. Overall, my stay in this hotel was exceptionally pleasant. I will definitely return to the hotel for my stay in Tokyo again. Highly recommended!

Stayed at this hotel for a few nights while exploring Tokyo. It's well located, modern, clean and about as big as a room you would expect in Tokyo. I stayed in a loft with a friend. It was tight, but it worked. Didn't spend much time in the hotel (as you would in Tokyo), but the lobby is spacious with plenty of work space and even a nice outdoor area. Good option at this price.

My adult daughter and I stayed in this hotel for five days at the beginning of our two week stay in Tokyo. We chose a 'Deluxe Hollywood Twin' room after having read some of the other reviews on TripAdvisor that some of the other rooms in this hotel were too small. Our room was a good size for us and our medium sized suitcases. The room was clean, furnished nicely and the layout very sensible with the vanity outside the shower/bath/toilet area.
