The toilet also had a separate sliding door. As it turned out this bathroom was probably the biggest of our entire holiday- having a walk in shower was a plus and unique to our hotels in Japan. The bathroom had a good supply and variety of toiletries. The beds were comfortable and the room had good blockout blinds and was very quiet.The hotel is just over 1 kilometer from the Shinjuku JR station and closer to the subway.Although the hotel is close to Kabukicho (the red light area), the streets are safe to walk around. There are many restaurants nearby for an easy dinner.The reception staff were friendly and efficient.Breakfast was an adequate buffet.This is good hotel, just choose a room that suits your needs.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this hotel. For the same price or marginally more, you can stay in a hotel with larger rooms, better service and somewhere that is just as convenient without having to walk through the ugly side of Shinjuku. I've heard The Gracery is good and a similar location and would also recommend staying at Solaria in Ginza.We stayed in a Deluxe Double Sept 5 - 9, 2017 and paid extra for a bigger room than the standard. The room was small which we were expecting, however it really was tiny. We stayed in three other hotels around Japan, including in Tokyo, and this was by far the smallest room for the same price. It also seemed like if there was a way to charge you extra for something they did. For example, we arrived a few hours early and they had our room ready however, because it was before check in time we had to pay 1,000 yen for every hour that we were early. In my opinion this is not great service and every other hotel in Japan that we stayed in offered early check in at no cost. Also, we headed to the rooftop one night for a drink and when we went to pay, were told that there was a compulsory cover charge per person. This wasn't stated on any of the flyers in our room or on the posters around the hotel. I assume it must have been somewhere but it seemed like they were trying to hide it and it would have been nice to have been made aware.Overall, perhaps a fine hotel if you're looking for a place to crash amongst Shinjuku and want a nice reception area to walk through, but Japan has great service and this hotel just doesn't do it justice. Also, if it's your first time in Tokyo and you're not planning on going out to party every night in Shinjuku, there are better locations that are just as central.

I stayed here for a week at the end of my month long visit to Japan. I booked it because I got an excellent deal on the price and I certainly don't regret it. I'd of paid double what I paid happily. The location of the hotel is right in kabukicho but don't let that put you off, you have to remember that you're still in Japan and trouble won't find you unless you're looking for it. I felt perfectly safe staggering back to the hotel alone at 3am on multiple occasions, if you don't then taxis will drop you right outside. It's a bit of a walk from here to Shinjuku train station but again an Uber or a taxi isn't ridiculously expensive. There is a very pleasant restaurant here although I found the menu very western and ended up with pizza and chips! The roof top bar is excellent with a pleasant view of the surrounding area and serving some lovely Japanese dark beers. Good to visit before and after going out! I'd stay here again in a heartbeat.

I dreamed of visiting Tokyo since I was a child growing up I still never shook the obsession. When we arrived in this glowing and flowing city I felt blown away by it's buzz. We were driven 5 minutes from Shinjuku station to the Granbell and felt instantly at ease in this building located in a perfect area of Shinjuku. The staff worked tirelessly to make you feel comfortable and everything seemed so easy. The view from the hotel was awesome as you could pretty much pick out where you wanted to eat, drink or be entertained, strangely from where bar is. Without a doubt the best city in the world with the beat attitude and the world leaders in respect and hospitality. I will return and day any time.

The hotel is conveniently situated near the centre of Shinjuku, but far enough away from the main action to ensure you can get a good nights sleep. It is surrounded by many 'love' hotels, but don't let that put you off. The staff were extremely courteous and helpful on both check-in and out. If you are not familiar with Tokyo hotels then be prepared that the standard bedrooms are small, to the extent that you struggle to open two suitcases in the room. The hotel has got bigger rooms/suites available. We used the roof top bar a few times which was very pleasant with an early happy hour starting at 5 p.m. Very pleased overall and would stay again.

It was our first time in Tokyo and staying in Shinjuku was a solid central home base. Pros: The hotel is near the train station and walking distance from many shops and bars. The room was very quiet which made sleeping easy. The rooftop bar had great views of the city (but not quite as a hip as pictured). Plentiful amenities in the bathroom. Cons: WiFi was very spotty. Staff/concierge were reluctant to help with any reservations before we arrived and unless we were physically present. Coffee bar on main level didn't open until 10 am. Overall I thought the hotel was fine but I'd likely look to someplace else on my next visit.

We loved the room we stayed in! It had amazing views of Tokyo! Especially at night we closed all the lights in the room and enjoyed the city lights! Great room, very clean! Proximity to the underground stations was OK not too close not too far! Breakfast was nothing special but fine!

This hotel is a good walk from the station, you will need a taxi with luggage. It is located in a less desirable part of town, and was not value for money. They rooms were unbelievably small, we needed to upgrade after arrival at additional cost, and the new room was still tiny. Everything costs extra, late checkout was additional, cover charge in the rooftop bar, limited facilities to offer. The beds were very uncomfortable and resulted in sore backs after our two night stay. Cleaning materials and piles of linen are the first thing you see on approaching the rooms, not a pleasant sight. Overall we were disappointed in our choice as it certainly did not compare favourably to the other hotels we stayed in throughout Japan. Next time we would choose closer to the JR station.

A friend in Tokyo recommended this hotel for our stay and I really enjoyed it. The location was great. A 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station and surrounded by subway lines. Our room was small but had everything you needed and it was very clean. Staff was friendly and helpful.Our reservation included breakfast but I did not really enjoy it. The buffet was rather large, it had elements of a typical Japanese breakfast and some elements of what you might call a Western or continental breakfast. They also had spaghetti, noodles and salad. Some things were ok, most if it was just average, I was bit disappointed by the overall quality.Another thing that bothered me was the table charge in the bar on the 13th floor. I know that a table charge is applied in many restaurants all over the country which is obviously no problem to me. You are having a meal and you receive a full service. We went to the hotel bar though during happy hour, to have a beer for 500 Yen and were charged an additional 500 Yen per person. We were told the charge was the same at the bar and at a table in the bar. I do think that this charge is a bit exaggerated when you are just going to have a drink. I honestly don't know if that is done in other bars too, though. Just pointing this out.

Amazing suite, friendly staff, I really only slept there as was out exploring the city. Was recommended it and the location was perfect for me, subway literally a 5 min walk. Taxi's sometimes cannot find it though, a minor inconvenience as if you have the number just give to driver.Will definitely stay there again next Tokyo trip.

Very small rooms (not suited for large luggage), but great location. Rooms are very clean and bed was comfortable.Close to train station and restaurants/night life. Nice roof top bar/restaurant that can give you great view. Breakfast buffet was good.

The toilet and bath area are separate, which is quite good. The location is good, with a lots of restaurants downstairs. There's also a hotel bus to go to JR shinjuku east exit which cost JPY100 a trip.

Stayed for two nights.Very comfortable hotel, in a great location 10 minute easy walk from Shinjuku station. Great area for different cafes and shops.Restaurant is average and you're better dining out.The WiFi was part of the room price but very slow, almost non existent.Overall great stay.

This is my all time favourite hotel. It's just quirky and unique. Its not your standard run of the mill mainstream boring hotel room. It's also central to cool places like golden guy and piss ally. Love this place...

It was my first time in Tokyo and I suppose I was used to the South African room standards. You could barely swing a cat. I took the no breakfast option - but wanting to have sushi for breakfast, besides everything was so expensive. The bathroom was even tinier but the toilet experience was incredible - very smart and functional toilets! I won't go back in a hurry but I guess it would be considered a good hotel by Tokyo standards. Next time I will stay in a name brand hotel. It was central but I felt we had to walk through a bit of a red light district to get there!

For me the biggest draw to this place is the location. Super close to golden gai and all the action of Shinjuku. I stayed in an economy room which was quite small by western standards but not unusual for Japan. Beautiful larger rooms are available for a premium.Room was very clean and perfect for my purposes as I didn't intend on spending much time in it. Nice rooftop bar and very friendly, helpful staff in the lobby.

We spent here 1 night arriving from Haneda, on our way to Nikko. Good location, fast check-in, very small room and bathroom but for the price paid (approx €100 through Agoda) is well worth. It's modern, clean, well equip and, once again, very centrally located, I would definitely be back.

We spent 2 nights in the hotel. The perfect location in Shinjuku, 5 mins walk from the station comes with a price. You need to decide, if you want to put your suitcase on the floor or you want to use the small path to navigate though your 15 sqm room. Nevertheless, the room offers everything you need. We decided to focus on the central location, the gorgeous view from the restaurant terrace located on the 13. floor. The staff is very helpful. Take a 18sqm room into consideration.

Shinjuku is crazy busy with pedestrians in the street at night making taxis reluctant to take you to the hotel. There are no street signs, just maps on a grid which are impossible to navigate your way to this hotel. Save yourself the stress and preorder a pocket wifi that you can collect from the airport so that you can use navigation Aps to give you walking directions to the hotel. We booked a standard queen. The room had the a/c turned off, had a small window and only about 30cm to move on one side of the bed but was purchased at a good rate. Do yourself a favour and book a large room you are in the least claustrophobic. We upgraded to a deluxe room, double the price but with every cent. Huge to ceiling windows, sitting area, better amenities and breakfast thrown in. Staff were very accomodating and the area is really fantastic, central to all the exciting stuff!

Stayed here before I departed on a two week cycle tour.In terms of room it was pretty standard and small, what you'd expect as a solo traveller. Bit pricey considering but not outrageous by any means.In Shibuya which is actually mental. But it's the quieter side of the highway which is perfect. It's a bit less crazy and has some great bars and restaurants in little streets, really chilled area and only two minutes walk from the bedlam.Highlight of hotel was staff. I needed luggage sent to a hotel in Kitakyushu but it was too large due to it being a bike bag. Three staff fannied on calling the post people, forcing my stuff into bags, measuring it every which way, shouting in Japanese on my behalf and generally building up a sweat. Total legends. It got sent despite me leaving it to the last minute. Thanks guys!Side note, breakfast has 3 options. Japanese, French toast and something else. French toast is hobbit size, the other thing I've forgotten. Japanese is the way to go as long as you eat fish......

We booked this hotel for our first night in Tokyo since we didn't want to use up hotel points for a place we weren't going to have time to enjoy. We arrived close to 11pm and left early the next morning to check into the Park Hyatt so it was fine for the one night. The room was super, super tiny! We couldn't even open up one luggage because there was simply no room for it. The bathroom was small too, felt very cramped. The only positive was the location. I've seen a few people mention that it's a sketchy area, but we didn't get that at all and we were traveling with a 5 year old. We walked around a little before leaving and thought it was a great area to explore. If you're coming to Tokyo and need a hotel for a night, this is a great choice. But I would not base myself here as there are much better ones!

This hotel is slightly outside the busy centre of Shinjuku. Easy access to bars, restaurants and the metro. We booked the economy room as we were on a city break. Of course you don't spend a lot of time in the room. The room was tiny and the bath we had booked unusable due to its size. It was very clean though. The staff in the hotel were excellent and perfectly ordered the taxis we needed. The rooftop bar is very pleasant and the prices reasonable. We didn't eat There so cannot comment on the food. All in all would definitely return to this hotel. Thanks Alan

We stayed here the whole trip (7 days). First 3 days the room was quite small, but with everything we needed. It was a clean and neat room with the city view. After our trip to Kyoto, we booked a bigger room, which was a designer suit with a kitchen, laundry, bathtub by the window, shower room, and toilet room. Very spacious, not to mention that it was under $200 (we traveled in June-kinda rainy season aka overcast). The front desk was helpful with any kind of question about the city, metro, etc. The location is great, close to subways and main streets. Never heard any noise from the streets. Highly recommend this place!!!
user_name:
AlinaG810
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is situated in heart of Shinjuku lots bar and restaurants. 5min walk from the train and metro station.has nice terrace view for breakfast. Rooms are bit small but I've been told this is big for Tokyo. Overall it was nice hotel I definitely recommend

We stayed for 2 nights at the end of a two week trip in Japan. This hotel was fine as a base for seeing more of the bright lights of Shinjuku and Shibuya - near a metro, but quite far from the main Shinjuku station on foot. The area around it is a bit seedy but nothing too bad.The hotel itself is a bit of a mixed bag - we had two rooms, one of which was much bigger with luxury bathroom etc, and one more standard. The difference was really noticeable - the bigger room felt quite luxurious, with amazing bathroom and views eyc, while the other one was more like any standard Japanese business hotel - worth trading up if you can afford it!Breakfast was a total shambles - best avoided - though it was a bit of work to find somewhere decent nearby - not really a morning part of town! Rooftop bar was fun on the Friday night, but as it's a "club" for two nights it was 1000Y each to get in including 1st drink, with terrible queues for the bar. The club shuts down at 10pm so no issues with noise later - we just stayed for one then went out.Stay here if you want to be in the heart of things in Shinjuku - but if you're exploring the rest of Tokyo I might look for somewhere nearer the main metro lines and stations, and in nicer surroundings.

The hotel and property itself is great, well maintained, centrally located. Room are very clean, basic amenities, small but this is the normal in Tokyo. So, so far so good. The staff on the other hand is another story, specially reception staff, they are the least accommodating staff I have ever encounter. First of all, service is almost in-existent in this hotel, while they speak very good english, they will NOT help you AT ALL. If you need an iron, you go get it yourself, if you need an adapter, you go down and get it yourself. Fine, no problem. But when I have just paid for 3 nights and kindly ask them to keep my luggage for 24 hours and that they refuse because I do not have another booking with them, I find this completely unacceptable. This is a basic service that cost them absolutely nothing but helped a traveller. Not ready to accept this, I insisted and insisted that this was not at all acceptable after I was a paying guests for 3 nights that they refuse to store my luggage for just one day, the front office lady finally said yes but clearly showing me that it was only out of exasperation that she agreed. So in terms of service, they should definitely review their reception staff services, understanding and empathy for their guests.
user_location: Flic en Flac, Black River, Mauritius
user_name:
izzyboul
Flic en Flac, Black River, Mauritius

review_body: Reception staff speaks good english, when we approach them at 1.45 p.m. They ask for 1'000 Yen for early check in per each room, though rooms were ready, check in time is at 3.00 p.m.!Also they asked 3'000 Yen for double bed per night per room, or else small beds, the booking was issued by a tour agent(confirmed queen size bed)!Louzy breakfast, wi-fi was also a depressing adventure anywhere in the hotel: most of the time not working properly, sometimes not working at all.The hotel is in the red distric lights of Kabukicho, one more good point to avoid the area unless specifically interested in such items!

The location of the hotel is a bit far from the shinjuku station, the first time we took a taxi. Have to say ,it's one of the best hotel in the area, considering the price and what you get. Decent breakfast, clean room and late night supper next doors.

We had 5 nights, yes the rooms are small but rooms have everything you need. We didn't realise when booking that it was in the red light district but this is absolutely not an issue. We felt perfectly safe walking around at night, location is close to subway and 10 minutes from Shinjuku Station. Breakfast was pretty good and lots of good info at reception to help with directions, things to do etc. Having to pay for access to the rooftop bar for a Friday and Saturday night was not great especially when paying enough for a room. Surely house guests can get up there without having to pay. Staff at reception and at the door to the bar didn't know much about it!

The reception staff were very friendly and the cold towel was very welcome! The room is small, but clean and has everything you could want, the ensuite has a shower over the bath. The room is best described as compact, but very well done! We are here for three nights.

We stayed here during our trip and loved it! Spotlessly clean and staff were kind, courteous and helpful - nothing was too much trouble! I would definitely recommend it! The buffet breakfast catered for all tastes and the terrace bar provided stunning views across the city.

It is qualified as four star hotel... that absolutelly depends on what type pé room you booked. I did not book one of those stylish and fency rooms decorated by and artist or architecture therefore it doesnt look like a four star at all... The location is good, you have three metro stations very close.

Stayed just one night at Granbell Hotel. Small room as expected but good, comfortable and clean. Convenient location for the sprawling shinjuku station. Staff helpful but did not have time to use facilities.

We stayed here to end our honeymoon. As most people have said the rooms are small. But after traveling around Japan I can confirm that all hotel rooms seem to be the same size. But for all the time you spend in a room I don't see why it matters too much. The rooms are clean, tidy and modern ! There is a fridge, kettle and plenty of little bathroom goodies. The staff are friendly and welcoming, and are more then happy to help. There is plenty of vending machines, and the hotel is right in the middle of Shinjuku, which is defiantly the nightlife district. Would defiantly stay here again.

For the final stay of our 16 night trip we booked a designer deluxe casual for 3 nights - beautiful room, super king size bed and large bathroom with separate slipper bath and shower.The hotel offers a club lounge for no standard rooms including free refreshments during the day and happy hour 5-7pm. We're sat on the 13th floor roof bar writing this review looking out at the city view.Excellent service from the staff especially at reception helping us to find good quality local restaurants catering vegetarian and Japanese food. Ideally located 3 minutes walk to the nearest subway station with a few more within 10-15 mins walk. Lots of variety of local bars and restaurants as well as tourist site seeing spots in easy reach.

The rooms are extremely small, if there is more than one person I would strongly advise upgrading to a larger room. However, the rooms are clean and have everything one needs, including a small refrigerator, hot water kettle and coffee. The location is wonderful in the Shinjuku district but on a quiet side street. The air conditioning works great and the rooftop bar is very nice. If it wasn't for the small room, I would give it five stars.

We stayed 4 nights at Granbell and this was a second time to stay as very convenient and located at Shinjuku (shopping and night life area). Deluxe room has a big long window. 5 mins walk to metro station and 25 mins to JR station.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for three nights this July. This was our first trip to Japan. The staff was friendly and efficient.The hotel is conveniently located within walking distance of the massive Shinjuku train station, and just minutes away from the shops, sights, restaurants and bars of the Shinjuku neighbourhood. The hotel is situated on a quiet street, so noise from traffic or passersby was not an issue.Our “Superior Hollywood Twin” room featured two comfortable single beds, a small fridge, as well as a small bench and lounge chair by the window. Although the room was thoughtfully designed – everything had a purpose and a place – it was quite compact. There was little room to navigate around the beds, and there was nowhere to put the suitcases or hang clothes, with the exception of a few hangers kept flush against the wall in the entry. We had initially booked this hotel for three nights at the beginning and three nights at the end of our two-week vacation. In the end, we found the tight space to be tiresome; we tried to upgrade to a larger room, but none was available. We ended up finding another hotel with a larger room (and a closet!) for a similar rate on the west side of Shinjuku station for the final days of our trip. If we were to stay at the Granbell again, we would try to reserve a different room.

Hi there I have sent few emails to confirm our booking and give you notification for our late check in but i have not received any reply back . this is not good, please communicate as we need to know if we have a booking or not.

This hotel is big! The standard room was extremely compact and felt claustrophobic to me. I do have to say that they made maximum use of the space in a clever way. But you should be at least able to open your suitcase properly. We booked a room for two and I don't know of this is normal but the bed was a little bit bigger than a one-person bed. With other words: too small. I know for sure many people won't like this. Let's end with a good note: breakfast is awesome, staff is friendly and everything you need (except space) is in the, very clean room. Overpriced but that's due to the top location.

A nice, modern hotel in a great location close to Shinjuku & metro. Rooms are very nice & clean. Breakfast has western options bur would have been nice with more variation. Overall a very pleasant stay!

Our second time in Tokyo and our first stay in Shinjuku. Reading all the other reviews good and bad and watching tons of Youtube videos. I can honestly say this little gem is perfect for everything, location, pricing and cleanliness. Located on the eastern side of Shinjuku you will find yourself with in a 4 min walk to Golden Gai, (A must see and experience for yourself area) The rooms are normal size for Tokyo if you want larger pay more and don't complain because you are frugal. After stalking the prices for weeks we finally found a really good price that included breakfast, normally we don't do breakfast but it was worth the extra 11 bucks a day and the breakfast was enormous and far far better then any skimpy European breakfast we had during out travels. The rooms were very clean and we stayed in a economy double on the 16th floor with a great view. They have a rooftop bar on the 13th floor landing that looked out over the city, they have daily happy hours and a decent menu as well at the rooftop bar. The front desk staff is more then helpful and will direct you and give you maps to anyplace you want to go. If you are a shopper , most big stores are by Shinjuku station which is about a 10 min walk. The area is very safe and you have tons of choices of food with in a couple min walk. I tried to cover all the bases here because I read a couple reviews that just seemed ridiculous and I want everyone to be upfront because thats how we book our hotels. Let me explain, if you have 4 to 5 Large suitcases and book a small double room for 3 or more people you get what you purchased its 15 SQ meters plus bath room they have larger that only cost 20 to 30 bucks more. The food in the restaurants was superior to or equal to most of the 4 to 5 stars we have stayed in. The area is a have a good time area , that is why you are staying in Shinjuku ! If you are looking for a hotel in Shinjuku and on a medium priced level then this far exceeds your perimeters.

This hotel is in a very convenient location if you're looking and willing to walk around. There are also a lot of dinner places around so finding a good place to eat isn't a problem. In the lobby, there's a rack of papers, where they made a list of places to eat/things to do, and how to get there which was also helpful. As for the room, it was a little smaller than expected (in comparison to what the picture made it seem like on the website) but it was good enough for my boyfriend and I to stay comfortably for 3 nights. Also on the last day since check out was early, we left our luggage at the front desk all day until we needed to get it at night without any trouble. I would recommend (if possible) to request a room that is higher up, because the view is absolutely amazing!

Rooftop bar definitely made this hotel worthwhile! We ended up there every night and the menu was delicious. We found the rooms small but rather big for Tokyo standards. The bathrooms tiny but once again it is japan. Our room was clean though.

My father and I stayed in Granbell for 6 nights. The best part of the hotel is the location however we paid for a superior double room and ended up with a room with hardly any space to move around. The cleaning services were not according to expectations at all. They didn't replace the soap and forgot to wash the mugs in addition to other issues. Also the staff was just okay however English is a big issue. Do try the Earl Grey tea in the reception. Also the continental buffet was horrible.

Location is about 5 minutes to Higashi Shinjuku Station. There's nothing to see except for love hotels and you have to walk farther to get to central Shinjuku area or good restaurants and shopping areas. Clean rooms. We chose non-smoking floor, but you can smell cigarettes at the corridor.Not advisable for family or with little children because of small rooms.

We stayed for two nights on a recent trip to Tokyo. We moved to this hotel after staying in a different suburb of Shinjuku for 3 nights prior. While the hotel was clean, we definitely were not satisfied with our stay. To start off, in my opinion this hotel is definitely not worthy of a 4-star rating. No idea why Trip Advisor thinks it is. It doesn't have the rooms, service or amenities I come to expect from 4-star hotels. We stayed in a 3.5 star Sheraton in Osaka previously on our trip, and it was nicer with bigger rooms, and had much better service than our stay at the Granbell. While the hotel is located in Shinjuku, I wouldn't say that this is a great location, just OK. You're 15 mins walk to Shinjuku station and the popular Yamanote line, among many other trains, so not terribly convenient if you're coming to do a lot of sightseeing, but it works if you don't mind 30 mins roundtrip from your main train station. There are other train stations close by but we didn't find them useful at all to get to top sightseeing spots in Tokyo. If you're coming to party, eat and hang out mostly in Shinjuku, then the hotel is in a better location. It's in a safe area and was quiet at night.We expected the rooms to be small, and they were, but compared to the other 3.5 and 4.5 star hotels on our trip, the Economy Double rooms were very, very tiny. It's tight for 2 people with luggage, you can make it work but it's not terribly comfortable. The bed is stiff but fine, the pillows sucked though to put it mildly. The bed is up against a wall, so you can only get off on one side or the end. There's no closet to store your things. Thankfully there is a small fridge to get some drinks and stuff.The best part about the hotel was the cleanliness. The rooms and hallways were very clean, so that was nice to see.The service really let me down. For a 4-star hotel, you expect high quality service. I emailed the hotel prior to check-in to ask some questions, and never got a response. When we arrived, zero chance of an early check-in, they already have a line for you setup when you arrive to drop your luggage for storage. Speaking of luggage storage, they will hold it for you, but it's just sitting in the lobby with everyone else's luggage, hardly secure. We asked for a 1 hour extension on our check-out time because our flight didn't leave until the evening. Again, zero service, they wanted to charge me $25 for 1 hour. I asked if they could make an exception, absolutely not. I asked if this was because they'd be promptly cleaning the rooms right the 12pm check-out time, and was told yes this was the case. 12pm came and went and no one was there to clean. It was a Tuesday, the hotel was not sold old, I have no idea what their problem was. So instead of letting people relax in their rooms for an extra 30-60 mins, everyone is just waiting in the lobby to head to the airport or their next destination.Regardless, the hotel did the trick if you're looking for a clean place to crash within walking distance to Shinjuku. Next time I'd probably look for something closer to a Yamanote line station elsewhere in Tokyo. You can still easily come to Shinjuku whenever you want. There's really no reason to stay here unless it's a last resort or you want to just stumble home to a clean hotel after a big night out. Make no mistake though, this is not a 4-star hotel.

This hotel has its pros and cons. Pros are that it's a really central area of Tokyo. The rooms were clean & the bed was comfortable. The room was very small but most places you stay in Tokyo will be small. Cons = The restaurant is no good so if you are wanting breakfast or a meal I would suggest you go for a walk & eat elsewhere. The roof top bar was a really great spot to sit & enjoy a drink but it was rather expensive. Keep in mind that this is the red light district and often even middle of the day you will encounter extremely drunk people roaming the streets. We loved the fact that it was so close to Golden Gai and would head there most nights for a drink in one of the many small bars. Everywhere around here there are adults only hotels where you can rent rooms by the hour. Not ideal but I guess like I said before it is the red light district. If you're not precious then I would say stay here. We enjoyed our stay but next time we visit Tokyo we would try somewhere else.

I agonized over where to stay in Tokyo and read all the reviews. I booked through flight Centre and they were pushing this hotel. I chose this hotel based on price and location. Like all the reviews say you are surrounded by love hotels and the red light district. It's totally safe but if you're traveling with kids and coming home at night you pass all the clubs with pics of girls on the wall so just depends what you're comfortable with. We arrived at 7am on the first day and there were literally 3 different people rolling drunk in the gutter which was pretty confronting but they're no threat. Our first room was a superior double which is a standard room FYI. It was TINY I thought people might be exaggerating in their reviews but they're not. For 2 people with bags it just doesn't work. We paid extra and they moved us to a Hollywood twin which was much more manageable but far from Hollywood. The annoying thing was that by the time I'd paid the upgrade I could have just stayed in a nice hotel with a gym and pool. They obviously have an amazing photographer because it looks much nicer in the pics but it's modern, clean and fine. The wifi is bad and drops in and out. I got better wifi in pubs or tullys coffee. The rooftop bar is nice but doesn't open until 5pm like pretty much everywhere in tokyo we found! It's open late on weekdays though so a nice way to finish a day out. The breakfast is TERRIBLE, literally the worst I've ever had. We didn't eat it and went to McDonald's! We found bfast generally tricky and maccas and Tullys coffee our safe options nearby and on the way to the subway. It's a pretty solid walk from the main Shinjuku station especially in the heat, don't attempt it with suitcases like we did. Grab a cab from Shinjuku station when u first arrive. There is a smaller station only four mins walk if you change lines at Shinjuku but we weren't up for that on arrival. After a shower and dropping our bags we found the subway easy to work out. Recommend you grab a day pass on the subway then it's easy to get around. We switched between that and our JR pass throughout the day depending on where you were going. Overall the hotel was fine, they had vending machines, maps, air con and was clean but I'd look at something like the Hilton or a full service hotel next time for a bit more comfort and a pool.

We stayed in different 3 hotels in Shinjuku area (same price range) and this was the best so far. As every hotel in Tokyo, the room was small but clean. The staff at the Front Desk was very nice. It is not close to the JT line but location was OK.

As like normal Japanese hotel, This is also tiny and clean.Unfortunately, there are too many love-hotels and clubs around.I could not recommend for family's stay.10 mins from Shinjuku Sanchome station.If you stay here, don't forget to visit Square Enix cafe and Donquijote.

We enjoyed our stay in the Granbell amongst a number of hotels you wouldn't want to stay in. This modern hotel has all you need and more. The roof top bar is a huge plus and they also do a great breakfast buffet with good views. Perfect for our time in Tokyo.

Prior to leaving my home country,Granbell Hotel Shinjuku were prompt and helpful in their response to my e-mail. I had requested my cousin and her partner be situated in their room close by to me. True to their word we were just a few rooms apart on the 4th level of the 17 floor building.I stayed in an Economy Double Room for 5 nights. Having expected a tiny room, it wasn't actually too bad for one person. I could lay my suitcase out flat under the desk. For two people, one large bag/suitcase would probably have to stay upright. The features of the room were ideal. The things I most appreciated was the modern look, fast working air-con, hair drier, bottled water x 2 daily, 4 pillows on the bed and the button up nightgown. The room was definitely consistently clean. I also got a coupon for the bar (wine only) upstairs but on the weekend the bar had closed at 11pm. Quite odd considering it was open much later during the week (3am). The staff were lovely though and let us have a quick look at the amazing views of Shinjuku. Other good points about this hotel: 12pm checkout. A good selection of maps in the lobby, and great selection of Japanese and Western food at breakfast.All in all a great stay. An easy walk to the metro and the very unique and lively Golden Gai bars (highly recommended checking out).Happy travels. JenSunshine Coast, Australia.

The location is very good, rooms are quite small but as we were aware of this it was no problem for us. The hotel is fairly new and the lobby, corridors and rooms were really clean. The rooftop bar was great. Staff was helpful as pretty much everywhere in Japan.

Was upgraded to a suite for free with a city view.The standard rooms are like boxes soooooo small.Had a large window in the bathroom with an amazing view of Tokyo.I went with my partner and 3 children from Hongkong to Japan short flight.High standard very helpful staff great English speaking.very clean and beautiful hotel will definelty be visiting again soon.very unique and stylish.The staff are very respectful and do not except tips well as is the same in most of Toyko.The indoor grills are amazing to eat if you are unsure of food.

The rooms are very small but you will have everything you need ,very clean nice bed and pillows ,I did'nt care for the breakfast in the 12 floor but the restaurant in the rooftop have a good pizza ,don't ask for olives they are very little spency and no flavor, I don't recoment the hotel for families because is locate in the red district and a lot of action at night

LOCATION:It was in a convenient location. About a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station. The hotel was a bit hard to find the first time. ROOM:We had a double, non-smoking room. The room was small by Western standards, but it is enough room with two adults. There was enough room for our bags and to hang up some items.AMENITIES:The bathroom was fully stocked! It had disposable razors, hair brush, toothbrush, toothpaste. They restocked all the items every day.Every day a wine coupon was left in the room by housekeeping for use at the rooftop restaurant.A good amount of USB outlets were located near the bed and near the sitting area in the room.FOOD:A continental breakfast was included with our room. It was Western and Japanese breakfast. Some items changed each day.The food at the rooftop restaurant was ok. They do have an evening Happy Hour!AREA:The area is full of "love hotels" and hostesses clubs. The area is very safe and at no point or time did I feel endangered.Lots of restaurants with all food types nearby and convenience stores.There is a batting cage nearby that is open until 4am!

The hotel is located in a quiet street in Shinjuku Kabukichol, where you could enjoy the foods/ restaurants arounds even at mid-night but not feeling noisy at all. The loft room is cozy & comfy, with projector & dvd machine as well. Breakfast is delicious too. If you aimed at a hotel near the Shinjuku Station, this may not fit for you. But it is still in a walkable distance about 20mins. If you prefer to stay in a rather quiet street and don't mind to hv a walk, you will gonna love this hotel as I do.

The hotel is everything you would want - great location, high up rooftop bar with a great view and happy hour, nice products in rooms. We paid a bit more for one of the nicer rooms through jetsetter.com and it was totally worth it. 16th floor view is amazing and they put out bath salts for a nice tub. Had fiends who got the 3rd floor and it not as comfortable with a small room and no view.

Pros:- Clean, modern rooms- Quiet- 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station- Nice rooftop bar- Free wifiCons:- Room is small. Not enough space for two suitcases in their economy double. - Bathroom was clean and modern but our shower was broken and would just spray the wall- Location is good, but is next to lots of love hotels and you get approached a lot by hookers and men trying to get you into night clubs. It was safe, but a dodgy area. As a single person I wouldn't stay here, however I was staying as a couple. - One thing that angered me was that they didn't allow early check in for free, even one hour early would cost you 1,600 yen PER HOUR. I was outraged at this, I call this just good customer service.Overall:This hotel is simply ok. I returned to Tokyo and didn't stay here as it's just average and is quite expensive (also a little too far from the station). The early check in really annoyed me as we stayed on our honeymoon and I didn't feel they valued our custom.If you're coming from Narita there is a bus that goes all the way to the station for about 1000 yen off the top of my head. It's then 15 minute walk.

Stayed here recently on my last night in Tokyo. The location of the hotel is great and easy to get on the metro aswell as being in the hub of the golden gai area which is a must see! The hotel has one of the best rooftop bars that i have been to in Tokyo with a fantastic view of the entire city.
user_name:
JacHiggins
New York City, New York

review_body: The Hotel is not too near any JR or Metro station, right in the middle of a large cluster of Love Hotels.Its in Shinjuku but not where the shopping is if you were thinking to do that.The room had a problem with sewer gas smells coming up through the bathroom drainage and every so often it would stink up the room even with the bathroom door closed ! Small but well planned room. Good Bed n Pillows. Nice and Modern. The window blinds dont cover the window fully so you will know its morning when the sun is up ! Pity, could be nicer except the location.

In short, good value for money.Friendly staffClean roomThe hotel room was as advertised, a bit small but all I needed was a comfortable and safe roomThe downside is that the internet connection wasn't stable and didnt enjoy the breakfast at the hotel

Granbell has many branches in Tokyo. I went to Shinjuku twice and three times at Shibuya. both location are excellent, it close to the heart of the location but yet it still privacy during my stay. The room is very nice, clean, good quality of bed ( Simmons)

We stayed here for 7 nights during our Tokyo holiday. The hotel is a street away from the 'red light district' but it's nothing to worry about at all. The hotel is a 10-15min walk from the main Shinjuku train station but there are some smaller station closer as well.It's in a great spot, close to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku and really close to some great restaurants and the very cool Golden Gai bar area and attractions like Robot Restaurant.Rooms were small (we stayed in a double room) but that's to be expected in Tokyo but the room was very clean and new. Pillows were a bit average - either very soft or very hard.We had breakfast included as part of our stay and that was probably the worst part of the stay. It was adequate but in terms of food for westerners it could be a lot better. Overall, I'd recommend the Granbell for anyone looking to stay in Shinjuku!

The hotel is nice and situated near kabukicho. It's walkable to the main hub of Shinjuku but it can take around 15mins walk. Lots of convenient shops around which is a plus to get water and food supplies. The rooms are sizable for japanese standards, so don't expect too much unless you can book the higher priced rooms.

Tokyo again, its my 2nd visit to Japan, and I decided to stay in Shinjuku this time, and during my search of hotels i just loved this one, they have Unique rooms with Separate character for each room or suite. So now wonder i tried 2 types of room While am in Tokyo.my 1st room was Deluxe Designer Double / Casual, Non-smoking (355-sq-foot (33-sq-meter) room with city views), quite big room room Tokyo standard, and really what attracted me to this room the design and most of all the BLACK bathtub in the bathroom :).- bathroom is in good size with bathtub, Separated rainfall shower.- king size bed.2nd type , it was The Club Suite (646-sq-foot (60-sq-meter)). ( and it was my birthday gift to me)- huge room with a lot of amazing details and most important all the white and black marble. the hotel it self is amazing, although located in Shinjuku but you have to walk a little bit to reach , because it kind of hidden. friendly stuff and free WiFi with good speedamazing experience and i thing i will try it again if am in town.

This hotel is all about the location. Very close to Shinjuku JR lines and the subway lines and close to all the action (red light district) restaurants, Golden gai, ISETAN, etc. The hotel is quite new and its perfect in terms of price and location. The rooms are very clean and they are small but enough for 1 person or 2. The beds were comfortable, and the shower and bath were clean and the amenities were pretty good. There is free wifi and also a stunning roof top bar and a seperate restaurant,This is great for millenial, Gen Y travellers who are on a budget but want the mod-cons and like i said its about the location.I would stay here again!

If you are a first time visitor to Tokyo, this is the place to go. The location could not be better. Yes it is in the 'red light' district but there is no concern for safety. Within walking distance is everything you need - lots of food, drink, culture, shopping. You name it, it is within walking distance. Now maybe this place wouldn't be the best for families simply because I don't think Shinjuku is a fun spot for kids (go to Disneyland). Awesome staff and extremely clean room. Our room was SMALL. Really small. We knew this going in so not a concern. I know they have other rooms for more money that have more space so if you don't a small room, pay up or don't go to Tokyo. Bar patio is a good place for a drink.Definitely would go back but pay a little more for that queen bed!Cheers

It's perfect fir what we were looking for. Great location. Train station and metro are close by. We prefer to walk so it was also good. Located in a greta neighborhood it's in the center of everything you need to visit as a tourist. The room was very clean. We chose the small room and it's small so be prepared to be in a tiny space. We just slept there so that was no big deal. We did not use the hotel restaurant. Wi fi works perfectly.

I stayed here my first two nights in Japan and I loved it. The hotel is spotless and in great condition - (something I appreciated more as I spent more time in Japan - always clean, but sometimes the worst for wear). Its a 10 minute stroll to Shinjuku station, but theres a closer metro stop, less than 10mins to the robot restaurant, great places to eat nearby & a 7/11 & Family Mart - 2 mins away. The hotel has great information. Be warned the economy compact rooms are small, but have everything you need. I had carry on luggage so there was enough room for me, but if you have a large case you need a bigger room. The rooftop bar is great. I loved peering down at the neon and love hotels of Shinjuku from the window in my room and the rooftop bar

I can't say enough good things about the Shinjuku Granbell hotel. You have to look hard to find things wrong with this hotel. I spent 4 nights in this hotel over Memorial day weekend and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I want to preface this review by stating that I've paid as much as $800/night for hotels in the past and I've stayed in pretty high end brands so I'm not exactly easy to please. Obviously I adjust my expectations based on the price. I paid about $220/night for my stay here. The Pros:1. The hotel staff is amazing. Really they are godsend. I had several great experiences and lots of support whenever I needed it. Miyaka at the front desk (hope I got the spelling right) was especially helpful calling a tour company to help me get in at the last minute. I didn't end up going on the tour but her going above and beyond was such a relief. At that stage I was early in my Tokyo trip and the first day is always tough for me in a new country until I get my "sea legs". So having a hotel that was willing to accommodate and support me was such a relief. More shocking to me is that Japan is not really a tipping country so these people go above and beyond without that expectation. For me (as an American) that makes it all the more impressive. 2. The hotel itself is beautiful. A nice coffee shop downstairs with light food options, outdoor seating, a lounge and dining area. It's very modern and clean and well kept. 3. The room: AMAZING. I thought I fell into a suite when I walked into this room. It's futuristic (as is common in Japan) so it took me some time to figure out how to turn on lights (and use the toilet!) but once you get the hang of it, it's great. I had am amazing view, a huge bed and sitting area, big TV (not that I ever watched it) and a huge bathroom with big clawfoot tub, walk-in shower and an ultra modern and comfortable toilet (with bidet). Also the amenity kits you get in the bathroom are among the BEST I've ever had in a hotel. 4. The breakfast: This was included. I've seen other reviewers criticize the quality of the food but really I don't know what the expectation would be. It's a breakfast buffet and it's included. This isnt the 4-seasons and I didn't expect steak and eggs. I thought the food was actually quite satisfying and well done. I enjoyed it each morning. Is it high end? No. Is it hot cooked food with interesting dishes, an extensive amount of choices (hot and cold), good coffee, and both American and Japanese options? Yes. 5. The biggest biggest PRO of this hotel to me is the location. I really hit the gold mine there. It's so close to so many things. Most importantly you are WALKING distance to Shinjuku station (the busiest train station on EARTH. Literally, I'm not just making hyperbole. It actually is.) So needless to say you can use this hotel as a base to explore Tokyo and many many areas around it. It's also in the heart of Shinjuku and there is endless endless things to see and do in Shinjuku. Not just the amazing neon lights and red light district and gay district and theaters and shopping and squares but also a huge central park Shinjuku-gyoen right up the road from the hotel. I didn't even realize all this was there until late in my trip. Just pick a direction and there is so much around you. Cons:1. Room closet space: The only big drawback to me was the amount of space to hang clothes. It's such a big room I really wish they'd give you a real armoir or closet so I don't have to squeeze my stuff into a small space to hang up clothes. I'd strongly reccomend adding an armor of some kind. If we had been two people there simply would not be any room to hang things up. 2. I really wish they'd install some USB ports. For such a modern room, I was very surprised about that oversight. It's minor but it would be nice. Overall I will absolutely be returning to this hotel on my next trip to Tokyo.

Small and clean room, all equipment needed is available, middle of the cool Shinjuku area, but in a calm side street which is full of live hotels :-). Two streets away from Golden Guy. I would recommend to stay.

Superbly located hotel off quiet street but within easy walking distance of all the sights, amenities and Shinjuku station. If tired after hard days exploring, take a taxi from Shinjuku station, at only around 500 yen it's very cheap.We stayed in a Delux Hollywood twin on seventh floor for three nights which had a good view and was reasonable size. Look at the m2 room size details provided though, three to five m2 is a big difference for a small hotel room to begin with. We also stayed in a Superior Hollywood twin for one night and the size difference was noticeable (Tip to hotel, do away with the hanging chairs! suspect they never get used and take up too much room. Also provide space under beds for cases) The beds were very comfy and the rooms otherwise well equipped (The heated, auto toilets are awesome!) Wi-fi bit hit and miss in our room at one of the extremities of the building, but it was ok elsewhere.The view from the rooftop cafe bar is fantastic and worth a stay on its own (tip to hotel: why play jazz in a funky Tokyo hotel? obviously it's inoffensive but in the largest and one of the coolest cities on the planet, surely there must be plenty of local alternatives?) We found the breakfast selection to be very comprehensive and definitely worth having. The staff were also helpful, attentive and friendly.

1.TERIBBLE breakfast!VERY LOW standard of food- in fact nothing to eat!this is a 4* hotel, where i found out that i need also to to download my food & staff from the breakfast table!!i spoke about it with the manager of the hotel, who was insolent in his answer telling me that this is standard in whole Japan 4* star hotel!!bottom line- DON'T RESERVE THIS HOTEL WITH BREAKFAST!u pay for it-& get nothing-at least for Western breakfastterrible coffee-Espresso machine in lobby-start operating after 10:00 am ??2.Room- was big room 50% bathroom, so practically the room itself was small3.not 4* high class hotel4.unfortunately we stayed in this hotel 8 ! nights & booked for 3 weeks later, for another 4 nights, which we of course cancelled in due time.

The advertisement for rooms is nothing close to what you will receive. I was not welcomed by a friendly staff at concierge as you would generally expect, she was rude, abrupt and could not care less. Her English was very difficult to understand and she never smiled or said "thank you" or "we hope you enjoy your stay", it felt no different to going through a McDonalds drive through. After that I went to the room to find what looked like a fur ball catch my feet as I had taken off my shoes and found blonde hair bundled up on my toes from the previous guest. Don't waste your money or your time.

I'm staying in this hotel, for the 3rd night. The rooms are tiny, no place even for our luggages! No closet in the room nor any solution for our stuff and clothing. The price per room is unbelievable highly for such a poor result! And it's not including breakfast. We paid one morning for breakfast and it's same poor as any other parts of this hotel.Above all, the attitude of the hotel employees, especially in the front desk, is arrogant and not friendly and you barely can manage with basic English I'm sorry, but the best thing I can say about this hotel, is that 2 days more and we'll stop suffering from this bad place

Myself and my boyfriend stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell for 10 nights from 19/5 to 30/5.First impressions were good, great location (2 min walk from Higashi-Shinjuku station, 20 min walk from main Shinjuku station) great decor and friendly staff. We arrived at 12.30pm and couldn't get our room until 3pm.. we were a bit disappointed having been travelling for almost 24 hours.Overall our stay was very comfortable. Although they are small, the rooms are very clean and have everything you need, hairdryer, shampoo, conditioner, toothbrush etc. The room also had air conditioning which was well used as it was pretty hot from the sun facing the window.My only dislike was the limited storage space. For a couple staying 10 nights we did have a lot of stuff so we had to live out of our suitcases due to there being no wardrobe and only 4 coat hangers. TV channels were also limited with only news channels being broadcast in English.We visited the roof top bar on our last night, drinks are expensive but you also get to see a spectacular view of Shinjuku/Kabukicho.Check out was efficient and quick, although they tried to charge me 410 yen for the privilege of calling a taxi (around £3.00).. we managed to hail one just outside the main road and it cost us 700 yen to take us to the main station to get the Narita Express to the airport.Would definitely stay here again but will most likely pay for an upgrade next time to have a larger room.

This is by far the best hotel I have stayed in for being quiet, I actually didn't think anyone else for on our floor, but there was, you hear nothing from the other rooms, even no doors opening and closing, and no outside noise, our room was on the same floor as the open bar, and we had no nose from therethe rooms are a little small, but we managed ok, they are very cleanthe location is perfect to see all of Shinjukuthe rooftop bar was brilliant, the drinks we thought were expensive, but when you go out to drinks it was morethe atmosphere was lovely and relaxing after walking for miles outsideNaomi on the bar was so friendly, she even wrote my name out for me in Japanesewe had breakfast 2 days of our 6 day stay, and there was a good selection, enough to keep you going while out and about, Shinjuku is great, so much happening day and night, it sometimes may seem a little seedy but we didn't have any problemsthe rooms are cleaned pristinely every day, and the bedding changed daily tocould not fault this hotel brilliant, the best we stayed in in Japan

My wife and I are currently staying at the Granbell. Room accommodations are good and you have everything you need. Front desk is helpful and they have a lot of maps and information for tourists that are already printed out. Breakfast was delicious and they have a good variety of food choices. I'd recommend staying at this hotel from my experience.

Great new hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. Easy to get to and we got perfect service throughout our stay. Buffet style breakfast was included and there was enough choice to fill up on for a day's adventuring throughout the city. Our room was impeccably clean as was the whole hotel. The rooms are very much in the smaller category but very neat and with sensible layout, we were on the 12th floor in the "loft room" which had a ladder up to a higher seating area - it was a cool novelty but the projector can only send DVD or Computer images and not the TV from the main set in the room so we were ill-equipped to use it.Well placed for Tokyo transport links - make sure to grab a Suica or Pasmo card if you aren't buying a rail pass - trust me it will save you money and heartache!There is a baseball batting centre just round the corner which was great fun - we couldn't figure out why we couldn't hit a thing until we left and realised we'd picked the lane with 120kmph pitching! So if you go there make sure you pay more attention to whats on the doors than we did!Well placed for the famous Robot Show if you have tickets for that I'd recommend this as a convenient place to stay.Hotel were very accomodating and held our bags when we left to collect our hire car, and were very prompt at getting them to us when we came back to collect them!Recommended!

We stayed in shinjinku grandbell for 4 nights in total. We did get the room through a booking website for a very good price- however this was definitely reflected in our room allocation!! It was tiny! We have been travelling for 1 month and our luggage would not fit in!The hotel is modern, clean and has most things you want- however as we seemed to find in all hotels in Japan- no gym!! We did not eat breakfast or dinner there- there is so much around you can easily buy stuff nearby.I read in a previous review about it being in the red light district, and after some further reading I think this is true. Walking back from shinjinku station at night- there are a very high number of strip joints/similar looking places. There are also lots of hotels that offer hourly rates! I must say- despite this I didn't ever feel unsafe.It's location is perfect if you really want access to all of kyoto- shinjinku station which is massive, as well as a huge number of sniping centres are <10 minute walk.
user_name:
lucysH508XM
Welwyn Garden City, United Kingdom

review_body: The room was clean and tidy and was probably exactly what we needed for our 6 night stay in Tokyo. Even though it was small (given it IS Tokyo) it was still enough room for us to lay comfortably in bed and move around the room some-what easily enough.We had breakfast in the hotel one day which was pretty average (1300Y each) and the food wasn't that great but we weren't expecting an amazing buffet given they're not known for breakfasts. The staff were super friendly and it was located approx. 10 min walk North of Shinjuku station which is only slightly out of the way but still in a really good location.

We stayed here for 4 days and loved everything about the hotel. We had a deluxe room on the 13th floor that was bigger then any US hotel room I have had. Very nice toiletries and a beautiful soaking tub that overlooks the city. The 13th floor rooms also have their own attendant and sitting area that provides tea,coffee,water, snacks and a daily happy hour with wine and beer from 5-7pm. A very nice treat after a long day of sight seeing. The 13th floor outdoor bar was a welcome sight and a great place to relax at the end of the day. The hotel staff spoke perfect english and were very helpful with maps and directions. We found the location a perfect jumping off point for everyplace else we wanted to visit. The hotel is nestled back away from the busy streets and is only a 5 minute walk to the nearest subway stop. Golden Gai is also a short walk away. There is a park about 1 km away that we would walk to and then run for 30 minutes. The hotel does have a buffet breakfast that caters to everybody. The only negative is there are no work out facilities in this hotel. Otherwise this place was perfect and we would stay here again. We loved Tokyo!!!

I loved this hotel, the staff are really professional and friendly.Its very modern with a lovely outdoor area to have coffee.It also has a brilliant roof top bar . Great views. The rooms a a bit small. Like everywhere in tokyo. However if i go back to tokyoI will stay here , but upgrade to a bigger room.The room has everything you need with great bathroom.Highly recommednded.

We stayed here for 5 days. The service is bad and staff is unfriendly. We can't get help easily. Location is bad far from station and not a place for family. I wished they had mentioned tht it is in a red light district. The rooms are too small and they are not forgiving at all in terms of pricing.

The hotel itself was clean and quiet about a block or two away from the centre of the Kabuki-cho. Its about a 10-15 minute walk away from the Shinjuku JR station which is not far unless its pouring down with rain (which was what it was like when we got into Tokyo). We stayed in this hotel twice when we were in Tokyo (once on the way into Japan and once on the way out) and we stayed in a economy double room twice - the first room was tiny! Maybe about 80cm from the bed to the edge of the wall. The second economy double room was a little bit larger which made it much easier when packing on the way out of the country. One thing that did irritate me was that we had a few delicates hanging in the bathroom to dry and when we came back from a day out, the cleaning staff had left them on the desk (still damp) because they had moved them when cleaning. Not a huge deal, but not terribly fantastic.

Had researched for many hotels in shinjuku prior to my trip, the photos posted on the online booking engine were beautiful and even more beautiful when you are there.As we dont speak japanese, we appreciate the fact they have a mandarin speaking staff on duty and she's been really helpful.In general, we love this hotel for its location, comfort and super thoughtful amenities. Will come back again!

We were supposed to stay at this hotel for 4 nights. We got in the room late on first night. However, when we saw the room we were surprised. It is tiny. Extremelly small. One person per room is already too much! It's also depressing. There was no view from our room and the single window was tiny also. Finally, we stayed 1 night only and transfered to a real hotel. It also needs renovations in the corridors and they need better ventilation. It's smelly and humid inside. We payed around 250 USD per night and it's really not worth it. Wouldn't recommend and would never go back.

Great Hotel in Shinjuku for a few days on business. Clean rooms and a comfortable nice hard bed. Rooms are small but by Tokyo standards good. Staff are great and the roof top bar has a great friendly atmosphere and the staff are just amazing and very helpful in recommending places to eat and telling you how to get there. In future whenever I'm in Tokyo this is where I will stay.

My family and I stayed here in Oct 2016. The location is great since it's walking distance to shops and restaurants. It is by motels or so-called "love hotel" but that didn't really bother us. It is a very safe place. There is a small convenient store around the corner or if you just want some refreshments or beer they have a vending machine in the lobby. The rooms are small but this is standard for Japan. It is very clean wherever you go. No complaints on their breakfast buffet either. I would definitely stay here again.

If you are in Tokyo for a few days and it's your first time, Shinjuku is the place to check out. This hotel is right smack in the centre of where all the action is. It is close to a 7/11 which is literally a 2 minute walk. Check-in was quick and staff spoke really good English. The rooms are tiny, but then it's Japan, you pay premium if you want more space. Since we were out most of the time, it wasn't really an issue for us. It would be an issue though for people that have a lot of luggage. Really do consider the room space before checking in (any hotel) as you wouldn't want to be disappointed when you get there.Although we only stayed here for 1.5 nights, we were lucky to check out the rooftop bar and see the amazing Japanese sunset.Hotel is clean, but there was an odd smell at first, which was easily sorted by opening the window. I would probably stay here again, but then there are a lot of hotels in Tokyo that may be worth giving a shout. If Shinjuku is an area you want to explore, this hotel is not a bad option.

Don't let the title of this review scare you! Regardless the fact where the location is, it is totally safe and lots of outlets, food and ample of stores and stuff to look at. The hotel is also near Meiji Jingu Shrine. My favorite part of this hotel is the mod feel of the lobby and free Wi-Fi. The rooms are small and clean but cozy enough to get some shuteye after a full day of touristing around. Wait, I forgot to mention that this hotel is close to a Seibu-Shinjuku station.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights in a standard double room as part 1 of our 14 night tour of Japan. - The hotel is approx a 10min walk from the Shinjuku train station (more with luggage and when you dont know where you are going so I would recommend a cab when you first arrive).- The area is questionable - right in the red light district near all of the love hotels although we did feel perfectly safe walking around late at night.- The staff at the reception are helpful and try their best to help but the hotel is just too busy.- This hotel is hectic and swarming with people all the time. It is popular with group tours so there are people queuing to check in or out all the time which is not relaxing at all.- That commotion continues at breakfast - we had to queue for an available table even though the breakfast room is huge and there are queues for food.- We had a standard double room and it was tiny! It was so small that one side of the double bed was pushed up against a wall but even with 2 suitcases, we couldn't move. The bathroom was equally tiny and had a funny smell like the smell of drainage. When we asked if we could upgrade the room, the hotel was full so if you are considering this hotel I would suggest selecting the bigger room at point of booking.

Stayed here for a 5 nights in a Deluxe Hollywood Twin room. The hotel is clean and although it is near the red light district of Shinjuku it is remarkably safe. There is plenty in walking distance and you are between 2 train stations so it is very easy to get around. The hotel itself is very clean and modern but be prepared for a small room. My husband and I stayed here and there was no room to open our 2 suitcases. There's also no closet or drawers so for our 5 nights there we had to live out of a suitcase. The staff is very helpful and friendly. Got us a cab and instructed the driver where to take us, even couriered my phone charger over to my next hotel in Osaka when I learned I left it there. You shouldn't be spending much time in the hotel room because there's so much to see in Tokyo so this place is a great, clean and safe crash pad. I would have given them 5 stars had there been a single drawer in the room to unpack a little but otherwise it was really great.

We stayed for 3nights and picked this location for budget and location. it's about 10 min walk from Shinjuku station and I didn't realise it was back of the red light district - not that this was a concern. The hotel is very busy, we saw hoards of suitcases every day in lobby from possible large group bookings. Check in , check out process was straight forward and smooth. We had a room on 6th floor , there wasn't much in a way of a view but it was a reasonable size with all essentials. It was quiet there. The room was clean and tidy. Location wise, loads of food outlets nearby, Shinjuku station is humongous and nearest exit is East exit - that was tricky to find! Quiet by day but Tokyo really does come alive at night.

This was a fair enough hotel for the money, if I was going to stay in the area again, I would be happy to stay there. It was clean and safe and the front staff were very helpful. The location was fine, I walked back to the hotel at night and never felt unsafe or witnessed anything seedy, despite the area being known as the red light district. The hotel is close to a station, but not the main Shinjuku station, which is not a problem because Shinjuku station is massive and very busy and easy to get lost in. Room size was OK, and bed was comfortable.

This is a boutique type hotel. It is in the red light area of Shinjuku although the area is quite safe. Facilities (small lobby cafe, rooftop bar, breakfast/dining area etc) are all quite good. Our rooms (for family of 7) were the standard deluxe type - quite small (15m2) but ok if all you want is somewhere to sleep. Very clean and affordable, particularly in a very expensive city like Tokyo. Recommended.

In the heart of Shinjuku, near the nest of love hotels, this is an international hotel. My room was large, equipped with a washing machine, stove top, shower and bath. The view was classic, all-night Shinjuku. The staff was very pleasant and helpful. Most spoke good English which looks like a must given their international customer base.

All staffs are very friendly and fluently speak English... After tired from our Osaka trip.We stayed here for 2 nights make us feel like someone understand what we're talking. Great location for walking around and enjoying Shinjuku.

This was the perfect solution for what e were looking for the room was small but organized well and so felt larger. everything was very clean and modern. Staff had okay English really tried to be helpful. The location was easy to access other areas but you should be aware walking around at night.

Our group flew in around 6.00am and couldn't get a room right till 3.00pm. They are strict with 3.00pm Checkin unless you pay more.. I was right at the counter at 3.00pm and was told it will be a further 15 mins.. We are a group of 4 with 3 room types. The 2 singles were happy with the size of the room. I had the Queen room and it was very small for 2 people. The bathroom was weird with a shower located where a sink should be and the sink in the actually bedroom. It was small compared to Japanese standards. Well stocked with Shampoo and different toiletries.It wasn't easy to initially find the hotel but after a few attempts it was close by to places. It was a 20 min walk from Shinjuku Station (East Exit). The hotel breakfast was 1300 yen and it was a basic Buffet with Japanese choices. We ate there twice and decided it was worth the money.The lobby has a Vending machine which sells many beers..Cheap for around 280 for a 500ml can of Japanese beer. The Cafe seems it for 800 Yen.We drank many cans from the vending machine whilst waiting for our rooms.Front desk staff are helpful in pointing you to Supermarkets and other locations.The internet was really bad for me. It would cut in and out and rarely get a WI FI signal The other 2 rooms had no problems. My room was on the edge of the building.

Stayed at Granbell for 3 nights. Check in was good however only allow checkin after 3pm, early check in is available for a fee. Room is typical size for a Japan hotel but comfortable nonetheless. Lobby is quite small and can get crowded when groups are checking in. Hotel is in a nice location and quiet, with restaurants and convenience stores close by, can be a little hard to get to when coming from Shinjuku station. Overall great stay at this hotel and hotel staff very helpful.

I stayed here for five days. Checkin was smooth, but this lobby is small and I never saw it without travelers laying about among piles of luggage. Although the rooms were clean and organized, the single rooms was very small (Tokyo style). Even for an individual, you had to step outside just think - there was no room anywhere to unpack or set things out. They did have a few things to lend/rent out which was helpful at times: I had a three-prong computer plug that I needed a converter for two prongs, and they rented one to me for 1000 JPY. In the bathroom, the water pressure was good and things were clean, but again, very tight. The breakfast provided is a mix of Asian and Western styles and was adequate - but things were often picked-over and the dining area was consistently full. Of note, the location was very central to lots of restaurants and activities.

I booked an Economy Double room, which is about 15 sq. meters. The room is comfortable but small. The room did not have a closet, but instead had four hangers against the wall near the entryway. Two bottles of water are provided complimentary each day. There was only 1 TV station (CNN) that was in English. The hotel is in conveniently located. The room provides a good value compared to other hotels that I looked at.
user_name:
D2142VXstevem
South San Francisco, California, USA

review_body: A great hotel with excellent staff! We were very pleased with the modern rooms, even though they were small (this is to be expected for this price in Tokyo). The area is full of hotels and a very lively nightlife. Bearing this in mind, we didn't hear a thing from our room. You can easily walk to Shinjuku station and the area that surrounds is full of interesting shops, great food and things to do. If we were to go back to Tokyo, we would definitely stay here again.

While offering luxury accommodations, the Granbell mostly caters to the economy class tourist. The standard double room, as in most Japanese business hotels, is compact and can be tricky to navigate if you and your spouse/partner are both lugging large suitcases. A lot of tour groups were in evidence during our stay, and at least 50% of the guests we observed at breakfast were foreigners. The included breakfast was good.. We would have rated a hotel like this in another location as average, but in Tokyo, and in Shinjuku in particular, the Granbell is a bargain and so we rate it as very good.

hotel is in great location. the room although small by australian standards was very modern and well appointed. nothing was missing from the room. the space was well used. the art in hotel made for modern fell.. we were right in what is called 'love hotel area'. It was great location. close everything -nightlife, restaurants, public transport, great shops. yet the hotel was very quiet in rooms and had a great feel.

We anticipated a small room but this room is so small gymnastics are required to get into bed. The room was very clean, neat and functional.The lifts are quick and reliable.Disappointing that the cafe does not open until 10am so breakfast was 7/11. We ate at the restaurant . There were very few patrons - maybe 6?We enjoyed the food and wine. Service was impeccable .The front desk was very helpful throughout our stay. The standard map was not very useful.The rooftop bar was very pleasant for a drink and to admire the view.Two taxi drivers struggled to locate our hotel but they persevered.We would stay here overnight again as have now oriented ourselves.

I was a bit skeptical due to the area but the hotel surprised me. It's only about a 7 min taxi ride from the Shinjuku Busta bus terminal (approx 900 yen depending on traffic). We had the room with the loft as this was the only room available. The room was spacious for a hotel in the metropolitan area of Tokyo. Because it's a relatively new hotel everything was clean and the bed was comfy too. It wasn't noisy either. Convenient if you want to stay out late at night drinking as there are many choices around. Just don't go to the wrong ones as the red light district is close by. The hotel can book your bus ticket back to the airport too but you need to book a day before your departure date.

Located in a quiet street near the Golden Gai and not far from the lights and crowds of Shinjuku this hotel is perfect for a stay in Tokyo. It's one change for the monorail from Haneda airport. The rooms are small-ish - typical, I guess in Tokyo - but are comfortable and clean. This hotel has a bar on the 13th floor but even here it's dwarfed by the skyscrapers that are a feature of the city.

Serviceable hotel, well located in Shinjuku if you're interested in spending time around the red light district and only a stone's throw from the wonderful Golden Gai drinking area. The hotel itself isn't bad -- the rooms are good value and the concierge is very helpful if requested. The food isn't so good, and their alcohol selection at the bar was rather bland, predictable. But the view from the restaurant and the upstairs lounge is impressive.

I stayed here two nights. Location is fine. It's about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station. Lots of restaurants around. Beds are very comfortable. Shower has good water pressure and hot water. Lobby can be busy and there's always luggage sitting out. I'd stay here again.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell for 2 nights during the first part of our Japan trip. The staff are very helpful and courteous. We walked from the airport limo bus to the hotel in the rain and they immediately provided us with towels to dry off with at the front desk. I noticed they they even had umbrellas in a stand and when I asked, they said the umbrellas are free for guests to borrow. There were 3 of us so we booked a loft type room on the ground floor.
