There were 2 beds in the main room and a ladder going up to the loft where the third bed was. Like most Japanese hotel rooms, the space was limited but the room was set up well enough that we were able to fit our luggage and ourselves pretty well. The room was clean and well maintained by the cleaning staff when we were out exploring for the day. The vending machines were conveniently located on the ground floor. The hotel itself is also very centrally located. Close to at least 3 subway entrances. And close to the center of the Shinjuku shopping area. There are many bars and restaurants in the streets surrounding the hotel. There were also a Lawson and a 7-11 around the corner from the hotel. They also provide complete bathroom amenities, including hair ties and hair brushes. The shampoo, conditioner and shower gel are all full sized and were nice to use. I liked Shinjuku Granbell and would stay there again.

Location is good for Shinjuku and is not far to the middle of the city. Rooms are typical of Tokyo, pretty small. I had 2 rooms booked, standard and premium. There was NO difference so don't fall into that trap, it was 5000yen more expensive too. I won't stay here again, even for Shinjuku it was over priced but it was okay for what it was. It's a busy hotel so I guess they do deals for holiday/tour companies. I would shop around though but if it comes in at a good rate for you then take it.

Good hotel, pleasant efficient staff and a great location. Totally recommend this hotel, clean and good services throughout. Added to that it has easy access to metro stations for speedy connections to all parts of the city.

Hotel check in and check out could not have been quicker. Good staff. Nice, clean room, amenities, tv, bed. Not much on the view. Five minute walk to the Shinjuku night life and plenty of choices to eat any type of food. 5 minutes also to the subway. Good value. I would stay here again.

This hotel has small rooms on floors 2 - 12 and larger rooms on 13 - 17. The service is absolutely great with staff going out of their way to make sure you are happy. The bar on the 13th floor is a must visit with a great view of the Shinjuku area from the patio area. The restaurant on the 12 floor is so-so, but with the hundreds of restaurants that are within walking distance you should definitely venture out.

stayed here for a week almostthe bedrooms are slightly small compared to the bigger brand hotelsbut once you stay for a night you get used to the spaceroom has everything one would require and placed so well in the limited spacethe bathrooms are very good and so is the sleep qualityi would suggest this hotel for anyone travelling to tokyo shinjuku

The design of the rooms in this hotel was EXCELLENT! Very modern, very clean and nice! They have a normal size bathtub in the toilet rather than a small one like other hotels! They have vending machine on the ground level and the top level is a restaurant where you can time with your love ones. Overall experience is AWESOME! Their service was excellent! Will return again in the future!

Did a nightstop here after flying in from Europe last night.Nice clean and friendly staff.Comfortable beds with a crammed up bathroom. The heated toilet seat was a nice touch.Centrally located you can walk to major shopping malls within 15 minutes. Lots of restaurants and clubs ( not family friendly) around as well. Enjoy

We stayed here for the last three nights of a recent trip to Japan. The location is great, a short walk to Shinjuku station (which is bafflingly huge) for JR, subway etc. and great views from the rooftop bar and bedroom room window. I'll attach a pic from our room. We had booked the smallest room available (15 sq metres I think) due to availability limitations for the dates we needed so expected it to be 'cosy', which it was. The facilities were great though, good bed, bathroom, kettle and fridge in room.Only criticisms really were that they could make better use of the space in such a small room to improve storage as there were a couple of panels that looked like small drawers or cupboards that didn't actually work, and the wardrobe area seemed to have a lot of wasted space above and below where you could fit a suitcase with better planning. Minor issues though and overall would recommended. Note if you've not stayed in Shinjuku before the streets after dark are something of a seedy culture shock but do feel very safe and certainly give you plenty of bright lights and culture for photo opportunities!

So, I'd gotten used to rooms the size of a postage stamp in Tokyo ... and then I arrived at the Granbell in Shinjuku. My expectations before getting there were not high ... I was moving across from their sister property in Shibuya (which also has great pics on the website. Unfortunately, that was the worst hotel I stayed in in Tokyo.On arriving at the Shinjuku location I knew immediately that we were playing a different game. A sleek clean modern and airy hotel with well kept staff behind the desk. Was this the same hotel chain?I went up to the room expecting to bump into the bed as soon as I opened the door and WOW - what view, what a room. The room (a deluxe double that I'd gotten a great insider price with Orbitz on) was huge. In fact the bathroom alone was the size of the previous room I'd stayed in in Shibuya. The windows were floor to ceiling with an expansive view of the Tokyo skyline, and there was a free standing bath as the centre piece in the bathroom (as well as a separate enclosed power shower), and even the telephone was Georg Jensen. The wall art was seriously upgraded from the cheap laminate photocopy in the sister property. This is what I'm talking about!The room amenities included a vanity kit (Jack Black (I think) for men, Shiseido for women), the cutest pinstripe yukata, slippers, complimentary bottled water and fabric freshener. Plus, as I was staying in a deluxe double, I had access to the club lounge on the 13th floor - which offers free beer and wine from 6.30 - 7.30 and complimentary snacks throughout the day. I enjoyed taking an hour each night to relax and take in the view over the glass of wine while planning my itinerary for the next day.The hotel is close to many many - too many things for me to take advantage of in the short time that I was there. I did go out for a run one morning and ran across two major parks on the tourist map (but couldn't go in as they actually don't open until 10am ... weird), and did have a very late night drinking in the Golden Gai area ... literally minutes away from the hotel. The buffet breakfast offers the best dining view that I had (along with the rooftop bar). They both offer a vast expansive view across the city. This hotel offers a Scarlet Johansenesque experience of Tokyo without the steep hotel tab! The breakfast buffet could get quite crowded, but there was never more than a few minutes wait to get a table (so don't stress if there is a huge line) and the options were plentiful (serving Western, Japanese and Chinese breakfasts). The only thing that needs a little more attention is the wardrobe space for a room of this size. There wasn't one. This may have been a problem if I was staying for more than 2 nights. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would stay here again. A great option if you're celebrating a special occasion with someone special. I did a Facebook live chat from the hotel room and everyone was commenting on how romantic the room was.
user_name:
JMO73
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at the Granbell for 2 nights during our Japanese holiday. Located in the heart of Shinjuku, it is very close to the nightlife, shopping and main train stations.We stayed in a casual deluxe room and joined their VIP club providing access to a club lounge (free refreshments and snacks all day) and higher floors.Our room was great - very spacious and a great outlook. Massive king bed, huge bathroom with tub, separate shower and separate toilet. Rooms were modern, well appointed and serviced daily.Breakfast was included in the room price. Served buffet style, it is a big restaurant and provides plenty of different options.Small drawbacks, it is a big, busy hotel, so you might wait a short time occasionally at the front desk and the reception area was very warm.All in all, we would definitely stay here again.

Stayed here two nights on the 16/17 floor. Wonderful city view. Room was compact, but had everything I needed and nicely appointed. Bathroom was very modern. Entire facility was spotless. Hotel staff friendly and helpful.Only downside was breakfast buffet. Had a bit of a mess hall feel, but the food was fine.

This hotel has a great location, other reviews say it is right in Kabukicho which is correct but the area is not dangerous or anything like that, it is perfectly safe. Walking distance to Shinjuku station and tons of restaurants and bars nearby. The hotel is clean, the rooms are very small but hat is the constant in Tokyo. The breakfast is average but there is a line every morning. This hotel is priced right and very good located. I would stay there again.

It was difficult to open our suitcases in our standard room, but you have everything you need crammed into limited space, where the bed occupied over 70% of the space. Pretty good amenities.The bed is comfortable and location was somewhat good, and it's cheaper than other hotels in Shinjuku in its class, still somewhat expensive considering the space. I would just use airbnb next time.

We stayed here just one night. Would have stayed longer but couldn't get booked. We had a room for 3 with a loft bed. Room was excellent _ quite big and extremely quiet. Beds were comfy, room was very clean. The hotel had a bar on the top floor which jet lag prohibited us from visiting. I would recommend.

I recently stayed here for a 2nd time for just under 2 weeks & once again it was a pleasant stay. I got a little room upgrade which was very nice. The room was well lit, bathroom was clean & tidy. The room's have been soundproofed extremely well which is very important to me as I can't sleep with lots of sound. The staff were lovely & very helpful. I honestly don't see myself staying anywhere else when in Tokyo, it's such a nice, convenient hotel.

Modern clean and comfortable. I booked this hotel with high expectations and the room {luxury designer double room - mature} exceeded these. Our room was large, spacious and as it looked in the pictures from the website. The bed was king sized and extremely comfortable.The room had a few extra items - Coca Cola & iced green tea in the fridge for free, shiseido makeup remover products, bath robes, bath salts for the bath etc. The bath was big enough for 2 and was a nice space to relax in. Our room came with club room access. The 5-7 happy hour of beer, wine, soft drinks and canapés. 2 beers were on ice and a bottle of red or house on offer. The lounge was very small - 5 seats in the window, 2 tables behind these window seats. We were the first to arrive, and people needed to ask for more beer and wine - the staff member was surprised that more was needed. The drinks came swiftly though.The canapés consisted of crisps, nuts, Oreos and dried fruit.The view could not be faulted - whilst we have been to many club lounges across the world, and this was the most disappointing, the view more than made up for the lack of snacks and beverage options. Just when we were about to leave, a storm rolled through - we would have left and gone somewhere else - but it was a great spot to wait out the storm!Breakfast was disappointing -a small room considering the hotel size and tables quite close together. Not many food options for such a large and modern hotel.Location was perfect - easy walking distance to train station and Shinjuku Gyoen park - many cherry blossoms in bloom during cherry blossom season - tip: the entry closest to Shinjuku station had a huge line up when we went, we decided not to go in, and we went for a walk around the outside of the park. Within 5 - 10 minutes {after walking past many closed gates} we came across another entrance which was open with no queue.The rooftop bar has an amazing view and is a great space with friendly staff and well priced - we payed 50000 for a cocktail, plum wine, 300ml bottle of sparkling sake, yamazaki whiskey and nachos (the nachos were disappointingly small - but tasty).I definitely would come back and stay in the same room.

atypical room size but with nice modern features. Very close to shinjuku station/subway. Breakfast choice good, nice rooftop bar. Very close to the redlight area but this was not a problem walking about at night.

The hotel Staff accommodated all my needs as I arrived early. They looked after my luggage so I could go visiting Tokyo. The rooms are small but very well maintained and clean. My only criticism is the evening menu could have a better range of food. I know this is possible as breakfast is very accommodating to all tastes. I pre-booked a taxi for the airport as I had a early flight. Reception introduced the taxi driver to me. My luggage was taken by the taxi driver to the car. Defiantly will stay here again

Small room but comfortable, typical for Tokyo in this price range. Located in bar/ nightclub area. This was fine when I was with a group but when I had to walk a short distance alone at night to get back to the hotel I was harassed by the nightclub promoters trying to get women into their clubs. Would not recommend this area for a woman traveling alone.

It was our last night stay in Japan and we thought it had a good vibe. We had a fun chat with one of the waiters at the bar on lvl 13.Smaller room than we had been used to. Super warm toilet seat put the missus off but I loved it.

I love Trip Advisor and a good mix of reviews before booking hotels. Shinjuku Granbell was a great location, easy walking distance to restaurants, the train and hustle and bustle of Tokyo. To be honest I was skeptical about the "Red Light District" and did consider different hotels/location however for the price and size of the room I was willing to take the risk. Honestly... there is nothing to see unless you are looking. The streets are extremely busy with men and women you barely realize its the red light district. When it gets later at night simply stay away from small talk with Nigerians who was attempt to allure men into their clubs that's about all we witnessed.

I stayed in the loft at Granbell Shinjuku for 1 night. This hotel is well maintained with new facilities. Sure, the rooms are small and compact, but that's expected for Tokyo. Due to the poor weather predicted at Hakone the next day, I decided to push my marriage proposal one day early. With this last minute change, I contacted to hotel staff to deliver flowers and champagne (both bought online) to my room while I brought my girlfriend (not fiancee) out for dinner. The front desk was very accommodating and asked for several details as to how I wanted things to be arranged. Needless to say, everything went smoothly. The next morning. We treated ourselves to an excellent buffet breakfast. If there's one complaint, it's that there was only one voucher provided for a free drink at the bar.

I stayed in Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for four nights. The loaction is good - just outside all of the buzz, but still withing walking distance. Rooms are nice, but very small. Had my luggage been bigger I would've had problem placing it (and I have a backpack...). For some reason the window in my room was very small. Even on the 5th floor I would've liked to see outside some more. I didn't order the breakfast, but tried it (for an additional cost) the first day. For a westerner it was totally NOT worth it. The asian section was probably OK, but the next mornings I got something fro 7-Eleven instead. To sum it up: the room was good an comfortable, but compared to the price I expected even better.

The first thing you notice about the area is that it is in the heart of Shinjuku. Off in one of the side streets, the hotel is surrounded by food outlets, bars and hotels with rooms by the hour.Some taxis have difficulty finding the hotel, but the hotel can give directions patiently. Expect to look after your luggage. There are no bell hops here. We wheeled our luggage into the main lobby and were greeted by a fairly professional reception team. With none of the warm Japanese hospitality, we went through the check-in process clinically. I was not impressed.The lobby is small and very busy. It gets the afternoon sun, so it can get quite hot. We were housed on the 12th floor in a triple share room with a loft. We were on the same floor as the Italian restaurant /breakfast venue, thus we had to swipe card access to the room area.Immediately apparent was a narrow corridor to a narrow room. The high ceilings take away the fairly narrow width. There are no cupboards for clothes and storage space is certainly lacking. Side tables don't have drawers or a cubby hole to throw stuff into. Everything is pretty compact and did I mention the lack of storage space to hide away our traveling junk?There's a tea making facility on the table below the flat screen TV. Only Japanese TV stations and CNN can be found. WiFi can be received from the room, but can be a little slow at peak hours. A fridge is hidden in the cupboard below; it works and there are no drinks/snacks provided. Next to the fridge is the room safe.Clothes are hung on a railing using hangers; there were 4 hangers for us. A round sink sits at the end of the corridor. There are generous amenities for the guest including shaving kits, tooth brushes, combs, cotton squares and cotton buds.The shower and toilet area is modern looking, while still retaining the Japanese fibre glass construction. A rain shower was a nice touch. A good sized bath tub is placed beside the shower. Organic bath products are provided. The toilet has the usual Japanese functionalities.The King bed for us was comfortable, neither hard nor soft. There are charging points on the bed side table. Charging points can also be found on the study table under the loft staircase. A leather bound mirror can be found on the shelf above the safe.The loft is a fairly small space. Our 13yo could fit in there comfortably, but a tall adult may be a little uncomfortable.We did not eat in the hotel. The surrounding area has a wide variety of food shops and convenience stores. The hotel about a 5min walk from Higashi-Shinjuku station. From here, make your way to Shinjuku station where a wide variety of trains can take you anywhere in central Tokyo.We liked the concept and design of the hotel room, though I felt it was small and had not very functional storage and work area. The service standards was a big put-off. There's a 50% chance we will return.

Partner and I stayed at the Granbell in Feb 2017 for 6 nights. We we incredibly happy with everything the hotel had to offer and the service we received during our stay. It was incredibly inviting and warm. While the room was small it was what I had expected of Japan. The layout was perfect, the bathroom modern and very clean. It is true however that you cannot open a suitcase unless on top of the bed but most Japanese rooms are the same and I wouldn't pay additional prices for bigger rooms just so I could open my suitcase on the floor? #firstworldproblemsWas fairly happy with the location, obviously you can find other hotels closer to the heart of Shinjuku. Just gave us more time to explore the area and all the restaurants nearby (7/11 only a 2 minute walk away, very convenient). Would happily stay here again!

The grandbell is absolutely perfect for a solo stay.i am currently staying here for the next couple of days.it is close to the station which is one of the most important things when you are in japan. It is surrounded by many restaurants so u can eat at different places everydaythe rooms are small bt alright if you are on your own...the rooms are clean.only downside is the room service menue.not much to choose from and only runs till 21:30 so not much use if you are getting back to your room late....overall i would definitely stay here again.

We stayed overnight after returning from the Myoko ski resort (about three hours of rail travel). The hotel is about ten minutes walk from the Shinjuku rail station and there are plenty of restaurants within the immediate area. The room was small but clean and the bathroom has a tech toilet with seat warmer, bidet and other functions. The rooftop bar is very nice and better than the hotel restaurant. The reception staff were very efficient and helpful.

The hotel itself is clean. Staff are friendly and can speak enough English to instruct and assist you. Beds are rock hard although I think in Japan it's the standard as all the hotels we went to had varying degrees of stiffness. Free breakfast is much better than a Best Western so I was pleased. My husband used alll the amenities, I didn't I prefer my own.Very close, about a few min walk to Shibuya Station, scramble, and Hachiko. Smaller than American hotels and window had a straight view of the wall of the next building (pretty much 3ft away)But I'm not picky. You're out and about exploring Tokyo, so why be so critical about a hotel you'll only sleep in.

We went as a family of 6 and the staff were really nice. All spoke good English and made us feel welcome. The price for the hotel was a bit pricey for what you get but when compared to the rest of Tokyo its actually a fair deal. Breakfast was included and worth it as happening Japanese breakfast in the morning is a great way to start the day although there are western items aswell. Would defiantly stay here again.

Contemporary hotel with most of the mod-cons you need. It doesn't have the 5 star service and attention, but its clean, modern and in a convenient location around Shinjuku. Price is relatively reasonable for Tokyo. I would definitely opt for the larger rooms for that little bit extra. It's located around a bunch of other hotels (mostly love hotels) and bars. Plenty of different Subway stations within walking distance. I would give this hotel a try.

As a complete novice ad not knowing where to stay in Tokyo, we decided to stay in the Shinjuku area, close to the transportation system. We chose the Executive Standard Double/Yau Ma Tei room which were were based on the 15th floor. We were allowed access to the Club Lounge on the 13th floor, free drinks and snacks.The room was like the photos on the internet, however, it was quite deceptive as the bed is up against the wall of the bathroom, so it was smaller than what I originally thought. Views were amazing from this level. Bed was comfortable, and the room was quiet, loads of amenities in the bathroom.There was a choice of foods at breakfast, you wouldn't leave hungry.The nearest subway is Higashi-Shinjuku, a 5 to 10 minute walk. We used this stop regularly, as it was a case of turning left out of the station and turning left again down the small street and it will take you to the side entrance of the hotel.

This hotel has an excellent location, and a pleasant bar upstairs. Very friendly reception staff provided me with a plastic wine bucket that I could use to hold a surprise bouquet of flowers for my wife in the room. The room with double bed I stayed in did not have any closet space or dresser space, so for a week long stay, it made the room feel a bit cramped. The breakfast spread is pretty nice, and the hotel is located near to lots of transportation options. (Note: The hotel is in a red-light district, but in Japan, you will not find prostitutes or drug dealers on the streets at all, so we never felt unsafe at any time, even when coming back to the hotel late at night.)

It's nice view, good service, every thing is very good, nearby shinjuku station can walk around 7-10 mins. And also good location such as shopping,eating,stationBreakfast are full option But room very small ..

If you want to stay in an upgraded and modernised version of a business hotel, this is the place, the location is ok, in Shinjuku but not slightly outside the busy crazy part of it.Pro : New and clean, great roof bar and nice coffee shop.The cons : The front desk staff is missing the boutique attitude, very strict no flexibility. if you have to leave late don't expect them to pass you a room to change or give you a place to relax.

Stayed for four nights initially but ended up returning after our flight got delayed for 48 hours. The location is in Kabukicho but we never felt unsafe when walking around, even late at night. We found the hotel easily using google maps. Shinjuku station is about a 10min walk. We really enjoyed staying in this area. The Golden Gai area is nearby too. Highly recommended. I would recommend this hotel to those looking for a hotel near the action. We visited the Park Hyatt area one night for a drink and although the view is beautiful from the top, there was not much happening in the surrounding area. We preferred the location of our hotel.

My husband and I stayed here for the final part of our honeymoon. We splurged on previous accommodations, so for the last part of the trip, we decided to tone down the pace and stay somewhere reasonably priced. This hotel is very close to the train and is centrally located in Shinjuku. It is walking distance from the Robot Restaurant, Golden Gai and many great restaurants. The hotel offered all standard amenities and was very modern/clean.I do however, find this hotel more of a three star hotel than a 4 star. The coffee maker was broken, the rooms were tiny (and I mean tiny; we even upgraded to a deluxe room and our stuff barely fit in the room). Overall, I don't have any complaints about this hotel. I just find it to be very average, with no frills. I would probably not stay here again, and would choose to spend a little bit more money to stay somewhere nicer. However, if you don't plan on spending much time (or any time) in the room, this might be a good pick due to it's location and cleanliness.
user_name:
yanvsnature
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel was a little bit hard to find, with our luggage and everything from Shinjuku Station on the first night (arrived around 10pm); however it is a walking distance from the main station and as well, very close to Family Marts and many many restaurants/nightlife. It is close to the red light district area with love hotels nearby;however, as I was travelling with my boyfriend, it did not bother us at all (i can see why it can for family with small children though). Overall great location.The hotel was extremely clean in the room and the bathroom and even though yes the room is smaller than what you would expect in some other countries, it wasn't as small as some other Japanese hotels and provided the necessary space we needed. The bed is very comfortable also with good heating/AC system. Nice small views from the window, especially at night.The staff was very helpful and easily understood any questions and inquiries we had. The hotel cleaning staff had accidentally misplaced my boyfriend's contact lenses actually two days in a row and the staff was helpful to getting them returned on the same day and apologized for the inconvenience. In the future, if we are to stay in Shinjuku area in Tokyo, we will book Granbell again!

Location: better check for the direction before going to the hotel, it located in the small alley and it takes us around 10 mins from subway station. Not so convenient if you are carrying luggage .Room: The room is clean and tidy and bigger than we expect, at least we can open up a big suitcase. The bathroom is clean and it provided everything we need like toothbrushes, toothpaste, shower gel and shampoo etc.Hotel Facility: There is a bar/ lounge at top floor of hotel, but it closed quite early, we went up at around 11:30pm and it already closed.Services: Front desk staff is polite and helpful, we ask directions for many places and they are willing to explain for us.Overall it is a nice hotel despite the location, but if you plan to do a lot of shopping in Tokyo I would prefer hotel close to JR station instead of Granbell.

excellent hotel and the rooms are much bigger than expected. It has all the amenities and quite new and as for most hotels in Tokyo is very clean. However, it is not easy to find especially if you are carrying luggage and it is late at night, so check out directions well before you arrive at Shinjuku stattion

The hotel location was great, close to train station and walking distance to main attractions.It was clean and reasonable size room for Japanese hotel. View from the hotel was alright. Staff were friendly and helpful.

I've been stay for 7 night in this hotel, location is near from subway station but kinda a bit tricky to find, not really near JR Shinjuku Station but there's Oedo Subway Station Nearby, also easy to find Lawson and Seven eleven, not really good for family stay cause a lot of love hotel nearby, The room is typical japanese room but a bit bigger and have bigger bed than japanese room it's big enough for me, I like the iPod plug in the room so you can listening the song in a whole room, rooftop bar also good choice to spend your night when you need some pizza and beer.you can also send your package all over japan from this hotel, I did send 3 boxes of my stuff to my apartment in Saitama Perfecture and the package arrived in 2 days.a bit busy in check out days.

The bed takes up most of the room but there is a desk and the bathroom is quite large. Everything you need for a brief stay, but you won't be using this room for much more than sleeping. Clean and easy check in. Stayed one night and would come back.

The rooms are very small and had little or no storage space. We stayed in 2 rooms with our children and it was a bad choice for our family. Its an adult area and there was an adult feel in the hotel. On the positive side the beds are comfortable and the rooms are very clean and modern. The staff at reception were helpful. The breakfast was very good with some cool views. We also ate in the roof top bar one evening and the food was very nice.

Overall, this hotel was good value for money. You would pay far more for a hotel of this quality and location in other cities of similar stature like New York, Paris or London.Positives(1) Single room was small, as expected in Tokyo, but was very clean and had a fresh feel to it. Good attention to details in the design, like a ledge by the bed for charging your phone, which made up for the lack of space for a side table. I also liked that at this price point, they had separate bottles of shampoo, conditioner and shower gel, not an all-in-one dispenser like at some chains.(2) Walking distance to multiple subway stations, restaurants, bars and shopping (Isetan, Marui, etc.). Yet, street noise was not an issue.(3) Tomo at the front desk was helpful with reserving a seat on the airport bus for my departure.Issues(1) No gym(2) Free wi-fi sometimes didn't work well for video streaming. Maybe too many users? You'll need it as there was a limited number of channels available via the TV in the room.(3) Kabuki-cho is a red-light district and there are a number of "love hotels" adjacent. But, this is Japan so the neighborhood still feels safe and not seedy at all. Something to bear in mind if this offends your sensibilities.(4) They would not offer late check-out beyond 12pm without having to pay extra. Something to keep in mind if your departure flight is in the evening or at night.

This is a great hotel.Good location in a quiet street. They have loft for 3 person which is very cozy. Even have a projector and dvd player in our room. Decent breakfast buffet in the morning food is good.

A lovely hotel to stay in. 10 minute walk from the subway and in a quieter area of Shinjuku - no noisy roads keeping you up in the night. The room was very clean and comfortable, a little on the small side (but this is Tokyo) and it has everything you need. There are washing machines and dryers available on the 2nd floor which come in handy and 4 or 5 vending machines in the lobby. I'd definitely recommend this hotel - perfect for a couple or small family. The breakfast is delicious. Perfect for exploring Tokyo.

The hotel was walking distance to many attractions in the shinjuku area and we always had something to do. Lots of great restaurants, the golden gai, robot bar, and shopping all an easy walk.The rooms were very small but from what I gather this is the norm in Tokyo and the price was reasonable. The staff were all very helpful and spoke decent English which made things easy. I enjoyed the breakfast buffet, the Japanese selection was great! Didn't try too much of the Western part of it, give me some miso and rice to start the day and I'm in heaven.

It's a nice hotel, rooms are modern, clean and have good facilities.For Tokyo and in this price range we had a good size room and bathroom.Bathroom was modern and had a washlet electric toilet which was fun.The staff were very nice and let us check in early.In terms of location, its a bit of a walk but is fairly near some nice districts.

Just a 10-15 minute walk from Shinjuku train station. Good location for exploring the city. Although in the "red-light" district there were no issues. Stayed in a standard room that is smaller to what many people are use to but this is standard in Japan. Good place to rest. Had dinner one night, the view was really good but the food is very basic. Tons of places to grab food nearby. Wifi worked well and staff were helpful. Everything was clean.
user_name:
Aaron_Agodjian
New York City, New York

review_body: Decide to stay in a different part of Shinjuku at this hotel. Attracted by the special design rooms, the regular rooms are very small and nothing special. This hotel is surrounded by love hotels and it's a good walk to bus and train stations. The breakfast is really not good.I will probably not stay here again.

The hotel is about a 10 minute walk from the Shinjuku train station.On arrival, the staff were very welcoming and checked us in quickly. We had breakfast on our first day before getting our bearings but this was a mistake. Unfortunately, it was terrible and a little chaotic, for the rest of our stay we went to the local Starbuck's so we knew what to expect.Service was excellent, while the rooms are small, we expected something along the lines of what is offered in a central London/New York location but there wasn't really anywhere to put your cases, so we had to climb around our luggage when in the room, luckily that wasn't much as the hotel is well situated to walk or take the train around Tokyo. I'd say the staff make this place, they were extremely polite and helpful. We needed to forward some of our luggage to Kyoto as we went travel to Nagano and Hakuba from Tokyo, they arranged everything for and it only cost ¥4000 for transfer 3 bags.Great staff, excellent service, but the breakfast, poor wifi connection in the evenings, room size and a noisy corridor in the early hours let it down somewhat.
user_name:
warden6
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Slightly off the beaten track so not noisy however the immediate neighbourhood/vicinity unsavoury - a lot of brothels. Never felt unsafe though and short walk was through it into shinjuku region. Good location though for shibuya and harajuku too. Hotel itself modern and clean. The club lounge v pleasant as was the rooftop bar. All staff helpful and polite. Only down sides: the rooms really are v small with nowhere for clothes- had to keep them in the suitcase and slide that under the bed of the duration and the breakfast is gross and canteen style.

Rooms are small, on par with the average Tokyo hotel. Amenities are good with free wifi. Staff are helpful with good English. Location is not bad - 15min walk from Shinjuku station (JR and subway), though my taxi driver initially has trouble knowing where to go (I only had the hotel name and English address). The hotel is near the red-light district, but as a couple we were never hassled. The locale felt vibrant, a bit sleazy but never unsafe. Plenty of good food at a reasonable price nearby.

Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is situated in the heart of Kabukicho (chome 2), the perfect location to stroll around Shinjuku and very close to Higashi Shinjuku subway station, so it's easy to reach all Tokyo districts. The rooms are small but comfortable and clean, the staff is very friendly and helpful.

We stayed at Granbell for 4 nights at the end of a 3 week Kyushu trip. we stayed in central Tokyo at the start of our trip and booked this on the run at the end. The area is pretty ordinary. Lots of Hotels "Cheek and Jowell".Sooooo many hotels in this area.. Many offering room for ' rest'. Getting in and out was ugly but not unsafe. The hotel was great!!!! really nice clean rooms. Great western restaurants and Bars. ( Except for too many loud Americans telling the locals what they need to know). WiFi was dodgy at best. Free breakfast was a real bonus! Great Hotel. Poor location. great for confident couples... not for families.

The hotel is located in a lively area in Shinjuku. Location is great, a little off the busy main streets but a minute walk away. About a 15 minute walk to the Shinjuku station which is great. Hotel is modern and very clean. Rooms are clean and comfortable. Twin rooms are a little tight but that's normal for Tokyo. Bathrooms were nice with heated mirrors and heated toilet seats (also normal for Tokyo). Only downside is Shinjuku is the red light district area so be ready to get constantly hassled by African men if you are there on your own or with just men. If you're there as a couple you'll be fine.

The hotel is modern and nice, the location is just 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station but not easy to find if it's your first time in Tokyo.Considering the rating of the hotel I was a bit disappointed by our room, especially by the sink area set outside the bathroom, in the small hall just in front of the entrance door. Also the shower didn't have a proper door but just a curtain and it was almost at the same level of the bathroom pavement so that when you showered you almost wet all the area. A proper place to lay your shampoo and soap while showering was missing, you had to stick yor head out to reach the nearest shelf.I was also disappointed by the international breakffast: great variety of Asian food but very restricted choice for westeners, not what I expected from this kind of hotel.The bar on the terrace has an amazing view but the staff was very slow and not very efficient.

Modern clean hotel. We got the loft and its really fun to sleep on the loft. However do be careful as the ladder is pretty steep and the foot landings are extremely narrow. Not recommended for kids. Due to low ceilings its quite common to knock against the ceiling lol. Hotel is not that near to Shinjuku station as shown on map. And navigating Shinjuku station is a recurring nightmare on daily basis. If you are staying more than 2 nights, try not to have a day a room make-up. You will get a little Japanese towel as a token of appreciation..

I stayed here for my first 2 nights in Tokyo before leaving to Takayama. The hotel is located a bit far from the main shinjuku area, however the architecture of the building was very nice. The receptionists are also very friendly. The room was very small which makes me feel a bit difficult to move around as I bring a very big luggages. However, this hotel is the only hotel that I stayed that offer us a vending machine, so I could assume that this hotel is perfect for travellers or backpackers as well.

My partner and I decided to splurge a little for the final two nights of our trip by booking the club suite on the top level (level 17).The suite was absolutely stunning with marble décor and an amazing view of Shinjuku. It came with all amenities (coffee machine, complimentary soft drinks/ bottled water & tea, klipsch speakers, bathrobes, Japanese style pjs, slippers, bath salts) and luxury toiletries for males and females (shiseido face wash and lotion was provided). The bed was large and comfortable, the bathroom included a bath tub (suitable for two people) and a rainwater shower!As we booked a suite room we had access to the executive lounge where complimentary snacks and drinks were provided. We also utilised the lounge to check in and out of the hotel without waiting in line.The buffet breakfast was good with a variety of western and Japanese food.The hotel is located at the end of the red light district in Shinjuku however, this did not bother us as the area is very safe and conveniently located to the subway.I would highly recommend booking a suite room if you are wanting to splurge a little! The suite rooms are excellent value and very luxurious without being too far from all the action.

The Granbell can be a little tricky to find at first but on arrival the staff were very helpful, the lobby was well decorated and the room was lovely. It seems that all accommodations in Tokyo are fairly small by Australian standards but our room was cosy without being cramped, very clean and very well appointed. The toilet even had a heated seat! The bed was comfortable, the room had plenty of natural light, tea/coffee making facilities - Tip: stay away from Japanese coffee - etc. Great location in the heart of Shinjuku, walking distance to the main hub.

Very large hotel, excellent facilities, good service, well located within walking distance of everything in Shinjuku. Helpful English speaking staff. Comfortable rooms, if a bit small – 2 people with 2 large wheelie cases and 2 travelling bags for a month long trip to cold climates meant you have to do some careful navigation around the room at times ! However, its Tokyo and that’s what you get !We only ate one breakfast there, which in terms of quality was good, however we didn’t really like the table layout, which took me back to refectory dining halls in boarding school, rubbing elbows with your neighbour. We didn’t do breakfast again !Aside from that, no real complaints, its clean, its comfortable, the service is excellent and we recommend it !

Had a fantastic stay here with one of my friends recently. The location is very convenient especially when relying on the trains to get around as it's a relatively short walk to the station. The room we stayed in was spacious and modern. I would definitely stay here again in the future.

Shinjuku is a great location to be based at given the multiple lines that run through the station. Shinjuku Granbell is clean, modern and conveniently located although the stay was meant for two females. Single ladies traveling alone might not find this hotel location too ideal as it is located near red light district and in the evening the area might get a little rowdy with the club touting with some intoxicated people in the morning. Nonetheless still a great location given the value and fairly decent room space for two huge luggages.

originally I was given a single room which reminded a prison cell. on the following morning I asked to move to a bigger room and was willing to pay the fare difference, hotel was nice to upgrade me with no extra cost.Hotel is very convenient regarding transport to/from both airports: limousine bus has a stop at the hotelMany restaurants in the building to choose from. a Family mart is in the hotel building open 24 hours a dayThe only bad thing is the location. the nearest subway station is far and the hotel does not offer any shuttle

Shinjuku is a wonderful base for being a traveller in Tokyo. Well connected by public transport to the whole city and beyond; great eating and night life options; plenty of shops if you want buy stuff. This hotel is the the heart of it all. It is fairly new so nice modern well featured rooms. For Tokyo they are big rooms too. The rooms have a range of themes and sizes based on what you pay. We arrived New Year's Eve and it was a bit chaotic at reception. Staff jaded and a bit cranky and baggage storage out of control. Management failure rather than the embattled staff. Beyond this starting glitch all fine. The club lounge with our room was nice for an early evening wine. Breakfast was OK not good. But for the price it was better than you might get in the neighbourhood.

From Shinjuku station, I had to walk through a very shady area to get to the hotel. In the morning around 8 a.m., there are people leaving the clubs drunk. There are scantily clad women in winter weatther. I was actually scared walking to my hotel even in daylight. It is directly across from a Love Hotel. The room itself on level 2 was terrible. Tiniest room even compared to already small rooms in Japan, and the window looked out to an alleyway. I think it's unacceptable to rent this room to a family with a small baby. I was scared even sleeping in my room. And the price is incredibly high at $150 considering everything. The experience tainted my vacation. Staff was very friendly and helpful in calling a taxi cab.

The room is large and clear. It offers nice travel good for you. You can take a comfortable bath. The bed is not to soft or hard. Sound insulation effect is nice. I had a sleep tight. You have enough place to pack the luggage. Very recommended for couple to live here.

My partner and I booked this hotel due to our Airbnb accommodation cancelling on us while we were trying to check into it. The staff at the front desk were so helpful and understanding of our situation as we needed a 6night stay over the New Years period and were able to offer us a discounted rate. The location of this hotel is in the red light district but is perfect for younger couples like us who like to go out for drinks and lots of food. The golden Gai area is about a 5 minute walk away and not once did we feel unsafe while walking through the streets here. While the actual hotel itself is really easy to access by taking the subway and stopping at higashi-Shinjuku station which is about 150m away from the side entrance of the hotel- don't know why people in other bad reviews were walking from the Shinjuku station (which is only like 10 or so minutes away) when there is a closer station (obviously didn't do enough research).We stayed in a superior double room which was nicely sized and comfortable for the two of us with two big suitcases. Everything was clean and neat when we arrived. Would definitely stay here again and would recommend it to other people wanting to visit Shinjuku

I stayed there on my own over 3 nights (Tue-Thu) and found the hotel to meet my needs almost perfectly: my room was upgraded from single to double at no extra cost; the buffet breakfast was varied and plentiful (make sure you have breakfast after 8am as hotel guests on organised tours can fill the entire place); it was easily accessible from Shinjuku Station and a smaller station (both located within 10-15mins on foot); it was a short stroll to a variety of restaurants, attractions and a major shopping centre (close to Shinjuku Station); the hotel amenities were modern and the rooms were tastefully decorated; there were even some vending machines on the ground floor for snacks, drinks, ice cream, etc; the wifi signal was consistently strong and easy to connect to. The only criticism I would have is that there was just 2 power ports in the room and 2 more in the bathroom and none were shaped to allow non-Japanese power plugs to be connected to them. In preparation for Tokyo 2020, my only suggestion would be to retrofit some power plugs to allow for USB ports charging. Having been used to staying in hotels in other cosmopolitan cities, I was not prepared for this but will be better prepared for my next stay ... which will definitely be at this hotel.

Stayed here for 3 nights. There was only an economy double left when we booked. Otherwise, definitely would have booked a bigger room next time. Having said that, it is Japan. Was expecting tiny rooms already.Room is comfortable enough and very new and stylish. It's clean with all amenities present and ready for use. Only complaint would be temperature control. With the air con on, it gets too cold. Turning it off, the hotel's central heating system gets too hot. Made it quite difficult to adjust to the temperature. Breakfast is good and they have both western and Japanese style breakfast. The mini croissant was especially nice. Make sure you get there early as it gets packed and you will have to wait for a table.The hotel is in a pretty good position. It's close to all the night life in Shinjuku so if you're in Tokyo for that, it's perfect. (Close to Robot Restaurant if you're here for that). Its position will throw you off at first though because it's surrounded by love hotels. Made us second guess whether we were in the right place.As for position to train lines, it is surrounded by a lot of stations but the closest one (Nishi-Shinjuku) doesn't usually take us to anywhere we want and most times, Google Maps will direct us to stations that's more than 10 mins walk away. This got a bit tiring when you've been walking around all day as it is. All in all, this is a pretty good hotel with a pretty good English-speaking staff. However, both my husband and I agree we will probably look for another hotel again next time we travel to Tokyo.TLDR: Clean, new, comfortable. Standard Tokyo sized room e.g. Small but what else are you expecting? Good breakfast. Get the bigger room if you can. Free WiFi. Good if you're exploring Shinjuku. Not so convenient once you need to go around to other parts of Tokyo.

Was upgraded to suite with free standing bath with a city view beautiful hotel quality style chic modern nice staff close to local shops and nightlife restaurants must try the robot cafe very unique and quirky

I hate writing a negative review because the staff at this hotel was extremely friendly and helpful. However the rest of our overall experience made me wish we had booked another place or even switched hotels while we were there. The rooms are tiny which is to be expected in Japan, but the only space for any of your clothes, etc, it a bar when you first walk into the room with 4-5 hangers. No drawers or anything. But the small space is to be expected. Right now the hotel is under a LOT of renovations. We ended up on a floor where it looked like we were the only guests and all other rooms were under construction. Despite coming and going frequently, we had a worker walk into our room while my boyfriend was in the bath and I was about to change. No knock. Nothing. He just barged in. This was distressing on many levels. I told the front desk and requested to switch rooms. They moved us a few floors down. The room was just slightly bigger. The amount of construction happening on the floor was basically just as much. If we had had more time to devote to switching hotels, I would have. Additionally the breakfast served in the morning was terrible. Hardly any options and overall not well made. Again, the hotel staff were extremely helpful but they were the only saving grace of our stay here. I'd certainly look for accommodations elsewhere. Perhaps the hotel will be better after the construction is finished.

Tokyo, Shinjuku, Shibuya can be one of the more difficult places to find a reasonably priced hotel. We became very lucky when booking this hotel. Booked "Free Cancellation" rooms many months in advance for a 4 and 2 night stay in the basic Superior Hollywood Rooms. Then in 1-2 weeks leading up manage to secure Executive Club rooms for the exact same price, so we called the original rooms and booked the much more spacious and refined rooms. The Executive rooms were spacious enough and I would have hated to be a the original room we booked. The Club lounge is very basic. Coffee throughout the day and then from 6-9pm beer and wine. We often had to ask the staff member for more drinks as it wasn't replenished very often. There is also only about 8-10 seats in total. The food consisted of potato chips, pretzels etc. Breakfast was surprising good. Decent western options and local options. The great thing was lots of vegetables, which we ate alot of each morning. The area was great. Baseball batting cages just around the corner along with train lines for the Superdome and anywhere else. Overall - Book Executive rooms for the room, not the club lounge. The views from the room and lounge were amazing. Otherwise expect to be cramped to some degree, expecially if you have large suitcases.The one downside was the very firm beds. Very common in Japan. Some are aware of this but others beware, they are firm. Really firm.

Stayed here for 4 nights over a 2 week trip in Japan. Overall, just poor. Location was at least a 10-20min walk away from most subway stations. Staff at reception were either friendly or completely rude to the point of being cold/ignorant/indifferent. Room is small which is understandable, buffet breakfast was limited and of poor quality. Could not wait to check out of this hotel. The worst hotel I've stayed in during my trip in Japan.

Great hotel - walking distance to many sites and near important train stations. We stayed for 10 days, barely spent time in the room. When we went to sleep it was always tidy and clean, space was small but not uncomfortable - there is an allotted space for everything. It is a great value, especially in expensive Japan.

We tried to book the Double Mature room for the whole 8 nights but it wasn't available, so we had a small room for the first night and the bigger for the remaining. What a huge difference. The economy double room was tiny hardly enough room to open our cases, the bathroom also a squeeze but if you travel light I'm sure it would be ok. The next morning we checked out, left our bags and ventured out, by the time we checked back in our bags were in our new room on the 16th floor. I was much happier with the size of the new room. We had an amazing view, huge bathroom and bed and a free standing bath, small wardrobe and plenty of room for our bags, shopping etc. We didn't have any issues with service in the hotel everyone was professional and helpful. The breakfast was nice with a good selection, I personally like fruit in the morning which it lacked but otherwise no complaints. We used the bar once, had a lovely cocktail, didn't really use the lounge or restaurant so can't comment on those. The coin laundry was used a couple of times but the dryer was not powerful enough to dry our clothes so we had to hang it over the bath. The area itself was lively with plenty to see and do, of course its in the red light area but never felt seedy or dangerous. Its a 10 - 15 minute walk to the station but if you are in Tokyo be prepared to walk anyway so no big deal, I would recommend this hotel for couples or group of friends not sure about calling this a family hotel even though we saw a few there only because of the area.

Good location at walking distance from Shinjuku station and the very animated Golden Gai and Kabukicho area... Rooms have a decent size for Tokyo if you take at least the Superior room. Some of them have a nicer decoration. Currently some progressive refurbishment. Friendly staff. Have not tried it but they have a bar and restaurant at the 12th floor.

I have booked an 11 night stay in this hotel and it was good with some exceptions.I had a round trip in Japan meaning my base was in this hotel but was staying in other cities for couple of nights to explore.The room I got was clean, small but enough for me. Bathroom was a window overlooking my bed which I found a bit weird but interesting. The shower gel, shampoo and conditioner as guest amenities were very good quality and had a nice scent.The Japanese toilet which I couldn't wait to try and play with was such an experience!!My room had a view of the street and some skyscrapers which I really liked. I was visiting in the hottest period of the summer, and the air conditioning was working, although I had difficulties finding the correct setting (if I switched it on after half an hour i was freezing in the room, but when turned it off I'd wake up in the middle of the night sweaty and having to turn back on and off several times to maintain a comfortable temperature in the room).I've made my room reservation including breakfast. For the breakfast I had to show my stamps on my separate breakfast stamp card every morning - I had 11 stamps for my stay but since I was away for 3 nights I had 3 unused/additional stamps. I had a friend staying over with me and went with him for breakfast, the staff said it's not possible to redeem my extra - 'unused stamps' for my friend to have breakfast but they charged me 1300 yen. I found it unfair and unacceptable BECAUSE the card does NOT state in any form that the stamps would be valid only for my name OR only for specific date, whatsoever... So next day I went to see front office manager with my complaint and to make them aware I am not willing to pay for this so I want them to remove this room charge. After a good 20 mins 'argument' which included sharing my views as a 5 star hotel employee from London about why I don't feel this charge reasonable and that I know how it works so will not hesitate to take my complaint further if he can't manage to remove this charge from my account. Well, I have seen the first (and only) angry Japanese person during my trip but he did remove the charge which I asked for, and although his anger was visible and he didn't maintain his welcoming smile as a front office manager, I said thank you and wished him a great day afterwards.The breakfast otherwise was excellent for me, wide range of continental choices, eggs, beans, sausages, fresh bakery and tea/coffee/juices so I liked it a lot as a good start of the day. Also the restaurant had brilliant views over Shinjuku.The housekeeping staff was very polite, caring and hard working, whenever I bumped into them they greeted me with a smile on their face.The staff in general all spoke English but not fully fluent. I don't blame them for this, as it's a global issue, even at train stations I had trouble finding English speaking staff sometimes, I wonder why exactly its this bad in a capital city like Tokyo which is full of tourists.Check in was smooth and timely, check out was quick and pleasant.The rooftop bar is nice although super expensive.There's coin operated laundry room provided for the guests which includes 2 washing machines and a dryer, the dryer is not powerful enough and had to run multiple times to get the clothes dried.The location is all right, it's relatively close to Shinjuku (16mins walk) station, and nightlife is just around the corner.I tried their bar/cafe on the ground floor, was good.The images online are bit misleading as they show the suites rather than regular rooms which are lot smaller.Overall, I was satisfied with my stay, and I would return again with a discounted room offer, to check their newly refurbished rooms.

Japan in general has wifi issues, free wifi is virtually non existent (large monopolies controlling the market) are a huge problem that needs looking at. Having a hotel where the wifi is patchy, weak & slow therefore really irritates you more. The hotel hasn't been fully finished yet (apology notes everywhere) as the cement still dries. Overall not a bad new hotel, there is a recent building frenzy of new hotels on Shinjuku which are pleasant but pretty identikit. Small rooms, modular bathrooms, Chinese speaking staff, windows that won't open and the flattening of Kabukicho. Problem is they are all so similar now in this budget range that problems like wifi issues have a greater impact on the stay. Nice enough, nothing special, construction should be finished 01,01,17

I love the energy and diversity in Shinjuku. It's super modern, sleazy, progressive, bright and dark. Hotel is on the edge of it amongst love hotels and a baseball hitting range amongst other things. Rooms are small but clean and well looked after. Wifi was really poor - I asked for help and the suggestion was rent a wifi mobile box which wasn't helpful.

I've stayed in a lot of places in Japan & they're usually super clean. Unfortunately, the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel falls well below expectation. There was thick dust underneath the bed along with an old bottle cap. Things were the same on top of the TV and much worse behind the fridge. I spent both nights struggling with asthma which improved whenever I stepped outside the hotel. Other than this, the rooms are small but functional with good water pressure. There is a lovely roof top bar and it's close to Shinjuku Station. The area is a little seedy, but very central.

Booked on line and the location plus the quirky rooms were the attraction. Arrived at 7.30 am and left our bags until 3pm checkin. Room was small but very comfortable. Staff were friendly and helpful, didn't use the restaurant but did have a drink in the rooftop bar which has great views of the city. Fridge and tea making in the room. Location was great, in the entertainment district but no noise at all. 5 minute walk to the main drag and stations.

I've stayed in three hotels in the Shinjuku area and this one was my favourite. My room was unique, spacious (for Tokyo standards), the staff friendly and very helpful and the location fairly central. 10 Minute walk from Shinjuku Station which makes it very easy to access all parts of Tokyo. I will definitely be back.

Location and Walk from Shinjuku to Granbell - We visited Tokyo with our 5 year old and stayed at Granbell for a total of 5 nights. We wheeled our luggage from Shinjuku station to the hotel, not knowing that there were multiple entrances and exits from Shinjuku station. (So good to research before coming if u intend to stay near Shinjuku). The walk took a total of 15 mins. Subsequently, without the luggage and being more familiar with the route, it took 9 mins. The hotel is situated in a red light district and occasionally at night, you'll see some touting along the streets. However, it's not obvious nor rowdy, and I can safely walk with my daughter back to the hotel alone at night. Hotel - The hotel is clean and upkept although the lighting at the lobby is too dim at night. We stayed at the room for doubles. it was small but clean and tidy. Hardly any space to place 2 luggages. The bed was comfortable though. the toilets were clean and well provided for and replenished in terms of toiletries. we appreciated the aircon and heating system. We could adjust it and it kept us at a suitable temperature in the room. there was free wi-fi too! On the whole, I think this hotel is more suited for couples or singles. not so for families with children who may need a space to play and run around. Staff - The staff were generally polite and helpful. i was very impressed by the patience and kindness of the staff we met. However, there was one particular staff whose name was Seki. When we asked for directions, she seemed unwilling to help us. She threw the pen on the table, slammed the files filled with maps on the table and didn't sufficiently provide the help that we needed. She avoided eye contact and showed her displeasure on her face the whole time. I was very upset by her behaviour. Maybe she was having a bad day but it definitely did not justify the attitude she displayed. that same day, my husband approached other staff who willingly helped us and were kind towards us. for that, we are thankful. on the whole, the experience was good. the hotel is new and some taxi drivers may not be familiar with the place. will I come back? yes, if alone with my husband. thank you Granbell.

Like most hotels we stayed in in Japan the rooms were tiny (by Western standards). Everything was clean, had all the basic amenities and the staff were helpful. Ideally we'd get a bigger room (I think we were in the Economy room) but it was reasonably priced and fine given that we weren't in the room that much. It was very close to the Metro station which was very handy. There's a good few bars (including the Golden Gai) and restaurants around the area too. There breakfast was fine, with a reasonable amount of choice.

Stayed there for 3 nights. The room was small but had anything I needed. The shampoo n body wash were amazing. Also two free bottles of water are nice gesture.The only thing that was kinda uncomfortable is the distance to Shinjuku train station - a bit far! I finally learnt how to get there from the hotel in two days, before that I had to take a cab:)Also the hotel is located in a rough Kabukicho area - the night life never stops there. But it was still safe.

I chose this hotel because it was immersed in the funky red light district of Shinjuku. As far as accommodations, it's strictly 4-star, which is to say that it's clean and the staff is helpful and friendly, but they don't exactly go out of the way to provide services. We tried to have them call for a dinner reservation in advance of our stay but were told they don't offer concierge services. That said, they were very helpful and patient upon our arrival. Interesting and modern designs are a treat here, but are dampened by things like buzzing vending machines on our floor and an array of laundry and maid-cart accessories that were lining the hallway outside the door of our room for the entire stay.Overall, this hotel seemed to put the others in the immediate neighborhood to shame, so I would say that if you want a cool Shinjuku experience, you can clearly do a lot worse than the Granbell. We paid up for the deluxe double, which seemed like money well spent.

This hotel is situated at a convenient location from both the subway and the shopping malls. The hotel is modern. The rooms are clean and have all the basic amenities. The rooms are a little small though. However for the price that they charged, it is good value.Most of the hotel staff are friendly.

I stayed in this hotel for two nights and before coming, didn't really have much time to search for the best option in Tokyo so I just went with one that had relatively good reviews being this you hotel!! The location from an access point of view is okay, but you don't want to navigate your heavy luggage through the narrow streets of Tokyo to this hotel from the metro station. So do yourself a favor, either have your baggage delivered from the airport or book another hotel right next to the train station. Also, this is in kind of red-light district, very sketchy area filled with ladies services! As for breakfast which is not included in the room service, I had to pay 1300 yen for some cereal and super buttery scrambled eggs (tasted like anything but eggs)! Don't eat in the hotel if you stay here. You can get awesome breakfast if you go to a restaurant for even a better price!! And check-out!! It's at 12 and on my last day, I had just gotten back to my room when I get a phone call at 11:47, reminding me of check-out time and asking me to leave!!! What on Earth??? I have been traveling in Asia for a month, staying in many hotels in different countries, none treated me like this. They also hr construction going on, so it was a mess in the hallway, they gave me a room right next to the construction area in the hallway! Thanks to their hospitality.I guess one cool thing about this place from pictures was the nice artwork in their tiny rooms, well mine didn't even have that. Just plain dark brown.Next time, I'm gonna do my research and stay in a hotel that's worth what I'm paying for.

This is a neat hotel situated in the Shinjuku’s kabuki-cho area, also known as the red-light district. Despite this, it is safe for you to walk in the area even at night.Getting to the hotel is about 15 – 20 mins walk from Shinjuku JR station or alternatively you can take a cab from the station to the hotel which cost around 700 – 800 YEN.There are many eateries near the hotel, hence you do not have to worry about feeding yourself.First impression of the hotel was simple, clean and no frills. However, once you step into the room you will feel comfortable as it was well kept except that the room is small. All the necessities were provided thus this is not a no frills hotel.Breakfast was provided for my reservation. However, if you are someone wanting a fancy breakfast spread, opt out of it since they offer continental breakfast which include porridge and some pickles.The front desk staff was helpful in offering information and directions in/out of the property.Overall, I will recommend this hotel if you do not mind staying a walking distance away from JR or metro station. If red-light district and walking 15 – 20 mins is a concern, then go somewhere else.

This hotel was a great location in the heart of Shinjuku. Our favorite city in Tokyo area. Nice walk to anywhere with great food and train stations.The rooms were very small. We weren't set in a room with a nice mural above our head, which was disappointing. Didn't ask, just wanted to explore the city!Staff were good and the rooftop was amazing. We signed our marriage certificate there.Art around the hotel was nice to see and beautiful.

We had an amazing stay at this hotel's Studio Double, which is a big room (even more so for Japanese standards), somewhat in between a standard double and a suite. The minibar is for free containing non-alcoholic beverages and the amenities include high-quality shampoo etc. and even razor, brushes and more. The bath was spacious with a large shower and bath tub. If you are staying above the 13th floor, you get access to the Club Lounge with free soft drinks, some snacks and wine or beer in the evening. All in all, we enjoyed this hotel as it was clean and well-located (near the famous Golden Gai).

I stayed in the Granbell for 3 nights in late October. The hotel is modern, and while the rooms are small, they are neat and well equipped. The staff are pleasant and speak good English. There is also a nice rooftop bar, a rarity in Tokyo. The service here isn't very good, but it is reasonably priced and has a great view over the city.I'd recommend the hotel for anyone who doesn't speak Japanese, there is a lot of "what's on" information at the hotel.

Had an amazing time in Japan! My dream vacay became a reality! Stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel! It's a beautiful artsy fartsy boutique hotel! I love the decor and front desk! It has this beautiful 3D floral and light display! Modern decor and furnishings and they had my portable wifi as I checked in! I ordered a portable wifi for my trip ( a must in Japan) a few days before and I knew I wouldn't be able to pick it up at the airport, so I had it delivered to my hotel! There is a tv inside the elevator. And this elevator does NOT play elevator music! It actually plays dope Japanese Hiphop! Haha Being a music lover, I totally appreciated the non-elevator music vibe! My room was on the 12th Floor, a floor down from the Rooftop restaurant and bar! I had a much smaller room, but compared to most hotel rooms (my older bro's room was microscopic he stayed in a different hotel), my room was a decent size! I can definitely move around and the view is amazing! Besides, it's like Vegas, you don't spend all your time in a hotel room! So, get a decent hotel and explore!And what can I say, I loved my toilet! It's like a car wash for your bum! Haha Not only are the seats warm, has a bidet and has a dryer, but it flushes by itself! Talk about hi-tech! I seriously need one at home!Lovely amenities and very deep soaking tub! And if you can, get a deal with the daily breakfast! The daily breakfast unfortunately, was not part of my deal, but I tried it anyway! And yessss, their breakfast buffet is sooooo good! And what an amazing view! I was ok with not having the daily breakfast because I was able to enjoy breakfast at other spots! But if you want to save, have your breakfast included! I personally would just try the hotel's breakfast and find your own daily breakfast gems! You're in Japan after all! Eat your heart out! HahaOverall, I enjoyed my stay at the Granbell Shinjuku, very close to the subway station and the heart of the city! You can't beat the Restaurants and shopping galore nearby! And enjoyed the hospitality! Can't wait for my next Japan trip! Tips:-You can take the Yamanote Line to Shinjuku Station, but it will be a couple blocks away and can get confusing if it's your first time! I recommend taking the back door of the hotel, walk 2-3 blocks to Higashi-Shinjuku Station and take the subway to Harajuku or Shinjuku Station to get back on the Yamanote Line. That will take you to all the major stations.-Your door keycard turns on the lights. I struggled finding the lights to turn on as I got to my hotel room. I didn't realize there was this slot by the door/closer to put your keycard in and it automatically turns on the lights and tv in your room! Love the hi-tech stuff!

Ignore the comments about the rooms being small, this is Japan, inventor of the capsule hotel. It would be unrealistic to expect huge rooms in a city where space is at a premium. The room may be smaller than what you'd expect in a western hotel, but it's very well designed and comfortable. The sofa opposite the bed is a great idea and makes the whole space much more sociable.Added to this, the clean and modern style and you've got a great hotel in a great location, with many restaurants / bars etc nearby. Staff were very helpful and the wifi was fast (even managed to use Netflix). Great place to stay while in Tokyo!

First time staying in a Japanese hotel room and I gotta say that it was a pleasurable experience, even if it was just one night. I will definitely come back to this hotel and stay there for a longer period of time.

Location: Far from the Shinjuku station (and I like walking!), go to the Nigashi-Shinjuku station instead. Not really on the main strip or in center of Shinjuku so room was quiet. Hotel room was great: clean, cozy, comes w/ lots of toiletries, also slippers, kettle, fridge, etc. One TV channel available in English (CNN). The rooftop bar is nice if you want to wind down after a long day of walking. Staff was very helpful, polite, spoke English. The one thing that ruined everything for me was the lack of wifi. They advertise the hotel as having wifi but the reception is terrible and it drops every 10 seconds, literally. So it is false advertising. It is difficult when you are relying on it for finding restaurants, information about touristic spots, etc. The location (far from Shinjuku station) and NO WIFI mean that I would not come back.

You'll make a few compromises at this hotel, but it is a terrific value.The Granbell is in Tokyo's red light district. As other reviewers have noted, this isn't the red light district that a Westerner would imagine. I found it clean, well lit, and so quiet it was almost peaceful. It is convenient to several train lines, too. One night I took a few wrong turns and ended up in a more seedy area (right near the Robot Restaurant) but even then a firm 'no' was enough to dissuade the touts.The Granbell is also a massive property, and the service was a bit impersonal. Still, my room was large by Japanese standards, with a terrific view and a spacious bath. There was a mini fridge as well. Terrific lighting. Housekeeping was prompt and efficient.The downsides? Water pressure from the sink was awful, and I found the wi-fi unreliable. It's also surprisingly noisy during the day. There isn't much soundproofing, and the staff are very talkative. Windows do not open, although I wasn't expecting them to.You can find a better hotel than the Granbell, but you'd pay for the privilege. I'd stay here again if I could.

Tiny room with stylish design, excellent location, very close to the shopping area & JR station. Staff English is ok, at least we can communicate. Smoking room is based on the ground floor. Another wing of the hotel is under construction.

I tend to book hotels long in advance of a trip, it's always a treat to see where I have sent myself. Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is in a tight cluster of hotels and night spots. I couldn't quite remember when I first got there why I booked this hotel. Then I remembered, due to its proximity to The Robot Restaurant and the "Redlight District" of Japan. I put "Redlight District" in quotes because I think Redlight implies dangerous and lurid. As a solo female traveler this can be a bit touch and go, but I never felt unsafe or concerned in this neighborhood. I did like looking at the signs for the maid restaurants. It was fun neighborhood with a great nightlife and there is a donut shop two blocks away. The hotel itself is modern and stylish with the necessary amenities. I was not disappointed and the location was great.

Stayed at the Granbell Shinjuku for 7 nights in total, which was our final destination after a month and a half honeymoon trip in New Zealand. Location : Central but quiet, 5 min. walk to subway (Higashi-Shinjuku) or 10 min. to the main Shinjuku station. 5 min. walk to Golden Gai Bars.Hotel and staff: looks new, friendly staff, fast check in and check out. Vending machines available on the 1st floor along with a cafe and a restaurant at the 12th and 13th floors. A small gift waited for us due to our honeymoon which was nice and thoughtful.The room: small as expected, especially with lots of luggage that we had but we managed. The room was clean and had everything we needed, including a nice view from the 10th floor. Bathroom was spotless and had lots of gadgets and disposables (toothbrush, hair brush, hair bands, shaving cream, shaving razors etc..). The bed was not too big but comfortable. Free bottled water everyday was a nice thing to start our day with...General : Breakfast, though not included in our rate, was good and had plenty of things to choose from (though no cheese of any kind?). 1300 yen a person was reasonable and good value for money for the single time we tried it.Overall, we really enjoyed our stay and I think it's one of the best value for money deals you can get in Tokyo where hotels aren't cheap at all...

Staff does not speak good english. Breakfast is ok. Restaurant does not serve japanese food for dinner. Nice view of the rooftop bar but they sell a bowl of popcorn 15$. Hotel does not exchange money. They ask for 400 yen to call a taxi for you. Room really really small.

This is the 1st time we have stayed in this hotel, the room is very nice and spacious.We like the bath room with a bath tub and shower/toilet separately.The location is still OK if you don't mind to have a 10-15 min walk away from the Subway.Surroundings with "Red Light" area which i personally think this hotel would not highly recommend for the family travelled with kids.Overall, it is good with convenient stores and restaurants near by. They also have few sets of snack/ice-cream/drink machines at the Lobby floor.

Locationed at the heart of Kabukicho~ it's close to a lot of things~ harder to find at first but once you found it, you can't miss it~ We chosed a loft since there were 3 of us~ the loft was pretty spacious~ We didn't chose to have breakfast in the hotel because it's close to a main street and we decided to have breakfast there instead~ all in all, a nice little hotel~ clean and convenient~

Nice hotel, modern, clean, nice rooftop. The location is a short walk to Shinjuku station. There are similar hotels closer to the station.
