The neighborhood is a red light district and has that vibe so you may want to avoid this hotel if you are sensitive. We found the area intriguing. Maybe not for a long stay.

Modern hotel in excellent location as only 10 min walk from main shinjuku station and loads of restaurants and buzzing streets on hand. Apparently on fringes of so called red light district but very tame and discreet so no problem with kids etc. Hotel itself is very quiet.Staff very friendly and service good, although we didn't take breakfast there.Rooms are pretty small - could only access double bed from one side and not much room for luggage, but this appears to be the norm unless you want to pay big money. However it was well equipped and had everything you need including hairdryer, complimentary toiletries, bottled water and tea and coffee making facilities. The bed was also very comfortable.Would defintely stay here again and would have given 5 star rating if room had been bigger.

we stayed a 2 nights before getting on a cruise. Shinjuku is an inner suburb of Tokyo and well placed. we arrived at Narita airport and caught the Express train to Shinjuku (3rd stop). Taxi had a little trouble finding it but 2nd try success. Hotel staff were very nice and helpful when we arrived at 8pm. Room was small as warned on previous review but comfortable. Is in 10 minute walk to park, 5 minutes to shopping centre. Hotel has rooftop bar with meals at reasonable prices. Breakfast included was good variety. We went into to Tokyo to see the lights and were told to go Shinjuku. Very alive at night and lots of restaurants.Has a banana split pancake in a cone washed down with a berr, Better than you might think.

If you are looking for a nice hotel close to Kabukichō, Shinjuku station and Golden Gai this hotel is perfect. Everything is within walking distance.The staff is perfect, they speak good english and the service was very good.The room was nice and clean and luckily not too small (after all it is Tokyo).Breakfast is okay, you can have Western and Asian food and the view is fantastic but if it's not included in your room I wouldn't pay extra for it. There are plenty of coffee places around where you can have breakfast.

In keeping with Japanese service, it's a clean and organised hotel. It has a bit of an art feel but it seems to be missing something. I only stayed in an entry level room, but I'm sure the more expensive suites offer more visual appeal and luxury. The breakfasts were disappointing. The views from the hotel are great. The narrow and awkward parking space was a little inconvenient because it involved a lock and chain and I needed to call for assistance every time I came and went. The location was convenient although you find yourself in amongst brothels and hourly motels wherever you look. This became a bit much after a while. Especially seeing that the hotel was being used for escort services.

This hotel was kind of off the beaten path being in kabuki - cho but it was clean and modern. Our room was tiny since we opted to get an economy double. But the amenities are good and the bedding was very nice. The staff was very friendly and helpful-we needed to go to a clinic as I forgot to bring one of my medications. They directed me to a clinic close by where they spoke English. Also they stored some our luggage for us while we traveled to other parts of Japan until our return. The coin laundry was a plus but wish the dryer worked a bit better. They also provide you with umbrellas should it rain.The buffet wasn't bad for the price and the view was quite nice from the 12th floor.The only downside is that it's quite a walk from the train station so if you're out of shape or elderly, you'll need to take a cab. But it is in the heart of kabuki cho where there are a lot of eating places and bars and despite all the bar/restaurant solicitors hanging outside, it was quite safe to walk around.

Beautiful new hotel, very modern, great buffet breakfast, outstanding service and rooms are rather large for Tokyo hotels. All fixtures work well and bed very comfortable, the location is great for transport and night out in shinjuko. Very much recommended

We booked the Designer Mature room for 6 nights and we loved the size of the room and amenities provided in the room. His and hers amenities, disposable flip flop to be used in the room, great shower, humidifier in the room and 2 bottles of free water daily. The location is right at the red light district which didn't bother us at all, feel safe to walk around and no issue. The only thing with the location is not close to subway or shinjuku station (around 8-15 mins walk), so could be hectic when you have multiple luggage and taking it thru subway. We option for luggage delivery service from the airport so we have no luggage with us on arrival and able to explore the city right away. When leaving, we took a taxi (about 1450 yen) to Shinjuku station and then limousine bus to Haneda which was pretty good (Considering we have 3 luggage and one carrying on bag)One last thing, we tried to get 30mins complimentary late check out and they can only offer it with fee. they are very straight on the check in and check out time and the front desk staff is ok friendly at most.

I stayed here for 7 nights recently & it was a very pleasant stay. It's conveniently located close to Shinjuku station so after day 2 I knew my way around the area. Room's are nice & quiet even with being near host club's/restaurants & a major train station, staff are very welcoming & helpful. The washing room is open 24/7 which is really nice & it's very reasonably priced, but the only downfall is that there are only 2 washing machines & 1 dryer, I would definitely suggest putting in a few more. I would definitely stay here again.

Friendly staff but terrible wifi, late check in not ideal when arriving on early morning flight, shower good, room fine but no way a 4 star hotel. Area is fine and close to lots of nice restaurants, most have English menus and if not you're in Japan, live a little and try some new foods

Nice enough hotel, reception good, room was tight to say the least. looking at photo of booking they must have used a very wide angle lens as it did look big. Only stayed a night, pleased it wasnt more.

We had this booked for us by a travel agent as a stop over on our way home to the UK. The room was very compact and small which made us laugh!! It had literally everything that we needed for our stop over night and was so clean. Good for one night but if staying longer, I would need somewhere alittle bigger, could be a claustrophobic I would imagine if you were coming back to it after a night but it was very quiet and we did have a good nights sleep, I must admit. We did go up to the roof top bar for a drink which was very pleasant and actually ate in the restaurant, a good, adequate meal. We tried walking around the area but were unsure of the restaurants and some of them did not look very accommodating so ended back at the hotel.

A group of 5 of us travelled to Tokyo and had 5 nights at the Grandbell with a 3 night stay sandwiched in between at Nagoya.The hotels location was spot on with the night scene of Shinjuku very close by and access to the underground 10 mins away.The hotel rooms are a good size for Tokyo and kitted out well. The staff are attentive, welcoming and very helpful. However, as with most of Japan check in times are strictly adhered to and if you want to access your room before the check-in time be prepared to pay 1000 yen per hour prior to check in.The roof top bar is a nice touch and is a little expensive in terms of beers but on par with most hotel bar prices. We were paying £9 a pint at the time of the stay but due to struggling £ in the exchange rates things in general were expensive on the trip.I had read the scare stories of pestering Nigerians and Shinjuku been a sleazy area but if anything it's people who've led a very sheltered travelling experience if they think it's bad. The Nigerians are there and do ask if you're interested in going to clubs and pubs but it's marketing and with some bars been in some instances 3 or 4 floors up how else are they going to promote there bars to tourists.I found Shinjuku a fun and very safe place to visit. At no point did I feel threatened and there are lots of people about even at 5/6am. Enjoy the experience and make sure you get to Golden Gai.

The hotel is conveniently located next to several attractions. We walked everywhere, so that was nice. Getting there was pretty easy as well since their website gave detailed instructions. The view from the superior deluxe room was awesome and the room had a king size bed! There was also a full size shower and tub. The staff was very knowledgeable and friendly. The hotel also provides several brochures with where to find sushi, money exchange, late night eats. Breakfast was interesting, nothing great but sufficed. I would definitely stay here again.

We stayed in Superior Hollywood Twin Room, the room was small. I checked under the bed since I thought I dropped my phone, and what I saw is that under the bed is so dirty. It looks like they didn't cleaned/vacuum it for months and then only cleans what's around you that you could see. The staff/ front desk are so so friendly and nice. The breakfast was ok.

The Granbell Hotel is in a great location with an easy walk to Shinjuku station through some really interesting cultural parts of Tokyo. It's quiet but you're only minutes away from bars and cafes, it's supposed to be the red lift district but Tokyo is incredibly safe and the people are so nice that you feel very comfortable there. The bars advertising male escorts are more amusing and interesting than seedy, nothing like red light districts in any other country I've seen.The staff at the hotel were very helpful, sweet and friendly (as was everyone we met in Tokyo actually), the hotel rooms are small but this wasn't a shock - we live in Hong Kong! The rooms are designed really well to make full use of the space - there's a safe, full mirror, small wardrobe etc so we didn't struggle. The bathroom was lovely with a heated toilet seat and mirror so even after a hot shower it didn't steam up, amazing. The rooftop bar is lovely, but expensive. We went there when we first arrived so we could plan our next moves and relax a bit before going out and it was perfect for that purpose, but there are many many more cooler and cheaper bars elsewhere. Thank you to the staff at the Granbell for being so welcoming.

Granbell hotel in shinjuku is located in a really good area. Very close to most main attractions otherwise a few minutes walk. The staff are very friendly and welcoming however cleaning staff are extremely loud even at early hours of the morning. We heard overly loud conversations at 730am which was frustrating. Our room was extremely small and barely had room to move. You'll have to pay quite a bit to stay in a bigger and better room. The rooftop bar/restaurant was really fun to hang out at. The food was nice and had very nice staff.

We stayed in a twin with a loft room and with three people staying for two nights is acceptable any longer then the space would be an issue and the person who will use the loft bed will need to be agile and not afraid of steep stairs. Otherwise a great hotel. Staff were very accommodating with keeping our luggage safe until check in time and flight time. Cleanliness like with most of Tokyo was faultless. The toilets by the lobby was the best I saw in Tokyo all singing and dancing. Umbrellas were available for use on rainy days.Location was a very short walk to the metro (take the back entrance of the hotel to Higashi) Location also holds an array of restaurant and eateries and convenient stores all very useful.

Stayed here last week , rooms on website look big and modern , we decided the photos must have been taken with a wide angle lens as the room was so tiny we were shocked ! Very clean , comfortable bed tiny bathroom , staff ok . We had nowhere to put our luggage had to shuffle past each other , I've been in bigger caravans , thankful we were only staying for one night

This hotel has a lovely rooftop terrace with great views, serves food (not Japanese) and drinks. The decor is modern, the staff were extremely helpful respectful and friendly. Room was small as expected but felt nice. Hanging space for about 6 items - bring coat hangers! Bathroom was small but modern and nice. Great location in Shinjuku. Didn't eat in the main restaurant, so can't comment on that. Would definitely stay there again.

It was my first time to Shinjuku, I went there with my husband. The room was tiny although I have booked a "larger" room type. We stayed for 3 nights, Housekeeping did a great job to keep the room clean. They were generous on giving amenities. Shinjuku Granbell is a stylish hotel, its decoration is quite cool. The location is quite close to train station, it takes 15 min walk from there. Many restaurants and entertainment nearby. As it close to Soho area, I personally think it is suitable for couples instead of family.

Room was nice, with comfortable bed and very quiet. It felt new and clean and had a few touches to separate it from an average four star hotel. Good wifi, helpful info in the lobby and good aircon (a respite from late summer heat).The location was convenient, close to a few different Shinjuku area train stations so connections to the rest of Tokyo were quick and easy. Not that we ever needed to leave the area for dinner with heaps of options nearby. Note the hotel is at the northern end of kabukicho (red light district), perfectly safe and no worries at all but some may not enjoy that aspect.Thanks for a good stay.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for a few days. It was clean and fairly spacious. Breakfast was included with room rate and was fabulous! It was in busy Shinjuku area with lots of restaurants around and easy to find.

I stayed at this place for a total of 3 nights, the price was reasonable, it was easy to book and I read some good reviews about the place. I arrived at the Shinjuku rail station which was quite far from the hotel, it took me a long time to find it after walking through the maze being Shinjuku and the help of local people and a map. The place is located in the slightly rougher area I would say but the hotel itself is modern and of good quality. The reception is very kind and helpful and also speak good English. After I checked in I went to my room which was a single room and pretty small but I guess in Japanese standards this is a standard room. It was enough for me, it had a bed, tv, shower and bathroom (window to the shower from the bed). Breakfast was also pretty good, it cost me an additional amount. The hotel is close to the Samurai museum but other than that I wasn't too impressed by the location, I always ended up getting lost in Shinjuku trying to find the hotel. If I would go back I would not pick this hotel for that sole reason and that is why I rated it 3 starts. All other things were great, good quality, great service and clean at a reasonable price.

A very nice place I want to stay there again close to the city downtown and close to the nightlife. The room was nice it was an OK size and hotel staff was very polite and very helpful. The best of it was Lucifer so you can see most of Tokyo city. And the best part of it what that there were subway station close to the hotel. I will definitely visit the city and stay at the Grand Bell again.

Our group of 6 stayed 2 nights in 3 rooms on the 6th floor. This was our first hotel stay after a 14 hour flight. Our check in and front desk experience was fine throughout our stay. We received assistance with the questions we had about options for eating and getting to places we wanted to visit. The rooms were really small. The website photographs may lull you to think they are larger than they actually are. Getting into bed was ok on one side, but you need to crawl in/out of the other side. The bathroom was also small, and had a pocket door that was partially blocked by the toilet when fully open. The room and bathroom were clean and well made up. The bed was comfortable. The best part of the stay was breakfast on the 12th floor. The space is large, with many windows that show off the surrounding area. The buffet options were many, so we always left quite satisfied. The closest metro station is Higashishinjuku, about 3 short blocks away. To get to the hotel and leave when we checked out, we took taxis. The fare to Shinjuku station was reasonable. Nearby there are 7/11s where cash can be obtained. My rating of average s directly related to the room size. With a bigger room, a very good would be in order.

If you're reading this then you're probably considering booking Shinjuku Granbell Hotel for your trip to Tokyo.Don't.With most reviews, I like to start with the good points. Unfortunately, with this place, there are none. This hotel is located in Kabukicho i.e. the red light district. If you're a virgin, sleazebag, off your face, or just generally lacking morals, this place is ideal. If however, your idea of a nice holiday doesn't involve brothels, prostitutes or strip clubs, this isn't the place for you.Every evening when walking the 10-15 minute journey to the hotel from Shinjuku Station, we were harassed by Nigerian males continuously trying to pressure us into strip clubs and massage parlours. Sometimes they wouldn't take "no" for an answer and followed us down the street. We often had to take a taxi at our own expense just to avoid the confrontation. Many people comment that they never felt unsafe in Japan. I would agree with that statement everywhere but Kabukicho for this very reason.The hotel itself was the worst part of our holiday though, to the point where we didn't want to spend any time there.Our room was microscopic. You have to be a hobbit or, better yet, a Borrower. The rooms they mainly advertise online are like the penthouse suites, which gives you a really false impression of what you'll actually get. Even the pictures OF our room don't give you an accurate impression of the minuscule size.As we were staying for 11 nights, we had 2 large suitcases and 2 smaller suitcases. There was absolutely nowhere to put them whilst still being able to enjoy and use the room. We called reception and explained this, but the only alternative they gave us was to pay an extra £50 per night for another room.The bathroom also wasn't clean. We found a pubic hair on the toilet seat when we arrived (nice), and hairs in the bath. The grouting and shower hose were mouldy, and there were soap marks in the wash basin and on the taps.The bath tub was so small, I couldn't sit in it unless I had my legs crossed and I'm only 5'2.During our stay, we had to use the 'laundry facilities' at the hotel. I'd use this term loosely, as it was actually 2 washing machines and 1 small dryer for a hotel with around 15 floors.When we checked the laundry room over different days, the washing machines were always in use, so we waited until 12.30am one morning thinking we'd be able to get in.Nope.Due to the length of time we had to wait for a washing machine AND the dryer, it was 5.40am by the time we finished. When we woke the next day it was almost evening, meaning we wasted almost an entire day due to the lack of washing facilities.When I complained about this to a receptionist, she actually suggested I leave the hotel and use a laundry mart in Shinjuku. I pointed out that it was 2am at this point and didn't want to leave the hotel so late at night. She just shrugged and told me to wait then. I asked if this was the first time someone had complained about the lack of washing facilities and she said "no, but the managers don't listen so what do you want us to do".Whilst also waiting for a washing machine, we saw a sex worker leaving a guest's room, as well as a half naked gentleman wearing a bra and pants parading down the hallway to collect his clothes. This was made all the more disappointing as this was supposed to be our proper honeymoon combined with our first wedding anniversary. The hotel knew this, but still weren't willing to help us.I should point out though in case they respond to this review, they did give us a free gift when we checked in - 2 roses made from what looked like face cloths. Compare this to our 1 night stay in Kyoto's Hotel Granvia who took a photograph of me and my husband and framed it for us as a memento of our special stay.In a country where everyone is so friendly, helpful, hard working and polite, this hotel really is an exception. I am baffled at how many positive reviews the Granbell Hotel has on here because it was just so disappointing.Also, a note to the hotel staff, please don't bother responding to this with some copy-and-paste response such as "we're sorry, we take your comments on board, we'll feed it back, we hope to welcome you back soon" because that's useless. You had an opportunity to help us whilst we were there and you didn't, so any reply now will be worthless.If you really would like to apologise, a partial refund would be fantastic.To everyone else reading this though, please don't make the mistake we did. Japan is too special a place for your holiday to be ruined by a sub-standard hotel. Spend a little extra cash (it will honestly be worth it) and book a hotel closer to the station on the side closest to the Government building. The Hilton and Keio both looked lovely.We can thank the Shinjuku Granbell for one thing though: we now know what a truly horrendous hotel is, so all our holidays in the future will seem positively fabulous.

Average hotel , room size pretty small , staff polite and courteous room was very clean . Beware though hotel is situated in the roughest part of the whole of Tokyo , so wouldn't be going out at night too much !!

Hotel is not easy to find. Cab drivers took a long time to search for it. The hotel name is not prominent enough for you to spot it. It is about 5-10min walk to the nearest train station. There are pubs/clubs around the hotel, not advisable to walk alone at night. But overall it's safe. (Although I see people drunk-walking in the area in the morning) Generally Japanese people are very polite and friendly but the hotel staffs are the only ones in Japan that I've met who's rude and with poor customer service. (Not all, but my friend and I each encountered bad experiences) The woman whom I'm dealing with didn't understand what I was trying to say and started mumbling in Japanese with a frown look. Cheapest single room in Shinjuku that I've found. Room is really small and not much space to walk. When you enter the room, it's the toilet, and then 2 steps to the bed with the table adjacent to it. Room is clean and have everything you need. If you're on budget and don't mind the space, this is perfect for you. No breakfast but there a free glass of wine voucher in the room (with min purchase). Nothing special.

The reception and breakfast Staff were always so helpful and courteous and attentive. Room was minuscule, the loft room had barely room for 2 people to move together at one time and no room for suitcases to be out open, ever. The Loft bed had very little head clearance and the bathroom was a hot box. The mattress on the loft bed wasn't much for back support than a futon. It was a rough sleep for 5 nights. The location of the hotel was good, close to the 305 and 302 and not far from the Shinjuku JR station and subway lines too. And there's so many bars, clubs, restaurants and shopping nearby to choose from. Morning runs were doable along the 302 and 305 before 7am, afterwards would become a frogger nightmare times 100. Breakast buffet wasn't too bad, had a nice salad bar but not a great option of warm food for vegeatarians or gluten free folks. Some cereal and milk or yogurt. Some runny, yellow orange scrambled eggs, rice and beyond old Kimchi, undercooked thick fatty ham, sausage and dry and overbaked croissants. And no sriracha, thank goodness they at least had Tabasco. Was disappointing at the fact there was no gym considering the overall size of the hotel and their wifi was unbelievably slow and intermittent.

Was here for two nights on our honeymoon. The hotel is in walking distance to main area of Shinjuku and around 10 minutes walk to station but not as easy if you have lots of luggage. It was a very nice stay and I would come back.The Good:- Decent price for a nice hotel in Shinjuku area.- The hotel looks newly remodeled, and modern- The room is nicely but similar to most Japan hotel, it does not have a lot of room for luggage. - all staff we talked to are very helpful The not so good:- The room was the Economy Double and one side is right at the wall and therefore it make it harder for one person to get out. Over all I would suggest to stay at this hotel as a nice stay.

Great hotel. Modern and stylish fit out. Room was spacious (in comparison to some other hotels stayed in while in Japan) with everything you need while traveling. Central location, walking distance to shinjuku station and a lot too see and do in the shinjuku area.

My wife and I were staying at Shinjuku Grandbell Hotel for five nights during May 2016. The hotel is absolutely newly renovated. We stayed in a standard room, which was decorated in modern style (somehow like a boutique hotel room in minimal style). But the room size is definitively small and without a closet. Other features of the hotel includes a restaurant, a cafe and a bar. However, it is lacked of relaxing facilities, such as a gym, sauna and Jacuzzi. Other short coming is cleanliness. There were something like tiny pieces of biscuit on the yukata provided in our room. Besides, outside the window of our room were array of antenna; I believe they affected our sleeping quality. I should have requested to change our room and I regretted I didn’t ask for. I strongly recommend others, if in case staying at that room, to change their room. The location of the hotel is okay, as explained in its official website, one has to expect a 10 minute walk from the JR station to the Grandbell. Anyhow, it is easy to access the shopping and dining area of Shinjuku. The neighbourhood was interesting with a lot of clubs and love motels yet still safe. Even we didn't go for the clubs, we could still see drunk people while we went out in the morning. We enjoyed watching them (it was culture anyhow) so it was okay for us.

Great view from our window. Well presented room. Clean modern bathroom facilities. They have thought of everything . Breakfast is provided with your room. There is a roof top bar which we frequented at the end of each day. The staff are helpful, friendly and knowledgeable. Arigato.

My husband and I were there for 5 nights. The area around it is the Japan with billboards everywhere, lots of restaurants, always busy with people. Lots of motels around, so the crowd can be "interesting". The hotel itself is great. Staff was very helpful. Room small but clean, comfortable bathroom. Restaurant is definitely overpriced, with a boring menu considering the food you can get at restaurants nearby. Not close to subway (options are about 15 min away, walking) but once you get to it (and we got lost multiple times, I'm sad to say) you can get to other areas of the city pretty easily.

This is my 2nd time in this hotel. Modern hotel, nice clean rooms (small) good service. Located near station providing easy access to all areas of Tokyo. Walking distance to main shinjuku shopping and entertainment areas reasonable room rates

We visited Japan for our honeymoon and our first stint was at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel.The hotel was excellent. The staff very friendly and were happy to keep our luggage on arrival and also departure. We even got a little gift as it was our honeymoon! The room was very clean and spacious (we had an executive room). The fresh water & green tea each day was welcomed.One thing to note was that out of the several places we stay, this was the only one that wouldn't book a restaurant for us. Many restaurants don't let you book online and require you to go through your hotel concierge. Being told "no" was a disappointment.The location was fantastic. It was just a short walk from Shinjuku station (connects to ~everywhere) and the entire area is very vibrant and lively. Several great alleys for food / drinks are within walking distance plus there's restaurants, arcades, bars and shops right by. Whilst there's lots of "love hotels" in the area, it felt very safe and we had no issues at all.The restaurant is OK. I enjoyed my meal there but my partner didn't. The breakfast was poor and we ended up skipping it To be honest, being in Shinjuku there's plenty great places for food in the area so the restaurant quality isn't too much of an issue. The bar had a good selection of drinks and was very pleasant plus our room gave us access to the another lounge that had free soft drinks, tea, coffee & nibbles plus between I think 5pm-7pm, free beer & wine. It was a nice place to unwind.So yeah - Shinjuku was fantastic and aside from the food, everything about our stay at Granbell was excellent. If you're planning on going out for food then I'd definitely recommend staying here.

We were treated to a perfect check in experience and a pleasant room when we arrived at this hotel. The room was clean as a whistle with plentiful and useful amenities, a comfortable bed, hot shower, heated "seat" and room to spare. We were in transit with two large suitcases, two small ones, a backpack and duffel bag. All were stowed out of the way easily. We could move around the room with no issues. I would call the room massive compared to others we have had and seen in this town. Of course, it wasn't massive - but I did learn for sure that how a room size is described in Japan tells more about the describer than the room. This room was tiny by American standards - but big for here - and this is where you are. We would pick this hotel instantly if visiting the area again. The cleanliness is what most impressed us.

Went solo travelling not expecting and boy was I taken by surprise. Highly recommended. Helpful staff and great location beautiful interior and view. Need no more words to say I enjoyed my stay. And would definetly go back.

Great location, nice rooms, friendly staff. All thisis the making of a great hotel. Add a super location in Shinjuku kubukichu AND a rooftop bar and this is just an outstanding hotel, and great value. A perfect base to explore from. Nearest subway is just a few minutes away.

I stayed in this hotel twice during my trip to Tokyo. On my 1st stay, my room was upgraded. I really liked the room, amazing view, great bay window and quite large for Japanese standard. Nice modern contemporary style. The room was clean. Perfect hotel If you want style more than service. The reception staff was a bit cold. The location is a bit far from Shinjuku train station but there is a metro station close by, 1 stop away from the main station. Plenty of bars and restaurants around. Great roof terrace but cocktails are not nice, stick to basic drinks. Breakfast is just average.
user_name:
Bruno V
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Nice hotel to sleep in the shinjuku area.Improvements:The grass in the lobby needs to be cut. Seems like you're walking into a forgotten area.Lobby staff try to do their best. Check-in till 3 pm and they can't move it or just won't.Rooms are small. But you can get the premium double which will allow you to open your suitcase. The rest of the room is convenient for the price.Breakfast ends shaeply at 1030.Too many steip clubs in the area but safe still.

I arrive at 10 AM, check-in should start at 15. they ask me to pay an early check-in fee (1000 yen/hour) of 5000 yen. After some time, we agree on 4000, but not a good start. Wi-fi never working decently in the whole week, at any time of night or day. The single room was a bit too small for my taste (could not even fully open my suitcase)The employees were anyway kind and supportive. The position is quite good, next to Higashi Shinjuku and also Shinjuku Central Station.

Entire hotel has a dryer 100 yen 30mins drying and it don't dry completely. Still need to hang dry. 2 washing machine shared by entire hotel... 200 yen.Safe hotel with card scan lift. Didn't see any security guards though.Room is quite clean except for the carpet floor. Disposable shoes provided.The house keeping is very impressive. The bathroom shower head is turned to face the wall so u don't accidentally on the tap and slash on yourself. They don't throw your rubbish anywhere else in the room except the dustbins in case it's not rubbish. They provided all clean towers and bedsheets. They give u all sets of toiletries daily regardless you used your old ones.Aircon is ok. Tv channels only has an English news channel, the rest are Japanese language. Radio alarm provided. Wifi is free and fast.For Pokemon lovers, there are 2 pokestops in the hotel. I spin them on my bed.Staff is average, not so friendly. No greetings but I'm not demanding any.Train station is 8mins walk away.Shinjuku is nearby, you can travel to anywhere Japan in that station.Lots of gigolo clubs and massage centres nearby. Lots of food around. Near the Korean area where there's Korean food and supermarket. 2 mins walk to 24hr convenient store.Taxi all over the places but expensive for long distances.Only one safety issue. Hope the management can rectify this. The toilet sliding door can clamp your fingers if you do not let go of the handle before the door slides open fully. It's really dangerous as I've got my fingers clamped a few times but not hard enough to injured myself as I've retrieve my fingers fast enough. Room 431

Had a nice experience at the Granbell. Staff was very gracious and helpful and spoke English well. Room was clean and well maintained by staff each day. Location is close to a lot of nightlife and shopping. Subway is just around the corner for convenience. It was a great stay for me.

Awesome. Just awesome. Good friendly staff that spoke English fairly well. First visit in Tokyo and this trip started with a great start thanks to their service style and great rooms with decent views. Spend well and get a better room if you want to make it an even more awesome trip !!

This hotel is announced as a 4* hotel and this is definitely not true. I think an average 3* would be more accurate. The size of the double rooms is kind of ridiculous, you don't even have much space to put your luggage and walk around. Most of the staff don't speak fluent english therefore the communication is not easy and you might be exposed to misunderstandings, even though they are cool people and they always try their best to help you but again the language barrier is an issue till certain extent. The views from the 13th floor are nice, not breathtaking, but the bar's menu is super limited, definitely not the menu that you are expecting at a 4* hotel. I am just being honest and fair in this review, the hotel is not bad located and it's pretty clean, it's not a bad approach to a high end establishment but like I said it has quite a few handicaps.
user_name:
ignaciob456
New York City, New York

review_body: My wife and I stayed here for 7 nights in mid-August and were happy with our experience. The hotel is in a great location, just steps off of the beaten path and in close proximity to the heart of Shinjuku. While the room is the smallest hotel room I've ever stayed in, it was very clean and makes good use of the space. We weren't in Tokyo to hang out in our room and were exploring basically all day, every day. I only interacted with the front desk during check-in/out and they were efficient and had my pocket Wi-Fi that I had sent to the hotel ready for me on arrival without any need to even mention it. The vending machines are nice (miss having them to count on, since they're everywhere in Tokyo) and we got a morning coffee, ice cream and even beer from them. Our room didn't include the breakfast buffet but we ate it at the hotel once. They had a nice selection and a great view. We also had drinks on the rooftop bar a couple times. They're open really late (like many things in Shinjuku) and that was nice to be able to come back to the hotel and still head up there. You may feel that beers are a little pricey, considering I can take the elevator the 1st floor and get one from the vending machine for 1/3 of the cost but they're in line with most surrounding places. The Shinjuku Granbell Hotel served as a great central hub for our time in Tokyo and I'd definitely consider staying here again in the future. There was never a moment where I felt unsafe and it's easy to avoid activities you may not be interested in that are nearby. My only tip is to ignore non-Japanese, English speakers that try to get you into their specific clubs. They stand out and are the only people in the area that walk right up to you to try to stop you in the streets. If they weren't around, the Kabukicho, Shinjuku area would be just about perfect.

PROS- Location: walking distance from Shinjuku Station and Shinjuku-sanchome subway station, so it is perfect for reaching all other Tokyo areas and districts and Narita Airport. The hotel is indeed in Kabukicho (red light) district and is surrounded by dozens of love hotels, but the area is super safe and often so crowded that you should not worry at all;- Rooftop: you can enjoy a terrific view of the area from the rooftop bar, which also serves good and reasonably priced cocktails. Nothing super fancy, but it is frequented also by locals or people not staying at the hotel.- Staff: although their English is very basic, they all were very kind and helpful - Cleanliness: rooms are squeaky clean, although you have to ask them daily to do the cleaning (see the CONS below)- Breakfast: not included in our rate. We tried it once and they had a wonderful buffet with both western and japanese dishes. CONS- Room size: our 9th floor Standard Hollywood Twin (which should nonetheless be bigger than Economy rooms) was indeed small, with no room for luggage and no closets at all.- Cleaning service: they won't clean your room unless you daily ask them by using the door sticker you find in your room. This is ridiculous in a 4-star hotel;- Breakfast: self service only. No table service whatsoever. Makes everything look like an overpriced Starbucks. Once again, unacceptable in a 4-star hotel, which is a pity because the food is great;- Air conditioning: the device to control the in-room A/C is located right beside one of the beds, and has a powerful green light that always stays switched on as long as the A/C is working. Therefore, if you leave A/C on during the night (as it always happens if you are in town during summertime), then the green light shines in all its glory in the darkness of the room. Bear this in mind if you require full darkness to enjoy your sleep.All in all, we did have a pleasant stay and we would recommend this hotel. There are some major cons which are unacceptable for a 4-star hotel that prevent me from giving an extra star.

The rooftop on 13f has a great view. Go for sunset! Beautiful scenery and a "happy hour" limited menu but good! I would had given it a five but the waiter said the wifi is "broken"! Bummer... Would have stayed longer!

Without a doubt, this hotel was the greatest "bang for our buck." I highly recommend this hotel to anyone seeking a place to stay in Tokyo.The hotel itself was very sleek. We stayed in an impressive all marble/mirrored room with a fantastic view of the city. For the same rate, we found hundreds of other hotel rooms that practically only had space for two beds pushed together and looked outdated and dirty. Needless to say, we were very pleased when we found this hotel.The room we stayed in was sizable with a full size king, huge bathroom, and large living room with a massive couch. We stayed on the 17th floor and there were only 4 other rooms on this floor. The accommodations within the room were incredible and welcomed, although some were certainly unnecessary. For instance, the toilet seats were heated and featured different buttons to flush the toilet different ways and the blinds in the bathroom could be raised or drawn by the press of a button. Hey... we didn't mind though. I was also very impressed with what was complimentary as part of the stay. Our room fee included free wifi, which was of adequate speed, complimentary breakfast for all three nights, many toiletries, including bath salts, makeup cleanser, etc., and a free drink card for the lounge. Although this hotel lacked a pool and gym (which are HUGE for me), what was offered overshadowed this inefficiency. Most importantly - LOCATION LOCATION LOCATION. We were able to walk to many of the must-see spots in the Shinjuku neighborhood, such as the Robot Restaurant, National Garden, Tokyo Government building, and many highly raved parks, shrines, pubs, etc. With this location, it was simple to walk outside at night and become immersed in city, walking through streets of neon and popping into little shops/restaurants. Without a doubt, this is the place to stay.

Our double room was way too small to comfortably accomodate myself and my 6.5 ft (2 meters) tall friend. There was no space to move and for a four star hotel, I expect to at least be able to walk around in a tight circle in the room but you couldn't even do that. Service was okay though not overtly friendly as you'd expect in Japan. Room was clean. Wifi was decent. Lots of outlets. Location is in kind of a not so nice area off of the Red Light area of Shinjuku. Wouldn't recommend to families and not the most interesting area anyways.

This hotel is in a great location. It couldn't really have been better value for money on that front. You're right in the thick of it, and only a short walk from the Shinjuku chaos and fun.Echoing the other reviews here, the rooms are teeny tiny. Good luck opening a large suitcase anywhere other than on the bed. Bed isn't massive either, but sufficient for a couple. All the amenities you'd expect to find; safe, hanging space, fridge, bottled water, etc.Bathroom was fine, but also small. Amusingly, provided shower gel, shampoo etc had Lorem Ipsum all over the bottle. Would love to know how that happened.Umbrellas were available to borrow from the lobby, which was handy as we had a spot of rain. Plenty of leaflets and information for tourists.Breakfast was fine, nothing special but not a rip off either.Lots of people have mentioned the customer service. It seemed fine to me, but we didn't really need any help. Your mileage may vary. They mentioned construction ongoing until November, but we didn't hear anything.Overall, a pleasant stay on a great area, and very good price considering where it is.

Clean, modern property in a good location. We paid an affordable price for the Luxury Designer Double / Mature room. It was quite nice. These rooms also came with access to a lounge on the 13th floor. The lounge was small and quaint, but offered free coffee and snacks during the day and free white or red wine during the evenings. It made for a good meeting place for our group. WiFi was complimentary.

This hotel is right in the heart of Shinjuku, easy to walk about to all the bars and shops and easy to get to the metro. The hotel itself was very nice, modern with decent sized rooms. Not the best service in the world but helpful enough. The roof terrace bar was very nice.

OK, I want to be REALLY fair here, because I use TripAdvisor all the time and rely on these reviews myself. I'm not just bashing this hotel but want to give it an honest review. Besides, the hotel had cards on the counter asking guests to review the hotel on Tripadvisor.First the good.The hotel is SUPER clean and pretty nice—it’s minimalist modern decor and is really clean.The breakfast, which was included, is decent. About what you can expect from an included breakfast :) There are some oddities (like eggs with hard yolk and soft whites, and undercooked bacon) but that is to be expected in a foreign country with different culinary tastes. We liked the breakfast.The location is central to Shinjuku, so if you are looking for over the top craziness, then the location is perfect. It is within walking distance of a metro station and about 8 minutes from the Shinjuku Train Station. One note about the reviews that talk about "love" hotels. Someone else said it and I agree, it's not what you think. This is not a red light district by any means. These are hotels that rent by the hour or night for young Japanese couples, and it’s pretty normal for the area. Not an issue at all—all part of the Shinjuku experience.Also, the rooftop bar is nice for a late night drinking it’s open very late so it’s a great place to unwind after a long day.OK, now the bad.We had booked 2 double rooms for my family of 4 (my kids are 18 and 23). My nephew travelled with us so we knew we had to add a room or upgrade when we got there. The rooms are TINY by even Japanese standards. The double bed is up against a wall so it’s impossible for 2 adults to sleep in it. We ended up getting a double/double for my son and nephew and my daughter stayed in the original double we had booked. Me and my wife had to upgrade to a queen. In all three rooms, the space around the bed is about a foot and a half on the side and foot of the bed (remember the other 2 sides are against a wall). The bathroom is OK, but not great. The room is clean, so that's a plus.THE SERVICE IS TERRIBLE. The Japanese are generally extremely courteous and helpful. The service at this hotel is bad on WESTERN standards. The desk staff is uninformed and unhelpful. Anything you ask for, the answer is no. They were very unhelpful arranging or recommending transportation from the airport to the hotel (I contacted them by email). They also knew nothing about any site seeing or places of interest, simply referring to the rack of tour brochures when asked anything. They wouldn't even get us taxis on the last day when we were leaving or book the bus from the Tokyo terminal to the airport. The day before we left, we ended up having to walk 8 minutes each way in pouring rain (typhoon) to reserve the bus.I also observed, while sitting in the lobby at the end of a day, an argument between a guest and the manager. Apparently, the guest was complaining that a woman had used a key to enter this his room (and she was available to confirm it) but the manager was having none of it. The very loud conversation lasted almost 30 minutes. A couple of thoughts: The manager should have taken this man to a private room so this argument would not be on display for all to see. Also, the manager has to think big picture here. let the guy checkout and go to another hotel, like he wanted, and forgo the 2 nights he would have collected vs risking a bad review and annoying at least 15 other guests who are sitting around watching and listening to this. So unprofessional.One thing that was not that bad, but was still very annoying was the lobby coffee bar hours. They open at 10AM, so if you are gathering in the lobby to go out for the day any time before that (which was every day) you are out of luck. It seems a bar serving cappuccino etc. should be open early in the morning. Like I said, not terrible, but strange.Overall, not a great experience. I would highly recommend you find another option for a hotel.

Before our trip to Japan, all we ever heard was how amazing the people are, how nice. I'm sad to say I cannot say that about the people working at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel, who have no understanding of hospitality or good customer service. We're in the middle of our three-night stay, and this morning, I stopped at the front desk to see if they could make a dinner reservation for us at a restaurant in Kyoto that only takes bookings by phone. I was told that they couldn't make a reservation for us if it was for a date we'd no longer be staying at the Granbell. Kidding me? She was not. Unapologetic and unkind is how the Shinjuki Granbell staff are. At $300+ a night, I highly recommend you put your money elsewhere, because this hotel is not okay.
user_name:
Stacey G
Brooklyn, New York, United States

review_body: This hotel was very easy to find as it is approx 500 m from the Odeon line subway station. The staff greeted us very warmly and check in was easy. The room although small had everything one needed for a 3 night stay (room size loses one star). Laundry located on the second floor is convenient, however it could be hard to get your clothes dried at a descent time with only one dryer. Previous reviews indicate lack of drying strength. I put my clothes on for 1.5 hrs (600 yen) and it dried perfectly. This hotel is steps from the red light and club district and near four major subway lines. The roof top patio was amazing and it was nice going up there for happy hour and apps. The constant replenishing of the water bottles was great as we walked approx 15 km every day. The complementary umbrellas that we could borrow for the day also came in handy the day of the Typhoon. I would personally recommend this hotel for anyone wanting stay in a happening area.

This is a new, clean, modern hotel. Our room was tight which remind me of rooms at places like the W. It's a little hard to find and even the taxi drivers couldn't find it with their GPS. Perhaps the hotel is too new for their database. We booked our room via Priceline.com and totally regret it. They charged us much more than the hotel charges if we walked in. Shame on Priceline.

We chose to stay here because we wanted to stay in Shinjuku and this looked like of the cheapest options for an hotel in that part of the city. The overall experience was mediocre: the room was little and featured no wardrobe. Cleaning was kind of superficial and not accurate: we asked to clean once and they did just a quick fix to the room, leaving the bathroom like we left it. The laundry is small: two washing machines and only one dryer!The concierge staff was quite helpful but a little on the cold side.

We really enjoyed our stay here. Very stylish rooms and a reasonable size for the price. The reception is very welcoming and it is a brilliant location for exploring Tokyo. Only 10 mins to the train station. The hotel said they were doing some construction work but this didn't interfere with our stay.

We had a really good experience staying there. Checking in and out was fast, staff were friendly and prompt.The rooms were clean, though wee bit small, but the toilet was a nice size.Location is really good with just a few mins walk to Shinjuku station and many eateries all round the hotel.I highly recommend this hotel and always look to it when I am in Tokyo.

*20-something couple, 2 week stay in a Deluxe Studio*The staff were friendly and helpful. They'll gladly hold your luggage before and after check-in/out. While you're waiting you can help yourself to the vending machines (drinks, coffees, ice-creams, WAFFLES). They provide info sheets and maps in the lobby. There's a laptop & printer there for your use. The place was clean. The room was small with a comfortable queen bed., but that's expected of Tokyo. The room had aircon, a TV, mini bar fridge, kettle, and a modern bathroom. This is all we needed really - didn't even use the TV. The hotel's in the redlight district but it felt safe and very convenient. It's within walking distance of stations, many places to eat, convenience stores, arcades, bars etc. A 10 minute walk will get you to main shopping area. A little further will get you to some beautiful gardens.In sum, we had zero issues in Granbell. I'd happily stay there again.

Even though this hotel is on the middle of the red light district I felt safe during the time I stayed here. The hotel is very modern with comfy beds and air conditioning. The hotel staff were very welcoming and lovely.mif I was to ever go back to Tokyo I would be staying here again.

The hotel is a 10-15 min walk from the JR Shinjuku Station, not a massive slog but is in the middle of Kabukicho (Red Light District), so families beware. The hotel itself seems a bit of an oasis in the desert, set amongst some more lower-grade establishments, as it is pretty modern and civilised once you are inside.The staff were helpful and friendly, and there are a rack of handouts when you walk in for directions to local eateries, getting to certain attractions (Disney/Skytree), metro maps etc., which was very helpful. We found our room to be spacious enough for two, with all the usual facilities you would expect, clean and tidy, which was fine. They even had an English channel - even if it was CNN. The only minor complaint I had was that the air con had an inconvenient habit of switching off after a few hours, which meant the room tended to get hot at night, until one of us woke up and switched it back on. But that's a minor grumble really, they could probably have sorted that if we had asked.There is a rooftop bar and restaurant, and first floor cafe, all charging hotel prices as you would expect (e.g. entry level beer at ¥950), but to be honest there are enough options to eat outside the hotel, so you'd probably only eat here if you particularly wanted European food (French/Italian), and there are probably cheaper options for that too in Shinjuku.A lot of folk have complained about the price and I think our experience was comparable, we probably paid over the odds for our room but we were square with that; given the hotel's location and amenities, and that it was our first trip to Japan, so we were looking for a place that was friendly to westerners. Lots of westerners were staying here during our visit, so clearly others thought the same as we did.Overall not a bad place, a bit overpriced but in a convenient (if a bit seedy) location and a relatively safe bet for first timers here.

Visited this hotel in July .. Our first stop Unfortunately .. Our luggage was held up which in some respects, was a blessing.After travelling all night from Australia via Singapore we arrived here about 8.30 Tired and ready to freshen up...Forget that ... If you arrive any time before 3 pm Go find something else to do .. Because you can't get your too till thenAlso the staff were " challenged " understanding English which made the whole episode even more frustratingAdd to that the fact that the hotel is in a red light district .. Which we didn't know .. And it wasn't pleasant so far ... It didn't get much better when we were given our roomThe smallest We have ever stayed in, and we have travelled the world If you have two suitcases ( which eventually arrived)..hard pressed getting them in the room without running into each other .. Yes it's that smallThey do have larger rooms ..but if you stay here You really need to specify you want a big roomBut you will payBreakfast was adequate with a lovely view over Tokyo.. But a word to the manager... You need two toasters .. And preferably one without a broken toast catcher at the end .. I found myself waiting for my toast to come out of the auto toaster like a wicket keeper in case it fell on the floor The staff just need to be a little more friendly tooUnless you speak Japanese, they are a little shy on communicationRegardless tho, it was a reasonably comfortable place ..and close to Shinjuku stationJust be aware of the above

This was my first time in Tokyo and I picked Shinjuku for it's vibrant nighttime lifestyle. Not sure I would stay in this part of town again, as it was pretty intense. I was however, very happy to have found this hotel as it was a sanctuary from the crazy surroundings of Shinjuku nightlife. It was clean, very comfortable, very friendly and very helpful. It was well priced and It is walking distance from the train station and all the Shinjuku hot spots. They had a great rooftop bar that had a nice view of the city and was an awesome place to have a drink to watch the sunset in the summer. We had a free drink voucher and after a long day of sightseeing, it was a great place for alcoholic relief. If I were to stay in Shinjuku again, I wouldn't stay anywhere else other than here!

The decor and interior furnishings of the hotel are very nice. The staff were polite during check in. Our room was very small with no where to put our luggage. For $300 a night I don't think it's worth it.

We stayed at this hotel for a family vacation after having to cancel an Airbnb. The front desk accommodated us with little notice and since rooms are a little small in Japan and my sons and husband are tall, the girl helping us placed us in a king bed loft the first night and then moved our luggage for the next two nights to another room with two twinXL/possibly full beds and a loft. The first room was more spacious with a patio, but the second room had more bed space, a little bit more of a squeeze. It is a nice hotel, very modern and clean. Restrooms were nice and roomy for showering and getting ready. I viewed a double room and it was a very tight squeeze and beds would not have fit two tall teen boys and husband and wife, glad the lofts were available. The girl even gave us a discount on our stay, which was nice and appreciated. Nice grill and bar on the 12th floor, where we had a couple of drinks with a good view the first night. The third night I went up for a coke and was charged $7, I should have gone down to the first floor for a vending machine coke at $1.50. Coffee at the bistro on the first floor was super small for $4 and it would have been better to go to the Starbucks or McDonalds. It is in what appears to be the red line district and so the nights were very lively and a little scary (although no one bothered us and I know it is safe in Japan). The front desk did have one lady, who on the second night wasn't the most helpful. I had asked if she would call a specialty cafe to make reservations for me and she asked that I walk down to do this. I asked her if she would please take the info and my email and just let me know if they had available reservations, she insisted that I go down to speak with her. So no shower (since I was waiting on the boys to finish showering) and in pjs, I had to clean up quick and dress to go down to ask her to call. She ended up emailing me with reservations throughout the day as we toured and it turned out ok. Other than that, our stay was good!Hotel is about 8-15 minutes away from the subway, depending on which way you exit.

staff have broken Englishnot kind service or welcomingrooms are ok, facilities not comering the price the hotel charge.if you pay in advance at booking or hotels.com - you pay twice than in the original hotel!!!!!!!!!!this is really insolence!we pay 330$ per night - not worth the money...

This was my first holiday with my partner, and the hotel was wonderful.First of all the hotel was clean and had a really nice modern feel to it. When greeted the staff were incredibly polite, not everyone spoke the best English but if they were unable to help they would try find someone who could assist. In the lobby there was plenty of seating available and food in the form of an Ice cream machine and a cafe.The room was comfortable and cozy with everything that you needed; TV, Tea pot and other amenities. Though honestly one of the best things was the toilet, that comes equip with heated toilet seat and automatic flush!Even though there was a lot of warnings about Kabuki cho, we never once felt intimidated by the people around us. There was plenty of convenience stores around us so if we needed something it was a brief walk. Two of the stations were a 5 minute walk away and it was easy to get back to the hotel.I would stay here again in a heartbeat.

Hotel is in great area close to shops and bars. the amenities in the hotel are compact but everything functions very well. The toilet is state of the art.The lobby is plain and effective and there are vending machines throughout the hotel where you can get just about anything you want during the night.Small room, especially if you have luggage, there is simply nowhere to put it. That said, this hotel is perfect for short stays.

First off, before you are planning to stay in this hotel, this hotel is right in the middle of kabuki cho, which is the dodgy red light district. (and I am quite shocked when I see family checked in to this hotel... seriously?...) As to the room, it is decent, but very small (understandably). The bathroom has this strange smell. But apart from that, it is ok. The one thing that bugs me is the staff who dealt with us when we checked in and checked out, especially the girl who checked us out. She was actually one of the few people that was rule to us, and in Japan, I found this to be quite astonishing. Not only was she blunt, she sounded irritated. But if you love to explore the dodgy kabuchi cho and walk around the area, this is the best hotel.

Liked the contemporary look of this hotel when searching online where to stay in Shinjuku. Room was comfortable and clean with coffee facilities, hair dryer and standard amenities. The lobby has a cool cafe culture vibe although turns out you can’t get your cappuccino until after 10am which is a pain for the early birds. The roof terrace is impressive and offers a glittering backdrop of the Shinjuku skyline although the cocktails are a little on the scanty side and the food took a long time to arrive and not at the same time if you’re dining with other people. WiFi is slow with poor access on the terrace. Plenty of things to do and see in the surrounding area, but felt a little too ‘club-culture-esque for my taste.

We stayed at the Granbell over two weeks while in Tokyo. It was clean, quiet and the staff were friendly and helpful. The rooms are...what you'd expect for Japan, slightly on the smaller side, but certainly manageable. You shouldn't come to Japan to spend time in your room anyway! The hotel is close to public transport, the golden gai drinking district and the nearest large main road is only a minute or two walk away. While the Kabukicho area is very close, we never had any issues with safety or anything untoward - my partner went out by himself to grab dinner and only had a few of the women try to entice him in! Would definitely stay here again!

4 of us in the family stayed at the Granbell from July 1-8. Hotel was lovely...the location just off the Kabukicho area was quiet and access to subway stops was fantastic. Rooms were clean and Front staff was very helpful. I made a compliant about the safe in the room and it was fixed within 15 minutes. Talk about speed! Overall highly recommended.

The hotel is loacted in Shinjuku one of the most crowded areas in Tokyo. However, the area around the hotel is silent compared to the area of Shinjuku station. It is very close to the metro station Higashi-Shinjuku (less than 5min walk) and close to Shinjuku station and Shinjukusanchome station. I arrived at Tokyo-Haneda airport and went with JR to Shinjuku station. From there it was around 10min walk. The hotel itself looked modern and clean and the staff was very friendly. They allowed me 30min earlier to check in. The room was a bit small, but I guess you can't expect much for a cheap room in Tokyo. However, it had what I needed: a kingsize bed, which was comfortable, a small table for my laptop and a TV on the wall. The bathroom was very clean, had all toiletries supply and the WC was the typical Japanese ones. Full automatic with water cleaning and heated seat! The most interesting thing was a glass panel in the bathroom. The view was the bed and the tiny window. The wifi-signal was good, tea and coffee were refilled daily and there is also a empty fridge for own stuff.If you are looking for a convenient place to stay which is also close for shopping center, this hotel might be your best choice. As I already mentioned, it is close to several metro station and maybe the best argument to stay there are the shopping center, which are offering tax free shopping on the way from Shinjuku/Shinjukusanchome station to the hotel.

Loved our stay! The room size is what to expect in Tokyo, but it was designed as efficiently as possible so that it didn't feel claustrophobic. Our room had a great view from the horizontal window (larger windows would have been nice), and the hotel was very convenient. Close to multiple train stations and in a vibrant area, full of good food and bright lights. The front desk gave us pretty rose towels to celebrate our honeymoon, and they were prepared with organized recommendations for ramen, sushi, and other restaurants in the neighborhood. The lobby is a good meeting spot. We enjoyed the rooftop bar on our last night. I would stay here again!

This was an excellent hotel for our needs -- a brief recover-from-jetlag and wander-around-Tokyo visit on our way somewhere else. The room was small but very clever in its design, so it was comfortable and pleasant to be in for our short stay. The location is excellent. We walked to/from from Shinjuku Station with our luggage on arrival and departure. Breakfast is extensive and in a nice room with lots of windows on the top floor.

Wow. Tokyo is one of the most expensive cities in the world but the Shinjuku Granbell is a fantastic option for those who want it all: price, style, location, and amenities. We booked an economy double non-smoking. The hotel is immaculate and looks very new. They are doing some expansion and we were warned about construction noise but the rooms were whisper quiet. Fun design that is very Japanese in the sense that every inch of space is efficiently utilized. If you need a huge room you may want to spring for the more expensive rooms. But you really don't need a ton of space. A little more luggage space would have been nice but it's Tokyo, just roll with it. Note: if you can't read Japanese there's a card in the drawer with the hotel information guide that explains how to adjust the aircon. The bathroom was small but great. If you haven't experienced high tech Japanese toilets you're in for a treat. Nice toiletries and free toothbrush, hairbrush, body towel etc. Coffee, tea, and water complimentary and there's a little fridge and in-room safe too. Free WiFi. Great location about 10-15 minutes walk from Shinjuku Jr station. Note: if you're planning on using Google maps know that the GPS signals in Tokyo can be very unreliable because of all of the big buildings. Easiest way to get to the hotel is to go out the Higashi (East) exit of the JR station. Walk straight out and head to the left by the rail tracks. Keep them on your left and when you get to Yasukuni Dori (by the huge LABI electronics store) turn right and then cross the street. Follow Yasukuni Dori past Don Quixote and look for Mister Donut which will be after an intersection and should be on your left. Next to the Mister Donut is a little pathway with signs to the Shinjuku Bunka Center. Follow this path all the way to the end (passing the Citadines hotel on your left and entrance to Golden Gai on your right) when you get to the end of the path cross the street and continue up the little hill (there's a Kyushu Ramen shop you should walk past, keep it on your right as you go up the little hill) follow the hill past all the love hotels (don't worry, despite being a red light area it's extremely safe and taking that path next to Mister Donut has saved you a walk through the gauntlet of touts too) Look up and you should see the Granbell Hotel (you may spot the scaffolding for the construction first) Other tips to note. The Higashi Shinjuku subway station for the Oedo and Fukotoshin lines is about 5-8 minutes walk and you can avoid the cluster of Shinjuku depending on your final destination. Don't miss the 500 yen wine and beer happy out in the lobby cafe. Hope this helps!

The location is amazing. Room is comfortable. My dirty dishes have been sitting in the room for 4 days, Housekeeping does not take them. The light bulb above my bed is out and has been out since we checked in. Housekeeping has NOT replaced any of the mugs or espresso cups since we have been here. The breakfast is AWFUL! For the money we paid for this room, we expected much better service. The wifi is also AWFUL!

Finding a good and reasonably priced hotel in Tokyo is nothing but easy. However, the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is a solid choice. The staff was always very helpful and friendly and gave good restaurant advise.While my room was pretty small, it was enough space for me, had everything I needed (I particularly liked the liquid against badly smelling cloths after having been to a restaurant where smoking was permitted) and it was perfectly clean. Another advantage of the hotel is its location.The only negative point about it was breakfast. I thought it was too expensive for what it was and the quality and quantity of the buffet could have been better. Yet, other than the the Shinjuku Grandbell Hotel offers great value for money.

We had booked a queen room for 5 nights and they gave us a free upgrade to a king room! An incredible surprise. Loved the clean and modern decor, high-end toiletries in the bathroom, wifi worked great, breakfast was a great value, the view from the 13th floor bar is lovely at night. This hotel is a 15 minute walk to Shinjuku station and tons of bars and restaurants to explore nearby.

Stayed here on my first visit to Tokyo. I understand hotels are expensive in Tokyo - this wasn't the cheapest but thought it fair value. The room we had was small - two twin beds side by side with just enough room for a small table, two chairs. If you want to spend large amounts of time in the room you might want a larger room. Frosted glass wall to very small bathroom. Clean and modern with air con. Large window for good natural light. Breakfast was good with mainly Japanese breakfast food which made it interesting. The restaurant is at top of building with great views on all three sides. Location was great as away from busy roads - so very quiet. Yes it's in the 'red light district' but wasn't too obvious nor seedy. I actually found it interesting. Great range of restaurants closeby.

We did our research and knew the rooms are small. They are small. Very small. But it's fine for a few days and the layout makes the most of the space. The bathrooms are excellent and everything is neat, clean and well maintained. The location is terrific. Don't worry about the hotel being in the so-called red light district. The touts aren't pushy and they ignore families altogether. The only direct approach I had was when i went for an early morning run. Weird being offered a "massage" at 6am ....There are heaps of great restaurants nearby and there is the subway and Shinjuku's massive station nearby. Front of house service was enthusiastic buy variable in quality. But there is plenty of local info printed and available in the lobby. Recommended

Stayed for 3 nights. The rooms were reviewed as small.. Which they were but big enough to fit our 2 suitcases and comfortable for our stay. Nice bath and bathroom. Didn't talk to reception staff much due to there being lots of info in the foyer, but staff were friendly whenever you entered the hotel and at check in/out. Close to the 'red light district' which is pretty mad after 9pm, but the streets are safe and the hotel is close to the metro. There is lots of really nice bars and restaurants within a 15 minute walk.

Strictly average all round. Expensive, small room (although probably par for the course for a double in Tokyo) and located in the more dodgy part of Shinjuku. The room was quite modern though, so made up for size to some degree. Staff not very friendly compared to other places we stayed in Japan. Only an overnighter, so bearable, but wouldn't want to stay here longer.

We booked the Luxury Design Double room and stayed for 3 nights. Absolutely love the great view of Shinjuku from our hotel and room.Its about 15mins walk from the station and is located on the outer ring of Kabukicho.A must visit is their roof top cafe that has a beautiful view of the sunset. The view from the breakfast restaurant makes up for their mixture of Continental style and Japanese style breakfast menu. A wonderful hotel in a fabulous location!

Stayed at the hotel for one night in the penthouse "resort" suite for my partners bday. The lobby is a little worn out. Front desk staff were friendly and provided a kind birthday gift. The lobby and hallways are dark, grey with a use of woods and natural elements. There is a large vending machine area to the left of the elevators. The "resort" penthouse suite was beautiful, clean and spacious. Nicely decorated by diesel designers, with large black French doors separating the private lobby to the main room. Floor to ceiling windows throughout. The best feature about the room is the private hot bath outside the bathroom which is encased in stone and glass partitions from the bathroom. Truly relaxing and a great addition to the perfect room. The shower was rain fall and also hand held fixture. The Thai bath amenities are high end and cover all uses. (Hair tonic, gel, shine, shampoo, etc). The bed was comfortable however was more firm not a pillow top. Still had a good nights rest. There is a Dehumidifer in the room and the air conditioning was very strong and worked well. Automatic blinds and sheers surround the glass windows. The floor is hard wood and there was granite throughout. There is a walk in closet as well. Capouncino machine and free water and minibar in the lobby area. Access to the club lounge wasn't anything special. A few selections of nuts, chips and some drinks (cola, water and Perrier). The private assigned concierge was there rarely however he was helpful when he was and gave us directions perfectly. The breakfast buffet differed in quality. The scrambled eggs were barely cooked (which is common in Japan we noticed) and the sausages were raw. It offered some nice salad selections however, and some fresh fruit juices. The rooftop patio bar was closed for renovations sadly, and there was a lot of roof top noise in the morning. The hotel area is right central inside the bar, club and restaurant area. There is some shopping near by and many many Korean restaurants and stores. The red light district is adjacent to it which was pretty sketchy at night to walk the street back to hotel after dinner. You get harassed by men trying To hustle you prostitutes. It's annoying but We didn't feel really at danger just harassed constantly by swarms of them on each corner. Public transit (subway) is about 15 minute walk away from the hotel. It is a congested area on some of the streets in the day so it was a little difficult to navigate with our luggage. You could always avoid this with a taxi however they are very expensive in Japan. Overall for the price I paid for the penthouse I expected more in terms of food quality for the breakfast and club level amenities. But the hotel delivered in terms of front desk and housekeeping service and the room product! The room was beautiful and my partner was very happy With the surprise birthday booking. Thanks for a memorable stay!
user_name:
CanJAD
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Shinjuku Granbell is located minutes from Tokyo's nightlife entertainment district. The check in process was easy. We stayed in a room for 2 with a double bed. The room was small but was well equipped and comfortable. The room was exceptionally clean. We chose this hotel because of the rooftop bar, which was well advertised at the hotel - sadly when we went up to the 13th floor where the bar is located the staff said it was currently under construction. We were disappointed that there were many misleading advertisements for this aspect of the hotel.

Good, clean, quiet hotel. Perfect location away from the hustle and bustle, but still within walking distance to the train, shopping and food. Wide variety of breakfast food options. Stayed in a room with a loft. Perfect for 3 adults.

Great modern hotel in the red light district of Shinjuku. The room is small (as expected) but compact and very comfortable. The views are great and it makes a wonderful base for discovering Tokyo. Don't bother with the breakfast as there are so many interesting and good places nearby.

Warning, the pictures look good but the hotel is not good! The room I had was smelly and damp, I eventually changed this after dealing with a very abrupt staff member. The air conditioning in the second room broke,,,so not a good experience. Also, the hotel in is in the red light district ~ it's safe, but be warned there are nicer areas in Tokyo. also, the wifi is very hit and miss...find somewhere else to stay!

Hotel is in the red light district, but no inconvenience, breakfast is bad, front desk good.I did not know that Kabukicho is the biggest red light district of Japan & the hotel is in this area.It lights up at night, so stay indoors.If you go on the road they ask if you want a massage. Which means sex. With Japanese girls. Breakfast is plain bad. Not worth the 1000 JPY they charge. The shinjuku area is a nice area in Tokyo. Its takes 15 mins to walk from hotel to Shinjukusanchome railway station.Don't go to shinjuku staion ever. Its the biggest in the world & its very complicated.Shinjukusanchome railway station is very good to navigate.Front desk girls are very good and helping.

Nothing super bad but not really impressed. Check in is not until 3pm but they'll hold your bags for you.We paid about $450 aud for two nights (sunday & monday). Rooms are tiny and there is nowhere to hang your clothes Area is very busy, lots of love hotels and girl bars. Make sure you google search before you go into a 'bar' as there's a good chance it'll be a brothel.Might stay closer to main Shinjuku area next time!

The hotel has a very good location close to shoping and dinning area. Nice hotel with a good breakfast (although without fresh fruits). The staff is nice and tries to be helpfull (English language skills could be better). Rooms are rather small but quiet and clean.

Around $400 in cash (20000 yen and around 200 euros) was stolen from our hotel room on Monday June 20th while we were out on a day trip to Kyoto. When we got back to our hotel room my daughter immediately noticed that someone had gone through her suitcase. She had actually taken a picture of her suitcase before we left because she was paranoid that the housekeeping people would steal her new clothes she had bought the day before in Ginza. At that time we just thought they had moved the suitcase to be able to make the bed because the rooms are so tiny.I had put 2 of my credit cards and some of my cash in my backpack that I left in our room in case I would loose my wallet in Kyoto. In only noticed the next morning the cash was gone. Luckily the credit cards were still there. I went to the front desk to complain and they got the manager. He spoke no English so the lady from the desk had to do her best in translating. They told me they would talk to the housekeeping staff and to come back that evening. Later that evening they told me that housekeeping never touch my stuff and that I should check my backpack again. I check the whole room but of course the money still wasn't there. I wrote an email to the hotel this time since communication with the manager was so difficult to tell them that the money was definitely stolen.
