Again they said housekeeping never touched my stuff and that all three people of the cleaning crew are in the room at the same time to avoid any suspicious of theft. I checked for the next few days if this statement was true but it wasn't. Almost always there was one cleaning person in the room, one in the supply room and one in the hall way.The hotel did offer me a discount of 10000yen ($100) which I appreciate but never apologized and kept denying any wrongdoing by their staff.

The rooms were small and compact. The hotel is very basic. No bellhop, minimal service, but clean. Not bad for the price. Location is close to a lot of night life. A bit of a walk to the main train station. The crowd is young. Meant for cheap- middle of the road, travelers. Definitely no more than two per room.
user_name:
TV435
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed here for 4 nights in June 2016. When I took the red eye flight from HK to Haneda Airport, it was too early to check in the hotel. However the staff was friendly to let me put the baggage there and did the admin work before I went back to take my room. Also the location is brilliant, although the it's close to Shinjuku, I chose to take more stops to Higashi-Shinjuku and walked back to hotel for 5 mins walk only. Beside, the room for solo traveler is acceptable, small but cozy. Highly recommend solo traveler to stay there and spend night time in crowed Shinjuku.

Just returned from a short trip to Tokyo with my partner, and friends. We found the hotel online and were happy with the location and the rooms.The hotel lived up to expectations for what it promised and offered. Rooms were clean and always well serviced. The rooms are small, but this seems to be the standard for Japan.My girlfriend's only knock on the place, was the humidity within the rooms. The ventilation system within the bathroom wasn't the best for a small room whilst having a steamy shower. I didn't notice it was an issue.The only negative I have for the place is the buffet breakfast. Whilst it wasn't terrible by any stretch, however I have had better for a 4 star hotel.All in all a great stay, and did the job nicely.

Clean and effective hotel. Rooms small but adequate. Coffee making facilities in room hair dryer. Well stocked toiletries. Impressed with cleanliness. Beware checkin at 3 pm though small cofee shop on ground floor if you need to wait. Reception will hold your luggage in secure location. Free wi fi. Lots of eating houses with lots of choice.

pretty cool, all the rooms are different, designed by a different artist,prices are reasonable, and the location is convenient.would stay there again.If you want to impress a new friend then this is perfect. Not sleazy.

The Shinjuku Granbell is a very cool modern hotel. I stayed in a Superior Designer Double room with access to the Club Lounge. I loved the room. It was very tastefully and smartly decorated, quiet, comfortable, and had a great view. The Club Lounge is very small, has limited hours, and is sparsely stocked with beverages and snacks. The included buffet breakfast was excellent. The overall service level of the hotel is firmly 3 star. The staff seemed disengaged from the guests and the service in the lobby cafe was almost nonexistent. That said, the hotel is reasonably priced for being a new and modern Tokyo hotel. The fatal flaw is the location. It is in a neighborhood of Love Hotels and Clubs. You can't walk around at night without getting interrupted and bothered by solicitors. It's not scary, it's just annoying. We stayed the last half of our trip in Shibuya (planned) and it was really pleasant, so why wouldn't you choose a better location?

This was a very nice hotel but small like most tokyo hotels. Staff was nice and it was clean and comfortable. My only slightly negative was that it was a bit of a walk (uphill) fro,mother train stop. Not that bad but it seemed more convene the when I booked it online than it actually was. Also it's a little hard to find even with Google maps

The hotel is located about a 20 minute brisk walk to the shopping area centre and about a 10 minute walk to the nearest Metro station. We were there sometime in the end of March so the weather was cool so the walks did not bother us. While the area may be a bit scary because of its proximity to the red light district the area is quite safe. The Golden Gai is very near and a very interesting area to visit for drinks. The rooms are small but very clean.

Hotel Granbell's rooms are small (but standard size in Japan), clean and comfortable. Downside is that the location of the hotel is a tad far off from the action and it is surrounded by hourly-rate hotels. It does not feel like a seedy area though, it's still safe!The bathroom is also on the small side. It has a clear glass that has a screen however you can still see shadows and if close enough, the person on the other side. haha just a warning if you are uncomfortable with see-through bathrooms.All in all a good stay, just that I wished the hotel was located nearer the JR station.

This hotel is located at Kabukicho area or red light district of Tokyo. But there is nothing scary or dark. You can come out at midnight to stroll the streets and find something to eat without problems. Japan is pretty safe even at the red light district. I think they keep the hard core stuffs well-hidden. The hotel is quite new with a modern style decoration. Each room is different. We stayed at the Club Suite on the top floor and it's very nice room - big, airy, and comfortable bed. The only thing I don't like is it's quite a walk to go to Shinjuku station fromhere. But if you love to walk, that shouldn't be a problem.

it was very nice and had a great location. it was just downtown where all the shopping and nightlife was. the staff was polite and the rooms was great with a great view. i would stay there again next time i visit tokyo

Nice rooms ,very clean and loaded with lots of facilities like vending machines at ground level which serves beers,coffee,yogurt drink and soft drinks. self service laundry was good but just 1 dryer was not right . our room was way small than i ever thought .wifi is really shame but luckily i was using my own prepaid data sim.Overall the service was great , great fluent english speaking knowledgeble staff at front of the house . I recommend everyone to stay here and visit samurai museum which is just few minutes walk from here .

Moved to this hotel after spending two nights at another hotel in the Shinjuku area. This hotel is modern and has slightly more comfortable and spacious room with smart use of the small space they have. However, it is located about 15mins away from the Shinjuku main station. Hence if you don't mind the walk, this is a good place to consider.

I had to book 2 night stay before i moved to a friends house just outside of tokyo. Thought why night Shinjuku. Great choice. This hotel is in a n interesting location, kind of just past the red light district sort of area. i walked from the main station with my luggage and only took my 20min i think. i was walking fairly slow checking things out. if you stay on the main road its a really nice area. google maps sent me in a strange direction.The lobby was really nice and the staff were great too. The room was very small, it was one of the larger one i could find in my price range. Very clean and had a nice view of the close area.

We stayed in the 'Standard designer double room' for 7 nights. The room was clean, beds were comfortable the view is fantastic. There is limited space for hanging/storing any clothes I think there were 5 hangers on a tiny rail attached to the wall. If your looking for a spacious room I would go for one of the suites. Location is pretty good around 15 minutes walk to the main Shinjuku station although if travelling with a big suitcase I'd recommend grabbing a taxi. There are lots of places to eat/drink around the area.The staff were polite and food was of a very low standard. After reading some reviews I was very much looking forward to the breakfast - it included small chicken nuggets, a salad bar, some hot soups, basic eggs and a couple of breads to select from. This breakfast really lets the hotel down so we opted to eat out for breakfast 5 of the 7 mornings! The biggest disappointment was the roof terrace - after booking the hotel for our engagement trip we selected the hotel on the basis that it had the 'best roof terrace in Tokyo' - the roof terrace was in fact closed for maintenance there was no information about this on the website or any booking sites for that matter! Also the wifi from the rooms is terrible - it cuts in and out throughout the day! To evaluate the hotel is pretty average - i'd recommend it for a few nights but not a whole week.

I booked a group of three friends traveling to Japan. This hotel gave us a good option for a room for three people. Two beds below and one in a loft area. We ladies stuck our guy friend upstairs and enjoyed our stay. People say the rooms are small, but I've seen smaller in New York. The shower was great, toiletries provided. We mostly loved the location, we walked through Shinjuku late at night. To the two nearby subway stations and Mr. Donut! The staff helped us with dinner reservations, a complicated arrangement with doctor's office for one of us, etc. I'd recommend for those who want the night life and the convenience to local transportation. Taxis were also easy to get.

The room was tiny but well appointed. Toilet was fully automated. Clean and well maintained hotel. Wi fi connection was good. Breakfast spread was also good. The entrance to the hotel was through a side road. There is a small sit out area outside the reception which we thoroughly enjoyed for catching up with friends and fellow travellers. The view from our room was good. Overall a good experience.

We only had a quick stop over on our way to the Philippines. Granbel Shinjuku was a perfect hotel for us. Rooms were emaculate. Very tiny but you get the idea from the photos. Staff very helpful. Helped us get wherever we needed to. If it helps take the express train straight from the airport. Very convenient. Golden Gai bars are only two blocks away.

I find it genuinely hard to write a bad review for this hotel as the staff were lovely, attentive and everything you could ask for......the problems lie elsewhere. There is not much they can do about the location, amongst the throngs of love hotels, dingy streets in an all-round dodgy locale. I would avoid this area of Tokyo completely!The room is the smallest of any hotel room I've stayed in, for the first time I'll post a picture for accuracy. I could easily touch one wall and the other (no simian references please). It was claustrophobic, poorly appointed and drab.

trying to book 10 rooms with the hotel we have to ding dong for 1 month (4 weeks) total 17 emails to lock it down and yet they ask people to book direct with them. We should have book with expedia ot tripadvisor. The hotel manager actually hang up the line on us when we call to re confirm the bookings. Upon arrival they refuse to allow us to check in as a team , have to check in base on ava rooms. ask for help on booking airport limo was turn away and was told they can help pls take a flyer and read ourselves, ask for morning call was told cant as we are in a tour group but we are not we only book as a team as its easier but later the front desk mgr apologize that they made a mistake on the booking sheet title. Was later told we can go back to room to ask for morning call individually.. how wired?? conclusion nice hotel and new setting but the service has a long way to go although all staff speak Jr level English but the service level has much to improve we are all disappoint and the trip was tinted with the bad service else would have been great the Olympia is coming hope they in prove on it.

We had a 12th floor room with the small loft. The loft was very helpful given that the rooms are otherwise rather small (typical for Tokyo). The complimentary breakfast was excellent, best breakfast buffet I've had at a hotel - includes both Japanese and American style options. The walk to Shinjuku station was a little far (about 15 minutes), especially with all of our bags, and it got tiring after a few days. There are also closer station options though, depending on where you are going. I liked the location, it is very near the "Golden Gai" area and other excellent food options, even rather late at night. Some visitors may be uncomfortable with the harmless but annoyingly assertive people on the street that try to get you to go into their various clubs and bars in this area of Shinjuku (Kabukicho). Staff at the hotel was very courteous and helpful. Rooms were clean and well set-up.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights. The room had everything we needed. It was reasonably small but well laid out. Both of us are over 6 foot and found the bed and space large enough. We really only slept there and were out and about all day. The bath was lovely. There was a small fridge which was nice and a shared iron available for use. The hotel staff were very friendly and helpful. The hotel is close to a metro station which goes to Shinjuku. Alternatively it is about a 15 minute walk. The walk does however take you through Kabuchiko was is a very obvious red light district. It didn't bother us too much but wouldn't recommend if you are a bit more conservative or travelling as a family. We found the vending machines in the hotel lobby fantastic. On another note we were extremely disappointed that we were unable to use the rooftop bar as this was under extensive renovation. We were not made aware of this at the time we booked and this was a big contributing factor why we originally chose this hotel. They later posted on their website that there is some renovation being undertaken but not specified where. I would also suggest that they get another ice machine is it was basically always out of ice. Overall we enjoyed our stay and would consider returning once all renovations are complete.

The Granbell in Shinjuku is a very nice hotel, in an excellent location in Shinjuku, TokyoThe rooms are small, so if you are aware of this, you wont be disappointed. Whilst they are small, they are very comfortable, in good condition and well appointed. My room was an economy double; I had a very comfortable double bed, which was against the wall on one side. There was a small desk, couch, small wardrobe. The room had a small stereo and a flat screen TV.The bathroom again is small, with a reduced length bath and a shower over that. The bathroom supplies all the bathroom stuff you'd normally need.The hotel itself is very friendly and helpful. Reception has lots of local maps and information. The staff spoke excellent English and were very helpful with info about how to find X and get to Y.One day it was raining, and reception even had free umbrellas for guests to use!Location is excellent, 2 minutes walk to a subway station, with lots of bars and restaurants close by.I'd stay again, but do be aware the rooms are small!

Stayed at the Granbell Shinjuku Hotel for four nights. The Hotel has a great location approx 10 mins walk from the Shinjuku station. which is also a great starting point for getting around with Metro in Tokyo. There are also a few other Metro stations in the area. We had an Executive room on the 14th floor with Club Lounge access. The room was large with a good view, clean, separate shower and bathtub, excellent toiletries. Breakfast was typical Japanese with a small selection of European food. Club Lounge was open until 22pm where alcohol was served between 5 and 7 pm only. WiFi was awailable at no additional charge but was very unstable during our entire stay. Area felt very safe during both day and night. Good selection of great restaurants in the area. All in all a pleasant stay at a nice Hotel with a few improvement areas.

Great hotel. Very close to everything, quiet, very clean, comfy bed. Room was tiny!!!....and pretty pricey. Roof top bar was closed for renovations which was a shame. Heard it was great. Staff good. All in all a great stay.

We got a room with 2 twin beds for 2 adult females. The room was small but clean. It is located in Kabukicho (known as the red light district near hostess bars and the 'seedier' things of Tokyo). But we always felt safe and we actually went to Golden Gai (alleyways of tiny bars) every night on our way back to the hotel. You can walk through it on your way to the hotel from the main Shinjuku station. The main Shinjuku train station is very close and walkable. Higashi-Shinjuku is the closest station (E- Oedo line and F - Fukutoshin line). Lots of shopping and restaurants nearby.

Very expensive for such a small room, we could hardly fit our suitcases in and the bed was very small. The hotel is retro and looks cool, taxis didn't know of it, so we had to ask around 5 before we could get there. Very good location, central to a lot and walkable distance. Good for a base, but room small and nothing amazing.

New hotel in Kabukicho area but on the quiet side. Nice room but be sure to book superior room which was bit bigger than standard type. Clean interior, very quiet, comfortable bed and helpful good English speaking staffs. I was a bit sick when arrived in Shinjuku so resting in this hotel was really helpful before flying long hour flight the day after. Walking to Isetan was less than 10 minutes, to east shinjuku railway station was about 15 minutes, to west shinjuku airport bus station was around 20 minutes. Very good location, plenty of restaurants.

Walk from Shinjuku station is very far with luggage. During the daytime the walk is relatively quiet but in the night time, it is a red light district which was slightly uncomfortable. They are very strict with the check-in time and said they would charge if we wanted to check in earlier at 2pm (instead of 3pm). Ended up waiting in the lobby till it was time. Room though small, is relatively comfortable and new, bath tub was clean and heated toilet. Roof top bar was unavailable. TIP: If you are heading to Harajuku / Shibuya, you can use the Higashi Shinjuku subway station which is much nearer than the Shinjuku JR station. If heading to Ginza, you can use the Shinjuku Sanchome subway station.

The front desk was surprisingly rude at check-in, totally unexpected in Japan. The room was very dirty, but was quickly corrected by the manager - after two phone calls. There was no place to unpack the luggage, even after removing an unnecessary hanging chair. Hotel staff never acknowledged us, neither coming nor going, never a smile, greeting or eye contact. Manager never checked back with us. I was surprised that the reviews from this site were so high, there are plenty of other options. I would not recommend a stay at this hotel.

Great hotel, 10 minute walk to Shinjuku JR/Subway lines. Lots and lots of shopping and bars closeby. You can get something great to eat anytime day or night. Reception is very helpful and kind. Hotel is immaculately kept. Rooms are economical and efficient. I loved the breakfast they offered. We only enjoyed it for 3 out of the 5 days because of our travel schedules but it was worth it. Fresh veggies, and assortment of foods that I'm familiar with and also a lot of foods I've never tried. Great exposure to Japanese culture. Beautiful city, awesome hotel and I would definitely stay there again the next time I'm in Tokyo.

My husband and I stayed here for the first night of our honeymoon and the room was very basic and small but clean. The use of space was very efficient. We did not even need any toiletries as the hotel (and all hotels in Tokyo) provide EVERYTHING you can imagine (toothpaste, razors, hair brush etc...). This is a very good hotel to stay in if you want to be close to the action and popular tourist areas in Shinjuku.

We stayed here as a mother daughter couple for 4 nights in May 2016The hotel location was excellent, just a short stroll to the main Shinjuku station and nightlife of Shinjuku and an even shorter stroll to Higashi shinjuku subway station. Quite a few 7/11 and Lawson convenience stores nearby which are helpful and for easy ATM access.The room was very cosy for 2 people but air conditioned and super clean but only a CNN english station on the TV. The beds were very firm asian style! Lifts were quick and used the convenient coin laundry on the second floor with no problems.The breakfast was in the restaurant on the 12th floor, great views of the city and we enjoyed it very much. The buffet had Limited western choices but all very tasty and of excellent quality. The coffee was excellent.. the best I have ever had in a hotel! All in all we enjoyed our stay very much. A point was lost simply for the high cost of the accomodation. I have travelled widely and at over $300 AUD per night this nice but standard hotel was very expensive compared to even pricey Europe and for the cost I would have expected a much larger room and a swimming pool if staying anywhere else but Tokyo. While nice it could not be considered value for money! I booked with Booking.com.

Very small room with comtemporary decor in common areas. No closet but wall mounted hanging rod and washing basin at foyer. Rain shower and hand held shower head available, but maybe shower curtain not long enough the water seemed to splashes all over the floor during the shower. Free bottled water a bonus. Location within walking distance and front desk helpful. Fee for booking taxi to airport.

The hotel room was very clean, the staff was very helpful and friendly. The room is small but we didnt go to Japan for the hotel ;). The price was good enough and we were happy with the overall experience . The area is quiet yet close to everything. They have preprinted stuff to do, other than the typical brochures, like restaurants that open for 24hrs...etc. The hotel is 10 mins from shinjuku station. Breakfast was not that great though but it was OK enough for a quick bite in the morning .

We spent 2 nights at the Granbell in May 2016. While the location is convenient and close to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku, the rooms are extremely small, but modern and comfortbale. LocationThe hotel is about a 15 min walk from Shinjuku station - best if you don't have very large bags. The location itself it closer to Kabuchiko with its numerous hourly rental hotels but strangely the area didn't feel unsafe or dodgy. There are lots of shops and restaurants nearby.RoomsThe room we got (basic) was TINY but comfortable. With 2 people and 2 pieces of luggage there was no place to walk in the room. As a place to get a good nights rest though it was fine, as we didn't spend much time in the room anyway. A bonus was a very decent DIY filter coffee that was provided. Service We found the check in staff who we interacted with to be curt and slightly unwelcoming. There was no flexibility around the 3pm check in time and we were told that an earlier check in would mean an extra charge (even though check out was at 11am).RestaurantThe rooftop bar was undergoing renovation while we were there and the restaurant, despite nice views was rather dull and uninspiring. We took a quick look before deciding to eat elsewhere.

An excellent hotel, would definitely stay again. Modern and clean and the staff were friendly. Great location - less than 15 minute walk to Shinjuku station. Only negative was that the rooftop bar was closed for our entire stay (renovations I believe).

I spent the last 2 nights here in Tokyo. The apartment was beautiful and the location was quite good. It was more in what people call the 'red light district' as it has clubs etc. it's still very safe. We used the laundry (2 washing machines and 1 dryer) and after using the dryer for 3 hours none of our clothes were dry and we had to resort to a coin laundry about a 5 minute walk away. Very disappointed as we spend so long trying to dry our clothes.Other than that, had a pleasant stay and would stay here again.

The hotel is modern and comfortable, in an excellent location within walking distance from Shinjuku station. The rooms are compact and very clean, with wifi and an external speaker which connects to iPhones/iPods.

I found this hotel pretty decent with so many food joints around.The hotel is very modernised.Staff is helpful and courteous. Easy access to convenience stores like 7 11....so many other hotels around....easy access to the train station...

very small room! bed is comfortable & nice bathroom with basic room amenities. staffs speak very little to non english. nearest jr station is 15mins walk. price is on the high side but its japan! overall good stay & managed to get a good rest...

This hotel is quite nice. Small room as all other hotels in japan. Modern design.The downside is it's a bit far from metro and i think the neighborhood is a red-light district area.Anyway, recommended for a light traveling but not recommended for those of you with heavy luggages and travelinv by metro.

We had one of the more expesive rooms, I believe executive they are called and it was very beautiful with a nice view over Shinjuku. We were on the 15th floor and had a nice big shower and a seperate bathtub which was right next to the window....so after a long walk to Tokyo the best way to relax in the tub and watch out over the city. Very nice! Only the closet was really small or lets say not available. On the 13th floor is also a great rooftop bar and we liked the hotel. The hotel is located in Shinjuku so expect to find Love Hotels, bars and lots of activity on the streets, although the street of the hotel is nice and quiet. Also Golden Gai is not far, so id you want to enjoy a drink in one of the small bars you are 2 minutes away.We would definetely come back to this hotel and recommend the rooms from 14-17th floor. Enjoy this great city!

Yes, the hotels rooms are small, but it is Tokyo after all. I've stayed in similar sized rooms in London, Amsterdam and New York. The rooms have every basic item you would need for your stay, and the bathroom was quite well laid out, considering space is at a premium. The location was good for us, as we were close to high activity areas without being in the middle of it. The rooftop bar was excellent, we finished every night up there enjoying the view.I've booked it again for our return in Oct/Nov 2016

This hotel was hard for the cab drivers to find. I guess if you are use to New York Hotels then this is a nice size for you. One reviewer called the rooms a closet and I agree. The worst part was during check out. It was a rainey day and the hotel informed us that they could not call us a cab due to the weather and if we wanted a cab we had to go out onto the street. (In the rain no doubt) so we go out with our luggage when the clerk runs out to tell us we were suppose to stay another night. I told him that was not true. So we went back inside only to be informed by another clerk that we were right. The first clerk never apologized. Neither did the second. Yes, it had a laundry room but that was not worth the price of admission.

We booked this hotel based on the location. I have never been in a hotel where the rooms are so small. They do not have closets. I tried to cancel my second night but it was impossible because of the cancellation policy.Avoid this hotel unless you travel with no luggage/

This hotel was beautiful, clean, and my favorite part about it was the coin laundry machines on the second floor. So many places offer a laundry service but it is so overpriced, and this place provides coin machines so you can do your own laundry which is really nice for people who have been traveling for a while. The restaurant upstairs was overpriced, but offered a great view of the city (Shinjuku area). I recommend going up there at least once for a drink. The hotel was very close to the Samurai Museum so we ended up stopping there for an hour and a half while we waited for check-in time. It was also walking distance to a lot of other cool restaurants and sights in Shinjuku. It was about an 8 minute walk to the subway and about a 15-20 minute walk to the JR line.

All in all god but abit expencive for what you get i think but then its also due to its location the prices are high. Otherwise nice and clean with nice rooms. Have to add that others that not have a tight budget might not find this expencive at all and well worth it to stay in Shinjuku. Had this hotell as a first stop in Tokyo.Would recommend this hotel if you have a good budget and want to stay in Shinjuku.Have a pleasant trip and greetings from Sweden //Jonas

The staff are excellent and helpful. The room was spotless, and had everything we needed including safe, kettle and fridge. Irons were also available in the corridor. The one downside is the room size, but we managed.

This was our first stop on our tour of Japan. The hotel is in a great location, if maybe a little 'lively' for some travellers.There are no shortage of restaurants, bars and other 'attractions' close to the hotel if required. Shinjuku's main JR station is a 10 minute walk from the hotel. The hotel has a nice bar on the top floor and the outside terrace is soon to be open again after refurbishment work is completed.The hotel staff are extremely helpful and friendly and spoke excellent English. As other visitors commented, the rooms are small but they are very comfortable and clean. My only criticism would be that the room had absolutely no storage space. We stayed for 4 nights and actually did not unpack our bags at all as there was nowhere to store anything. If you stay here, travel light !

We Stayed for two nights In a one bedroom apartment. The room was clean and had all the things we needed. The room wasn't large but thats just normal for Japan. The staff were very courteous and friendly and we only speak english but this wasn't a problem at the front dest. There was some great vending machines on the ground floor for those times you want a snack a small cafe and a roof top bar / restaraunt. We didnt use the roof top bar however but just walked around the close to 8000 eating places in Shinjuku which were all just a close walking fistance from the hotel. We walked our luggage from the main Shinjuku train station and didnt have a problem. We didnt have lots of heavy luggage though either, just two 13kg suitcases and two cabin bags. Shinjuku is a great place to visit and we would definitely stay at the Shinjuku Granbell again!

convenience location and clean hotel at a fair price; I also love the design of this hotel, I probably sure I will stay at this hotel when I visit tokyo next time. quite near the metro station and shopping mall.

We ended our trip to Japan with Tokyo and stayed 5 nights at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel. I was extremely excited for this hotel because not only did the photos look amazing online but it was 4 stars. The room we stayed in were extremely small, I couldn't open my luggage fully on the floor, I guess this is expected in Japan but I had no issues at the other hotels we stayed at. The breakfast were disappointing compared to the other 3 hotels I stayed at in Japan, the variety was very limited although the view at breakfast was awesome. The only thing is that the hotel is reasonably prices and the location is great, it's literally a 2min walk from the Higashi-Shinjuku Station. 2 incidents that really bothered me was one day when we returned at 5pm, our rooms were still being cleaned, for some reason they cleaned it late that day but the cleaning staff rooms were literally next to us. Since we couldn't go into our rooms, we decided to chill upstairs at the bar, the barman was so rude to us because we didn't order anything since we just wanted to wait there for 10min till our room is clean, he literally chased us out even though we were hotel guests. This is the very first rude encounter we experienced in Japan for 2 weeks! I don't think I'll want to go back to that hotel, we will probably stay in Roppongi next time.

We had a budget room which was small but very comfortable and functional. The room was serviced every day to a very high standard. We found the bed excellent and the shower excellent and that is all we required. The bar was empty as the roof terrace was being refurbished, we never got to eat in the Hotel restaurant as it had a private function on the day we had set aside to try it.
user_name:
markalbert60
Hamilton & Waikato Region, New Zealand

review_body: This is our second attempt staying at this hotel after 2 years, the service and standard never fails us. Its very easy to find the hotel using the GPS, since is located near Kabukicho its always easy to find food during late night. Hope their rates will maintain the same after several years to keep their loyal customers :))

We stayed here for a week on our first trip to Tokyo. The room was small which we expected but was immaculate in cleanliness and reception. Amenities was always stocked and the room came with shampoo, conditioner and shower gel. Only downside to room was you were not allowed to open the window for fresh air. Our only major concern was we were smokers and the hotel provides a smoking room which was literally like a gas chamber from Hitlers' days. We like to smoke outside and this was not allowed ANYWHERE so this made our trip difficult.

We arrived at this hotel straight from Narita. Took the Shinjuku area hotels bus and then walked the last couple of kilometers from the Shinjuku station, since we had backpacks. The area is busy, alive and interesting. However, the hotel itself is set back away a bit from all the hub-hub and in a relatively quiet area. The staff was welcoming and helpful, and spoke English well. We did go to the restaurant in the hotel for a drink and it had nice views. But, there are plenty of great places of eat all around and I would recommend them. The room itself was small (as is normal in Tokyo) but comfortable. Not a unique hotel, but, certainly decent and you will not go wrong staying here.

Front desk was extremely friendly and helpful. Hotel room was small (as is common with Tokyo) however didn't feel too cramped and made good use of the space. Extremely clean, stylish, & modern. I really loved the bathroom and considering the size of the room, felt very spacious!Best part of the hotel was definitely the location - right in the heart of Shinjuku and walking distance from everything! Although some reviewers have mentioned the 'seedy' establishments nearby, I never felt unsafe even walking late at night. Not too far from the train station as well. Lots of great places to eat nearby, and the hotel gave excellent recommendations. There's a gorgeous rooftop bar at the hotel and the hotel provided free vouchers for drinks when we checked in. Overall, a wonderful two night stay! Would recommend for a visit if wanting to stay in Shinjuku!

This was our first hotel during a two week Japan trip and of the many small rooms we stayed in, this was the nicest (but also the most expensive). Our room - an Economy Double - was compact but well designed to maximize the space available: there are little shelves and compartments where you can store your things, make sure to look around and find them all. The bed was comfortable and the bedding of good quality. The curtains worked well to keep the light out in the mornings (important for jet-lagged travellers sleeping late!) The wireless worked consistently and had a good strong signal. When we checked out, we realized that we had left some concert tickets in the room. We phoned and the person who answered went and checked our room and found them. It was a great relief and a really impressive bit of customer service!For those travelling by subway, consider using Higashi-Shinjuku station rather than Shinjuku Station proper. Higashi-Shinjuku is much closer to the hotel, much smaller and easier to navigate and, at night, allows you to access the hotel while avoiding a lot of the Kabukicho melee.

This was a great choice. Large room with very well appointed facilities. Location was ok if you want shopping and nightlife. I would have preferred a bit more laid back area but no real complaints.Staff were very helpful and good English so all east checkin even had the room early as it was ready.

Was stay there for 5 nights, 2 rooms during sakura season(super peak season). Room was great, awesome view. Easy access from subway. Beware, when walk alone to Shinjuku area, hotel is surrounded by male and female prostitution, club, bars and budget hotels.Decent room, complete with all needs, huge TV, fabric spray and other amenities was great ! Thumbs up for house keeping staff, good job, polite, always great with smile (they are foreign worker, Pinoy)Bad review goes to lobby staff, probably senior staff or some sort of superior, name AKIBA. Details not going to elaborate.1) Front line staff, are not well trained for information suppose given to customers.2) Even thought, request was not accepted due to time limit for deliver. She not suppose raise her voice to customers. Very obviously, we were treated different due to skin colour. We are Chinese, but not from China. 3) As well established hotel, staff are not well trained with English speaking. I mentioned this lady name AKIBA, particularly. 4) She throw her name tag on desk, while we asking for it. She is not wearing it, like other junior else. 5) We reported this to management, yet the replied is not satisfied. 6) Very different treat to customer, morning lobby staff with evening lobby staff. We love Japan, no the 1st time we travel. We respect this country culture, and world class manners ! Is it due to peak season, too much hotel guest ? or bad reputation of yellow skin visit rising sun country ? After all, we do hope management can handle this well. We still love this beautiful and rich culture country ! Gambate ne ~~

The hotel was clean and well maintained. We had the Hollywood twin room as we were concerned the double bed would be too small. This was a good choice for us. We were disappointed that the rooftop bar was under construction- this was one of them in reasons we booked this hotel. Some people have said its a little far from the station- but there are so many little bars and restaurants close by that we found it a very convenient location. Overall, we would stay here again.

The biggest pro about this place is the location. Shinjuku is where all the action is and exactly the Tokyo experience we were looking for. Close to the "Golden Gai"; great access to transit; tons of places to eat, drink, shop and discover within walking distance. Our room was very clean, comfortable and had everything we needed. Convenient vending machines on the ground floor for drinks (beer included), ice cream bars and snacks.Trying to find the hotel from Shinjuku Station (that it's the world's busiest transport hub is no lie), can be tricky if it's your first time in the city. We found it worth it to pay for a taxi ride instead of navigating the station to find the right exit and then navigate the streets. Best to get checked in right away and start exploring the neighbourhood!Only complaint would be that we weren't notified on check in that the rooftop bar was under construction. Otherwise, an excellent stay.

The hotel is located in a perfect part of town with a lot of nightlife on your doorstep and near the main shopping area.The rooms are small, as expected in Japan, but very comfortable, immaculately clean and sound proof (you don't hear anything from the street.The only thing that lets the hotel down is the breakfast which is pretty bad. No real choice and the stuff they do serve is below average. Apart from this a great hotel.

This hotel is not right at Shinjuku station but is not a far walk by any means. The hotel staff were helpful and professional and the rooms were comfortable and clean. Comfortable bed and good shower and toilet. Breakfast was good and varied with both western and some Japanese fare. I would definitely stay here again next time.

Hotel is located at the heart of shinjuku, around 15 mins away from the shinjuku JR station. it's quite convenient, but for people with big luggage, it may be a bit far and quite challenging to get there. The room in this hotel is Clean and neat. but it's quite small. If you travel light, with small luggage, this hotel is a good option.

Hotel is Located just 2 blocks away from Kabukicho which is the main Tokyo's nightlife spot. We spent 3 nights at the hotel. Staff was very friendly and helpful. They provided us with the list of the restaurants in the neighborhood which was very helpful. Room size can be described as compact (not small) which is expected for most of the Tokyo hotels. The room was very clean with comfortable beds and plenty of bathroom amenities. Since we were traveling light, the walk from Shinjuku JR station to the hotel was just fine. For people with a lot of luggage this can be a bit challenging. WiFi worked well. In short we would recommend this property.

I picked this hotel mainly for the rooftop bar. Unfortunately it was closed during our visit. The inside bar served me the smallest mojito I have never had in my life, and it was also the yummiest one. The location of the hotel is too far from the train station, Omoide Yokocho, Robot Restaurant, and Golden Gai. The room was small but comfortable and clean.

positives: -very clean room with comfortable firm bed-good strong water pressure in shower-staff was very friendly and helpful -many outlets for your electronics -self-serve washer and dryer machine- 100 yen a load -location: great restaurant scene, about 10-15 min walk from train station con:-be ready to step into a small compact room with little space for even your luggage.even with the one con I would still come back and stay at granbell again!! highly recommend!
user_name:
Sharon W
New York City, New York

review_body: Positives: The room was great, compact but that's to be expected in Tokyo, fantastic toiletries and bathroom amenities. The cafe/bar downstairs does an OK coffee and has a selection of craft beers :-) The location is good and in walking distance of many things in and around Shinjuku; and you can connect easily with other subway/overground lines to get where you want to go. Negatives: The breakfast was a bit average; with a strange mix of Asian and western'ish food served buffet style. Treat it as a bonus but don't let "breakfast included" influence your booking.The WiFi seemed to alternate between performing really well and really badly with both slow speeds, poor reception and regular disconnect/connect events.Warnings: The location is good **IF** you don't have to cart a lot of luggage. If you've got anything more than a simple carry-on/roller, but not enough to really justify using a taxi, getting where you need to go can be painful due to just enough distance to the main Shinjuku station, and the lack of a direct line from Higashi-Shinjuku to the main Shinjuku station. You'll need to walk to Shinjuku-Sanchome or do the extra transfer from Higashi-Shinjuku. It's quicker to walk but beware of rain.Taxi wait times vary and could be 15-20 minutes. A taxi to Shinjuku JR East entry (for Narita Express etc) can easily take 15-20 minutes if there's a lot of traffic, and will cost upwards of 2000-3000 yen. Allow 45 minutes to get there. It'd be quicker to walk the whole way in many cases.

Located in the heart of Shinjuku, a part of town famous for its nightlife, this is a neat and new hotel. Our room, an executive on the 14th floor, was smallish in size but didn't lack some charm. Breakfast was good and the buffet offered a variety of Western and Japanese foods.

Granbell Hotel was exactly as what has shown in their website and more! A very compact boutique hotel with lots of style. A memorable stay, very enjoyable. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The hotel located few blocks from the train station. Depending on which way you're coming, some alley can be a bit dark to walk through at night time.

We only stayed for one night – the hotel is located in a very peculiar area called "Golden Gai" which we only found out later on after meeting with Japanese friends. The hotel itself is well located, very clean and updated. However, I found the room to be very-very small — Loved the night gown they provided and the shower products. Overall, I would find hard to stay in such a small room for more than a night, but if you are looking to stay in Shinjuku and perhaps booking a bigger room, this is a very good option.

The hotel was very clean. Very friendly staff. The price for the room is very good. Rooms a bit small so if you spend a lot of time here it's a downer otherwise it's ok. Breakfast was a big disappointment everything was cold I recommend to have something on the street.

Perfect hotel for night life in Tokyo. Right at the heart of Shinjuku. We stayed in a standard room for three nights and had no issues checking in. I had my Japanese sim delivered to the hotel to be picked up with no problems. The room itself is on the small side if you have big luggage it would be hard to move around but normal for Japan. On the plus side there are heated toilet seats in the rooms and they replenish your toiletries every day. There are vending machines downstairs for a late night boss coffee.This place is in the middle of the love hotel district which might sound seedy but I actually think it was more embarrassing for the couples getting caught going in. Great sights nearby. Minutes from Golden Gai and a plethora of small bars to explore there. Means you don't need to worry about crowded last drunk train problems. A late night batting cage for when you're drunk and want that Japanese sports anime experience. A really good Sushi place down the street which is open for 24/h called Sushi Zanmai. And also walking distance from pretty much every sight in the area.Breakfast was good with standard English and Japanese variety. Great views from the restaurant.Downsides is it is a little bit of a walk from JR Shinjuku station. It's much closer to higashi-Shinjuku station on the metro.Overall a great stay.

Stayed here with my partner for 5 nights late March. Like many reviews on this page it has really small rooms which made movement and storing bags difficult. The hotel staff were friendly and we managed to check in early as well (which was a bonus after an 11 hour flight). The location is what makes this hotel stand out. We walked straight to all the malls in Shunjuku and also close to the Gyeon park for cherry blossoms. I recommend going to the train station through entry E2 which is on the main road. Then to Shinjuku-Sanchome station to catch the Marounochi line to most of the main areas in Tokyo. There are 2 7 elevens nearby and a great noodle place on the main road. It is next to the 'red light' district but coming back to the hotel at 2 am after shopping at Don Quixote gave us no problems and rarely witnessed anything unusual. If you want to avoid this then I recommend walking on the main road around Kabukicho. Vending machines on the G floor was convenient for some mid night snacks. We didn't eat at this hotels restaurant (why eat here when Tokyo is just outside the door?). It would've helped if this place had a gym.Otherwise a great place to stay.

With Shinjuku Granbell, you will find yourself in the heart of Tokyo's colorful and exciting nightlife where everything is near like Isetann, Don Quijote, brand-off shops and local Japanese restaurants. You can wander around the alleys and always find a way back to this hotel. Staff are young and friendly as well. With them wearing t-shirts and jeans and sweet smiles, makes your stay more comfortable.

I would definitely stay here again. Clean rooms with everything available even though it was small (no washing machine though). Good location too. Friendly service as well. Reception were willing to keep calling a restaurant to make a last minute reservation. The restaurant was booked out so the staff member was happy to recommend and call other places. I do prefer Shibuya better though but luckily there's a Granbell there too!

The hotel has an awesome location, its just 2 blocks away from Kabukicho, which means you are right beside where all the bars and nightlife are with being in the middle of it like other hotels. Rooms are modern and cool with all amenities, they are compact though (which is the standard in Japan). Staff was friendly and concierge helpful. They key here is convenience, and based on that, I recommend it.

Stayed overnight. Lobby impressive with efficient and friendly staff. Economy room was typical Japanese size and very compact but surprisingly comfortable. Good bathroom with all the amenities. Easy walk to bars, restaurants and nightlife. Highly recommended.

Though we did enjoy our stay, we faced countless challenges at our hotel. Our bathroom had a terrible smell at all times that never went away— somewhere between mildew and chex mix. Our room was sometimes not cleaned and the hotel staff unplugged all of our chargers and left a small piece of dried mucus near the headboard. The restaurant staff were very passive aggressive and accused me of lying about a payment. The bed was comfortable, despite the TERRIBLE pillows which are bricks. Overall, I did enjoy this hotel because it was close to the train station and the front desk staff was helpful when we needed some assistance. They also had unique donut shaped shaped ice chips which were throughly enjoyed by the whole family. 6/10.

The rooms are tiny but service was greet and location is superb for the happening Shinjuku. It is near the red light district but felt safe walking there day or night. While Japan is relatively cheap, accommodation is not so this was a real find.

The hotel had large rooms for a Japanese hotel. The beds was a full sized queen bed. The staff weree friendly and accommodating. The rooms were perfectly cleaned. The Granbell was a 5 minute walk to the Golden Gai area of Shinjuku and a 7 to 10 minute walk to the main entertainment area. Shinjuku-Higashi metro station is only a few minutes away. Its a 15 minute walk to Shinjuku JR station.

Stayed 3 nights in March. Room was alright if a little small. Service was friendly but basic. Location was on the interesting side as long as you don't alterative night life. Just about acceptable for the price, but probably woundn't go back.

We staid here for three nights, checked in is easily, the room is very large, stylish, and functional, room is very quite during night, the bathroom is functional with free cosmetics and fluffy towels, the service was excellent.

Overall a great stay. We were only here for 1 night during a transfer between cities, but enjoyed the location and the room was spacious, clean & modern. We had a club room which meant we had access to complementary drinks & nibbles in the evening on a club access only floor which was great. Our 3 year old was quite tired and fell asleep on the couches in the lobby while we were waiting for our check in time so the staff kindly got our room ready asap and checked us in early so he could have a nap. Overall, happy with this hotel. The only downside was that the outdoor terrace was closed due to renovations (which we were aware of at the time of booking).

Although this is a large hotel, it has a boutique feel about it and is in a great location not far from Shinjuku station and some great bars/restaurants. We had an executive suite on a high floor with great views over Tokyo. As with all places in Japan, the service was exceptional and the staff very friendly and helpful. The only downside to the hotel was the quality of the breakfast. It fell somewhere between being Japanese and Western but not achieving either very well.

Chose this hotel as we wanted to be in Shinjuku. The hotel was a short walk from Shinjuku station, through Kabukicho area. We did not get to see all the debauchery until the very last night of our stay. But it was pretty mild, nothing to be worried about. We had a standard double room on the 6th floor and it was enough for us - 2 girls - with only carry-on luggage. So if you have big suitcases, space WILL BE a problem as you may not be able to open and arrange anything, unless you put them on the bed. Comfortable bed, very nice bath tub and bathroom. We filled the bathtub up and used it as an Ofuro every night, very relaxing after a full day of walking around in Tokyo. The only negative thing I'd say about this hotel is Wifi, extremely slow on the 6th floor, as someone else already mentioned. We opted for our pocket Wifi instead. Other than that, I'd add another observation, not necessarily negative, but the staff at the front desk did not seem as warm or hospitable as the other places we've stayed at in Japan, which seemed a bit disappointed. Everything else went according to what we hoped for, so we may stay here again unless we found a better value in the same area.

The most amazing shower.Excellent location. One of the best breakfast buffets I have ever had. Very helpful Staff. Lovely decor throughout. Real cafe style coffee machine downstairs in the cafe section.

Great location in a bustling part of Tokyo. Easy too get to Shinjuku main station and lots of metros stops in the vicinity.Yes, the rooms are smaller than you might be normally used to in a hotel but this is Tokyo people! The room was creatively designed to accommodate for the maximum use of the small space available and clean - the bathroom was spotless and the room itself was fine. The only negative I have with this place was that I could not open the window for air; perhaps it was me, I had been out for a few drinks I must confess, however I could not get fresh air into the room so I woke up hot and bothered. If you like that sort of thing though - book here. You won't be disappointed.

This was our first visit to Tokyo, so at first we were a little concerned about the size of the room. However, once we got used to it, it was fine, and was in fact very well designed for the limited space. Bathroom especially, having both a bath and separate shower.From the beginning. We arrived at Shinjuku station and followed the directions supplied by the hotel (which include pictures). A couple of moments of doubt, but it worked well, and we arrived at the hotel. Staff are very friendly and helpful at all times.This part of Shinjuku is also quite fascinating - it is the center of the late night bars and "Love hotels" and though a little seedy, is perfectly safe and certainly provides a different insight into Tokyo life.My only complaint with the hotel concerns the breakfast. Luckily it was not included in our package. We tried it on the first morning and found it be unsatisfactory, so self catered for the rest of our stay.Would stay again. Maybe even upgrade to a more expensive option with a bit more space.

You can check in at 3pm and check out 11pm. You can left your bagged in lobby. The room's very clean and not much small. I really love soap. It's good smell. Higashi-Shinjuku station is nearest from hotel and walk 5 minute. I've stay 2 time. If i come back to tokyo, i will stay again.

Hotel was nice and clean short walk from train station and busy area of shinjuku if your planning on been out a lot of the time it's perfect but my partner was ill so spent a couple of days recovering in the hotel the lack of space and one English channel started to drive her a little mad..

We arrived by Subway, just a short walk from the hotel, nice spacious lobby, very contemporary, there are vending and ice machines behind the elevators in the lobby and just around the corner are 7-11 and Lawson's if you need to pick up anything you may need. Our room had a double bed, small japenese style room but nice and comfy for us. Air worked great. I loved the bidet toilet. Didn't think I'd be a fan, but it was very cool. Room had a translucent wall seperating the bath from the bedroom very interesting. If you like new contemporary, you'll like this hotel. Our room also included breakfast daily. Very nice variety of items. Salad for breakfast too if thats your style. Great stay, we were never in room at all just to sleep, out seeing the sights from morning till night but this was a great place to come back to. I would definitely stay here again.

I'll focus on two things - hotel and location.The hotel is very good. We were fortunate enough to stay in a villa suite for 5 days and it was spectacular. Didn't have a chance to see the quality of other rooms but suspect they would be as clean and well kept as the rest of the hotel. The facilities were good - decent bar, decent breakfast buffet.Location was great. Close enough to walk to any number of metro stations, close enough to the debauchery in Kabukicho, lots of very good eateries and bars close by as was shopping. Yes there are "love hotel" surrounding the Granbell but they are of no concern and shouldn't be the basis for declining a stay at this hotel.All in all I would highly recommend the Granbell Shinjuku.

We stayed here for 8 nights in a twin room and were very pleased with our room. As the rooms in Tokyo are generally smaller than what we are used to, I generally book twin rooms to get more space in the room or at least the bed. This hotel is in a great location, close enough to walk either to Siinkjuku station or a 3 min walk to the Higashi-Shinjuku metro. Complimentary water provided each day. The pillows were very flat and hard, I had to ask for another, which the reception happily brought up for me. I was also able to get 2 additional coat hangers with no difficulty. The wifi was not very good on the 6th floor. A couple of comments:- consider getting a coin machine for the washing machine and dryer- there are 2 washing machines which the cycle takes 30min, however only 1 dryer which takes over 2 hrs to dry those clothes. Consider getting a second dryer. The only other negatives were:- when housekeeping made the beds, they broke our phone charger that was plugged in the wall beside it, however didn't leave a note, it was just placed it broken on the bedside table. - when my friend returned to her room one afternoon, she'd found that house keeping had spilt the coffee that was sitting on the bedside table onto the sheets. It must have been them as the spill was on the sheets and not on the quilt. It seems strange that it appears housekeeping continued to make the bed and ignore the spill. Although, once reported, a lady came up in the next 10 min to change the sheets over.

We had 3 nights in Tokyo after snowboarding and decided to stay in a similar location to our last trip. We were greeted by wonderful staff and through the check in process very quickly and on our way through the modern artistic lobby. Being 30, we absolutely loved the decor being more on the individual and artistic side.Having stayed in Tokyo before, we were well aware of the size of hotel rooms, but were very pleasantly surprised when we opened the door to find a great sized room, a decent sized bed (i'm 184cm) and a great bathroom, not just a pod style bathroom installed in a room. To sum this hotel up, its quite new or newly renovated, arty chic, with a cafe (doing espresso coffee) in the lobby, an outdoor garden area, a bar upstairs with outdoor space looking out over some of Shinjuku, very competent staff and a choice of room types.We'd be happy to stay here again

Many of the reviews mention the size of the rooms, yes, the room is small, but it's Tokyo, the rooms are all small (This is not my first trip to the city, I have also visited friends in their hotels and found the rooms of comparable size at hotels that cost more per night) and as I was travelling alone this wasn't a problem for me. Further to that, I am on holiday to explore the city, not lounge around a hotel room all day.My room was clean, the bed was very comfortable and the bathroom a good size, I wouldn't hesitate to book here again.The hotel is an easy 10 minute or so walk from Shinjuku station, once you've found your way there once you won't have any problems, the instructions on the website were good, failing that just use the GPS on your smart phone. The Higashi-Shinjuku station is mere minutes walk away, this will give you access to the Odeo and Fukutoshin subway lines. The hotel will put Shinjuku at your doorstep but is also far enough away to be lovely and quiet so you can sleep peacefully.The room I stayed in was a superior double and I was on the 11th floor, I booked directly via the hotel rather than through a 3rd party website so I don't know if this had any bearing on me being placed on one of the higher floors. I rented a pocket wi-fi which was delivered to the hotel and was waiting for me when I arrived, the hotel does offer free wi-fi, which was excellent, however I like to have access to wi-fi when I am out and about too, it is handy for finding your way around Tokyo as the addresses can be confusing.

Everything is okay, but just the room design is not ergonomically. Have the sink outside the bathroom and the shower water goes everywhere. Not sure why is designed like this. It makes the room very small with the sink out of the bathroom. Oh BTW, shower area and bathtub are separated.Not place to place our suitcase P.S. I stayed at deluxe double ( or called premier double)

I planned to stay for five days and from day one, I almost decided to walk away and go to a different hotel. I got two big suitcases, one carry-on and a laptop and was trying to drag everything into the lobby. The staff saw how much baggage I had and I went back and forth from the lobby to the street where the cab dropped me off (the hotel has no place for the cab to pull in and I was left off at the street) several time, but did not seem to pay any attention or offer any helps.Then I found out that there was no shower cap in the bathroom. So, I asked the maid and she said that the hotel had no shower cap. I went down to the reception and asked for it. They said that they don't provide shower caps at their hotel. A shower cap is a necessary item for any guest who wish to keep their hard dry while taking a shower. I know that we could use a hair-dryer but why wasting time when you are very tired and don't want to spend time drying your hair. The best way is to just have a shower cap. The hotel receptionist merely said that no shower cap was provided. They were being cheap and although I understand that not everyone needs a shower cap, they should have it handy for people who need it since it costs almost nothing. From the very first night that I stayed in the room, I got a real bad allergy from the pollen and sneezed like crazy and could not sleep. I ended up sick because the room was very uncomfortable and probably full of pollen. I ended up not being able to get up the second day because I was sick in bed and only got up at around 1 pm. By the time I was going to go out and look for something to eat, I saw a note on my door saying that no full cleaning of room will be provided because it was already after 2 pm. I understood their policy and did not ask them to clean it up. When I returned to my room, I called and asked for new towels, new Yukata (pajama) and some bottled water because they did not give me or change any of these stuff. The receptionist told me that I had to go down to the front desk to pick up the stuff by myself. I told her I was sick and could not do so. She finally brought the stuff.I would advise anybody who look to book this hotel to reconsider. It may be a bit cheaper than other hotel in the area but the location is really bad. It takes about 20 minutes to reach the train station. Also, the service is terrible. To be more precise, they provided no services at all. The staff was not helpful and they don't really think about customers' needs. All they will tell you is that this is all we have and don't try to provide any extra service. It will be my first and last time to stay at this hotel.

Granbell Hotel is relatively close to Shinjuku station (about a 14min walk or 7min cab ride from the station). Rooms vary greatly in size. If you can I recommend staying a larger room. I stayed in the luxury designer room - 1501. Perfect for a couple or solo who wants a feeling of space. I stayed 5 nights (4 consecutive and 1 more after a trip to Kyoto), so the room having a washing machine was a must.The staff at the hotel are great. When heading out for dinner and you want great sushi or sashimi, they pre-printed pages with maps that are in walking distance.Tip #1 - when flying in to Narita Airport, pre plan the times to catch the Narita Express to Shinjuku station. I missed the train by 10mins and had a 50min wait. If this also happens to you, go and buy your 1, 2 or 3 day tourist metro train fare. Very handy.Tip #2 - pre arrange a mobile wifi to be at the airport on your arrival.0

We stayed there the last night of our trip because we wanted to have a good view of the city. The view was not that good, because the external area of the bar is being refurbished. The day we were there, the staff said the hotel was full, still the first receptionist would allow us to stay at the 7th floor. When we were back later, the second receptionist said we would stay at the 3rd floor, we repeated what had been said to us, and we ended up at the 6th floor (with no view from our room, but calm and quiet). The bathroom was not so clean and the room was very tight, not even possible to open completely a four-wheels suitcase. The breakfast was good and the staff at the dining spaces were nice and helpful. If you are not worried with the things I mentioned, and just want a central place to stay in Shinjuku, this is the place.

I stayed here twice during my time in Japan. First for 4 nights at the beginning of January in a Standard Triple Loft room and again for 5 nights at the end of January in a Superior Designer Double/Studio room.The loft room was great, however for 3 people with luggage was a little small, but there was space at the end of the bed that we put some of our suitcases into and we found space for the others. The bed loft bed was a futon/foam mattress (not completely sure which) which was very comfortable, and the downstairs double bed was very comfortable.The Superior Designer Double/Studio room was very spacious and well decorated (which you would expect from the higher price). In addition to the free water each day we also got a bottle of Coca Cola and Green Tea which was really nice. Again the bed was very comfortable.Overall we had a great experience at this hotel, the staff were very friendly, breakfast was great with a lot of options for both Western and Japanese style breakfast and the location was great being so central. It is in a bit of a confusing spot to get to at first, but once you get used to it its really easy to get to, being around a 7-10 minute walk to JR Shinjuku Station (which we used because we had a JR pass rather than the closer subway station) I would definitely recommend this hotel, and would definitely stay here again next time :)

Perhaps we had been spoilt from the Ryokan in Kyoto we stayed at but this was a disappointment. Centrally located with great reception staff, the bedrooms were very cramped. Fine for one person but not enough space for two. The bed itself was very comfortable and the room quiet. The bathroom was small but everything worked well including a heated mirror so that it didn't steam up which was clever. The breakfast was adequate and the breakfast room had spectacular views but we were disappointed as it was very noisy there at breakfast, first from the loud music they seemed intent on playing and then followed by some construction going on which started towards the end of breakfast. they did forewarn us but we all did wonder whether the construction crew could have waited just another 15 minutes until everyone had left the breakfast area. The manager in the restaurant was very nice and helpful but he was fighting a losing battle with the noise.

We loved this hotel, perfectly situated in an quiet area just two minutes walk to the best area of Shinjuku.Breakfast was great, but we did miss fresh fruits.Our room was brand new, big and fantastic. We had luxury double room with bath tub with a view.The only things we lacked was hangers for towels to dry and clothes. Staff was very friendly and helpful.There was construction for a roof bar while we were there but we never noticed it.We'll definitely choose this hotel again if we come back.

We were trying to use the directions given by the Granbell website to go to the hotel but had a hard time following it. Apparently the hotel is just about 5 minute easy walking from the A1 Exit of Higashi-Shinjuku Station. There are 2 convenient stores within minute walking from the hotel. If you're in those beauty pharmacies (tax-free), there is also one around the corner of the hotel and I believe it closes around 10:30 p.m. We stayed at the standard room so by no surprise, the room size is small. But overall, the hotel looks very clean and rooms are clean as well.

Probably one of the smallest hotel room I have ever stayed in. Even if you get the twin room, it will be hard to fit two suitcases.The hotel is right next to the red light district. It's an interesting area to walk around, but not sure about everyday.Service is also hit or miss. On my day of departure, I ordered a taxi to the train station, but no one helped direct me to the taxi driver, and I almost lost the taxi.

Right near Golden Gai in the shinjuku area. If with two people, splurge foot the room with the loft...very cool!! High ceilings and a projector. Bring an HDMI cable and watch movies on the big screen. Highly recommend.

Room is small yet clean and nicely decorated. Walking distance to many 24hours restaurants & convenience stores, which's great for late night supper persons like us. Down-side: 10min walk from train station.Still worth to re-visit in future!

The hotel was overall nice, the front desk staff was very helpful and professional. The cleaning staff was very nice and our rooms were well kept. I did like the location and close proximity to food, shopping and the train. The food options at the hotel were horrible. The greeter at the restaurant was not friendly at all and the staff overall was not helpful and did provide a good customer experience with simple request. Getting a morning cup of coffee was a significant challenge and I had to walk to the local Tully's or McDonald's every morning, the restaurant would not sell you a cup!!! The rooms are very small so even with the loft space unless you're very small it will be very tight, no closet space and place for coats or luggage.

No complaints with our stay at Granbell - The room was nicely decorated and clean (yes, small but its Tokyo!). We were amazed how quiet the room was and how comfy and cozy the bed was - we slept so well! The hotel is in a great location for discovering shinjuku which is a very fun area. It does get a slightly seedy vibe at night time, but we never felt unsafe and it seems like the tourists generally get left alone.

We upgraded to a nice room, it was modern and had a decent amount of space. The design was pretty cool, and the room had an awesome shower. The hotel was very crowded and the lobby area was full of people's luggage, covered in nets. For day keeping? Seemed stupid. The staff was minimally helpful, and generally mediocre. The area is full of seedy sex motels, which dragged down the experience. I much preferred other areas of Tokyo. This didn't feel like the future.

I stayed at the shinjuku grandbell hotel in January 2016. It was a great stay. I arrived early in the morning and the staff was happy to take my bag and save it while I explored the city. I was so happy to find they placed the bag in my room when I came back later in the day and checked in. The hotel is a little far from the epicenter of shinjuku but is only about a 10-15 minute walk. The rooms themselves are incredibly small. But well laid out and all you need if you're mostly spending time outside the hotel. The room was completely modern and clean and the electronics were seemingly brand new.

We stayed in the Granbell in Shinjuku twice when we were in Japan.Both times we found that the rooms albeit small (to be expected in Tokyo) were very clean and comfortable.The Hotel is in the Shinjuku area but just far enough away from the hustle and bustle that you can enjoy a good night's sleep. There were lots of young people staying when we were here but very little noise.All the staff that we had contact with were really helpful. When I managed to get the safe in the room stuck open they were up in a matter of minutes to fix it for us.They've also got a bar on the rooftop with decent views of Shinjuku as well as vending machines in the lobby that dispense snacks and beer!!I would happily recommend for those looking to stay in this area.

Rooms isn't big but economically set up. Including table, sofa, fridge, bed, blinding blinds, kimono, amenities, heated mirror and toilet seat, small bath with hot hot shower, safety box, daily cleaning, good view. Its location is in the middle of the so called red light district but wasn't disturbing at all. Nearby restaurants and bars, mini markets and 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station. Super friendly staff. Try to make a booking through Agoda which gave us the best price. Currently the roof top bar is under maintenance so better wake up before 9am. This is a great place with 'affordable' price compared to the other hotels. We'll most certainly come back if we'd visit Tokyo again.

We stayed here for 2nights. We flew in from NRT, took the Keisei bullet train to Ikebukuro and took that to Higashi Shinjuku a brief 5minute walk had us at the side entrance of the hotel .It took about an hour and 15mins to reach the hotel give or take a few minutes. We flew out HND and it was a little over an hour with transfers...etcCheck in was simple. We had a 2 twin room. The room was updated. The twin beds do touch each other. Nice ammenities in the bathroom, replenished daily. Only con about the bathroom it had a slight sewage smell when you run the tub or the bidet. All personnel we came in contact with was friendly. They hold your baggage for you when you check out so you can still visit the town. As far as the location, it wasnt too far from the Shinjuku night life. Right around the corner from a 7-11, Mcdonalds and pharmacy. Remember to visit the Roof Top Bar for an excellnt view and I love the ambience that it brings. Dont forget to hit the yes button if the review helps you out! Check out the pictures we took and email me with any questions.

This hotel was perfect for my needs as a solo traveler. Despite the standard room being small it was quite clean and designed well with space where necessary. I didn't have a huge bag so I had no problem fitting my things on there. I loved the fancy toilet and the large deep bathtub. The service was efficient, they were a little too "in the box" though. When I asked for recommendations for a nice Japanese restaurant where I could get grilled fish she just kept recommending different malls. But that's okay. Luckily I had internet and was able to find something on my own. It is very close to multiple train stations and lots of shopping and popular sights. Pros: CLEAN, accessible, efficient, cozy, modern, slippers and Japanese robe in room, the body wash and shampoo smell AMAZINGCons: On the smaller side, not so luxurious but certainly meets your needs, lots of girly bars and love hotels around the area (but this is Japan so there's really nothing to worry about).
user_name:
Victoria D
New York City, New York

review_body: Just arrived back from 11 nights in the Shinjuku Granbell when visiting Tokyo.Staff make a hotel and all of the staff were absolutely excellent throughout the stay, happy to help in any way possible. Helped us source a hire car, numerous directions and tips for the local area from the bar staff on the roof bar.Hotel itself is modern and clean. Toiletries were generous and refilled daily, and the rooftop bar was very reasonably priced with a great view of the city. Rooms were a bit small but seems like this is the Tokyo norm.Location is also good, was skeptical of staying so close to Kabukicho but never once felt unsafe or intimidated, loads to do on the doorstep and a 5 min walk to the station.Couldn't recommend higher!

Stayed 3 nights at the Granbell, looked like a popular and busy hotel. Great quiet location in Shinjuku. Nice roof bar for a drink or 2, lively coffee cafe with live music or dj on the ground floor.Breakfast was very average however but it did the job and until 11am! Executive lounge was small but came with a great view and offered good coffee (opposed to the American coffee at breakfast), tea, nuts/chips, soft drinks, wine etc.I looked into a standard room and was glad I booked a larger room which I still found small. The standard room looked tiny!

Very Clean, nice staff, big room, great location and Very close to the station, and close to batting ⚾ an many restaurant. This hotel have a smoking area which is useful when the weather is cold. You can go anywhere from this hotel.Everything is great.. Love it.. And sure i will stay at this hotel again for my next trip to tokyo..

Love the newness of the hotel. Love the modern décor of the hotel. Love its amenity, facilities, and bed size. Not sure about the location. The hotel is a little far from main attraction of Shinjuku but close the train station (not main station, though). The front desk can also be improved. Their manners are good, but they can’t communicate in English well. I talk to four staffs. Three out of four staffs cannot communicate in English well (I think they are Chinese or able to speak Chinese fluently). When I ask question that is not very basic like they best way to go to airport or how to go to Dikanyama, they give me half finished answer. Regarding the room, we choose Hollywood twin room, we checked the bed size and room size (24 SQM), we look at the pictures, and think we can live comfortably here for 4 days. When we saw the real room, we are a little upset that the room looks smaller than the picture (that what a professional photo can done to you, wide lens and everything) and we can only open on luggage only if we move all the furniture. It would be a perfect room if we can have a space to open our luggage.

Hotels in central Tokyo can be expensive, and you should expect tiny rooms. With that said, this hotel prices it's small rooms very well. Better value than many other hotels in the vicinity.It takes a bit of walking to get to the hotel, as it's not on a main street. Try to avoid Shinjuku station if you can, there's other stations nearby that are easier to access (Shin-Okubo, Higashi-Shinjuku or Shinjuku-Sanchome). But when walking the streets of Kabukicho, it's not hard to see where you're heading. I found it easy to spot the hotel from a few streets away. Although Kabukicho is a red-light district, it's not dangerous by any means.Any hotel staff that I encountered spoke English and were friendly, though some reception staff were a little too "efficient".The room is small but the space is extremely well designed.
