There's ample storage given the size of the room, and the bathroom doesn't suffer for lack of space. In the bathroom, the toilet may seem intimidating but the controls are easy to figure out. The bed is quite comfortable to sleep in, not as hard as some Asian beds can be.

This hotel is just fineThe rooms are very small, even the double roomsThe location is just great, is not easy to get to the hotel even with a taxi but once there its easy to go to the red light zone and the shopping avenues by walking.The hotel is surrounded by xxx hotels that charge for the hour or the day.One thing i didnt like is that i made two reservations for two different days but the reception girl wanted me to use the same room the two days, i make two reservations to get fresh rooms every day, i had to insist to finally get the service i paid for.In conclusion i will probably return to this hotel, is friendly with guests if you invite any and is very well located once you manage to arrive there.Very good price/location for Shinjuku in Tokyo!

We had a great little room that though compact but not cramped, especially compared to other hotels I've stayed in in Tokyo. It was incredibly conveniently located near within walking distance to all sorts of attractions, stores, and restaurants, and the hotel itself is easy to find and get to on foot. The room has lots of nice amenities (good bathroom, access to laundry/ironing, a safe, a mini-fridge, plenty of storage, TV, and so on). Free wi-fi too, and clean. I didn't have breakfast or eat in the restaurant so I don't know how that was. The view was nice, but nothing too unusual. I think it was a very good hotel, and I will definitely stay here again.

Avoid room 1305 or luxury designer double/ mature rooms on 13th floor as look directly at rooftop bar (even from bath). Blinds block spectators & city views too. Ask for room on other side of building as can see into most rooms from rooftop bar.If downgraded to a room with privacy you were not able to receive refund for price difference.Otherwise great hotel and friendly staff.

I stayed four nights here. It is an easy 10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station and can be found down a quiet side street. The room was very compact which was fine as I was traveling solo and not in the room all day anyway. I especially like that they have a safe in the room. The bed was comfortable and clean as was the bathroom. The shower doubled as a bath and the water pressure was brilliant, better than what I have at home! I did have an issue with my toilet not flushing and filling up with too much water...I called reception who were very apologetic and the problem was immediately rectified. So no complaints there. A range of foods is on offer for the buffet breakfast and is available until late in the morning. Reception will also happily store your luggage if you arrive before check-in time or need to leave well after the check out time. Shinjuku Granbell is an excellent choice.

stayed for 1n in a "designer room" which was very spacious. highlight was the large bathroom occupying perhaps half of the room area, with separate shower and bath. the room was on a higher floor and had a nice view. wifi worked well, and tv had plenty of channels. breakfast had a good selection. reception staff was helpful to retrieve an item left behind. will seriously consider returning to this place.

Shinjuku Granbell is a clean and very stylish located near the higashi-shinjuku metro. You'll have access to food anytime of the day as there are many 24 hours eatery and convenience shops around. Would definitely come back again.

Stayed for two nights over New Year. Standard double on the 4th floor was quiet with a non-descript view but the roof bar gave us the skyline when needed. The room was much smaller than our Ginza hotel but adequate for a short stay. Hotel staff were helpful. Shinjuku was a bit like staying in Leicester Sq in London and a quite trashy, but being near the station was perfect to get around the city.

Enjoyed a week in this hotel and found it easy get to and from the main shopping precinct with family of three children. Staff were helpful. Rooms were very nicely decorated and serviced. Close to eating spots.

Pros: Very friendly staff who were always there to help, including the cleaners who helped me carry my bags to the room. :) Additionally, they allowed us to store our luggage downstairs for an extra 2 days after we checked out. Our room on the 11th floor was very clean and came with basic amenities. Rooftop bar has a great view, with heaters and accommodating waiters who offered us blankets. The cocktails are reasonably priced too! I paid about $7 for a Tequila Sunrise. The location is more suitable for those who like to drink and party, as it is very close to the red-light district. It is also a short walk away from supermarkets, small restaurants and the mega discount variety store, Don Quijote. Cons: At first it can be a bit difficult to find. Even our taxi driver got lost and had to call hotel staff for directions! However, if you're travelling by foot from Shinjuku station, it will only take about 5 minutes. Overall? We had a pleasant stay in a safe, quiet and clean hotel in a convenient location. Although for $210 AUD per night, I found it quite expensive so you could find cheaper places which are just as good.

It is a trendy place, and about 2 minutes away from the Higashi-Shinjuku metro station. To get to the main Shinjuku station however, it can be difficult to navigate as it is not a direct ride along the Toei Oedo line. The in-room dock/alarm clock/speaker was a nice touch and you could just play music while charging your phone. Wifi was also very strong so that's a plus. Rooms are quite comfortable, and we were provided with pillows of varying hardness and height so one could possibly switch to see which was more comfortable. As with most Tokyo rooms, the space given is really small though and it can feel very claustrophobic at times. Nonetheless, it had everything a traveller needed and it was a good stay here.

Granbell is one of the larger, proper hotels, located in a nestle of discrete love-hotels. The room is somewhat small but cosy. The bed is super comfy, and the bathroom is very clean. They are however, very strict on check-out times, and late check-outs have to be bought by the hour. The nearest train station is actually the Higashi-Shinjuku station (Toei Odeo train line), which is about 5-8mins walk away. It's a little far from JR Shinjuku train station, which could be quite a challenge for 1st time travelers to navigate through. Although the hotel website had a walking guide that could take you from JR Shinjuku station to the hotel within 10 mins, I still got lost in the kabuki-cho area before finally finding the place 25 mins later.The hotel staff are all young with no problems speaking English, and there are quite a few vending machines for drinks/ice-cream/snacks/beer on various floors. There are also 2 washing machines and 1 dryer for guests to share.The vicinity (kabuki-cho) is a colourful district of bars, izayakis, karaoke, convenience stalls... And men's clubs and ladies' clubs. Although these clubs have their bouncers on the streets, they won't push or pull you in. It's a place with very difference facades in the day and in the night. :)

The hotel is nice & comfortable, staff are helpful, rooms are clean & not too small comparatively. Located about 10 mins away from the Shinjuku Station, many shops on the way to the hotel, so it is okay for me. The neighborhood is safe although it is near the Kabukicho (red-light district).

Last year, during an unusually ferocious heat wave, I stayed at the Granbell. While the room was small and my friend and I had to coordinate our movements to accommodate the furniture, each other and our minimal luggage, it was clean, neat and nicely appointed. The TV was huge and the bed linens were luxurious. The bathroom was small and dimly lit and the shower was just so-so, I have to give a shout-out for Japanese toilets. Yes, I know it seems somewhat indiscreet to discuss the commode but if you've never experienced a Japanese toilet, it's a rather fantastic experience. 'Nuff said. The air conditioning was not up to American standards which, in any event, I find entirely too cold. But here, at the Granbell it was not adequate to cool the room considering the 90+ F temperature outdoors. The bar and the outdoor roof facility were fine. I didn't find the staff particularly helpful when a wine refill was needed but again, overall, the Granbell was fine...not great but certainly adequate.
user_name:
Madelleine212
New York City, New York

review_body: Excellent service by hotel staff, provided everything I needed. The rooms were nice, clean and modern, albeit quite small. The cleaning staff were here everyday and were very respectful. Although location could be better, it didn't bother me too much. Definitely coming back here!

I raved about this hotel when I stayed here 10 months ago, but on this trip I noticed the customer service was not as good as it should have been. I am an keen foodie and spent a lot of time researching restaurants for this trip to Tokyo. Many top restaurants require bookings to be made by your hotel (i.e. in Japanese) but Granbell refused to do this before my stay.I stayed in a Luxury Designer Double (mature) room, as before, which was a good room. It gave access to the Club Lounge, but this was not highlighted on check in, so when we used the lounge we were the only ones in it every time. And staff were never in the lounge outside cocktail period, so it was not possible for executive rooms to check in/out there, which you are meant to be able to do, according to the website. So it seemed clear they were more interested in earning premium room rates than providing premium service.

I staid here for 2 nights while on a stopover. I am only vaguely familiar with Tokyo but I knew Shinjuku is not the safest place. I didn't realize the entrance to this hotel is on a narrow street with little traffic at night - I confess I didn't feel the safest. This being said, the place is clean, modern and with a nice coffee place, a sky bar and a restaurant. If you don't intend to go out late or are traveling in a group, this place is just a stone thrown away from a subway station and quite close to the shopping area. The price is also quite good! I heard a few people complain about the size of the room and indeed, despite having opted for a double room instead of single I barely had space to walk around with my (closed) suitcase around. However, that is the norm for hotels in Tokyo in that price category and you must accept that rooms aren't the size you would get elsewhere.

Have a wonderful 5 nights stay at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel with a great location that can access Japan railway stations in such a convenient way. The reason I chose this hotel is due to the room type being offered for family like us, and my son loves the loft bed so much. We opted for the breakfast package, and they do offer reasonable variety of options

I had the pleasure of three nights here in October.Unfortunately i caught the tail end of a cyclone so spent more time than planned in the hotel which as it turned out wasn't so bad.Personally this is exactly the type of hotel for me. Stylish, Modern, great service, good location, small outside terrace and great rooms.Staff were fantastic, the room was great the facilities excellent.I opted for one of the superior designer double rooms and wasn't disappointed, the room was big for Tokyo with a large comfy double bed and a nice seating area. Views out over Tokyo were great. The bathroom and shower are modern and in good condition and are separated by the sink area.This room came with access to an executive common area which had supplies of tea coffee etc.The rooftop bar was a real treat with great views and good and reasonable drinks.My only grumble would be the hotels check in policy. The room was unoccupied but not available to me before 15.00pm (hotel check in time) unless i wanted to pay extra. The extra amounted to half a days rate so i decided against it. I do believe this is common in this part of the world. Either way i am not a fan of this.I will return to Tokyo before too long and will definitely stay here again.

After arriving from a 15 hour journey it was nice to have a place to go to get away from the craziness of Tokyo. Easy check in and info about the area. The room was tiny. But had all of the necessities we needed. Fancy toilets and a nice shower! The bed was ok. Horrible pillows. But that's ok. They have a roof top bar. It was raining so we didn't get to enjoy it as much. They also have a cafe in the lobby. But it seemed to have strange hours. 10am to 4pm. With our jet lag and up super early. We had to wonder around to get breakfast and coffee. Lots of stuff going on around this hotel. Like restaurants and bars/clubs. And the lights oh the lights. Everywhere!!! Good little place in the heart of shinjuku. Not close to transit. So we needed to take a taxi to the hotel from the shinjuku train station.

I highly recommend this hotel. You only need walk half a block and you are right where the action is. Lots of restaurants within easy walking distance. Even a 7/11 right across the street with plenty of very fresh deli products, alcohol, and coffee. There's a grocery store about half a block away. The breakfast buffet is generous, with Western and Japanese selections. The front desk attendants speak very good English. The concierge could use a little work, was flustered on two different occasions when giving directions. Shinjuku station is an always entertaining 10 minute walk away. The Shinjuku area is a more grownup version of the Shibuya area. Great hotel!

I think this hotel has nice and new facility for fair price. It is also nice for tourists to enjoy the city center of tokyo especially for shinjuku area. You can get a few metro stations by a few to 10 mins walk.

There's a lot to like about this hotel. It's located a bit out of the way, but that's only a problem if you can't negotiate a couple of narrow streets before the main drags of Shinjuku. The location makes for a quiet and peaceful stay. The staff are friendly and courteous, and willing to help, with good English skills. I had a single room and despite the usual small-ish room area, it was light, bright and pleasant. The frosted glass wall between the bedroom and bathroom opened it up a lot. The double blinds kept it dark when needed. The bed was incredibly comfortable and there was a good sized desk space (I was on a work trip and appreciated the desk and the fast wifi). Breakfast (1330 yen) was very good. Despite the crowds of tour groups, food was plentiful, fresh and hot, and the very busy staff cleared tables quickly (a bit too quickly for me one morning). I had a buffet lunch with pasta one day which was excellent. The vending machines on the ground floor give you plenty of beer and other drinks if you need them. I have stayed at the Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku before and will think about staying at the Granbell again.

Great hotel at a very cheap by comparison price in a fantastic location. Small rooms but this is a japanese thing and not a criticism of this hotel. Buffet breakfast was also very good. Overall i would recommend this hotel.

I booked an economy single room and the good price and reviews made me book this particicular hotel. Afterwards I realized how good and central the choosen location is (an easy 10min walk from Shinjuku station). The hotel looks like a nice designer hotel and even my small (but large enough) room looked nice and well maintained. Check-in (as always in Japan) is possiple after 3 p.m. only but they provide generous luggage storage. The bed was very comfortable and probaly 140cm wide. The bathroom was especially nice with plenty of hygiene amenities provided. The brekfast is nicely provided with a great view in the 13th storey of the building. The area around the hotel is quiet and offers good restaurants and shopping facilities nearby.

Easy walk from Shinjuku station, lots of restaurants and bars nearby. However location very seedy near red light district.The room was very small, but to be expected for the price. Having a large glass window between shower and bed would have been off-putting if sharing room with anyone else.The staff were virtually invisible, but not unpleasant. However this is an area I would not recommend for any other female travelling alone, as to reach it from Shinjuku station you have to walk through Tokyo's red light district.

The rooms are as small as you'd imagine in Tokyo! But it's comfortable and well placed near tube stations, which is how you'll explore Tokyo anyway. Its in a bit of a seedy area, but they're isn't any trouble. You get free water each day, and you can post your luggage to your next location from reception for about £8 a bag! Which is super handy when you're doing a fast tour of Japan!

Good hotel in the centre of Shinjuku. It is one of those hotels that you'll find all over the World, so it has a slight generic feel. Service is flawless albeit without any personal touch - but what to expect from a hotel this size. The rooms are an ok size for Tokyo standards, but admittedly we did not stay in the fancier once. The rooftop bar is rather cozy and serves ok drinks.

Design and ambiance is very young - I would say it's Muji-styled - simple. Guests generally are international and young too. One sad thing is about the shower, not strong enough and you cannot get the best temperature. The location is so-so, closest subway station is not exactly Shinjuku. If you walk back from Shinjuku center (let's say IOIO mall), it takes you about 15 mins. Feeling insecure at night on the way as there are motels and naughty night clubs nearby. Price therefore is relatively cheaper than those in the center (e.g. Gracery).

This hotel was our first stop in Japan. The cab driver had a bit of trouble finding it from the main shinjuku train station. The staff were very helpful, and spoke good English which made it easier after the long flight. The room was a little but very clean and with all the mod cons. The buffet breakfast was great value and had a vast array of foods. There is also a great 7/11 just up the street for late night snacks. I'd say the only down side is that the hotel is a little bit out of the way of all the action of shinjuku, but could be seen as a great getaway from the chaos without being totally removed from the action.

We stayed in the shinjuku granbell for 4 nights 3rd-7th November 2015 The good:- very helpful reception staff who can speak good English. We arranged to have a wifi walker delivered to the hotel (highly recommended in Japan) and the hotel staff were very helpful making the pickup smooth. There are leaflets in reception with suggestions for restaurants etc and the reception staff can happily arrange any excursions. They kindly assisted us in going to the lawsons shop to use the machine to purchase tickets for the studio ghibli museum. - excellent location. The hotel is close to the "red light area" Kabukichō but it is perfectly safe and lively. We walked around till early hours and were not hassled at all. There are plenty of bars and countless restaurant options of a range of cuisines within 5-10min walking distance. The JR shinjuku station line is 10-15min walk for those with JR passes which is handy. The higashi-shinjuku metro station is even closer (5mins) which can access all the major attractions if don't wish to activate JR pass while in Tokyo. The metro lines are quite easy to follow. - we found shinjuku is a much more lively and "adult" than the more teeny bopper shibuya area. - rooms were very clean and modern albeit very small by western standards. I shared with my wife and there wasn't much space to open our suitcase but we laid it out on the desk in the room which was fine. The toiletries provided were very good and the "fabreeze"fabric spray was handy. - the Japanese toilets are amazing! - the roof top bar was a very friendly place to have a drink with nice views and the attentive staff were very considerate to offer heating and blankets on the cooler nights. - the free wifi was a good usable speed and streaming was fine Areas to improve/things to be aware of:- very small rooms. This hotel is more of a business hotel so rooms are tiny by western standards but are perfectly fine for individuals but there isn't much space to store suitcases in the room but can put on the desks. The beds were comfortable and bathrooms were perfectly adequate with good toiletries. - the breakfast options were fine but would be nice if had an omelette station. - there are no porters so have to take your luggage to your room yourself - the taxi drivers sometimes struggle to find the hotel maybe the postcode doesn't show up on the sat nav accurately. It is very easy to locate on foot however when coming back from a night out In short a very good hotel in a good fun location to explore Tokyo.

The Granbell Hotel located at the entry way to Kabukicho, a major adult entertainment district in Tokyo, was a mixed bag in my opinion. The Good was the price which is quite reasonable when you consider all options. Here you will get a typical Japanese Hotel room...very small compared to western standards, but very, very clean. The cleaning staff here is 5 star. They are almost invisible, but work their magic everyday in your room. They are the superstars here.Smal, dark lobby which the ladies did not like.The location is in the Kabukicho red light district of Tokyo and considered "seedy" by some . A few people may consider its location as "Bad" or "not so good." I was stopped in broad day light by two very polite ,uniformed police officers who did a "security check," asked for I.D. and patted me down. I am 72 years old and didn't think that I posed much of a threat. A front desk clerk had a similar experience. As the officers told me, "here have drugs and stabbing." I, however, found the location quite interesting and colorful though not really a venue for a family. Fortunately, Japan is still one of the safest countries in the world so being almost anywhere is not really a problem from a safety stand point.The Higashi Shinjuku subway station is about a 3 minute walk if you take the shortcut through the small side streets...totally safe even at night though dark in some places. I traveled with my wife and four friends...we were never compromised in any way.The front desk staff: Here, the "Bad" experience was subjective. It may have been just me, but another person in our party felt that the front desk staff were a bit "tired of all the questions being asked about directions to places." I believe it was just one person who gave us a negative experience, but it nonetheless colored our opinion of the staff.Most were extremely helpful in answering our questions. We did not speak the language and judging from the clientele, few did. Most of the visitors were visitors from China, the U.S, Europe and Thailand.All front desk staff spoke decent English. My personal indignation, while beginning to ask a front desk clerk for directions, was her telling me to move away so that the 'line" could be open for other customers. When I looked behind me, there was no one around. For the most part, the front desk staff was wonderful and helpful although maybe somewhat tired of being asked the same kinds of questions over and over. It is my opinion that that is part and parcel of their duties and their job...it's the people.For the management, one person on your staff may need retraining. Unfortunately, it just takes one to taint the rest. It was our opinion that it was not a language barrier, but rather an issue of being less rigid to protocol and more flexible to individual situations. If the staff member was too busy, she should have excused herself and have some one else address my question.Still, the Granbell Shinjuku in Kabukicho will probably meet most of your needs. For my part, I will not return mainly because of its location and not because of the staff.

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights in Sep. Around 10-15 mins walk to Shinjuku JR station, this hotel is close to 歌舞伎町. We booked designer casual room. The room is stylish and clean. The bed is comfortable. We can sleep well. The wash room is big and not the standard Japanese style. It is great However, the breakfast is so so.. Not many choices. For more detailed review, may read workheartplayheart blog.

We went of a family holiday with two adults and one young teenager with our need for two rooms next door to each other. The single and double rooms we booked were cosy but had all the amenities we needed. The bathrooms had a bath shower. The hotel was a 4 minute walk to Higashi-Shinjuku metro station and a 7 minute walk to Shinjuku-Sanchome metro station. The hotel offers everything you need for a visit to Tokyo, a clean and convenient located bed. The location is great as Shinjuku is renowned for shopping, restaurants, bars and great nightlife. I would recommend anyone to stay at this hotel.

A great prices suite at the top of the hotel is what brought us to this centrally located shinjuku hotel. On the plus side it is a hop skip and jump from the centre of the most vibrant commercial area. It is, however, surrounded by "love hotels" and that offers an unusual vibe.Hotel restaurant is best avoided. Based on a prison canteen motif, this is achieved but at expense of the patron. Queuing with a tray to sit on utility furniture on a stained carpet- not quite 4 star! Staff promise a lot verbally, deliver little in reality. But do enjoy the humane of cheap luggage perpetually stores across the lobby.

Typically small Japanese room, but very clean and extremely comfortable. The location is ideally situated in the heart of Tokyo and very near to the subway station and main train station. Would definitely stay again.

We stayed for 4 nights at this small but very comfortable and convenient hotel. Short walks to all areas worth visiting around Shinjuku Tokyo. Staffs are friendly, many quite good with English. Beds are small. So is the toilet. Service very good.

Rooms are small (normal for this type of hotel in Tokyo) but comfortable. The staff was very helpful and the location was pretty good, in the middle of Shinjuku. My only complain would be the restaurant. Breakfast is overpriced and the dinner menu is very limited.

Everything you need in a hotel including amenities and an easy location to get to. Get a package that includes breakfast. Their huge buffet has everything to cater to any dietary needs.Super friendly & helpful staff. Nice rooftop bar to wind down after a day in Tokyo.

I was traveling solo, and took the deal room with one bed. The room was small, but honestly, I liked it. It had a built in sofa, or more a seating arrangement, enough for two people, or a place to lay out clothes. It was very clean, comfortable mattress, nice linens. Bathroom was also small, but first class, with a deep soaking tub and very hot water. The hotel was in a very quiet, safe feeling area. It was a short stroll down a quiet alley to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku

This hotel is very deserving of the good reviews. Located in a 'quieter' part of Kabukicho. Modern hotel that was a very nice change from typical Japanese business hotel. Quite spacious for a room in Tokyo.We found the staff very helpful, especially with assisting with our luggage forwarding forms. Highly recommended!

Tokyo was our last stop as part of our 3 week trip to Japan. Tokyo is a bustling and crazy city with many different areas to stay in. We chose the Shinjuku area as it is highly recommended by other travelers and locals. Hotel Granbell is tucked away about a 10 min walk from main Shinjuku city or 5 mins by train from the Shinjuku to Higashi-Shinjuku line. From the Tokyo station it is only 20mins by train. The hotel is still fairly new and offers a little bit quiet from the busy end. The reception is large and offers English speaking staff. It has a small cafe downstairs for coffee and other drink. Check in process is not too long depending time of day. My wife and I chose to stay in the Designer superior room which is on the executive level (level 13 above). We have stayed at other hotels around the world and as part of these floors you are always taken upstairs with drinks and personal check in options. There was no such option provided even though we found out later this could have been a possibility. Our room was spacious with a large window looking out to Shinjuku and a little beyond. It had a comfortable bed and the bathroom was large too. This sort of space is a rare in Japan so I would recommend spending a little more to get the space or you will be literally be living in a shoebox. The room came a lot of amenities including shaving razors, shaving cream, and makeup for the ladies. Plush bath robes were provided too. There is only Japanese tv channels offered but you do have the option of purchasing Video On Demand for blockbusters. Wireless is provided but sometimes is really bad and does drop off from time to time.The club lounge provided is small and offers limited drinks and no special food. It is a good place to go and relax sometimes. Breakfast is provided as part of some packages but once again the options are limited. The hotel has a restaurant and bar facility that provides some options for lunch and dinner. I have to advise though the hotel is located close to the Shinjuku night life (red light district) area. Night times may be a little hard walking through with younger family members. The owners/ promoters aren't in your face about things but it has to be noted. From the closest Higashi-Shinjuku station you are able to travel to many attractions around Tokyo. There is the Mitsui Outlet Centre located on the same line as Disneyland. You can go to Shibuya that has many different types of experiences inclusive of shopping and the busiest crossing. The Tokyo fish market is about 30mins by train and then you can go to Tokyo central station to look around the amazing building, later venturing out on foot to the imperial palace. The Shinjuku area itself offers great eating places and shopping. Tokyo tower and sky tree are all nearby as well. If you need to fly back using Narita airport then I would recommend catching a taxi from the hotel to Shinjuku station which should cost ~ 1,100 ¥. This helps you from carrying your bags around from one train station to another.

We stayed for 4 nights at this hotel. Its somewhere between a typical Japanese business hotel and a more standard hotel such as a hilton.On the plus side the rooms are ever so slightly bigger meaning that you are not tripping over your suitcase and the bathroom is just a little bigger giving more of a feeling of space. The cleaning is on par with any Japanese hotel - clean! We found the bed comfortable. The hotel is definitely new. Nice amenities are included with the room even some single serve drip coffee and great shower gel etc. The two biggest negatives I can say about the room is the Wifi although free was really not fast at all and by far the worst is the lack of black out blinds. The room features a set of double blinds - a sheer and a dark blind. Unfortunately the blinds themselves do not block out light and there are gaps either side of the blind (about 1.5") meaning that in the morning when the sun rises it just streams in. If you are like me and need a very dark room to sleep, you are going to struggle. In the end we blocked the gaps up with paper etc but its far from ideal and I did not encounter this with other hotels in Japan so its seems a strange oversight.The hotel is located in Shinjuku and essentially at the end of the red-light district. If you haven't been to Japan before then you must understand that all Japanese cities have these areas and they are very safe, you would not feel uncomfortable walking around (we were a couple), but it is not in the most central location in Shinjuku - it takes around 15 minutes to walk from the station although there is a metro within 5 minutes its not on the best line.The staff at checkin were just doing their job, nobody was rude but not that friendly either we were just another number for sure.I paid a high price for this place (around 25,000/night) and on reflection I think I would rather of just taken a more simple business hotel as we hardly spent any time in the room anyway and the lack of black out curtains/blinds was too big an issue for me.

Good: the rooms are clean, not very spacious but that's typical in Tokyo. the bathroom is also very clean and functional. English speaking staff is available. Takkyubin service also available to transport your luggage to/from airports.Bad: the location is not ideal in Shinjuku, especially in the summer. Be prepared to walk a lot.The staff basically ruined the entire stay. Originally we booked the place online and though my and my friend was getting a good deal. We specified that there are two people and we needed two beds. I called to make sure this and they said that our room was booked for a single bed and to upgrade to a double bed it'll be a 4,000yen/night upcharge (fine). Then when we go to the hotel they tried to charge over 8,000yen/night. I had to pull out their rate sheet to show them that they're full of garbage. After about 30 minutes of back and forth they finally gave in but that was completely unnecessary and unprofessional. Won't be staying here again.

We recently spent 2 nights at the Granbell. It is situated right at the edge of the shopping area, about a 10-minute walk to Isetan or Kabuki Cho. It's not the most convenient location, but definitely quiet.Rooms are slightly larger than most smallish hotel rooms in Tokyo. Decor is stylish. Free Wi-fi connection is excellent. Overall, everything is very clean and well-maintained. Bathrooms are of reasonable size. Beds are VERY comfortable with Simmons mattress, and they use feathered blankets. Blinds are designed to completely block out almost any light. We had some of the best night's sleep in Japan at the Granbell. Originally, I thought we may not want to return to this hotel due to its location. However, we stayed at two more hotels in Tokyo during our trip. I have to say Granbell compares favorably to the other two. One is very conveniently located, but the beds aren't comfortable. The other one is more upscale. Although comfortable, is even less convenient. I would say that a 10-minute walk is definitely something we could deal with.

The Shinjuku Granbell was a lovely hotel that was quite funky and cool. We stayed in a economy double room, and although it was on the small side, it was well sized compared to other hotels in Japan within a similar price range. We had good space to store our luggage and the bathroom was very nice (in many places we didn't have such luxury. They also have a roof-top bar which gives nice views over Shinjuku. The location is not bad, it's in Shinjuku, and about a 10-15 minute walk to Shinjuku station. However, for me the hotel is on the wrong side of Shinjuku. I wouldn't say it's a bad area, but it's a bit seedier with many gentleman's clubs, love hotels and bars in the area. Having stayed in another hotel in Shinjuku a week earlier, I would rather stay on the other side of town.

wanted to stay centrally for my last two nights in Tokyo, good priced four start hotel in Shinjuku, easy walk to the station. Very clean hotel, quite a spacious room. Very friendly staff had made a mistake with the dates of my booking which they kindly resolved. Hotel is based surrounded by clubs of various types but had no issues with any noise etc. May get invited into a few clubs on your walk back to the hotel at night.

Nice and trendy 4 star hotel, with nice rooms and large bathrooms - the rooms are good for up to 3-4 days due to size, but then after all Tokyo hotel rooms are small. Breakfast is decent, but the best thing about their restaurant is the bottom to ceiling windows front giving great views over Shinjuku while having breakfast. Had drinks at their rooftop bar - good selection of drinks and very friendly staff - all hotel staff had been very helpful during the stay. Next time, I will consider to stay here again.

We booked the Penthouse Suite, which was surprisingly affordable for what it is. There are four suites on the same floor, all of which are unique, very large and have amazing views - and they all generally book for a lot less than you might expect. The Penthouse Suite has a separate toilet and bathroom (with a double shower and large tub) off the main entryway, with a large bedroom and living room through a set of double doors. This room has floor to ceiling windows that reach higher than the regular ceiling, then a skylight above that. It's an experience I've never had in a hotel view, and I seek out hotels for their views. (The view itself is a generic view of Shinjuku, but the design of the room and its windows is very unique.)We were worried that there might be parties going on in the other suites (and we knew they were all booked), but we didn't hear a peep out of anyone else on the floor.There's a small lounge for those on floors 13 and above with free drinks and snacks, but it's basically just an office that they've put a couple tables and chairs in. Still, may as well get that free beer and wine.We tried the bar on the 12th floor, which has an outdoor terrace and a surprisingly better food menu than the restaurant next door. The food was pretty good bar food (and I don't know where else to get Taco Rice outside of Okinawa), but the bartenders seemed a little inexperienced and weren't able to recommend a popular Japanese cocktail to the Australian couple next to us. The terrace is really nice if it's open, but we ended up eating at the bar because of the cold and wind.I didn't eat the included breakfast, but my wife did and she said they actually had a lot of different types of food. It's not just a continental breakfast; she said there were Japanese, western and even Korean food options. She was happy with it, although she said it was quite crowded.The lobby is small and was constantly packed whenever we passed through it. They seemed to be having several tour groups from China come through when we were there. Almost all of the guests we saw were foreign, which isn't really a problem but was just unusual to see. At other hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo, most guests are usually Japanese. Maybe that's why the public areas of this hotel seemed a little loud in comparison.Location-wise, the hotel is in Kabuki-cho, surrounded by "love hotels" and host/hostess bars. This didn't bother either me or my wife, but it might bother some people. Kabuki-cho isn't really a "red light" district in the sense westerners might think of one, with all the dregs of society hanging out on the street. It's still just regular people, it's just that the types of businesses you see are geared towards a certain industry. The Granbell is kind of on the edge of Kabuki-cho, so it's really easy to just walk a couple blocks and be in the business part of Shinjuku. The train station is a little bit of a walk, but not too far. They will call you a cab at the front desk, but they charge 400 yen for it.
user_location: Valley Stream, New York, United States
user_name:
Jeff W
Valley Stream, New York, United States

review_body: Myself and two friends stayed here for a few days in a double room with a loft. I'd recommend having very clear directions to the hotel if you are travelling by taxi as it wasn't known by our Taxi driver. The room was decorated well, it was quite compact but had a lot of storage space. If you have quite big luggage it will be hard to fit this into a room lying down, it would be okay for a few days. The room window was very big and gave a great view of Toyko. The breakfast was an average price and buffet style with good selection. The hotel staff were helpful and arranged a taxi at our request.

This was the first hotel we stayed in Japan and was a really good quality and standard. Yes our room was small but perfectly contained. The room was spotless (with a great toilet), but not a huge space to unpack. Whilst the hotel is in Shinjuku you are set away from the hostess bars and the receptionists are very helpful and friendly.We enjoyed the rooftop bar but as its a hotel the beers were on the dearer side (¥900 as opposed to ¥500 in other places nearby).

We stayed at shinjuku's granbell for a little bit more than a week. The room was quite small, but the hotel is very clean, well organized and very good attention from all the personal. Has a good location for subway (2 blocks away) and walking distance from jr shinjuku's station.

As others have mentioned, this hotel is surrounded - literally - by "love hotels", nightclubs, etc.While Tokyo is VERY safe, if you're a man and walking alone at night, expect to be continuously pestered by extremely aggressive touts, to the point where they'll follow you down the street for several blocks.Not my idea of a good time.

This was our second time staying at this hotel and we loved it as much as the first time. Fortunately there were convenience stores nearby because we woke up at 3am from jet lag and we were hungry. There is a discount for returning guest if you book directly from the hotel website. Breakfast consisted of Japanese and Western style foods. Price was around $13 CAD per person. Lots of selection and servers were attentive. There were reviews that travelers were concerned about the safety of this area but we felt very safe going out even in the middle of the night.

Location - very well connected underground line about a 7min walk away - we used this to get to all the tourist spots in Tokyo. 5min walk from an outstanding sushi restaurant and convenience stores. Yes it's close to Kabuchiko, famously the red light district in Tokyo, however it's on the outside of this so you don't necessarily need to walk through it. Also, we walked through very late at night and always felt completely safe, I would have happily walked through on my own without needing to worry.Rooms - we stayed in a standard double for 8 days and it was perfect. Very comfortable, clean, peaceful, great view, spacious rooms, deep bath, great facilities. Lovely little touches and added extras in the rooms too.Facilities - roof top bar was excellent, amazing views, excellent service, they even offered blankets when it got cold! Vending machines with a good range of food. Lovely little cosy cafe as you come in. Fast, free wi-fi. Room service was excellent - the only down side was that they only offered Western food.Staff - very friendly and helpful, most spoke very good English. The reception was always well staffed.

The room and hotel facilities at Shinjuku Granbell Hotel were decent, but not as nice as pictured in management’s photos. The room certainly appeared larger in the photos. Because I was not expecting much in the way of space, I took little issue. The in-hotel laundry machine was much appreciated. The hotel staff was professional and courteous. I cannot comment on the breakfast because it was not included with my room.I stayed at this hotel because the price appeared reasonable for a major metropolitan city. During my stay I realized that was a reflection of the hotel’s location. The cleanliness of the neighboring streets belies the fact that Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is located in a red light district and is surrounded by short-time hotels, pimps and hustlers. I eventually gave up walking around at night because the area is not safe. I was approached several times by African men trying to arrange prostitutes or sell me drugs that only took “no” for an answer when I mentioned alerting the police. With little to do after dinner, I researched the area to see what I had gotten myself in to. I found quite a number of dangerous and outright disturbing scams in the immediate area of Shinjuku Granbell Hotel as described by tourists and the US State Department. It is far from the Tokyo I was expecting.

Located in very lively neighbourhood of Shinjuku – Kabukicho, Granbell Hotel is a great choice for people interested in good entertainment after darkness. Area is full of restaurant, karaoke bars, shops, cinemas. The hotel is close enough for easy and effortless walk to all of it, and in the same time far enough for peaceful and quiet nights. The restaurant is on the 12th floor, offering nice views over Shinjuku. The breakfast choices were quite good, varying from Asian to continental foods. We stayed in economy double room, the space was small but manageable, same with bathroom – decent size bathtub and good choice of toiletries. Everything was spotless clean. There is very easy connection to other suburbs of Tokyo – subway stations are just minutes away, and walk to JR station doesn’t take longer then 15 minutes.

Overall a nice and clean hotel. Rooms are a little small. Most staff spoke/understood English and were very helpful. Our hallway floor had a damp smell always after cleaning. Better signage on hotel website to show maps for directional pathway when arriving at train station. Would stay again.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell in October 2015. It's an OK hotel with a pretty good location if you use public transport (close to metro station). It is also fairly good value when considering general prices in Tokyo. A few points however: the room was very small, the breakfast was not great (all self service and no additional requests could be made + no English speaking staff), and the concierge recommendations were average/poor. Overall clean, Central and fair value hotel.

Top notch hotel with all the comfort you could ask for in the room. The rooms were quite large for Tokyo and had it all. Helpful staff and with a roof snack bar, it was nice to sit and see the views after a day around town.The hotel also is central located to shopping, nightlife and restaurants.

The location of the Granbell is fantastic, just a few minutes walk from Golden Gai's cute hovel bars and close to a couple of metro stations. Shinjuku centre is only a few minutes walk away so no need to worry about making your way home later at night. We were upgraded to a room on the 16th floor upon arrival which gave us free access to the Club Lounge on the 13th floor. This meant free soft drinks and nuts/sweets etc all day and between 5-7pm there was free wine and beer, excellent! The room was nice, although definitely could have done with some storage. We found this to be a theme in a lot of Japanese hotels, but here more so. Our view was amazing looking out over the city and the hotels roof terrace, so we did have to use the blind a few times to ensure no one could see us changing! The major stumbling block was the wifi which prevented any FaceTime/Skype from being clear and Netflix etc was a no go. In a city like Tokyo there is admittedly little need to stay in and watch movies, but the poor wifi in a city so technically advanced as Tokyo seemed a bit ironic. If you were here on business it could prove a real issue, but for us it was just a bit irritating. Otherwise good with a location that cannot be faulted.

We stayed for 4 nights in the Granbell and really liked it. It was our first visit to Tokyo, so Shinjuku and its buzz was a bit of a culture shock, but overall the area is convenient. The room we stayed in was great, 13th floor with a very big bathroom and a good view. Breakfast was fantastic, and the rooftop bar provided a nice ambience for evening drinks. My only negative point is their check in policy. Yes, I know it's common practice in Tokyo, but when you arrive at 8 in the morning, jet lagged and desperate for a bed, a 3 o'clock check in time is ridiculous. Our room was ready, but we could only check in by paying an hourly rate which amounted to a pretty hefty sum. That felt a bit like blackmail.

After staying at Shinjuku Sunroute Plaza hotel for 4 days, nothing compares. This location is a 10 minute walk to the subway and you have to walk through random streets, not very easily accessible. The bathroom door wouldn't even close. The views were awesome though! Definitely NOT CONVENIENT!

The Granbell is a modern hotel, well located down a few back streets in Shinjuku. You can follow the park pathway from the main street, passed the Golden Gai and turn left at the end to find it's location.This stay we got an average sized room, that was tidy and well maintained. While we did have a window, it faced an adjacent building, so we had little natural light or any views. I would still stay at this hotel next time in Tokyo as all-in-all it is an excellent choice and good value for money considering the excellent breakfast they offer.

What a beautiful room we staid at! We were on the 14th floor, we had a huge room with a lovely bathtub and big shower. Lovely beauty products in the bathroom. Staff was very polite and helpful. Good breakfast with an awesome view!Only negative point is that people could see into our room from the rooftop bar, so had to close the blinds in the evening when using the bathtub

As a frequent traveller to Tokyo I've stayed in many hotels, some good some not so good. This hotel sets a new standard for mid level priced hotels. Yes the area in Shinjuku is "colourful" but perfectly safe and the staff are friendly and helpful but it's the rooms that stand out. For tokyo the rooms are a great size and the roof top bar is a must.Would highly recommend this hotel for both the business and leisure traveller.

A clean, convenient and stylish hotel in Shinjuku, we enjoyed our stay here. Reception staff speak good English and are very helpful. There is a good terrace bar on the 12th floor too. About 10 mins walk from the train station and 2 minutes from the awesome Golden Gai area.

Great location, with easy (walking) access to nearby attractions. Staff were really helpful and there was lots of information in English for tourists. Downside was that the rooms were tiny. Would definitely return though - recommended.

Overall we had a great experience at this hotel. The room was quite little, but as expected in Japan, the staff even though not completely fluent in English very helpful and available. Great position to reach the metro. The sky bar was a delight! Good place to stay while visiting Tokyo

In March of 2014 my wife and I visited the Shinjuku District in Tokyo, we stayed at the Granbell Hotel. What a great pick perfect location. The check-in was quick and they spoke some English. This was one of the cleanliest hotels I have ever stayed at. It was pretty much brand new at the time I think it had been open for less than 3 months. I would recommend this hotel to everyone travelling to Tokyo.

I got lost trying to find it, Shinjuku being so big, compact and crowded, probably overestimated my ability to navigate my way. Once found, it was very easy to get around the east side of Shijuku, kabukicho area. The big malls are nearby, Odakyu, Taka, Marui, Uniqlo and Isetan among them. Good restaurants near the hotel too like Black Hole (wagyu beef). The night time is where the area around there becomes alive with bars, clubs and entertainment. Beware of touts and they can be friendly and yet persistent, but you wont feel unsafe. Tried the single room and the twin room. The single one was really small, just nice to sleep for 1 person. The twin was slightly better but still small, Japan standard. having said that, the bed was comfy and amenities good. Would stay there again if i go back.

The hotel was nice, the pictures make it look nicer, but nothing wrong with it. The staff was friendly. Comfortable bed, nice bathroom, small room. Area is fine, it's near all the shinjuku neighborhood attractions. Easy to get to the train. Near Shibuya. Cool rooftop.

Very pleasantly surprised. A great hotel. Nice lobby, welcoming staff. Room small but all good. Very quiet so a great nights sleep whilst still being central. Breakfast was plentiful, lots of choice. A great hotel to choose for a stay in Tokyo

Rooms were clean, definitely cosy but ok for Tokyo. Staff were great and very helpful. Breakfast was adequate not spectacular. About 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station and Lumine East. Just far enough away from the night life but not too far as a base to explore Tokyo from.Hotel offers free wifi which works reasonably well in my room (4th floor). Coverage doesn't extend to Level 12 where breakfast is served though.

I stayed for 5 nights at Shinjuku Granbell in Double Deluxe as a last minute purchase. Even though when I booked it via Agoda it didn't had breakfast, but the hotel gave me free breakfast which was a wonderful surprise! ;) As we were at the 15th floor, we can also access to the executive lounge. The stay was good, nice bed and facilities even though I thought it could be better if there is clothing hooks in the room! It was a great modern and spacious room nonetheless! Will try other Granbell property in the future!

When I arrived at the Shinjuku Granbelll I was caught in a sudden rainstorm, and dripping wet. The lovely staff at the front desk allowed me to check in as soon as my room was ready, before the official check in time. I was very grateful!The hotel room was very clean and welcoming. While the room was small by western standards, this is normal in Japan. The facilities of the building were good, and I appreciated the wifi access. I had dinner at the hotel restaurant, and it was delicious. Both Japanese and Western food were on the menu. I also ate breakfast at the restaurant, and again, both Japanese and Western breakfasts were present at the buffet. The hotel was conveniently located, and close to all the Shinjuku action, including a cat cafe! While there is a lot of night life, I felt very safe walking to the hotel at night. Overall a wonderful stay, thankyou Granbell!!

We stayed at the Granbell on the last night of a recent trip to Japan. The hotel is 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, located right on the edge of the Shinjuku night life. The room was very intelligently designed, and our son loved the split-level arrangement that allowed him to have his own little loft above us. The view (14th floor) was great, and if we'd tired of that we could have dropped the shades and projected a film from the projector on the upper level. Buffet-style breakfast was included and there was a good selection of Japanese and Western food on offer. Great value for money - highly recommended.

My partner & I stayed for 4 nights after arriving from Australia. Hotel was easy enough to find- taxi from Shinjuku main station as it was late-ish & driver knew where to go. Closest metro station was Higashi-Shinjuku, only a 5-10 minute walk- was a good station that was only a max of half an hour from any main sights in Tokyo & well-connected to other lines. Walk to main Shinjuku area again only 5-10 minutes from hotel.We had a standard room- yes it was small, but we were prepared for that from the website/previous reviews. And really, who needs to be spending lots of time in their room when in Tokyo! Bathroom was compact, nice to have plentiful amenities & nice shampoos etc in normal sized bottles! Bottled water that was replenished each day is always appreciated :)Rooftop bar was great- fabulous view & reasonably priced food/drink. Breakfast was okay, but there's so many food options close!If you're keen to spend lots of time out & about in Shinjuku, I would suggest this place!

We've visited Tokyo many times, most of the hotel rooms were quite small, so I decided to get an upgraded room at Granbell, it was not too much more than the regular room, but it was very spacious. It had a big tub and a separate shower stall, and double sinks. Rooms like these were very rare. It was very new and very nice. It was also very close to the metro.

The room was super dark, hardly can see anything things. We couldn't even pack our luggage in the dark. We booked a KING suite, but only got one room, from the entrance we had to climb a spiral stair with 12 steps . We can't lift our luggage up in narrow stairs. This was totally different as I saw on the website, which shows two levels with two beds. I got two levels, with only one bed. I felt earthquake on 8th floor at 11pm, called the front desk, the staff told me to call back to talk with someone who can speak English in the morning. I checked online, it was an earthquake!!! The room is not clean. There are thick dust over the bed. The last things was so disappointing... we booked the express bus from Cerulean hotel to Narita airport at the front desk. The staff told us that we could get the tickets on the bus. When the bus arrived at Cerulean hotel, waited for 20 minutes. When the bus came, the driver told us to purchase the tickets in the lobby at upstairs. It made us almost missed our bus and plane! WHY the front desk of Granbell didn't remind us in advance when we book the bus? We will never stay at a place this such inadequate service!

Near the train station, easy to find and excellent room! The bed was comfy, the complimentary bar was great, staff were very helpful and spoke decent English. A very detailed and thoughtful hotel. "Confirm go back. Double confirm!"

The hotel is 12 mins away from shinjuku station in the midst of love hotels. There are a lot of restaurants and bars near by so you don't need to go to the train station. The hotel room is very small, not many amenities and the room was consistently moist. If you are all about night life then this might be ok but not really great for anything else
user_name:
misskono
New York City, New York

review_body: This room was so small that with two people, you both have to basically be on your beds to be in the room at the same time. The wall between the bathroom and the bedroom is partially glass, so you can see the outline of the person showering (and one of the beds is right by this wall, which is a little odd if you are not traveling as a couple). We got lost trying to get to/from the hotel and the subway stations--it is off a main road in a sort of alley that is tough to find. If you aren't a seasoned traveler and don't speak Japanese, you will have a tough time navigating to and from this hotel without a taxi.
user_name:
emarienyc
New York City, New York

review_body: Our plane was delayed and arrived late at 1:15am. All public transports stopped at midnight so we took a taxi from Haneda-airport to the hotel, around 10,000 yen.The room is clean and a good size bed for a couple. Tea, coffee and 2 drinking bottles supplied everyday. A safety box and a small fridge are also handy. If you need an adapter for recharging your phone, iPad... asked staff. There are plenty local shops/restaurants nearby. The room get clean everyday and good bathroom products supplied and refilled. Friendly environment!

We spent our last night in Tokyo at the Granbell and were very pleased with the level of service and the style of the room. We had a loft room with a tatami mat sleeping area upstairs and a Western style (and extremely comfortable) double bed down. Floor to ceiling windows made the room so bright and it was nice to look out at the city lights. There were room darkening blinds for sleeping. We had a projector screen as well as a TV and a tiny, but well organized bathroom. The room was indeed small, but for one night not a problem. Anyhow - we spend most of our time out and about seeing the city. The complimentary breakfast buffet was excellent and there were nice in room amenities - coffee, tea, a fridge, and toiletries. There was a lot of helpful information in the lobby for travelers, like maps and information for getting to the airport and the staff were outstandingly helpful. There was also a bar, a coffee bar and a DJ in the evening (but a not-too-loud DJ, this is Japan after all) We were very impressed with the value for money and would certainly stay at the Granbell again.

Rooms are modern and clean if somewhat cramped. Blackout blind or curtains required, a paper thin blind simply does not suffice. In room wifi was some of the worst I've ever used, complained to reception but to no avail. A/C worked very well. The hotel is 15 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station but would recommend a taxi. The dinner menu is very poor.

I read so many reviews of Japans small hotel rooms before I went, that when I came the room sizes appeared to me as good. This is also the case for Granbell Shinjuku Hotel. Decent size room, good bed and great location. We didn't have breakfast so I don't know the quality in that term. The hotel is situated right next to the red light district, but I found it more interesting than anything else. It was a bit hard to find the hotel the first day - ended up taking a cab from Shinjuku Station, but the taxi-driver didn't either know it. Found it eventually.

During our visit to Japan last month, we decided to try this hotel. As the review is quite good.What we find in reality is difficult to find this hotel. We have to ask 4 peoples until we found this place and 1 of them even could not speak english but he is so nice tried to help us out.The hotel should offer the guests to email their hotel map location. As we find out they have one printed and they actually able to share with their foreigner guest prior to our visit.The staff are very helpfull and can speak english very well. This is the only best part of this hotel as this hotel space are too small even for only a couple with 2 suitcase. Too expensive for that kind of space. So not comfortable during our stayed just to move around inside our room.

Location in love motel district, north of entertainment district and south of Korean town. Equidistant from both shinjuku station and shin okubo station. For JRrail pass holders, easy access to yamanote line but hotel is closest to tokyo subway higashima station which requires a different pass. Can avoid skeevy elements by walking along garden pathway instead of main strip. We were hustled by at least 2 guys along the path around 11am. Walking distance to Golden-gai for famous drinking bars.Yummy red bean cake cart usually located on the street outside.Hotel: lobby ambience is nice, a quiet retreat in midst of busy district and all rooms are very new and clean. We paid for lowest priced rooms so it had the unfortunate glass wall between bathroom and bed. This is, after all, a hotel in the love district, so.... be comfortable with your partner or at least have a pair of headphones and eye mask for those "personal moments". Had great amenities otherwise Hotel breakfast was great with both western and eastern options available. Laundry machines were tricky as they only have 2 washers and 1 dryer, and a bit of a wait to use them. If you come back late, your laundry may/will be at front desk, the machines don't "magically" extend their cycle. Overall being in shinjuku is nice and central but would pick west shinjuku for quieter ambience.

Typical good large hotel in a quite good position in Shinjuku; you can get to the underground and train Station (be ready to deal with real labyrinths in Tokyo) within ten minutes on foot. Common areas are in a fancy style. Rooms are clean and not large (we had a superior "hollywood double" and had to reason a while about where to put our two pieces of medium sized luggage; no closet in the room) even though I realized they are probably considered spacious for Tokyo standards. Breakfast is average and they could do much better considering the style of the hotel.

Clean and compact room, everything you need and even a few things you don't. Didn't stay for long but the staff were very friendly, spoke English very well which was helpful. Can't think of any downsides for the place. Highly recommended if you need to stay in Shinjuku.

Overall a very good experience. The hotel is clean and stylish and at a great location. Close to subway and nightlife. There are just a fewminor things that bothered me a little. Firstly they offer free wifi, which is a good idea, but at an unbearably slow speed; secondly they have a cafe at the lobby that serves decent coffee of all sorts but it wouldn't open until 10am. Can't understand the reasoning behind. And lastly if did happen once or twice that the room was ready very late - around 4pm.Other than that I can recommend the hotel.

We stayed at the hotel for 7 nights. The room are very small but it's the local "standard" . The hotel was recently renovated and the room are clean & new. The staff were very nice and helpful. Breakfast was very nice . The location is great, only 10 min from JR and is the nightlife erea

This hotels location is quite central in Kabukicho. But at night time it's a little seedy and a few love hotels nearby. Staff were not extremely helpful and the price of the room is not really worthwhile. I travel to Japan 3 times a year and this would be my least favourite hotel stay. The roof top bar is not to bad but more aimed towards Japanese clientele.

Location is ok for me. Close to the red light district, which I really did not mind. the staff were friendly enough. Indeed no one to help you with the suitcase and all, but I really did not expect that. The rooms were well organised but slightly too small. Plus point, it had a laundromat, though I had to wait till 4 am to be able to use the single Dryer. I had already wash, no way, was I going to haul wet laundry to Kyoto. It's an Ok hotel.

A well considered and designed hotel. We stayed in the double deluxe and its compact but well detailed. The location of the hotel is not that convenient to Shinjuku Station. However the breakfast is fantastic. There is no gym. There are laundry facilities are coin operated and you will need to purchase liquid from the reception. There are no ironing facilities in the room. That being said everything else is included as per a good hotel. We had a great week here and will recommend to others!

Everybody recognices that finding a totally rounded hotel in Tokio is very dificult If not imposible at a reasonable rate in terms of locación, friendliness, room space and convenience, for example. Its locación is great as the metro station is very close. However, If you don't need a "massage" better go to other area. Definitively not a family place. Breakfast was cheap in both senses of the word. However lets finish positive: friendly service people, good rates and The terrace is superb with great views.
user_name:
Pedro A
Community of Madrid, Spain

review_body: Best hotel bed ever, a loft my son didn't want to leave, beautiful evening views from the terrace, helpful staff & a great value breakfast. The fresh slippers & kimono daily was a thoughtful addition. It was also only 3 minutes' walk to Higashi Shinjuku train station. Highly recommended.

This is a typical Tokyo hotel. Very small rooms and a fairly high prices. Hotel facilities are quite good and the rooms were very clean and nicely designed. Close enough to metro station. Nevertheless, the location of the hotel is not the best for families. It is at the heart o Tokyo's red light district.

Stayed for two nights. The room was clean and the hotel was nice. But the staff was not friendly at all. Asked in advance if the hotel could reserve a resturant table as the resturant only accepted reservations through a hotel, they refused, saying this was something they only did for their premium guests or something. The staff was not friendly or attentive during our stay either.The location is convenient, but be aware as it is centrally located in the red light district, surrounded by shady hotels renting rooms by the hour. But the area did not feel unsafe.But stay away if you can.

Mostly foreigners here so the staff speaks English very well and is very accomodating. I came early before check-in time and they held my suitcase at the front desk. When I went to the room it was a double room and not what I requested. Mia at the front desk came to my room and gave me a new key to a different room and walked me there. She was very nice. The room had a see-through wall ( like frosted glass) as a wall for the bathroom. I had a friend there waiting for me which was kind of awkward.. Overal great experience and great location.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Adam H
New York, New York, United States

review_body: The hotel itself was nice enough, short walk from Shinjuku station and very close to many restaurants and convenience stores. The rooms were great and the bed was comfy, the staff were helpful. However it was very strange that what separated the bathroom and the bedroom was a giant window that didn't have a curtain or mist setting or anything. I was travelling with a male friend and didn't really want to use the bathroom with him there and vice versa so we called to get a curtain put up. They duct taped it to the ceiling and it of course immediately fell down when the room became steamy and humid. Anyway it was the only bad part about the stay and we had a good laugh about it, so overall a nice place to stay.

Pros:-5 min walk to Higashi shinjuku Metro Station-We have booked economy double room. Room size is reasonable compare to many Japan mini size hotel.-Hotel is new, all furniture and decoration is stylish and clean.-with Bath tub and good water pressure and hot water.-Air condition is good. Easy control room temperature.Cons:-Walking distance to Shinjuku shopping area is a bit far, especially when tired

Nice hotel. Works were in progress when we arrived, but this should be complete by November 2015 according to the signs. Located in nice area. Friendly staff. Washer dryer available. Lovely breakfast - well worth getting. Good value for money.

Electricity went out in our room 5 minutes into our stay. They made us wait an hour (without AC in the summer!) while they tried to fix it. They couldn't fix it in the end and switched us to an identical room, despite nicer rooms being available. Not something I would expect from a hotel in this price range.

Very Stylish,modern and new hotel in prime location,close to restaurants and nightlife easy walk to Shinjuku station.Loved the decor Breakfast included and good .Helpful staff Will certainly stay again

In the heart of Kabukicho, about 20min walk from JR east exit, room's small as usual in Tokyo but with everything you need. I did't try the bar or restaurant inside as there're too many choices around. Stay for two night at JPY $24000 which's not cheap but worth for a trial.

Stayed here for about 4 nights just for a personal vacation. The location is great. The subway station is easy to get to and there is lots of nightlife in walking distance. We actually went to a bar in the Golden Gai which I did not think we'd be able to do as foreigners but we found a tourist friendly bar and had a great time. I would stay here again if staying in the area. The hotel also has ironing boards, vending machines and lots of nice amenities. I only docked one star because the staff was not as friendly as some other hotels we stayed at and there is not shuttle or anything to help you get to the airport but I suppose I should only expect that of a fancier hotel anyway. The room was very clean though and the bathrooms were great.

Yes. The room was small but it was perfectly appointed. My husband and I had no problems with it because, well, we were out touring Tokyo for hours upon hours. Super clean and modern hotel in a great location for seeing the city but coming back to shinjuku to party. Definitely hit up the golden gai area which is a 2 minute walk from the hotel. I was most amazed by this section of streets filled with the tiniest bars you've ever seen. Some of them might fit only 2-4 people. We had Ramen at a place around the corner from the hotel, one of those spots where you pay from a vending machine! It was damn good! (Don't know the name bc everything was obviously written in japanese. Like others have said, it's super close to a metro station and where you can get dropped off for the airport limousine bus. I highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay here again!

We stayed here for the first three nights in Tokyo - arriving early we got to the hotel extremely hot and tired having arrived from 14C degrees to 34 C degrees. We walked from the main Shinjuku station which was probably a mistake but nevertheless a more hospitable welcome and an iced water or something would've been nice. We asked whether our room would be free earlier and it was at a charge of 9000Yen - we were desperate for showers and a lie down so the money was inconsequential. We had the designer casual room which was a great size with king bed and lovely free standing bath, shower and toilet room. The decor and facilities in the room were great and faultless. Our room was at a the end of the corridor and seemed to be the meeting spot for the cleaners and all their bits and bags so each time we exited we were met with laundry, carts etc and afternoon naps were broken with chatter outside. The breakfast option was ok to get you going and for westerns especially craving breakfast cereals and eggs this is a ok option. It s rather cafeteria style but you eat and get out and about. The location was great and others have said the Istean department store food hall was a saviour as they had delicious salads, rolls and mixture of Japanese foods. We visited this at least 3 times whilst there. We dined in the restaurant one night and ate a pasta and pork and rice but one thing which is great is the rooftop bar overlooking the city - even if you have a drink before venturing out it is well worth it. Can't fault the location to golden Gai area and other sites from the station. Would stay back at another Granbell for sure perhaps to experience another area of Tokyo

The location of the hotel is PERFECT. It is about a 10-15 minute walk from Shinjuku station and a 5 minute walk from Golden Gai (bar neighborhood). I felt the price was fair for the room. Everything was very clean and they provided us with complementary water. The bathtub was lovely. At the top of the hotel is a bar/restaurant that has FANTASTIC views of the city. I'd recommend going there for a drink even if you don't stay at the hotel. If it is your first time visiting Tokyo I would strongly recommend staying here due to its perfect location. You won't be disappointed at how close you are to everything!

Our stay at Granbell Hotel was nice. The location was the best part of the stay, near enough to plenty of stations and the Isetan which is great for food in the basement if you want to pick something up on the go. Besides that the accommodation was nice and the rooftop bar was nice to have a drink on. The food (breakfast buffet and dinner) were not great and the food options close by (we did find a nice sushi option within 2-3 min walk) were also not great. The restaurants around the area may be because we didn't go to the best options, however the area seems to be more for its clubs and bars than for its dinner and food options. The buffet was very mixed cuisine and therefore didn't have enough of any one cuisine, they also didn't have the coffee options they offer downstairs at the cafe in the breakfast area. Dinner was less than we had expected from the photos that constantly run on the TVs in the elevator. The food was again limited and the quality was not the same as shown in the pictures. The only time I would eat there is if you were out of any other option and just wanted something near by.If we were back in this location for our hotel we would take a taxi/train to another area for dinner. We choose not to do this as in the summer heat at the end of the day we wanted to eat quick and get ready for the following day.The staff at the hotel were friendly and always willing to help. The rooms were very clean and a comfortable size. The cafe at the bottom of the building was good but it seemed to be only open in the afternoon, maybe this could be opened from early morning as they had more coffee options and would be good for traveller wanting to get something quick and go out for the day. We went to a tour of the fish markets one morning which started early (not the tuna sales but still early) and it would have been nice to pick something up from here on the way out.Overall the stay at Granbell was very comfortable.

If you want to spend your vacation time holed up in a palatial hotel room, don't stay here. If you want to blow your hard-earned money on a "luxury" hotel chain, don't stay here. If you want to stay in a dodgy cheapo hotel because "it adds to the experience," don't stay here. Stay at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel because you want to spend your time and money exploring Tokyo, and have a clean, well-serviced, and inexpensive hotel room to come back to at night.

Stay at Shinjuku Granbell economic double for four nights. The room indeed is quite small but I feel better after I saw my frenz' hotel in somewhere nearby. I guess the management really puts their effort based on their guests feedback. I was depressed that the covered the glass between the bathroom and the room. I think it won't be a problem to solo traveler or couple. The glass will also enlarged the vision of the view. The location is really convenient from East Shinjuku MRT station and there's 24 hr supermarket nearby but I only able to discover it on the last night. I went back to the hotel almost 1-2am in the morning and I feel safe while walking back from Shinjuku. Those hotel or bars surrounded didn't bother me at all. The rooftop bar is really worth to pay the visit!! The view is nice and the price is just the same as the bar nearby. The average price I paid for a night is about Y9,000 with 50 days advance rate that I think it's quite reasonable with what I got and also would love to recommend this nice hotel to those who wish to stay at Shinjuku area.

i stayed at this hotel earlier this month for my trip, i stayed six night in a single room, the room was small as expected, but is has all the amenities a traveler need, the only downside i have to say it the fridge was too small to even hold a regular carton of milk. but i got it on a good price so little complain here. the location of the hotel is however, better than I expected, it's within 5 mins walk to a subway station servicing directly to shibuya and many other major attraction and while it is located in the red light district, it is in the outskirt of it, which means you can enjoy all the fun this entertainment capital has to offer within walking distance but not having to deal with the noise. overall this is a nice hotel, and would recommend to people who is all about night life and a great night out.

Worth paying the extra fora bigger room, This hotel is a little gem! Very clean very modern great shower. Our suite was fantastic. Staff speak good English, location was 10-15 min walk to Shinjuku and 5 mins to higashishinjuku station. Red light district was a little seedy on a fri and sat night but only when foreigners were hounding you for your business.. Otherwise great!!

Clean, tidy, great design, nice view. Very good sleep by SIMMOs bed, very convinent(5mins walk from East Shinjuku Metro Station, 10 mins to Shinjuku JR Station)We stayed at Hollywood twins and double rooms for five nights.
