The house keeping teams are professional and had done a excellent job.The reception are also very helpful for arrangement The Korea street behind hotel provide more choice of shopping for Drinks, foods, cosmetics ...and moreIf you walk down from JR station, you can find many different Japanese restaurants around corners

Location: Kabukicho, the red light district of Shinjuku, and if you ask the locals, pretty much all of Japan. Now, having been around the world and visited red light districts and/or "seedier" in places in the likes Amsterdam, Vegas, etc., this was by far the most unnerving location for a hotel. Through no fault of the hotel, its a 15 minute hike from Shinjuku Station that takes you through Kabukicho. Now, if you appreciate being solicited by bar girls, pimps, hustlers on the way to the hotel, by all means, this is the place to be. Granted, as long as their is light outside, you dont need to worry but when it gets dark, they come out and are pretty aggressive (i.e. put their arms around you, follow you for a couple minutes, etc.). Would not recommend this place if you have a family since they would be exposed to this on a daily basis if you come back in the evening from a long day of touristy attractions.Room: In the 10 countries and 12 different hotels that Ive stayed in during the past 3 years, the wifi in the hotel is by far the worst. The reception is spotty as best. In the 5 nights that we stayed, I would say total connect time was may 15 minutes. You can get a better, faster connection in the lobby. The Standard Twin room we had, in and of itself, was fine but dated and due for an upgrade. The amenities are standard across all Japanese business hotels: shampoo ⁄ hair conditioner ⁄ body shampoo ⁄ soap ⁄ face towel ⁄ bath towel ⁄ body sponge ⁄ shaving kit ⁄ shaving cream ⁄ toothbrush ⁄ hair comb ⁄ nightwear ⁄ hair dryer ⁄ coffee ⁄ tea. The mini fridge allows you to store some treats from your daily adventures but best of all, they provide you with new bottle water when they clean your room if you use it.Service: The best part of this hotel is their staff. They were always helpful and tried their best to answer all our questions in English. Its limited --- but there was always someone there who could speak English and they knew enough to get the point across. They assisted us with providing their recommendations for things to do in Shinjuku and greater Tokyo, helped get our bags delivered to our next hotel, and overall very friendly and service oriented.Cafe: Its average at best. With all the food places and vending machines around, best to skip unless you need your morning cup of joe.Laundry: Being on the road for two weeks takes it toll on your wardrobe. This was the only hotel of the three we stayed to have a small laundry room (2 washers and 1 dryer). Its 200 yen to wash and 100 yen to dry. You can also buy detergent at the front desk for 100 yen/load and they can provide change.

Went a bit crazy and stayed for nearly a month. You won't get any special discount for a long period of stay. However we have tried many types of rooms this hotel can offer, from the smallest one to a penthouse suite, and all of them are stylishly designed, fresh and clean, modern and comfortable. Some of them were big and spacey, some small and cozy. Great location, easy access to a metro station but area in the night time turn up to be full of dodgy shot bars and approaching men. Love hotels are on every corner, literally surrounding Grandbell.I highly recommend its rooftop bar and restaurant with always smiley and lovely stuff, shepherd pie made by Ann is to die for, professional bartenders ready to create tasty cocktails you can sip on it whilst enjoying exciting view over city. Reception staff is very helpful and strictly professional. All in all I would so recommend this hotel. Must try.

We had a double room on the 4th floor. It was very small, but very modern and light. Surprisingly there were no coffee/tea-making facilities available in the room.Quite expensive, given what you get. The hotel is in a central area, very busy with bars and restaurants, and is surrounded by "love hotels".The roof-top terrace bar is impressive and you get a free drink token per room.When I become a millionaire I'll stay here in one of the fancy suites, but until then I won't return.

I booked the studio loft room for my boyfriend and I on his birthday. It was a nice and spacious room, with comfortable bedding and was very clean. It was well decorated, however the feature painting was peeling off the wall in the corner and the side wall was very dinted and really did need a re-paint. Staying in this room, we also got access to an executive area where you could help yourself to some snacks and alcoholic beverages. The view from here was awesome! There is also a roof top bar, which is open late which in convenient for some final drinks after a night out. The staff were very friendly and eager to help with anything.The breakfast was pretty standard.All in all, was a nice and pleasant stay, but for the money I paid, I did expect the room to be better kept. Side note: we went to the robot restaurant show whilst staying here - it's a great night and only a 5-10 min walk from this hotel.

We had a good stay at this hotel in June 2015. The room was 'compact' but very clean and new. The staff were accommodating and the location is really good for Higashi-Shinjuku station as well as Shinjuku Sanchome. The area is a little seedy (think Love Hotels and strip clubs) but the hotel is an oasis of class and calm. Good roof terrace, too.

Stayed here one night with my girlfriend who played for the night as a surprise :) it was a great room we were second from the top the room was spacious and the bed was big, don't get the breakfast it's average to say the best. The bar up top in lovely and the staff were nice, good local and most importantly very clean.

The rooms are small but pretty standard in Tokyo as we have come to learn. The rooms have everything you need despite the size. Clean and ample toiletries are provided. Privacy was a little bit of an issue as we had a room with a large glass separating the bathroom from the rest of the room. This meant no privacy when using the toilet. Make sure to ask for a room with a completely private bathroom if this is an issue for you. The location is alright. Shinjuju station is a little far to walk to with luggage especially but there are other train stops near by if you can figure the train system out. Alternatively it's a short inexpensive taxi ride from Shinjuju station. Remember to write the address in Japanese. practice your Japanese cause while the staff speak some English more complex requests can be challenging. Having said that the staff are willing and always ready to help. The area is safe but close to the red light district. We stayed for three nights which was just perfect. Lots of places to eat nearby. All and all good location and hotel for the price point.

I was expecting a small room, but this was still smaller than expected! There wasn't even room on the floor for suitcases, it is literally just a bed and just enough space to walk around it. (The bed is in the corner).Another surprise was that the wall separating the bathroom from the rest of the room is just a window! My room had a curtain (which was white) however my friends in another room did not have a curtain.When I booked the room, I had not read any reviews that indicated that it was in love hotel central, but it was. It was smack bang in the middle of lots of love hotels, and whilst I never felt unsafe during my stay, you do see a few girls coming and going in vans etc.The location is fairly decent as it is near a station, however there isn't much to do around there, we wandered to what we thought was the central Shinjuku area but it turned out to be the red light district, which mainly consists of a lot of guys standing around on the streets.Overall a beautiful hotel with lovely staff, however definitely on the smaller side and in a non-family friendly area.Although it should be noted that in general, the cheaper the hotel is in Tokyo for a 4/5 star, the tinier the room is.

If you're hoping to be right near an entertainment district, then Shinjuku Granbell might just be what you're looking for. The room I stayed in with my girlfriend was absolutely amazing, if not a little too pricey for what we paid. The rooftop bar is awesome, and so is the food and drinks they serve. Recommend if you're looking to relax a bit more, but it's not exactly the best location if you're looking to explore the rest of Tokyo.

Our first day in Japan, so after a long transit so we arrived late and tired. We had two rooms, a double on the 16th and a triple on the 12th The double was well appointed with a great view, the triple was a little tight but what we expected. The rooftop bar after a shower was a great start before going out for dinner. A lively area but our excursion was short. The bed was better than expected and the breakfast had enough variety for all of us. The staff were helpful and the location good.

First of all - great location: 10 min from Shinjuku station, 7 min from main streets, 3 min from Golden Gai bars area, 3 min from Higashi-Shinjuku metro station. Plenty of shops of any type and price range around, very active district. While it IS a love hotel and host club area, no uncomfortable feelings or issues were present.... In fact, you might feel uncomfortable only if you mind seeing pictures of good-looking young Japanese boys (no erotics, pop-music-style posters). Staff is friendly, very helpful, speaks sufficient English. Breakfast is average: bacon is glorious and delicious, sausages are very fat, scrambled eggs have rather odd texture but taste ok. You have rice, miso soup, yummy curry sauce and other Japanese-style goods.Breakfast room has beautiful panoramic windows - very inspiring at the beginning of the day. The room (even having a Deluxe) is smaaall! We couldn't open our big suitcase properly... And no wardrobe in our room, oly a rack with hangers in the corridor (and others on the floor as far as I could see). If you are a fashionista with 3 suitcases - take a suite maybe... Otherwise, the size bothered us only on the first day. Then it was ok.In terms of toiletery they give you everything you would wish for from shampoos to shavers and hair ties, no worries if you have forgotten anything. Bed is on the hard side but you sleep very well. I often have little back pains, but did not have any in this hotel. There are vending machines on the ground floor, and only one smoking room that is very tiny :( But, oh, Tokyo is definitely not welcoming for smokers anyway. Overall - good hotel! Would definitely recommend.

Pros: Hotel close to the station, looks new, rooms are very clean with nice amenities and nice bar in the roof and fine staff.Cons: Rooms are very small,breakfast is so expensive and not so good, I missed a pool or a hot spring for the hotel price.

I stayed here for 3 nights initially when I arrived in Tokyo, very easy to find just a 2 minute walk from Higashi-Shinjuku metro station on the Fukutoshin Line or Oedo Line. Or a 5 min taxi from Shinjuku Station on the JR Line. The staff aren’t the most polite and they are very annoying not letting anyone check in after 3pm and charge you if you wish to check in 12pm-3pm but I paid about £15 to check in early as I was so jet lagged travelling for 18 hours from the London, UK. Only downside is the staff manners and also it’s in the red light district surrounded by Love/Sex Hotels. But the rooms themselves are very clean and compact. I don’t think the size is a huge deal as the beds are very big. The bath tub is very deep and I love the electronic toilet. The rooms are cleaned daily, beds made and fresh towels. The water in the room is complimentary also which is great. I really enjoyed the comfortable room so I ended up staying there again on my final night in Japan. I was lucky to stay on my own, but if you are sharing with a friend ask for a blocked bathroom window as the bathroom shows everything with a glass window, so if you’re staying with someone you’re not intimate with, it can be embarrassing. Wifi was also extremely slow.

The hotel is located at the eastern part of Shinjuku, need a bit of walk to the shopping area and right in the famous red-light district. The hotel lobby was nicely designed, but not functional for keeping luggage for check-out guests and lack of seats. I was staying at a loft on 12/F, which is good for younger travelers as the ladder is very steep. The room itself is well maintained and can accommodate up to 3 adults (with 1 sleeping at the loft). Hotel amenities were good quality too. Overall very quiet environment and good bedding. Slightly over-priced and the hotel should consider its direction for going towards accommodating tour groups or individual guests since it is hard to achieve a balance in terms of the price and quality.

Hotel is around 7- 8 minute walk from Shunjuku Station provided you take the correct exit. Check in time is strictly 3 PM and don't take any exception. You will have to leave your luggage with the hotel staff if you don't want to waste your time sitting in the hotel lobby. By the way this is something common with all the hotels in Japan. Room was really small but quite neat and clean. Small toilet was having all the required stuff and was modern like as any other hotel in Japan. Overall it is a quite a good property keeping the location in mind.

If you want to be within 1 minute of sex, sex, and sex. this is it. I am not endorsing this aspect of the area but it is what it is. Assuming you have the guts and can get into the red-light establishments, this is the place to be. In addition, adjacent to the hotel are literally 50 "love" hotels in that area that have '3 hour' rates, half day rates, overnight, etc. You can even be a member of some of these love hotels. Having never been in one, I assume it is for the obvious. Even though the area is edgy, Granbell is a safe place. Even the area around it is safe as all the people just come and go into these bars and hotels. They don't want to be seen so the streets have people but they go about their business. It is not seedy at all like you might find in the US. The Japanese have a little more class and discretion when it comes to this. The area is an experience worth a try. As for the hotel, it would be an excellent hotel in any area. Service is impeccable, down to the cleaning staff. They clean quietly, never interrupting you. And, are always very pleasant when greeting you....unlike their American counterparts. Front desk was always helpful and spoke English good enough to get you going. The people in the bar and restaurant were equally helpful. So, for you English speaking people afraid of staying in a Japanese hotel, don't be. I had an upgraded room on the 15th floor. See pictures. It must of been 300+ sq ft and had a huge bathroom. You could put a bed in it. It has a separate shower and toilet area. The bathtub and sink area well separated. There was a 50 inch Sony TV with a Bose like music player that you can hook your phone into. Very well appointed room. Clean, good size, and quiet. They give 3 bottles of free water per day along with a bottle of iced tea and coke. Breakfast was good enough. They had western, some Chinese, and some Japanese. Eggs and bacon everyday along with salad, bread, cereals, etc. Good enough. Although not the level of a Four Seasons or Ritz, this hotel surpassed my expectations. 4.5 stars, 5.0 stars for value, They are a smallish sized hotel but I would put it above most Marriot's and Hilton's I have stayed at. Give them a try if you want to experience something different and want to be in the middle of where life is moving fast. Oh yeah, Shinjuku station is about a 10 minute walk but the walk goes real fast because everything around you is so interesting. Just do it!

While the room was typically Tokyo-sized (i.e. small), this hotel was a revelation, a rare example of one that exceeds expectations. The Reception staff were extremely courteous, helpful and efficient. The room, although small, was modern, clean and had a great view of the great urban wonder that is Tokyo. The only niggle was that the bathroom had a large glass window directly into the bedroom that failed to provide any modesty while in the bathroom! Not a major problem, but a curtain would be a useful addition. The star attraction of the hotel is, however, the rooftop terrace which provides spectacular views over the city. We dined here twice and both the food and drink was reasonably priced (the food was good for bar food). Overall, a great experience, especially for the reasonable price.

I would certainly go back.Very clean roomNice view from the 10th floor. A/c is essentialBreakfast is okLove the body and hair product in the bathroomAbout 10-12 minutes from the shinjuku train station.Very quiet street but very close 2mins away from the nightlife

Wow, what can I say, hotel staff go above and beyond here, nothing is an issue for anyone. Yes it near the red light district, but compared to old soho London it's very tame. Also easy to avoid by walking left when exiting the hotel.Loads of places to eat near the hotel and train station is very close. As it been said before get ready to do a lot of walking :)

An ok hotel above average I woud say. Our room was very small, but otherwise clean an ok. Breakfast also about average, you get what you need, but nothing special. Nice view from the restaurant. There is a nice bar on the roof with good view. Service is excellent. The hotel is located in an area with some doubtful businesses, but it is no problem. 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku station.

I was overwhelmed by my stay in Shinjuku Granbell Hotel. I don't know where to start! First the English all reception staff was excellent it made everything so much easier. Our room was clean spotless perfect sized for a couple. The balcony and rooftop bar was relaxing at night time. Great location in Shinjuku. Highly recommend anyone to stay here who are coming to Tokyo ! Worth the price.

Our experience was great. Staff were very helpful. The location is great and wiht breakfast included, the price was very reasonable. Sure the rooms are small, but you can't get everything, right? All in all, a great place to stay.

A great hotel, incredible comfortable beds, helpful friendly staff and the design touches add a level of personalisation you wouldn't get at this price elsewhere in the city. A good location where you're on the fringe of the Shinjuku madness, and as first timers to Tokyo it was a great base to be able to walk to lots of the popular places (Shinjuku shopping, the Golden Gai, Park Hyatt bar) as well as get on the subway easily to see other tourist attractions. We stayed in one of the executive rooms, for the extra space, and it was fantastic, definitely worth the extra cash, we felt like we had our own studio space which was a welcome retreat when the chaos of the surrounding areas got too much. The rooftop bar is a definite bonus for when you want to sit back and admire the skyline.

Location: It is about 10 mins walking from both, Higashi Shinjuku and Shinjuku Sanchome metro stations. The Shinjuku terminal is a bit of a long walk, and costs about 800 yen via taxi. If you do intend to walk from the terminal, use the underground walkway from exit E1 which leads you out to Shinjuku Sanchome station.The red light area is on the adjacent street, but is absolutely not a nuisance.Staff, Services: Be prepared with cash / credit card when you check in, as the receptionist demands for upfront payment, even though not mentioned on the online booking sites. The wifi is patchy in the rooms. The room we stayed in was extremely cramped, but was well designed and kept very clean. The breakfast (1300 yen) has Japanese and English spread, and is quite filling.

I stayed here for a few nights on a stop over on the way back home. The (single) room was very small, but that didn't matter. It was very nice, well laid out, well equiped and had a comfortable bed. The bathroom was excellent and had a very good shower.There was a bar on the hotel roof which was nice, and the breakfasts were quite good. The only slight criticism is that the price should be a fraction lower for a room of that size.The hotel is a five/ten minutes walk from Shinjuku train station and is well situated for local bars and restaurants.I'd happily stay here again.

I love their toilets...very clean and awesome bidet :) Location was very close to Shinjuku area and train station. Family mart and 7/11 are close by. WIFI is ok. Japanese/Western breakfasts was nice. Housekeeping did a very good job every time we asked for clean up.

The staff were friendly and accommodating. Room was nice, small but clean - hard to fit our two large bags on the floor. Location was great and it was easy to get around Shinjuku. Great rooftop bar - although it was raining so we were unable to go outside. A little hard to find - the cabbie had no idea where to go and had to call the hotel for directions. Now, the negatives. You have to pay extra to check in before 3pm, which was frustrating as it was pouring rain outside and we didn't have anywhere else to go. Wi-fi was spotty at best and barely worked. I had to try 3 non-smoking rooms before I found one that actually didn't smell like smoke. The staff were kind and kept trying to help on that end, but it was frustrating that it was happening at all - especially since I had just sat in the lobby for over 2 hours waiting to check in. The restaurant breakfast and lunch were very American which I was not a fan of - pasta and pizza?! It might just have been the day we were there, but we paid a lot more than what is being quoted as the normal price. All in all, solid location and a clean hotel - amidst other frustrations.

*Manager admits it's not actually a 4-star hotel*We booked our last night in Japan at the Granbell Shinjuku and it almost ruined our otherwise fantastic holiday. We knew something wasn't quite right when we arrived - the hotel is located in a depressing area of the sex district, far from Shinjuku station and surrounded by cheap love hotels and brothels. The Granbell also offers a 'short term rate' and we noticed many potential 'sex tourists' staying as guests.We entered the noisy lobby, strewn with luggage littering the space, and were met with a cheap and overpowering scent.Matters got worse when we saw the room: although clean, our 'Superior Double Room' was depressingly small, with a stale odour and stuffy, dank air quality. The hard beds are set against a wall so you can only access them from one side, and the bunker-style window adds to an overall claustrophobic feeling. The rooms are nonetheless adequately appointed, but they are much smaller and darker than they appear in the photographs.We were immediately dissatisfied, and complained to reception twice. The reaction from staff was robotically apologetic, and they did nothing to resolve or address our concerns, so we asked to speak with a manager.The hotel manager was diffident and defensive, conceding that the hotel was not actually a four-star hotel, but that Booking.com and other sites imposed a rating, shifting the onus onto us for choosing unwisely. She seemed to feign confusion at the thought anyone would complain about the hotel, and tried to demonstrate that our dissatisfaction was unwarranted. Indeed, many of the staff seem to be under pressure, and ill at ease. We witnessed cost-cutting measures such as the offer of gifts to guests if they forewent daily room-cleaning services.The hotel does not provide any of the little extras that make a hotel stay comfortable. The front desk refused to send up milk for our coffee and tea. They don't help you with your bags. The lobby is a zoo. Breakfast is awful. The WiFi is very unreliable.After a flight cancellation we stayed a further night at the nearby Hilton, which was a supremely better experience and, at a similar cost, infinitely better value for money.This was a truly awful experience - not just a 'bad hotel' but a place that can potentially ruin a holiday.

A little hard to find on my walk from the nearby station, but worth the walk to see the shopping (above &below ground) and great selection of cafes / restaurants. Hotel was super clean and bright with brilliant staff.

The best thing about the shinjuku granbell is thier very friendly and courteous staff at the reception..they can speak decent English and try their very best to explain directions to us..you just have to name the place and they will give you a map and explain the easiest ways to get there!!!The granbell is also in a very convenient location and at a great price...it's just a few minutes away from the higashi shinjuku station that's the metro line(the A1-exit)!!! It's better to get a metro pass done along with the JR pass..we spent quite a bit for the metro tickets!! The disappointing part is the size of the rooms.. There's hardly any space for a second bag and a third bag is practically impossible..we stayed in a three occupancy room..the third bed is in the loft and the stairs to the loft is quite narrow..but once you go up there there's enough room to sleep..the wifi connectivity in the room is great..The bathrooms are decent sized except that the doors do not have a lock :)The breakfast buffet is wide spread but there is hardly anything vegetarian except for the cornflakes and bread..so if you are a vegetarian its best for you to avoid breakfast in your package..there are quite a few decent restaurants around the hotel..do visit the rooftop bar..The place has an amazing view during sunset!!!

We stayed at the Granbell Hotel for 3 nights at the start of a 2 week holiday in Japan and were pleased with our choice of hotel for the start of our trip.The reception staff were efficient and proficient in English, we arrived a little early for check in and they kept our bags for us (the lobby does often look like a luggage showroom). The breakfast service was good, with an adequate range of both western and asian foods and the resturant had enough room to accomodate the number of diners.If you're using public transport to get to the hotel, you might want to consider aiming for Higashishinjuku station rather than Shinjuku itself. Apart from being closer and just a 5 minute walk, it's very easy to get lost if it's your first time in Shinjuku. Use exit A1 from Higashishinjuku (unfortunately no lift to street level from this exit) and as you exit onto the street, turn to your left. Walk to the next street corner and turn left into that street (if there are any, cars will be coming up the street towards you) and the Granbell is a couple of blocks on your right, just over 100m down the street. You can see the car park and a side entrance to the hotel from this street, the main entrance is just round the corner on the diagonal street.The hotel is located a short walk away from the main hustle and bustle of Shinjuku, and as others have commented many of the surrounding establishments are love hotels that typically sell day use room plans, this does not detract from the Granbell and there was no perception of the area being seedy or unsafe. Although the Granbell does state it has day use plans available I didn't feel this was something it really focussed on and at the time we were there it was very busy with high occupancy levels (it was Cherry Blossom season).We had booked one of the two Ya Ma Tei Designer Doubles and although at 19m2 wasn't overly spacious it didnt feel cramped. It had a great view over the city (facing south) and over the rooftop bar a couple of floors below us. One of the really odd things is that the neither the staff nor the literature in the room pointed out that we had access to and use of the Club Lounge on the 13th Floor. Fortunately we had read the website and we made use of it several times - it had a complimentary view of the city looking towards the north.When checking out we got the hotel to send one of our suitcases forward to a future hotel using a luggage forwarding service which they did without issue. Overall we have nothing negative to say about this place, it was conveniently located with good transport links and Shinjuku just a few minutes away. Highly recommended.

We had four nights at the Shinjuku Granbell. It's in a pretty good location shopping wise. A lot of reviews talk about the red light area surrounding the hotel. It was very tame, it felt safer there than walking down Carlisle Street some days. I found the breakfast delicious. I did eat cabbage salad, rice and pickles though. We booked the deluxe designer double- casual room, which was quite spacious and had a lovely bath. The club lounge was nothing to write home about, we only went in once and weren't impressed with the lack of anything decent to drink. I think if you are going to do a club lounge, do it well or forget about it. The endless suitcases in the foyer area wasn't a very good look. All in all it was fine though. Very clean and comfortable, with the vending machines downstairs for your late night beer or ice cream . We also found good places nearby to eat.

We've chosen this hotel as it seemed to be great value for its position, considering the average price for hotels in the area.Overall we have been satisfied with the experience, possibly on of the best reception staff we have meet during our honeymoon in Japan. Rooms were small as usual, although not as small as many other hotels in Tokyo (but to open a second luggage we had to juggle it on top of the small sofa besides the desk).The rooftap bar was nice for an evening drink, quiet with a decent view and a good selection of drinks.The biggest flaw is that this hotel seems to operate also as a "love hotel", offering the "few hours stay" formula like many other hotels in that specific area of Kabukicho. This didn't cause any specific issue with the guests, but our room was pretty peculiar when you talk about privacy... the bathroom had a huge glass window with a great view... on the bed! Obviously there was no way to cover, even partially, that window so everything that was happening in the bathroom was just in plain view for whoever else was in the room.I can understand this might be "entertaining" for some, but it might be embarassing also for a couple and a disaster if the room was shared by friends travelling together.I don't think this is the case for all the rooms, but keep in mind to check before booking. Unless you like that kind of view in the morning... :)

Finding a hotel in Tokyo for the right price at the right location is hard. So when I cam across Shinjuku Granbell hotel, I was surprised that rooms were fairly reasonable and from it looked like a trendy hotel. Getting there is a bit of a trek unless you take a taxi, which isn't advisable as you pay through the teeth....luckily the hotel is just a 5 min walk from Higashi-Shinjuku station, and about 15 minute walk to Shinjuku station. Great thing about the location is 5 minute walk away, and you are right in the heart of Kabukicho. Rooms are a bit small but still comfortable. The staff are friendly and very helpful as well. They will go try their hardest to get a restaurant reservation which I was very impressed with and we appreciated it. They even were able to get a booking at Sushi Yoshitake for us during Golden Week.Another great thing about the hotel is their rooftop bar. After a tiring day of walking, head up to the bar for a nice view of the sunset and a cocktail.

My wife and I stayed here for 3 nights. Having been in Japan before I was aware of how small hotel rooms can be so I upgraded. Larger very nice rooms are on the 13th floor or higher. We were in room 1405 and it was superb. Our friends didn't upgrade and had the typical tiny room. While there is TV in the room, all the channels are in Japanese. The roof top bar was nice. Breakfast was expensive (included in our upgrade) at $13 US and just so so. We ate dinner there the first night because we weren't familiar with the terrain yet. My recommendation - Don't eat there. The staff spoke very little English which was surprising since at least half of the guests were Europeans although I think we were the only Americans there.
user_name:
Tom P
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: A very functional hotel in a slightly grubby area, surrounded by love hotels. Good location for night owls though. The room was so small. It became frustrating even though we were only staying one night. The bed was small, and there wasn't much room for luggage or toiletries,This is a busy hotel - the lobby was busy, and full of people's luggage. Breakfast was very busy, in hindsight we should have gone earlier to get the freshest food, (though it was replenished) and perhaps some peace. The roof top bar was nice, but otherwise this place lacked charm.

The hotel is conveniently near the Higashi-Shinjuku Station of Tokyo Metro line and exits at A1. There is no escalator or elevators up the exit, you will have to carry your luggages up the stairs, and that is common in many places in Japan. Another option to the hotel would be to take to Shinjuku line and walk a good 15 mins, or take a taxi to the hotel.The surrounding has many motels/hotels that charges hourly rates. But it is safe even when it is really late. The location of Granbell is considered central and excellent to start exploring Shinjuku.The hotel is modern and cosy and the size of the room is comfortable compared to another hotel that I have stayed near Shinjuku which had a much smaller room for similar price.

Modern designer hotel, small but quirky rooms, excellent service and many staff speak good English. It's only a 10-15 min walk from Shinjuku and easy to avoid the red light district of Kabukicho if you prefer by keeping to the main streets. But even then, this area is pretty safe by international standards. Wifi is variable and the lobby area is packed with luggage and sleepy travellers waiting to check in (which really detracts from its boutique tag) but nonetheless this is a good and deservedly popular option in Shinjuku and booking in advance online means a great deal too.

The Shinjuku Granbell is an excellent, modern hotel in busy Shinjuku, situated between some very cheezy looking hotels. Check-in was fast in efficient and the staff friendly. The rooms are small and oddly designed but clean and modern. There are no cupboards so try not to bring too much luggage. The bathroom was big (almost the same size as the room) with an open shower next to the bathtub. The washbasin is situated outside the bathroom (a bit odd). We had a big window with a lovely view from the 11th floor and had a little table and two chairs in front of the window. Do visit the rooftop bar for a wonderful view of the area (especially at sunset). Food and drinks are pretty expensive at the bar but worth the cost because of the fabulous location and view. Wifi was fast in the lobby but got very slow by the time you got to the 11th floor. If you like busy areas like Shinjuku, do stay here. If not, head to one of the smaller hotels in a quieter area i.e. Akasaka).

My wife and I began our honeymoon in Japan at the Granbell. We stayed in three different rooms, two of which were the same type, over seven days. We spent our first and last nights in a Superior Designer Double Studio and the rest of the stay in the Luxury Designer Double Mature. While both rooms lacked a lot of storage options, the LDDM was by far the superior room and had much more space as well as a very cool layout. However some wall hooks would have been useful as there was really nowhere to hang towels or robes. The hotel itself is busy. The lobby is fairly small and this means there are groups coming and going all the time and a lot of stowed luggage floating around. Not a bad thing but this is not an out of the way place. In fact the location was great as a base to explore Tokyo. It's close enough to to Shinjuku station as well as nightlife in Kabuki-cho (Golden Gai, Robot Restaurant, Piss Alley) along with great shopping and food. There's a series of food stalls every weekend by the nearby Hanazono shrine that we happened onto one Saturday. The breakfast offered by the hotel was awesome and totally worth getting. I still dream about the eggs at the buffet. The only downside is the laundry situation. One washer, two dryers and you will most likely be hang drying your clothes in your room. The staff was great and spoke English well enough to help us find where to go and even book dinner reservations. Would totally recommend anyone venturing to Tokyo for the first time to consider the Granbell Shinjuku.

The hotel was very nice and modern. We got two rooms for a family of four with each one of us sleeping in our own bed. This was absolutely necessary as we are traveling with a 16-year-old and a nine-year-old.The hotel is in a great location right near the main center of Shinjuku where it's lit up and wild at night. It is very safe and everybody was very helpful and nice. The beds were extremely comfortable and the hotel was very very quiet at night, which was great. The buffet breakfast was both Western and Japanese, but the "western" breakfast was not very good. The views from the hotel restaurant on the 12th floor are great and it is very modern.if I come to Tokyo again I will stay in Shibuya.

My wife and I are traveling in Asia for the first time with our two sons, 9&16. Our trip around Japan started here in Tokyo at the Shinjuku Gran Bell. On day three we are checking out and heading north to Nikko. We have had a wonderful experience here and found this hotel a perfect place to recover from the time change and experience the sights and sounds of this special area of Tokyo. Traveling from Colorado, we knew our rooms would be too small for the four of us so we booked two and the hotel was kind enough to make sure they were side by side. We had spoken to the staff a few months in advance by phone when we booked our rooms. They were very helpful with our reservation in English. That courteousness and friendliness has been extended throughout our stay and I must say that we have felt very content here with our experience. I can't imagine a better experience overall. Our rooms did not have an adjoining door as this is a purely Western idea and we found no hotels in Japan that have this sort of design. However, we are connected via text by our pocket Wi-Fi that we rented from Japan-i-can and had delivered to the front desk at our hotel the day we arrived. *Note: This is a key technological component for travel in Japan. For a total trip cost of about $80 US, we carry this little wireless router around in our backpack and our phones are constantly connected to the Internet. With unlimited data for the two weeks that we are here, we have access to all of the maps and apps that we need to thoroughly explore this beautiful country. (I've also been able to check my bank accounts, credit card accounts and everything else that I need and have at home.)The restaurant here is on the 12th floor with a beautiful view of the rooftops of surrounding Shinjuku area of Tokyo. The breakfast buffet is very good with lots of choices. However my wife disagrees completely. Most of the food is cold and unfortunately there is no fruit. Nevertheless, we are leaving the restaurant again today full and ready to check out. * Note: for a great breakfast try Café Aaliya not too far away. They have the best French toast in the world. Okay so here are the details. Beds are eight out of 10. We like firm beds. If you like soft beds you're not going to like these beds. Sheets eight out of 10. Cleanliness of the hotel is a 10 out of 10. And yes the rooms are small but all the rooms in Tokyo or small unless you're paying $700 a night.  The air conditioning was excellent. Coming from Colorado, I was a little concerned about the heat and humidity as my wife and I don't sleep well if we are hot. We slept well and the room was very quiet. Overall we would recommend this hotel for numerous different types of guests. The elegant entrance is on a side street and has a welcoming and verdant access. Yes verdant in downtown Tokyo. We experienced a mix of families and students and business travelers staying at this hotel. The hotel's somewhat concerning juxtaposition near the love hotel district of Shinjuku has been a non-issue for us. Had I not read about this ahead of our trip, I would never have noticed while we were here. And our children will go home not having known at all that this was a concern for for us. Great showers, laundry service if you want (we didn't), friendly English speaking staff,centralized location, easy access, clean and modern decor all lead this family to recommend staying here for other families.

the hotel has a strict check in policy, so there wont be any luck to get early check in anyway, you need to secure it by payment if you are arriving really early.you can, however, deposit your luggage under the hotel's care.There are many hotels around the area but generally, the location is accessible. (there is two nearby metro station so please check which is more convenient for you! walking from JR station is really, far away with your luggage) if you are on the JR pass, you should get tokyo metro pass as well which you will need alot to get to this hotel and around.rooms are REALLY small, but comfortable for us! pay for a bigger if you must. if you are staying here for long, there is a supermarket "Maruetsu" 7am-1am behind Shinjuku Meijidori Post office.there is some good restaurants around the area so take your time to look out for them!

Good hotel with excellent accessibility and located close to the metro station . The rooms are a little small but I think that is to be expected in a city like Tokyo where real estate is at a premium .We stayed in a triple sharing room and it had a really cute loft for the third occupant .My only grouse is with the breakfast ,Would have preferred a wider selection of food . Lastly the staff at the reception need a special mention .They were very positive and always happy to guide us around .Made the whole experience all the more enjoyable .P.S : Do try their rooftop restaurant. Excellent views .

Stayed at the shinjuku granbell for two nights and while the area itself was great i was a little dissapointed in the room itself it looked a lot nicer in the photograghs than in reality. The room was quite small although very comfortable beds. The heated toilet was amazing. Staff were quite freindly But i think id choose somewhere else to stay next time.

We stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell for a total of 9 nights and really couldn't fault the hotel at all. It's close to all the fun and craziness Shinjuku has to offer, and is just a 10-15 minute walk to Shinjuku Station (East Exit) which is perfect when getting the NEX train from the airport, or even for getting around to other areas of Tokyo.The staff were very helpful and happy to provide directions and help finding attractions (in English). The room we booked was one of the Deluxe Designer rooms as we had read that some hotel rooms in Japan can be on the small side, and we were happy with the choice - large bed and a really spacious bathroom. If you are concerned about space, then I'd definitely suggest paying extra for a bigger room. Our stay came with breakfast included and the buffet had plenty of choices.The rooftop bar is a must do for at least one drink around sunset so you can experience how lovely it is to see all the city lights come on as the sun goes down - really pretty on a warm night.I can't think of a single bad thing about this hotel. Our room was modern, clean and quiet and we had access to vending machines on our floor as well as those in the lobby for drinks and snacks. There were also free drinks provided in the room's mini bar. This is a really great choice for your stay in Tokyo and I'd definitely stay there again!

I stayed for three nights at the new Granbell in Shinjuku. The executive room I chose was lovely with a huge bath, nice furnishings, and quite a lot of space but I wouldn't recommend basing your decision to stay on the club floor just to get access to the lounge facilities. They are very average, food and beverage choices are limited and wine/beer is only available for one hour per day. Likewise, the breakfast is only ok.The neighbourhood is fun and it's easy enough to get to the station. Staff at the hotel were all lovely and very helpful. I'd definitely stay again.

TL:DR - tiny, tiny rooms, in a love hotel district, but great price, clean and does a lot well pros- price was great, paid £80 GBP for one night and as we were coming in late and leaving early for a flight it didn't make sense to pay loads- good wifi- high spec rooms, lots of new equipment, felt 'fresh'- nice staff- coffee bar in foyer- very centralCons- tiny rooms. Literally not enough floor space for bags, had to open them in the corridor and hop over them, one was almost too long for the corridor - shower curtain was smelly (only ding against cleanliness, rest of room was fine)- love hotel district (we didn't mind actually, thought it was fun to see this side of Tokyo, but clearly some people might prefer not to stay in this district). At this hotel even you can rent a room by the 8 hours....Would stay again if passing through Tokyo

We are pretty happy with our stay, just make sure you do not expecting too much then it is a nice and reasonable priced hotel to stay with. RoomWe had the superior room and requested to be Hollywood twin setting. That's a 20cm in-between 2 beds which was good enough for me and my best friend. Small room as expected for all tokyo room but we are surprised that the bathroom is of a comfortable size which is a true delight. It's ok for us to have a semi-transparent glasses , basically you juz see the shadow when the one in the bathroom is real close to the glasses. If you are fine with 20cm gap between beds, the semi-transparent glasses should be ok. We love the sofa area as well, classy and provides space for you to sit instead of just on the bed all the time.We have 2-hand carry suitcases, so they fit to the room and can be opened most of the time.LocationNot the best in shinjuku, but good enough. Next to the red-light area with many "hotels" next to it, not a big problem for us (2 girls), we still feel safe to walk back at night around midnight. We find the signage on top of "Hotel Atlas" is most helpful to help us locating Granbell ( opposite to each other)We normally use the station called "shinjuku sanchome" to get access to other attractions. It's around 10 mins walk. If you arrive from shinjuku main station, that's around 15-20 mins walk with the luggage.ServiceWe would like to extend special thanks to Miyabayashi from the reservation team. She(or he?) is the best and most helpful among all we encountered. Fast response and totally understand our concern! Thanks Miyabayashi! Other than Miyabayashi, we actually didn't receive much "service" from others. I bet the staff is too tired in greeting all those early arriving guests from HK or China ( Ya, I admit that HK has too many too-early flight to Tokyo), when they greeted us at 14:30, check in done, storage done and that's it. We do understand their difficulty after seeing those hundreds of luggage at the lobby probably also waiting for the room ready, but we don't appreciate much with the service as others mentioned in the review. When we are back from the hotel at night, the staff looks less stress than the one on duty in the morning. At least we saw his smile and kindness. The bags were in the room already which is out of our surprise, as they needs to handle all hundreds bags accurately. Or the hotel would be thinking of adding more manpower in the morning due to the flight pattern of the city? Just some of our thoughts.We didn't get to talk with the staff on suggestions as they seems have prepared all the details in the travel brochure rack. It's kind of a good idea as everything on the paper is suggested by themselves and well written in English. It may have saved some time for them to repeat similar answers and make sure all non-Japanese speaking guests are well explained.

This hotel has some very typical Japanese room sizes, which means small. Despite of its room size you will find everything you need inside the room. Rooms are clean, well equipped and modern. The hotel is just 3 minutes away from Higashi-Shinjuku Station (metro line) and 8 minutes from Shinjuku JR Station (if you know the way). Very convenient and staffs were very helpful. Wifi was okay, not the best in class but functional. Overall a good hotel and great value for money.

After staying in several great hotels in Japan, both budget and more expensive, I found this disappointing.The location is in Kabukicho. It takes some time to walk from Shinjuku station, which can be a drag if you have a lot to carry. Kabukicho is the red-light district of Tokyo. You’ll see plenty of love hotels, hostess clubs and massage parlors in the area. Walk here at night and you will be approached by touts on every corner, some of who may be assosciated with seedy activities. I was travelling solo, I walked the area alone plenty of times late at night, and I always felt safe. It might not be the prettiest area for a family vacation however, and some might find the touts bothersome.The hotel should receive credit for very modern facilities. Everything seems new and clean, including bathrooms. The view from the top floors and bar was also lovely.The room was quite small, but I had smaller in Japan. The bed was hard and uncomfortable. I had a room at one of the top floors, with windows facing the rooftop bar several floors below. I was kept awake by loud guests. The doors to the room seemed to be made of paper, so noise from the hallway was also noticeable. Not ideal if you’re a light sleeper.The wifi was the worst I’ve seen in years. Expect extremely slow speeds and frequent disconnects. I found it barely usable for important tasks, and chose to find wifi outside the hotel on a few occasions.The breakfast was not enjoyable. Staff seemed stressed and was not welcoming. The pots were left open at all times, so much of the warm dishes got cold. Arriving around 8 am, long before breakfast was closing, I found some of the vegetables had dried out.I found this hotel to be poor value for money. While everything is new and the view is great, this hotel does not deliver on basic functional levels such as sleep quality and breakfast. I did not get the same great hospitality experience that I found in most other hotels I stayed at in Japan. I’d recommend you to find a different place. There are so many wonderful hotels in the area, including cheaper options.

This hotell should advertise better about theyr bar view, it's stunning to relax there an evening with friends and good drinks and look across Tokyo and Shinjuku. The hotell as a whole is very modern in design, the rooms are really beautiful, not big, but this is Japan afterall:)

This hotel may have small rooms, but thats the way it is in Tokyo. But this one makes it up with friendliness and it is very clean! Ask for room at a higher level so you can enjoy the view. They have vending machines on several different floors. Staff very friendly. The hotel located not near by the shinjuku metro station but there is another metro station right around the corner. I would definitely come again!!

I stay here because I hace stay in many hotels in Tokio and Japan and you know that the rooms are small in that area but this is to much for two people and in the photo didn't look that way and the location is kind of far from shinjuku main street and station if you are carrying a lot of lauge you better get a taxi from de Jr station . The other thing is that my room really don't have a view I stay in room 732 and my view was to a very close to a ugly rooftop and the bed clothes are too sintétic didn't look like 50 50 mix look like 80 20 polyester so not so great the TV is big and that's good but the don't have not even one English spoken channel

Helpful staff and very clean room. The views from the rooms depend a lot from which one you get. A bit far away from the main Shinjuku station, but still reachable on foot. Wifi is fast and there are many restaurants and attractions nearby in the district of Shinjuku.

This hotel was one of our favourites in Tokyo. Although a smaller room, the facilities were great and the perfect spot for getting around. There was also a beer vending machine in the lobby which was a real novelty!!

Cons - Far from the train station- Small room- Glass wall/window from bathroom to bedroom (see-through)- Kept the shades closed, neighbors are close byPros- Clean room- The space is small, but efficient - Good price, I looked for a room in the Shinjuku area that was nice- Helpful staff, polite- Free wifiI had a price and level of quality I was looking for in Shinjuku and I believe I found it here. The room is small, but I think that's normal in Tokyo, and again the prices are good. I stayed in the smallest room they had and I believe it's just good for one person, but it might begin to feel a bit tight for 2 people. The hotel is a good walk from the train station. The staff was able to answer my questions in English and were also very thorough. I would like to stay closer to the train station next time, but if I was looking for something in the same price range and level of quality I would pick this place again.

Good recently renovated hotel. The first room we stayed in which was 'economical' was really quite small but when we went back for our final night in Tokyo we had a different type of room which had a loft area and we really appreciated the little bit more space. Very good quality rooms though. Helpful reception staff despite a seemingly always busy reception area. Relatively close to the train stations but kind of an odd area with lots of hotels at 'hourly' rates. Otherwise not unsafe and close to lots of action.

My wife and I stayed here on our first ever trip to Tokyo for 9 nights. The hotel is brand new and very modern. We never went to the bars or restaurants in the hotel, but our room was excellent. There are vending machines downstairs for quick and cheap snacks and drinks. The staff was friendly, and the hotel was very quiet. It is close to many subway stations, so getting around Tokyo was an absolute breeze. The hotel is near many "love-hotels" but it doesn't feel like you are in a red-light district at all. Very quiet and very safe.There is a Tully's coffee right around the corner, which is great for a cheap and quick breakfast. There is also a McDonalds right across the street, and a CoCo Curry House close by, which are both very friendly to foreigners. A 7-11 is nearby as well so you can easily get cash using your American debit card, and also score some snacks.I can't imagine having a much better experience at any hotel in Tokyo. The only thing you could hope for is being closer to sites you want to see, as most of the places we wanted to go to were not in Shinjuku, but relatively close by. The hotel itself is great though.

We used to book Tokyo / Ginza area but this time due to the countryside we want to go is easier to depart from Shinjuku West Exit, we chose to stay at Shinjuku this time. We read about this hotel is new, hip design style but unfortunately other than the lobby, the rooms are the same small, typical tourist hotels design (we booked the Premium Deluxe room). But despite what other people like about the location, I do not like the location at all. It is at least 15 minutes walk from the Shinjuku JR station (but that is okay) and it is right in the red light district with a whole street of fancy love hotels around. Though in Japan, the red light district is quite fun and safe, I still do not like such location, sorry personal preference. The staff okay, can communicate in English. Breakfast okay. We got a far corner room (#701) and WiFi signal was not good. Overall, okay but nothing great. Will try other hotels in this area if need to stay in Shinjuku again.

This was an amazing stay! 3 nights before coming back to Europe and this hotel was a great choice. One of the biggest challenges in Tokyo is space and this hotels deals with limited space in the rooms fantastic! Very clever design and lots of amenities made my stay there really nice. I stayed in 2 other hotels in Tokyo but this one was definitely the best. There are plenty of bars, restaurants and bistro around and you can be sure that even late at night you can eat a decent meal. Also, subway is very close. Highly recommended!

Service is top notch at this hotel. The hotel staff are all very friendly and helpful, it was also great that they can communicate with us clearly. Location is not really ideal for families since it was a bit near the bars and red light district. Fortunately for me and my girlfriends, we didn't really have any unpleasant experiences walking to and from the hotel.We were 3 in the room it was a small with our huge luggages but the room was really clean and beds were comfy. The steps leading to the loft was really steep that I have to really be careful in going up and down the loft.Price is really reasonsable considering the overall design and feel of the hotel. We had fun with all the vendo machines available in the hotel too! :)

This was first time I stayed at Granbell Hotel Shinjuku.For the price, location and size of room, I wouldn't stay again....I have spoken to number of western guests and all they said was room is small. especially the bathroom is small.Room window, you have to keep your blind down/ closed otherwise all other guess can see you in the room. Not good privacy.Breakfast is average, from 12F you can overview the city nothing is special.Elevators are fast enough.Location of hotel is not so good. It will be far from JR station. underground station not too bad.Going around, shopping and visiting Disney land from Granbell hotel not recommended.Something wrong with WIFI system, slow and keep disconnecting.This hotel will be last resort to stay if you have only option to stay APA hotel or other.

Good hotel, clean but tiny rooms. Great bar on roof but the lobby is amazingly small. You can walk to station but if you don't have a sense of direction forget it. Lots of interesting back streets and restaurants nearby. For me I prefer Ueno to stay - especially ryokan type of hotel like Suigetsu which is close to parks and museums. Shinjuku is great but crowded and glitzy. Think about what you want. If you have JR Pass you can use Yamanote Line easily to get around - but Ueno is quieter if you want peace.

Booked the hotel based on its proximity to the train station (subway and JR line) and the price of the hotel. Room was not that big considering we had 3 people but the room was cozy and had a hidden extra bed above the bathroom. Toiletries were replenished daily and were of great use. Despite the rather small room, the from the room made up for it. For the price that me and my friends paid, the hotel had already exceeded out expectations. The hotel is about a 15mins walk from the main Shinjuku stations (those with JR passes should take note) but about a 5mins walk from the nearest Tokyo Metro station, Higashi-Shinjuku. Me and my friends returned usually past 9pm and we felt safe walking back from the subway station despite the numerous love hotels and the reviews here saying that streets were mostly unsafe. The staff were polite and helpful and spoke fluent english.Would definitely recommend this hotel for those who are travelling in threes since most hotels in Tokyo don't offer there option of having 3 per room.

The hotel is a good business hotel. Very accessible with the subway station just a few meters away. Walking distance from the main shopping center of Tokyo - Shinjuku. Lots of places to eat. The rooms and fixtures are new and very clean. The bathroom mirror is heated to prevent fogging and the toilet -- has more buttons than your average car's dashboard console. Free wired and wifi internet in the room and in common areas. The bar on the roofdeck offers a great view of the city and is a perfect place to unwind after a long days work without having to leave the hotel. Almost everyone in the front desk knows how to speak, read and write English...not very common in Japan.

Booked the superior double for 3 nights during the Golden Week (1st week of May) and was a tad disappointed with the size of the room - hardly enough space to move around, with window view to the office building next door. Room is clean, big tv, clean toilet, 2x water bottles complimentary every day. Toiletries are refilled daily (hair brush, toothbrush, toothpaste).The hotel staff is very friendly (they all are in Japan btw) and the reception staff speak English. The Granbell is conveniently located, close to the main arterial roads of Shinjuku as well as the Shinjuku Station (10 mins walk) for those travellers with their JR Passes. The closest train station is Higashi-Shinjuku station (3 mins away) so you would have to alight at Shinjuku and get on the subway to get to the hotel if you're travelling with heavy luggage.There is also a post office that is a few minutes walk from the hotel if you're planning to send items overseas (note not all post office in Tokyo have international parcel services).Vending machines are available on the ground floor, as well as toilets and a smoking room.Will go again for the location, but will make sure to get a slightly bigger room next time.

Picked hotel on price, trip advisor reviews and location. Location was ok, if you don't mind being around love hotels. Easy walk to Shinjuku station. Lots of places to eat around the station. Good place to stay if you like the night life etc.Hotel staff were helpful. Room was big enough. Bathroom good. You will ever love or hate the interior design of the room. Quite modern and quirky.We had breakfast each day. It was average.

Stayed 4 nights in an economy double room. The hotel is a modern and clean but the economy double room are very small. In room Safe and tea making facilities are provided. No storage space to unpack, literally living out of the suitcase. Location is within 10 minutes from Higashi-Shinjuku Station which is not the most convenient Station. The hotel is located in a slightly seedy area but never felt unsafe.

Perfect location in the middle of a shopping and bar district with plenty of restaurants. Very modern and 'young' atmosphere: friendly receptionists and a very functional, no nonsens room: not too big (we had an economy room) but with all what you need and very clean. Good wifi quality.

This hotel is not very easy to find, and access wise, very narrow roads. It is surrounded by love hotels but the area itself is relatively safe. Location wise - very convenient to the centre of shinjuku, however it is not exactly close to Shinjuku station. It is still walkable though.The room itself was rather small, but very clean. The reception area was very peaceful and nicely decorated. Friendly staff. This hotel has a rooftop bar which is the HIGHLIGHT - the view is awesome, a must to have some drinks at night after a long day out exploring!

This is a decent hotel for the price. Rooms were clean and while small, had all the amenities you'd expect.Service is efficient and friendly. Location is excellent, being a short stroll away from the heart of Shinjuku entertainment and nightlife. We were also pleasantly surprised by the hotel's restaurant and bar. While they didn't offer a huge selection of menu items, the dished we tried were excellent and far exceeds the quality of food we've had for double the price at some 5-star properties. Would happily recommend this place to others.

When we first passed by the area of Shinjuku, we thought our hotel will be in a well-appointed area(an area that does not have a lot of potential danger or whatsoever) but not. This hotel is located in an area where it is so polarizing(not much people frequent the area, many love hotels, and bars). This area was not certainly family friendly. Check in was great. We were referred to checking in at the 7th floor(a private one) and the floor had complimentary snacks for tired travelers. Rooms were not that great. They were cramped and had a ridiculous design elements like a big window that separates the washroom and the sleeping area, a corner couch that was supposed to be a makeshift office space and a tiny minibar with a shelf that was stacked up instead of the usual flat one. The TV had this annoying motion sensor so every time you would pass by after putting the power card in its slot, the TV would always turn on. Whoever redesigned this rooms should also have put into consideration the users of the room. The hallway also reeked of cigar and tobacco(so did the elevator). It was also a big disappointment that their in house restaurant was serving Western fare. It would have been nice to have that restaurant serve Japanese fare. Staff were very accommodating and would attend to your beck and call and your needs. Overall, stay was okay but ruined by the anxiety that the nearby bars and love hotels pose. Would not recommend this hotel to those who would like serenity and comfort in the urban jungle.

Really nice and tidy, the location is not extremely convenient but good enough to save time on travelling.Staff are helpful, the room is small but well equipped.I did enjoy my stay here, but just to remind you, if you take JR to get there, the Shinokubo station is actually not that near, you will need a map or google map to help. You would pass through a Korean district when you goes from Shinokubo.

I'm very surprised there's only one review mentioning about this HUGE window (as in the length of my queen size bed) that acts as a 'wall' between the bed (which is located adjacent to the 'window wall' and the washroom. As a result, the translucent window glares light and transmits all sounds between the 'sleeping area' and the 'washroom'...this is absolutely ridiculous. Whoever that designed the hotel rooms never considered about the actual users and how the users will use the room I stayed with my partner. So whenever he was in the washroom, I can hear everything (toilet or shower). He tends to wake up before me, so I immediately wake up once he enters the washroom. And when I go to the washroom during midnight, he is awaken. The rooms here are considered pretty big for Japan, fitting a queen size bed easily. But the design, again is ridiculous. They have a useless sofa on the edge of the room, taking up potential useful space. We have two luggages and if they're opened, there's no walking space. There's no closer space. They designed this room to look nice aesthetically in photos, but when you actually use the room, you will find how impractical it is. Most importantly, I Truly detest the area. It's my first time to Japan and I did not know where this hotel is, I just saw it was a 10ish minute walk to JR. However, the walk from JR to the hotel is a nightmare. You will walk through their red light district. And you will walk UP HILL. It's horrible because 1) I'm tired after a full day of walking 2) it's my 3rd day at the hotel and I still can't really remember how to get to/from JR-hotel because there's so many 'streets' and turns. 3) I never realized how big shinjuku station is--I can never find the 'right' exit so we end up detouring the station to get back to the hotel 4) there's no convenient store around (you must use their vending machine at lobby --but they do have some good selections ). But this poses inconvenience. It's the neighbourhood that raises a red flag for me. All the AV rentals , night clubs (gentlemen's) and many many love hotels that you must walk past in order to get to hotel from JR makes me feel very unsafe walking back. Also, because there's many bars around the area, you wil find a LOT of drunks at night. Another reason for red flag. Shinjuku itself is a great tourist area. But I do not recommend it for staying as accommodation. The hotel itself, the room gets a big thumbs down. The staff is so-so. They were not particularly helpful/nice/mean. Very neutral. My experience was with a gentlemen that checked us into our rooms. He spoke in decent English. He was polite. I wouldn't say they were 'friendly' or 'helpful' though. The key thing is, I didn't feel welcomed. Probably because no staff was smiling, which is very different to the other hotels I've stayed in (Japan and North America). I don't recommend this hotel for couples or girls. Especially if you will stay out past 9, because that's when the crowd gets rowdy and things go wild--it will make your walk back a bit uncomfortable (at least that's how I felt). Also, most of the 'good' food (recommended on trip advisor) is on the opposite side of JR station--east side. So it's a bit of a walk since this hotel is 15 minute walk from the west side of JR.

Hotel room (standard room) was big for the price, considering the small rooms in Tokyo.Toilet accessories and water replenished daily, which was great. Modern artsy design room decor for the standard rooms. Has an iPhone/ipod speaker for use, which is a nice touch. Massive TV in room, and the bed and toilet were clean and comfortable. The free wifi provided is good and fast as well.Breakfast was not great, and I highly recommend going around the neighbourhood to get your breakfast. The rooftop bar's view is pretty good though.Although near the Kabukicho area, as a previous reviewer had said, turn left or right, and it's normal other than love hotels lining the alley. Did not feel unsafe at all staying here. Location is about a 10-15min walk to the main Shinjuku shopping district. It's nice taking a walk down to Shinjuku and taking in the wonderful city. Overall, Shinjuku Granbell is great for its price point, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for mid-range hotels around the Shinjuku area.

Granbell is a 5 minute walk from Higashishinjuku station so if youre coming from the airport, get off at Shinjuku and take the subway to Higashishinjuku.Rooms are tiny but that's a Japanese thing. a decent location to explore Tokyo. Would recommend it as a mid-low cost option

Stayed here for last night in Tokyo. Thankfully it was just one night. On getting to the room I could not believe that there was a massive glass window between the bedroom and bathroom. I'm surprised more people haven't mentioned this!! No privacy whatsoever! I rang up and complained to reception, and they moved us to another room which was the same but at least had a sort of shower curtain you could pull across! WHO wants to see the other guest on the toilet whilst lying on the bed!?!?Other than that it was modern but room absolutely tiny and set amongst all the love hotels in a back alley. I would not return or recommend to anyone who values any sort of privacy! Who would design a room like this!?

Check in went smooth with early check in available at a fair price. I chose a room one size up from the standard room and didn't regret it for the few extra bucks. The room was very comfortable and well equipped. The lovely breakfast is efficiently organized with a nice selection of Japanese and Continental choices. I really enjoyed the rooftop bar with great views over Shinjuku.There is a huge selection of restaurants a few blocks to the south, and a few blocks to the north many Korean barbecue style restaurants to choose from.Ok, so the hotel is located in the red light district but if you turn left or right when you leave the hotel towards the main streets there is not much you will notice except perhaps passing by the doors of some love hotels. Nothing x-rated to be seen in any case!

Overall, the hotel service was good. The room was comfortable,modern, and clean. And it’s better than I expected. But it was a bit far from shinjuku station.The restaurant was not great because the menu is quite limited in the dinner time. And then we went a bar that was a bit small, but that bar had a nice terrace. Also, We visited the coffee shop in the first floor twice. There was a female staff who is friendly and good in making a heart shape in a latte. Generally speaking, all staffs in the hotel seemed busy but they gave a good service.

Shinjuku is a fascinating district of greater Tokyo. In the middle of the thousands of shopping outlets, restaurants and hotels, is the Shinjuku Granbell. It is an easy walk to the Shinjuku Railway Station (but not with heavy bags!) where you can catch a train to everywhere! The hotel is clean and modern, and seems to cater for people younger than us, although this was not an issue and caused no inconvenience to us. The room was small, which we expected, and was an excellent example of utilising every inch of space to good effect. It had everything we needed. We faced a street but heard no noise whatsoever and slept peacefully. Breakfast (included in the price) was good and the view from that floor is excellent. Two things that need attention in our opinion are, the lack of English speaking TV programs (inexplicable in an international hotel) and the lack of English at Reception (again, somewhat puzzling in a hotel of this type). On the latter issue, there were staff who spoke good English, but this was a bit of a hit and miss situation. All staff were friendly and helpful. We would stay here again. Wifi was free.

On check in an early one wasn't available even for a cost despite me asking via email before travel. Seemed to be a long queue for check in and not many English speaking staff. For a hotel lobby it wasn't run very slick, a hotel lobby should be a hub of activity yes but also some space for tranquility - after all it is the entrance to the property and should be a gleaming beacon. The lobby was littered with hundreds of suitcases which looks unsightly and not conducive to a 4* Hotel. It took 25 minutes for us to check in when we finally did - seemed to be a lot of confusion and not much work going on. This was the last thing we needed after being awake for 30 hours. This experience did tar my stay at the property some what so my judgement is clouded to the rest of the property due to such a bad check in first impressions etc. Location wise was good - rooms clean but wouldn't recommend.

Very convenient in the heart of Shinjuku. Easy access from train, buses and walking distance to few attractions. The hotel is very clean, staff are professional and amneties are adequate and good quality.

10 minutes walk from the Shinjuku Station and practically u can go anywhere in Japan from Shinjuku Station..!although close to the red light district but i've never felt threatened at all. I even went to the family mart (24hrs convenience store) to grab something in the middle of the night but not for a moment felt unsafe. Hotel rooms were modern and really clean. Staff were friendly and very efficient. 10/10 for location and room price.

We stayed here for 6 nights on the 8th and 12th floors. It seems to me the higher up you go the better it gets. Very simple but stylish rooms. The rooms are small but as I'm coming to understand most rooms in Japan are small. The beds were comfortable, great shower, and a wonderful toilet with heated seat. This is not the uncommon in Japan but I'm still marveling at their toilets and toilet seats. You will see when you get here. Centrally located and very helpful reception staff.

The room was small, but we managed it for 6 nights with not too many problems. Be aware this hotel is located in the well known red light district of Tokyo (we did not realise this on booking) - saying that, we did not feel unsafe when walking into the main streets of Shinjuku at any time of day or night. I imagine a girls only group would feel quite intimidated. Overall good cost effect hotel if you are planning to travel Tokyo and not stay in your room all day !

My boyfriend and I arrived at around 9pm on April 19 and were able to check in immediately, the staff were friendly and efficient. At check in we had a B-Mobile sim sent to the hotel which we were given with our keys (highly recommend the unlimited data 14 day sim). Our room was on the 16th floor, a Deluxe designer double (casual) which was spacious and very clean. By no means is the room as large as it looks in the photos provided on the website but there is enough space for suitcases while still being able to move comfortably around the room. The closet space is almost non-existent but enough to hang a couple a things. The bathroom has a large bath and separate shower, it is quite large and very well stocked! There is a mini bar and tea and coffee facilities within the room. All of the TV channels are in Japanese. Wifi is available in the lobby and rooms but did not seem to work in the bar or restaurant.The hotel is in the Kabuchiko area which is known as the redlight district, whilst there was a lot of people standing around on the streets we were never bothered and never felt unsafe (after a quick google we found out these people are often outside to draw people into the many establishments which line the streets). The hotel is 5 minutes walk away from the Higashishinjuku metro station and approx 10-15 walk away from the Shinjuku JR station. Breakfast was included in our booking and consisted of a mixed Western/Japanese style buffet. Each morning items such as scrambled eggs, breakfast sausages bacon, hash browns, toast, brioche buns, congee, pork rolls and a salad bar were available. The dining room is clean with a view of the surrounding area. On one of our more busy days we visited the hotels restaurant which we felt to be quite underwhelming, the staff were very rushed with their service almost to the point of being rude. The food was very average and the menu is quite limited which was disappointing, thankfully there are a lot of great places to eat in the local area. We also attended the hotel bar, unfortunately on the night we went it was extremely windy and the inside/outside linking doors were closed. The drinks again were average served in a straight glass with no real presentation. We also had access to the lounge as we were on one of the higher floors which had drinks and a couple of snacks such as nuts etc available but we did not feel the need to visit it other than to have a little look.We felt that overall the hotel was great! Our room was beautiful, with a fantastic service each morning. The breakfast was fine to get you going in the morning and the staff (with exception to the night we ate dinner) were all lovely and friendly and happy to help. The hotels location was also convenient and i wouldnt hesitate to stay here again or recommend it to others.

Great hotel, a short walk to the main area of Shinjuku. The hotel is near the hostess bars both male and female. You shall see them as you walk to and fro from the hotel. If your a foreigner they leave you alone. As this is Japan great food choices near the area. A lawson's and 7-11 located very near. 3 elevators for the hotel. Room was nice and clean. It was me and my girlfriend we had room to move around but hard to do with our luggage. One of the better hotels i have stayed in Japan for the price.
