The hotel has only one dryer and two washers located on one floor if you plan to wash. The Godzilla hotel is close by. A batting cage just located around the corner.I did not visit the rooftop can't say what the view was like. Hotel staff are friendly.

The hotel was well situated in the heart of Shinjuku close to everything. I could easily alk to Shibuya as well i.e. Yoyogi Park, Shibuya Station with Hachiko statue and the week-end extravaganza in Harajuku. My room was tiny but it was well designed and layed out. The restaurant was not great but the bar had a nice deck.
user_name:
vbegana
La Penita de Jaltemba, Mexico

review_body: This hotel uses its room space creatively the room i used had a loft or mezzanine, the view was good. Transport wise its near a subway station( around five minutes walk) the JR station is a bot farther though (fifteen minute walk JR shinjuku station) . Breakfast was sufficient, service was great as the staff were proficient in english and very very helpful and patient... its near robot retaurant and the Shinjuku shopping area, though its in the alleged red light district its still safe walked at night without incident... Our room even had a projector tv

Definitely loved the rooftop! One of the greatest views in Shinjuku during the evening. Also, love the fact they serve drinks and food until 11pm because one evening we slept until 9pm and realized we were hungry and wanted to eat. Great for us because they served food upstairs!!!Nice clean rooms with glass window in the bathroom where people in your room can see you showering...

The hotel is quite new. Room is similar size comparing to other hotel in Japan. Fully amenities in room. Thus, no English Channel listed. Pillow is comfortable but bed is too soft.Cleanliness is 90% satisfy. There is only some spot in the bathroom.

Yes tiny rooms, really too small for the price you pay, decent breakfast, but not 4 star. Location is far from station and not really in Shinjuku central. Fancy toilet with full functioning bidet and dryer built into it.

We stayed here for 5 nights on the first leg of our 4 week Japan trip. The rooms were small (as expected) and very clean. The hotel is about a 10-15 min walk from Shinjuku station, we found it a bit of a pain lugging our suitcases through the city (especially during the day) so if your carrying lots of luggage aim for a closer station. The hotel is in the red light district, but we had no issues. We found a couple of routes back to the hotel so we could miss the club/bar crowds in the later evenings. We always felt safe whilst walking around the area. We had the buffet breakfast on our last day, it was ok nothing to special, just convenient if your in a hurry somewhere. It had nice views of the city, and wasn't too badly priced. Overall we enjoyed our stay here. We would definitely stay again in the future!!

This hotel is brand new, at just a few minutes walking distance from Golden Gai and Shinjiku dori. Rooms are clean, nice and modern. Elevated floors offer a very nice view and, for those who don't want to buy an elevated floor, restaurant and bar lounge at 13th floor will do.The reception team was not very flexible over check-in time when we arrived and we had to wait almost 1 hour in the lobby with tens of other customers though our room was ready... Apart from this negative point, everything else was perfect for the price we payed (quite cheap for Tokyo). We recommend.

For the price and location this is a great, modern, nicely located hotel. The rooms indeed are small, but it's Tokyo where everything is small. Learn to pack light and you will fit fine. The rooms are clean and bright with a great bathroom, water pressure and soaking tub. Only cleanliness issue I had was that the surfaces need to be dusted on a more regular basis. With that in mind, you might rinse the provided coffee mugs/cups before using. The other downside is they do not provide restaurant booking services, which is the main reason we visited Tokyo. This was a huge bummer and we ended up having to find another paid concierge service to make reservations for us. The coin laundry's one dryer was broken during our stay so we had to dry our items in our room the following day. Laundry services were pretty expensive (900yen for 1 pair of jeans).The location is near a dicier area (Kabukicho) but nothing you can see on the street is even remotely sexual so if you are with your family it's still better than walking through Bourbon street in New Orleans. You might see some drunk people passed out in the mornings on your way to the train station, but if you walk a different path that doesn't cut right through that neighborhood (or take the pedestrian park next to Golden Gai) you will avoid any of these scenes. It is also conveniently located near other subway stops to get to other parts of town. I especially loved the location near Golden Gai. In the past I've stayed in other parts of Tokyo and had to leave Golden Gai before midnight to catch the last train.I think a lot of people are expecting a high-end hotel based on its modern furnishings in photos. It is not. Service definitely has a lot of room for improvement and they seem to be understaffed. Everyday in the lobby there was a huge check-in line, lots of people waiting around, and large collections of luggage stored against any free wall. This could annoy some travelers of a certain pedigree I suspect. The free wine ticket is only for the restaurant and you must purchase something else to get the free wine. This was not clear on the ticket. The rooftop bar is a nice respite but also could improve on its service. In the end you get what you pay for.Cab drivers seemed to have a hard time finding this hotel, so be prepared and have a copy of the hotel name and address in Japanese printed out or on your phone. We also used Uber a few times, which was cheaper than a cab, and they seemed to have no problem finding us.I would stay here again if I didn't need restaurant concierge services and found a good early booking deal.

The Grandbell hotel is well placed in downtown Shinjuku. The rooms are quite small but clean and well equipped. The hotel has a nice outdoor bar on the top floor overlooking Shinjuku. The hotel is easy to access with public transportation very close by. The area is full of various restaurants and bars so if you like to go out in the evening, you will not be disappointed.

Granbell is not a hotel I will book again if I ever returned to Shinjuku.Where to start? When we arrived to check in, there was no one to help us unload our luggage from the taxi. The lady who served us, seemed very rude and unfriendly/unwelcoming. Once we checked in, we had to carry our luggage into our rooms on our own. The photos of the rooms look much bigger than in reality. There wasn't any room to pack and sort out our luggage. The location (for us) was TERRIBLE. I'm a pretty brave person but while staying at this hotel, I was very scared. The hotel is located seconds away from a street full of bars and clubs. And the street next to that is the red light district ( please google what that is before booking your hotel in japan!!!!). If you are traveling with kids, this is not the hotel for your stay. We checked out early in the morning (6am) and we booked a taxi to avoid passing by drunk people leaving bars and clubs as this time. It this definitely walk able to Shinjuku station but its pretty scary with your luggage and the drunk locals around. On a good ending, the rooms were ok clean. The male worker who helped us with booking our taxi was very nice and helpful.

The hotel is very modern and staff are very helpful and have good english. The hotel is quiet (rooms higher up at least), nice clean white sheets in the beds that are very comfortable, great place to stay if you are staying in Tokyo. We had breakfast here on one of the mornings, it was only ok, not great, would recommend going out for breakfast rather than staying in. Over all really nice stay and very good night sleeps.

This hotel is very new- the rooms are funky and modern, although incredibly small (as expected). The staff are very professional and fantastic with offering suggestions on where to eat and providing any assistance as required. Breakfast is a very good western/ japanese spread up in the restaurant with great views over Shinjuku. It is abit of a walk from the main Shinjuku station (10 mins) but there are other metro stops closer by. Whilst the hotel is in the red light district, we had no issues, and to be honest, it was pretty fun to walk around the area at night. Great stay!

We stayed for 5 nights in the "Luxury Designer Double/Mature" room and were very pleased with the room itself and the amenities. With the Executive Rooms, you have access to the Executive Lounge on the 13th floor, which provides drinks, snacks, etc from 9am - 10pm every day. Our room was on the 13th floor, which had a great view of the skyline, which was awesome at night while sitting in the gigantic tub in the gigantic bathroom. The rooms are key card protected, so only 13th floor people can get into the hallway where the rooms are, which is nice if you're worried about safety.Other Pros:-Rooftop bar (which is cool when it's not raining, which it did almost the entire time we were in Tokyo)-Very close to several metro an JR stations (5 minute walk)-An insane amount of choices for eating -While it says "kabukicho" as the location, it is about 5 minutes from what I would consider the actual kabukicho (with the dancing girls, hard sales approaches, and golden gai). That being said, if you're into that kind of thing, it's really close and a short walk home after you've been drinking all night - bars are open until 5am!-Free breakfast that had rotating selections. A good selection of both Japanese and Western choices such as scrambled eggs, toast, miso soup, salad, etc. -Toilet had a separate area and had all of the bells and whistles you would expect from a luxury Japanese toilet. -Friendly and helpful staff. We only had housekeeping twice during our five days by our choice, but they did a great job and refilled our fridge with the complimentary beverages.-Great bathroom amenities that go above and beyond anything you could find in a Western hotelCons:-Must have key in the slot for the lights to work. And, when you stick the key in the slot, it auto starts the TV and some really annoying loud music. There is no way to turn this off.-No top sheets! (But this seems typical for most of Japan)-For such a large hotel, the bar was pretty dead. Prices were pretty high for drinks too compared to some of the other places in the area-No check in until 3pm, which was very firm. They rope your luggage together in the lobby with everyone else's - which didn't seem all that secure to me. All in all, we had a great stay at this hotel. I would definitely stay here again. After talking to other people at the hotel though, I think it's worth the extra money for the executive rooms. Thank you, Granbell!

We chose the Moderate Hollywood Twin in 2nd floor so it's not very quiet in the night. The room is modern and clean; the bed is enormous and comfortable; however the couch area does seem too crowded to fit in the table. The counter staff speaks perfect English and is very helpful. However the convenience store is a little bit too far, considering this is Shinjuku area. We caught up with the festival in the Hanazono Jinja and the night market is an interesting experience.

We arrived at Granbell as our first stop in Japan and we really enjoyed it. The standard room is very small works if you're a couple or close friends but might be awkward. There's no door for the bathroom and the bathroom has a window into the bed room. If your not shy its cozy! Location nice but literally in the middle of the red light district. Beware of men outside of clubs trying to get you to go inside, we heard its a trap and they either charge you a lot of money or rob you! But just be smart and aware. We had fun! Arti Vancouver

very good location, near the metro and many interesting things in walking distance. The standard rooms are very small, the double bed is just big enough for a European average size person. The twin room is only a little better. 2 small single beds, no room really for suitcases. The superior rooms are not much more expensive but well worth it. Still on the small side but big enough. Staff was friendly. Very clean.

Our key takeaway from this place is - do not stay here if you like concierge services and ad-hoc housekeeping requests. Also if you enjoy being addressed by your name in reply emails (during an email conversation with the hotel - during which I always signed my name - they kept replying with "Dear Madam". And then later they even wrote "Dear Sir/Madam"! It's not really a huge deal, but just the little things that add on to our existing frustration with this hotel).We got a good deal on this hotel through Expedia at less than AU$150/night during a weekend of the Spring school holidays. We wanted to stay in Shinjuku in hopes of being convenient to travel outside of Tokyo from the station. But this place is a good 10-15 minute walk to Shinjuku Station, so that plan didn't really work out.Our first encounter with the hotel's lack of service was during our planning. Many nice restaurants in Japan don't allow international guests to book directly with them, it must be booked through their hotel. We've done this before, so figured this would be easy. But Granbell said they would not help us book due to potential no-shows. We were willing to provide credit card details or any source of guarantee that they required, but they would not help us, despite the fact they were well aware they were our only option due to the restaurants' booking policies.Second encounter was asking for some help regarding tickets to an attraction that we wanted to visit on the day of our arrival. They replied with "check with the concierge on your arrival", which defeats the whole purpose of our request in the first place!Next - upon check-in, we clearly had too many bags to carry ourselves but they did not even offer to help, when most other hotels would automatically take your bags for you.Again - we called guest services to request fresh bottles of water as we had not had our room cleaned that day. They told us to go down to reception and pick them up ourselves. That's like being asked to go to the housekeeping cupboard and pick up our own fresh towels! It's just not what you expect from a hotel!And lastly, we requested some help with Ta-Q-Bin services. Two of our previous hotels were really helpful - all we had to do was tell them where we wanted our luggage to go and when, and they did all the rest for us! Granbell was adamant about us having to do everything on our own. Even one easy phone call to help us out (as our Japanese skills are pretty lacking), was out of the question. We offered to organise everything and just have them greet the Ta-Q-Bin folk when they came to pick up our goods, and they were very hesitant about that too.The following morning we asked for help again to a very unfriendly staff member. She seemed annoyed that we were expecting anything from her, and actually gave us the wrong information (told us we could pick up Yamato forms from the Post Office which was 24 hours - both of which were incorrect). We went back to the hotel after our trip to the Post Office, but this time we had a nice staff member (I wanted to get her name but they don't wear name badges). She helped us call Yamato a couple of times to figure out that only local Japanese can send international Ta-Q-Bin, not visitors. We could have saved a lot of effort if the first lady would have just helped us call and confirm.We also happened to leave something behind in our room. We've done this at other places before and they have always helped ship it back to us (once they did it at no charge, and another time we had to provide credit card details for the shipping cost). But this hotel refuses to ship internationally, and we had already left the country! So we had to find our own way of getting the item back to us. Of all the hotels we could have left something behind at, it had to be at the one with the worst service.So that's our experience with service. The hotel itself - It is in a pretty dodgy area and you have to walk a long way through that from the station to get home. The hotel itself is pretty new, so we found the lack of security kind of weird - most new hotels (and even most old ones) require room keys to get up to the required floor, but this hotel allows anyone onto any floor.And then the room - we stayed in an Economy Double so it was small. We had to keep our standard sized suitcase closed all the time so that we could walk through the room. Luckily we had a couple of hand carries to live out of for our few days here. Also, would not recommend staying here with a friend who you're not that close with. The bathroom and bedroom are separated by a glass window, so no matter where you are in the bedroom, you will have full view of anyone showering or on the toilet.There's free wi-fi, but it cuts out after some time.We would never stay here again.

Although the hotel is not on the main road, it's not too far from Shinjuku Station by cab which costs approx. 3,000yen, shared by 4 persons, it's reasonable. The size of the room is small but the designer managed to packed all the necessities into the small space, am impressed. We were able to find some nice food around the hotel but trying to return to the hotel using the GPS when it's dark, proved to be quite a challenge. Overall experience was pretty good.

Our stay at this hotel was a pleasure.Even though most of the reviews talk about the 'red light district', at no time does one ever feel unsafe, in fact it's quite the opposite. Love hotels that surround the district are merely there for engaged/dating couples to meet as Tokyo is so crowded that they usually cannot have privacy at home. To us it was more entertaining. The red light district does not affect you in any way.We stayed in the CLUB suite and it was very spacious, (60 sq m) luxurious and incredibly comfortable. Wonderful views and spotlessly clean. Bottles of water along with lavish toiletries supplied daily. WIFI is great and only slows down occasionally. Huge flat screen tv, sorry, no English options but very funny and entertaining Japanese variety shows!Breakfast was the highlight, with a huge variety and adorable staff, always polite and welcoming. Best scrambled eggs amongst other tasty items. Try the tangy, crispy muesli with yoghurt, delightful. It can get crowded, so time yourself. 8 am is usually best, if there is a queue, go back later, nothing runs out and is replenished regularly.Reception staff do struggle a little with Engilsh, but there are a couple of staff members that communicate well. Use google translate if you have to.We had a small problem with a late checkout, but after a little negotiation, they obliged.The hotel is approximately a $10 taxi ride from Shinjuku JR station and a 2-3 minute walk to HIGASHI_SHINJUKU station which is only 2 stops further from Shinjuku JR.Screen shot the railway map to assist getting around as it can be difficult to navigate. Collect free maps from the stations. The JR railway site is very easy to use and most stations have customer service assistants who are very helpful.Use your Lonely planet guide to find food such as dumplings and ramen and ask the hotel staff for recommendations. There are '7-11' stores everywhere which have great gourmet lunch options if you're on a budget or simply want a quick meal.Do not miss SHINJUKU GYOEN NATIONAL park. A colourful burst of precisely maintained cherry blossom gardens, with amazing Cherry blossom soft serve ice cream on offer (during cherry blossom season). Pack a lunch and enjoy it there. Simply beautiful.I would stay here again and would recommend the hotel.To the staff at Shinjuku Granbell Thank you very much どうもありがとうございましたDōmo arigatōgozaimashita

In the middle of the red-light district this hotel is situated. You can stay here for a couple of hours and pay for the room.. We booked a suite with lounge access. The check in was not friendly at all. At the lounge there were no staff and nor food or alcoholic beverages prepared. We had to ask staff in the restaurant to stock up with beer and wine. The lounge was overall terrible. Just beer, wine and snacks to choose from, no food. We were supposed to stay here for 7 nights but checked out after two. Then came to Ana intercontinental were they sure know how to run a lounge. Would not stay here again! Breakfast hall was very noisy and busy and nothing good to eat.

Stayed in this hotel from the 2nd of April till the 11th 2015 and have really enjoyed it. I found it to be a lovely and very welcoming hotel, great for our first time in Japan. The room itself is cozy and modern with cool artwork on the wall and a great view of the kabukicho area of Shinjuku. Very clean and you get lots of complimentary items that I haven't found in other hotels such as razors, bottles of water, brushes, toothbrushes etc. I thought this was brilliant. I found the staff to be lovely and really good at communicating in English too, so good that I wish my Japanese was a lot better! Also, we found the free wifi at the hotel to be a godsend during our trip. Good central location in vibrant Shinjuku, only a ten minute walk from the nearest JR station and very near the Golden Gai. Great hotel and very well priced, you wouldn't find anything as stylish in Scotland that's on par with it for so cheap. Recommended highly!

We already stayed once in this hotel last September and we loved the location, views and accommodation. This time we arrived around 20:00 after a long 5 hours journey from Hiroshima and we were looking forward to our suite. What a great surprise to see that the front desk had gave out our room, not because we were late but because their reservation system was faulty. They informed us that the whole hotel was booked and then offered us a room in another hotel of the same chain, with less rating and 5 km away, she kindly offered a discount but we immediately saw that the same room was still available at half the price she was offering through any online booking site. We spent 2 hours negotiating the price, something I would had never expected in a country like Japan i felt like I was bragging with a taxi at Bangkok, but instead I was in a high standard hotel at Tokyo. We finally get to a reasonable price and went to the other hotel. The location is not the peaceful surroundings of Shinjuku Granbell Hotel but instead a noisy popular street full of night clubs and drunk people, the staff at this hotel (Asakase Granbell Hotel) pressed us to pay before we could even inspect the room and the views are inexistent.At the moment of writing this review we are still at Tokyo and our plans for enjoying the city have been completely ruined. I would recommend to everybody to stay very far away from Shinjuku Granbell Hotel, We've never experienced anything like this in any of our travels.

We spent 5 nights in an economy double room and found it very comfortable. The hotel is located a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station, slightly off from the busy hustle and bustle of the Golden Gai. Our taxi when we arrived struggled to find the hotel. We found the area trouble free to walk around. The hotel itself is stylish and well designed and the staff are friendly and helpful. Our room was small but as it has been well thought out it was very comfortable. Plenty of plug sockets, excellent toiletries, kettle, hair dryer and safe all provided. Very comfortable bed with great pillows. Our only issue was the window between the bathroom and bedroom! Rather disconcerting and we quickly agreed a backs turned policy!If you have large suitcases this room might seem cramped. With two backpacks plus hand luggage which stowed easily under the desk it was fine.The bar terrace has a great view. All in all we really liked this hotel and would return.

Boutique hotels used to mean style over substance- all Starck-inspired furniture and no service. The Granbell is more than up to scratch: it's a modern, lively hotel with very good service in one of Tokyo's most vibrant districts. To deal with one of the criticisms here, be careful what room you book. Japanese hotels traditionally have smaller rooms, but ours was lovely and had a full wet-room bathroom. Also book carefully for style: the Granbell is situated in love-hotel territory, and whilst they're very subtle about it, there are some rooms that are more gangster-brothel-chic than might suit a family audience!Service is excellent (our 430am checkout was hitch-free), the rooftop bar is lovely, and you're in a great part of town for heading out- which is why I'm glad breakfast runs until 11am.Thoroughly recommended.Tips: - Got suitcases? Get metro to Higashi-Shinjuku rather than walking from Shinjuku itself- Hotel supplies are very good: toothbrushes, hair dryer, dressing gowns etc. are all included; cheap DIY laundry available too

Stayed for 3 nights in April, as Couple in Rm 1703The room is spacious, nicely decorated, new and comfortable. The property locates within 3 mins walk to Tokyo Metro station, and just outside the busiest area of Shinjuku.The staff are very nice, all of them speak very good English, and very welcoming. Whenever we faced a problem, and need a hands or helps, they are always there to help and offer the best solution to us. Big Big credits to them!The property itself is very new, nice and neat. The room, since we stayed in a Suite, so it's very spacious, have a lot of window and day lights. The housekeeping is fab too. A highlight of the room - there's a lot of fornasetti deco in the room, which makes this designer room very stylishBreakfast on the 12/F - well, not a lot of food to choose from, but good salad and eggs!We will definitely stay with Granbell again! =)

The Granbell Hotel is a nice business style hotel designed for tourists. I've stayed here a few times since its opening and have never been disappointed. Recently they've frosted the shower windows which used to be open to the sleeping area. They also added framing to the window blinds to block the morning sun from leaking around the blinds.....nice.My only complaint is it's a little too far from the train station so I usually take a taxi.

We stayed at this hotel for couple of days while touring Japan last year. We were at one of the loft rooms with great views. The hotel is really nice in a very good location to explore most of Tokyo's best attractions. Clean rooms and good facilities. Great stay!

I spent a couple night at the Granbell Shinjuku in one of the upper floor loft rooms. A high ceiling , remote controlled movie screen and projection unit and a cool upstairs loft in the room is great for watching a movie. The loft made me want to climb up and have an afternoon nap there. I loved the room and it was one of the most unique I've seen. The hotel is near Shinjuku 3-chome station, in the center of the love hotel district. That alone makes it culturally unique if you are visiting Japan. But it is a long walk from Shinjuku station. Higashi Shinjuku station is a block away, but involved an annoying train change one stop away at the metropolitan government station. Overall, the Granbell offers good value for money and personally I like the location. Great for singles and couples, but I'm not sure parents want to walk with their small children through the love hotel district. I though, would stay here again.

The Shinjuku Granbell lived up to other reviewer's praises. The hotel is rather new and clean, small as expected in tokyo, and chic. The downside is the rather long walk from the JR station (about 10 to 15 mins). Having to cut through Kabuchiko to get to the hotel from the JR station seems sketchy, but it's not at all dangerous, and even entertaining i would say. Staff is attentive. When I checked in at 5pm, the reception regrettably told me that the room needs another 15 minutes to be available and provided me a coupon for a free drink as a compensation, which I find was acceptable. Walked by the rooftop bar, and it seems to have a nice view. However, did not captialize for a drink since it was cold in January.As most other hotels in Tokyo, Granbell do hold your luggage free of charge if you decide to detour out of Tokyo for a couple days, then check back in Granbell for a stay just before leaving Tokyo. (they even have a scale for you to weight your luggage if you want to make sure it's not over weight upon request)

We spent three nights here. Two of them in a luxury design room and one in a standard double. There is a considerable difference in size and price of these rooms of course. But both rooms were spotless and comfortable. The luxury room has a king size bed and a massive bathroom with separate bath and double shower. Lots of toiletries, robes and free soft drinks in the fridge. The standard room was teeny tiny so don't bring too much luggage or you may not fit in. There is free wifi in the rooms and lobby but not in the restaurant or roof top bar. Our breakfast was included and was a pretty good selection of East and west choices. The scrambled eggs are fantastic. Other choices include miso, salads, fruit, cereal, bacon. The bread choices were a bit basic, only white bread and rolls. The hotel is surrounded by restaurants and nightlife including the famous golden gai area. We felt safe walking around as it's quite lively and populated, but do be aware that the hotel sits right on the edge of the red light district so you may see things you might not necessarily see at home! We had no hassles though. It's also only about a 10 min walk to Shinjuku train station. Staff were friendly and helpful and all spoke English in varied degrees. One thing I should mention is there are no English speaking channels on the TV, so you will need to get your news and entertainment fix from mobile devices.

Stayed at Granbell hotel- Superior Double with couch- last December for 7days for New Year's eve celebration.The hotel is walking distance from Shinjuku station, about 15min. It is closer and faster to walk from Shinjuku Sanchome station to the hotel. Hanazono Shrine is right outside of the sanchome. The room is very clean and decent size (since most hotels are small in Japan)Bathroom has nice soaking tub with provincia products.The lounge has a nice view of the night lights in Kabukicho.There are many different types of rooms- will definitely return and experience other rooms.

I really enjoyed the location of this hotel, within easy walking distance to the excellent Golden Gai bars, to restaurants and to a baseball batting cage which we visited a couple of times. The area always felt safe when walking about at night, but it's away from the action enough that your sleep isn't disturbed. Good wifi and a handy cafe in the lobby.It's not the easiest hotel to find from Shinjuku train station, so make sure you're well prepared and ready to drag your bags a good 15 mins to get there. Check-in time is strictly 2pm (no negotations), but you can drop your bags off, and the hotel was happy to store some of our luggage while we went to Kyoto for three days.We had the second smallest room, but it's well thought-out and fine if you're on holiday for a few days. I wouldn't stay in this room for business or longer-term, as there's no proper storage for clothes, so you're living out of a suitcase for the duration. The rooftop bar is a nice spot for a pre-dinner drink or nightcap, with great views across the city.The front desk staff are polite but a bit limited in the assistance they provide, so if you are used to relying on concierge recommendations and bookings, this hotel may not suit you. Good value for money in my opinion, and I'd happily stay again.

The good: Right in the middle of Shinjuku's 'red light district' however off in a quiet street and very convenient being only 10mins stroll to Shinjuku station & all the major shops/main road. It's also 5 mins away from the Robot Restaurant - fantastic and must visit! WE never had a problem with being in the red light district - it's very safe & you don't see anything during the day anyway. Also the locals won't bother tourists/westerners. The front desk/concierge was very helpful and spoke good English helping us book Robot rest' tickets, recommended restaurants nearby and organise whatever is required. Rooms were quite and well insulated against noise. As you would expect everything was very clean, and the little touches were nice (room/fabric spray, toilet amenities etc). good value for the a top location! The bad: Rooms are very small which is typical in Japan (unless you go for Superior Suites) however well organised and logistically planned. Also there is no wardrobe so not so suitable if you have big suitcases and lots of clothes to hang.

Great value hotel for Tokyo. Rooms are new and very clean. Rooms are small but this is consistent across Tokyo. Price is reasonable. Location is great to jump on train around Tokyo. To get there, take the approx 60 minute nex Narita Express train ride from Narita Airport into Shinjuku station. Make sure you get on the right train cabin on your ticket! At one point the train splits and if you are in the wrong carriage you may end up going the wrong way. You will need to take a cab with suitcases from the station. It isn't far, but not an easy walk. Non English speaking cab driver eventually found the hotel after driving around in circles a bit. Once found the hotel is modern, clean and quirky. Check in was fast and easy, regardless of the staff speaking minimal English. (Japanese in general are not great in assisting in English).We did not opt for the breakfast as it was rather expensive. There is about 3 Starbucks all within 10 minutes walking distance. Please do not go by the hotel food recommendations. Go onto Trip Advsior. There are so many great restaurants in Tokyo and we were disappointed with a few of the hotel's recommendations.Roof Top Bar was ok for a few drinks in the evening. A quiet place to talk.Location is within a red light district, but appeared to be safe. We would walk around late at night and there was no trouble. The district didn't bother us.Overall great hotel for Tokyo standards.

Located about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station (closer to local subway stations) next to Kabukicho which is a very tame and intriguing red light district. The address is difficult to find in Google maps so make sure you use the GPS coordinates from the booking confirmation. Also close to the Golden Gai and there is a batting cage across the road. We stayed in the smallest (15m2) and cheapest room but it was really nice and clean. Rooftop bar looked good but not great in winter. Staff went out of their way to help us book tickets to the soccer.

On checking into this hotel, we were told the room we thought we had booked did not have twin beds. We had to pay an additional fee for another room. I didn't think much about it until I noticed that on either side of me at the reception desk, they were getting variations on the same spiel. Beware.

Location wise it is not easiest to find, but my sister spoke japanese and it wasn't terribly hard or far from shinjuku station. Maybe a 15min walk at most. Despite being amongst alot of love hotels it was not intimidating or red light like as the street whereby the hotel was is adjacent to kabukicho thus away from hustle and the bustle. Lobby is cool with designer boutique vibe, staff always helpful with both preprinted sheets for popular destinations like ramen, skytree, tsukiji fish market. Also I enquired about studio ghibli at 10pm at night and staff stthan fill helped and told me of opening hours and method to get there despite I have to prompt the questions etc as they only answer what is being asked and not proactive but they are understandable in English and friendly.as we spent 3 days in hakone we were lucky enough to be able to leave behind our unneeded luggage from 17 to 19 without an issue, but suggest no valuables left behind as the luggage is not stowed away in lock away area and just left in lobby. We stayed in 2 rooms as we stayed 4 night from 13 to 16 and another 4 from 19 to 22. We stayed 13 to 16 march 2015 inside loft styled 3 ppl room first at ground floor which was very clean which is awesome. there was great vibe with the loft and third bed up like the attic, just be weary of the staircase up as it is steep and you must plan your toilet visit if you sleep in attic bed.. the amenities including soap and shampoo was excellent and no smoke smell to be smelt of. however the fridge was never cold and no wardrobe available only 4 coat hangers and room a bit small but its ok. you play around with tetris to fit in your luggage for 3 ppl. excellent tv as it is a sony bravia and phone is cool and a cool design radio. ground floor was quiet suprisingly. now the second room also a loft but on 12th floor, very impressed. it's same price as ground floor loft but better view plus the room included a projector so me sleeping in the attic bed can use it, cool gimmick. but pointless as i do not have usb stick or dvd and not connected to tv. however if you dohave dvd you can use it as it projects onto the windows projector screen, you can create own movie theatres. But the attic area alot nicer vs ground floor with a table on the open ended side of attic and 3 large comfy cushions and carpeted floor for cushiness. this room overall same layout except more bed to tv space as there's no tv cabinet so more room for luggage. the room is nicer than ground floor as it is fitted out with wooden interiors and carpet. carpet smeltof no smoke. Very chic in design. the 12th floor was also the ladies floor thus we as ladies got shiseido samples and liners to use, great touch of details. attic bed was comfy and pillows were good. warm blankets. very clean bathrooms. free wifi in hotel so its excellent and shinjuku has many places that includes free wifi like drug stores and the travel japan app with 200,000 hotspots so you can go online for free for up to 2 weeks. we didn't get to use breakfast or cafe so can't comment. cost is pricier vs other 4star options but cleanliness is key. if you book loft you must do it at least 3 months plus as not many rooms available. real downside a little bit far but acceptable and I would stay here again.

Was super impressed with this hotel - the room was clean and updated, a decent size given that this is Japan and the beds were comfortable. The staff was soooo helpful in providing directions, Etc. The location is also great I think- right in the heart of Shinjuku. Do not be worried about it being near the "Red Light District" (it's not like Amsterdam Red Light) but full of lights and action! Yet still tucked away a bit. It's also close to the Gokden Gai (would highly recommend for a drink) and the robot show if that's something you're interested in.

As many other reviews mention it's a little tricky to find when you first arrive but if you've got the address written down in Japanese you won't have any problems.In Kabuki-cho rather than central Shinjuku and lots of love hotels around, but that's funny more than anything else - nothing like a 'red-light district' elsewhere in the world, very safe and you wouldn't really know unless you looked for it.Really handy for Shinjuku station (10 min stroll) which makes the whole of Tokyo easily accessible, plenty of places to eat and drink nearby, great shopping around the station too.We stayed for 8 days and found the rooms small, but fine for two of us - really nicely designed to make use of the small space. Everywhere was clean, well designed and exactly what you'd expect from their website.Restaurant's not brilliant but handy, same with breakfast, we didn't get it included but paid for it on our first day for convenience and didn't bother going back - plenty of better places to eat in Shinjuku. Bar/terrace is probably good in summer.All in all, good hotel for a good price in a really good location.

Shinjuku Granbell is a good option in the Shinjuku area if you are looking to stay in a newish property for an affordable price, however it is let down by disinterested customer service staff, a very average buffet breakfast and an inconvenient location.Located in a back street of Kabukicho, surrounded by love hotels, the property is essentially a business hotel (think small rooms and average food offerings) that has been themed up with a design hotel vibe.There are a vast array of room types available at various price points, with the majority in the small but affordable category. The property is not ideally located if you are looking for convenience – you can’t access it easily from the train or airport bus, there are few shops and food options immediately nearby and it is difficult to get taxis. As with most Japanese hotels at this pricepoint, the front desk staff are completely inflexible in terms of early check in, so it is not a great option if you are arriving off a flight first thing in the morning and are in need of a freshen up.The hotel seems to have been embraced by mainly Chinese and Western tourists. A Japanese friend told me that Japanese people wouldn’t want to stay in this ‘dangerous’ part of town, however I didn’t experience any issues walking around the immediate area.Overall I think it is a case of style over substance. It was good to experience it once but I won’t be rushing back.

I was pretty impressed with this hotel given the relatively cheap rate. I stayed for 2 nights in a small ground floor room with a loft. It would have been tight at its full capacity of 3 people but was fine for just me. I was shocked by how quiet...silent, really...it was considering it's in Shinjuku and I was on the ground floor with a window just yards from the entrance. My only complaint is that the "concierge" was awful. This is a city where you rely heavily on recommendations and directions from your hotel, but every time I asked for guidance I was handed a lame preprinted sheet of options. They could not give tailored options at all, and the maps are useless. One night I took a taxi to one of these restaurants only for the driver to be completely lost and confused, and once he found it I was dropped off at one of the busiest areas, trying to match the restaurant's Japanese name against 100 different signs and never found it. Needless to say the hotel needs to improve their information desk.

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 3 nights in February. The room was excellent - modern and a good use of the space. We didnt eat at the hotel but we did enjoy some drinks on the roof terrace - go at sunset for brilliant views over the city. The area was a little sleezy but also full of great restaurants and bars. The hotel was a short walk (10-15mins) to the train station so it was a useful base to explore Tokyo.

We stayed for 3 nights on level 8 in a small room, which was very modern and funky. Handy location, about 10-15 minute easy walk from Shinjuku JR Station, the hardest part is finding the right exit - which is the east exit BTW. The hotel is apparently in a "sleazy" area, but I felt safe at all times. Bed was comfy, plenty of hot water and room amenities were all good. Also plenty of restaurants nearby. Only negative was we asked for a non smoking room and although there were signs everywhere saying non smoking, someone very obviously had taken no notice of this.

Small space but comfortable. Close to higashi-shinjuku station. Clean hotel. Staff also helpful. Reccomended. If we walk around this hotel also not hard to find foods. But need a little walk. In Japan we need to print the hotel name in Japan letters. Otherwise the taxi wont know where to find the hotel. I go from airport to hotel by taxi and vice versa. Need around 10,000 jpy one trip.

Shinjuku Granbell is located in a very good location. It's few minutes away from the metro and Shinjuku main station. Walkable distance to the shopping area. It's great for both business and holiday.We stayed in a Superior Designer Double Studio for 3 nights in Tokyo. The room we stayed look exactly like the pictures they showed on their website. I love the big window facing the city. It looks great both in day time and night time. The room is not big but with very smart design to make it doesn't look as small as it is. It's amazing to be able comfortably place a nice sofa in the room. Little detail like bluetooth speaker and air-purifier are very impressive. I love the design of the room very much. The hotel divided into 3 parts. Standard rooms, Loft Rooms and Executive rooms. Superior Designer Double Studios are considered as an executive rooms. They are located on 14/F -16/F (17/F is the top of the building). So you would get great view of the city. We also gained the access to use the Club Lounge on the 13/F. It's good to have a drink and some snacks there. The toiletries of the room are also amazing. In most hotels, even five stars hotels, you would expect shower gel, shampoo, hair conditioner and body lotion. You might see bath salt in a really good one. In our, apart from what I mentioned, they even provide something I have never expected. Things like makeup cleansing gel, cleansing foam, lifting moisture lotion, lifting moisture emulsion, moisturising lotion, hair tonic (I've never heard of this product, but my scalp really felt great after using it) and hair gel. All the toiletries they provide are in good quality. This is really very impressive.The only thing I really think they should improve is the breakfast. Compare with most other hotels in Japan. The breakfast Granbell provides is quite weak. The breakfast restaurant reminded me of the canteen of my university. Totally self-serviced. Very little choices on either western and Japanese food. They can still fill your stomach for sure but nothing really fancy. I saw another review complained about the speed and stability of the Wifi. It was totally on good condition during my stay.

I stayed at Shinjuku Granbell for 2 nights (22-24 Feb 2015) and we booked the non-smoking economy double room. The hotel is new and service at the reception was fast and friendly (do note that we also checked in quite late, around 9pm). In gist, the hotel is great but the location was so-so.The hotel is located in the Kabuki-cho district, which is a red-light district in Shinjuku but both my cousin and I did not feel uncomfortable when I was there (but hey, I resided in Geylang for a good 10 years, which is the red-light district of Singapore so I could be immune). In terms of location, the hotel is quite a considerable distance from the Shinjuku JR station but it is quite near to the Higashishinjuku metro station. As I was travelling with my JR pass, I chose to walk from the JR station and it was a tough walk with my luggage (hilly and rough paths).The hotel room was small but tastefully decorated with a sofa and a small window. Everything was clean and new and they even had bedroom slippers (pet peeve of mine as I don't like to step on the carpet in my bare feet)! Though the bed was smaller than the standard queen bed, it was good enough for me and my cousin. Cleanliness was tops in the hotel for me. :) The room was also brightly lit, which makes my cousin and I feel really comfortable (scaredy cats we are).If you don't mind the walk to the JR station or that you have to take the metro line to get to the main station (which is an interchange for many train lines), and if you don't mind that the hotel room is slightly on the small side, I would strongly recommend that you can choose this hotel. :)

Stayed five nights at this hotel. Room was OK, but not like the ones pictured on their website, but it was still adequate and large by Tokyo standards, but I had a double room with two beds. Morning breakfast was just ok. Surprised that their was no fresh fruit. Did have the standard running scrambled eggs and pork links and bacon, and a few local (Japanese) favorites, but nothing too spectacular, but it did fill your stomach. But the single reason why I would probably never come back here was the absolutely terrible wifi access. It was poor at best and non existent often. Because I was there for work this was very frustrating for me and to be honest not something I expect in a modern city like Tokyo. This hotel is probably best suited for leisure travelers who do not require consistent internet access.

Nice hotel with a great location. Vending machines in the lobby, wifi in the rooms, great and helpful staff (Who booked us tickets for the Robot Restaurant). The roof top bar has a fantastic view, staff wasn't the quickest but were friendly. I'd definitely stay here again if I decide to come back to Tokyo.

My boyfriend and I stayed for two nights at the granbell and we loved it! It was easy to walk to from the main Shinjuku station(with our luggage) and easy to find. The staff were terrific. Their English was excellent and their local knowledge was great. Tomo was particularly helpful. We were very happy with our rooms. Compact, yet elegant and very comfortable. Rooms extremely clean and facilities near new. Breakfast was well worth it. Check out of 12 noon was most civilised. Hotel happy to store baggage. All around great experience. Thank you!

Difficult to find hotels in Tokyo which are not priced in mega bucks. This is a very new hotel with a nice modern feeling. Great views of Shinjuku tho I wasn't overkeen on the love hotels nearby but it's near Kabukicho so unavoidable really. Hotel roof bar was great - nice atmosphere and amazing views. Room was a little small but then again most hotel rooms in Tokyo can be small. Would definitely stay here again.Close location to Shinjuku Station (about 6 mins walk)

Shinjuku Granbell is a modern Hotel nestled away in the backstreets of Shinjuku. It's Really close to the Metro station and a short cab ride or moderate walk from Shinjuku Station.The room was fairly small but it's pretty much what I expected in tokyo for that price (We got the second smallest one). There isn't much room around the bed and our suitcases took up the whole couch so when you are in the room you are literally hanging out on the bed. It is however very comfortable and nicely furnished. Bathroom was decent sized, with all the accessories. The staff were friendly and the restaurant upstairs does pretty good breakfast to eat before you hit the city in the morning. The bar also has an awesome view of Shinjuku and does some good cocktails.Its is pretty close to the Red light district and surrounded by love hotels but I never felt unsafe and they are kind of quirky. Do look out for the Nigerians that are trying to get you into the strip clubs (on the main street, but they can be avoided).. Its really close to Golden Gai and we ended up having a few night caps there nearly every night. Try out "Hip Bar," we made good friends with the owner who spoke pretty good english and was keen to swap stories.. and awesome drinks and small foods.The Granbell is a great hotel for people who want something comfortable to come back to of an evening after exploring, and don't mind that it really is just a place to crash, albeit a very well located, comfortable and modern place to crash.

This seems to be a new hotel surrounded by many other love hotels. However the area is safe and just 3 mins walk from the metro station. If you are coming from the main Shinjuku station be prepared for up to 15 mins walk. I got the second smallest room and it was still pretty small but comfortable. Just don't expect to open a large luggage on the floor. No English channels on the TV which is quite surprising for a big hotel. I booked early so got a good price. The hotel is packed with tourists though.

Tiny rooms, but very clean and well-designed compact layout, well-equipped toiletries. Contrary to some of the reviews here, there is a bathroom blind for the glass window in my bathroom. There is no closet space to hang our jackets or clothes, just live directly out of our suitcases. 2 persons is just manageable at a squeeze. I like the pajamas/yukatas provided. You would stay here for a a clean comfortable place for sleeping, not to hang out and sip coffee. Housekeeping is good. The hotel is new and noise level is low. Off the main roads.The breakfast is adequate, average tasting, with more japanese choices than western. Poor coffee.Good rooftop view of shinjuku from the rooftop bar. Go up at night.Location is so-so. I took a taxi upon arriving at Shinjuku Station from Narita using the NEX. All 5 days we were there, we didn't managed to try walking fr Shinjuku Station. The Hihashi-Shinjuku station (E2 Oedo Line) is a very much closer 3 min walk to the hotel. Be warned that the transfer at Shinjuku from the common tourist Marunouchi Line to Oedo is a looong confusing walkabout. The Oedo Line is not bad for destinations like Tsukiji, Ueno, Asakusa, Shibuya.. we actually ended up using it a lot.Many have commented about the "red light" district, but it is nothing. Should not even be a factor. I wouldn't even know it unless I was looking for it - perhaps we never walked southwards. We felt safe walking around.The only thing I don't like about this hotel is the reception. Yes, most speak English, and some have an attitude problem. I was checked in by a graveyard-faced receptionist after 14 hours travel, no smiles, nothing that might be remotely construed as welcoming, not a hint of helpfulness as to which eateries would be recommended at that time of the night. They also misplaced an internet dongle package for 3 days which caused me a lot of problems having to liaise with the sender who correctly insisted they have sent it. Although the manager did apologized after that.If you find a good deal, this hotel may be worthwhile. I paid ~US140 during an online offer for a double in Nov peak, but there are many different and confusing room-types. And hope you find a better welcome than I did..

In Tokyo hotel rooms tend to be very small so be prepared for that. No proper wardrobe or cupboard for your clothes and barely any place to out your suitcase. Located in a very busy nightlife area (but perfectly safe) it's still a very quiet hotel. Staff are nice but I always find issues with communications. For ex I was desperate for a workout (hotel has no gym) and they give me a map to find my way to a gym. The gym was inside a mall so no signs on the front of the building but hotel staff did not mention this. They also failed to mention that when you get there you need to change your shoes, I changed at the hotel and walked over to the gym and they refused to let me in if I didn't rent shoes from them. Pretty unpleasant to rent running shoes other people have worn and of course I need my proper running shoes to run. So back to the hotel and I think I will do staircase running, but no, the staircases are locked for emergencies only. So if you need to work out pls take note of this before you go to the Oasis gym if wearing proper running shoes is important to you.Back to the hotel. There is good wifi, a pleasant coffee shop near in the reception with a small outdoor seating area too. The bathroom has a great supply of toiletries. The only issue in my room (besides the small size) was the fact that between the bathroom and the room there is a window and no possibility to draw a curtain etc so if you share the room with someone make sure you know the person extremely well as you have no privacy in the bathroom whatsoever. But it makes the room look bigger I guess.

I stayed at Granbell for two nights on my way home from skiing in Niseko and found it to be lovely. The beds were comfortable, decor of the rooms exceptional and clean, our view was great and the staff were very helpful and could speak excellent English. The location is also great too - it is just minutes walk from the busiest subway station in the world and around excellent dining options (also close to the red light district too). If you're a first timer to Tokyo, a simple walk out of the Granbell leads you onto a busy main street that really shows off the best of Tokyo at night. Breakfast downstairs was reasonably priced and nourishing. My only issue was the relatively small rooms with no space to put luggage, especially luggage containing a week's-worth of ski gear.

I was disappointed in terms of the room wasn't shown as in web site photo. The room is small but clean. We got a room on level 3, which doesn't have any view. It s a place just to sleep. The good bit is it s quiet. I don't like the location as it is located on the red light district. Staff is nice. The best thing is the unlimited internet!

We spent 5 days in Tokyo. We found this beautiful boutique hotel online & booked through their website. We choose to go with their luxury designer room because we loved the layout of the room with the shower in the middle. We were very pleased with our choice. The location of this hotel is so convenient. Walking distance from subway & train station. Short can ride from shinjuku station. The hotel room was extremely clean, spacious & beautiful views. The amenities in the room were top quality. I would definitively stay at this hotel again. It was walking distance from night life, restaurants and stores. We asked the front desk to make reservations for us for a restaurant. They went out of their way to tell the restaurant it was our honeymoon so they would surprise us with a little something. The attention they pay to detail. Breakfast was included also in our rate. You had a variety of North American and Asian which was perfect to try every morning. The rooftop looked perfect for drinks however we didn't spend a lot of time at the hotel. It was very quiet and peaceful. They gave complimentary bottles of water everyday. Amazing service. Excellent location.

This hotel is situated a short walk from the main station and is very modern due to the fact it has only been open 2 years.Do not try and get your room before 3pm on check in because it just won't happen.Rooms are small but with everything you could possibly want in it.Staff are polite and professional and speak English so no language barrier.The best thing is the roof terrace and bar on the 13th floor which gives superb views over the city.The surrounding area is the only slight downside with "love" hotels very close by but even so it's a safe and clean area and don't let that put you off.

we stayed at shinjuku granbell hotel for 4 nights. we booked one of the room with the loft. the room was very nice and clean, though a bit small for us 3, but we managed to fit in with our 3 big luggages with a bit of shuffling things around lol the bed was comfy, bathroom was clean and stuffed with toiletries. i just find the clear glass with just a curtain covering the bathroom a bit odd. daily breakfast for us was a plus because we were staying at rentals days prior. food was decent and had enough choices. staffs we're friendly and tried to book us at a famous sushi restaurant. the location might throw some people off because it's a couple of blocks near Kabuchiko, Tokyo's red light district, but i'm telling you, it's not like european cities red light district ;) of course there are sex-related establishments in the area, but the area is also full of good, affordable restaurants and bars. Shinjuku station is about 10 minutes walking distance which is narita express train's final stop (we also took the bus going to lake kawaguchiko near shinjuku station) and there is also a local station 2 minutes from the hotel. all in all, a very nice accomodation to get a break from renting apartments for us, without breaking our banks.

First time we stayed in this area. Granbell is in an area near 2 different train stations and only a few mins away from good restaurants and shopping. Our room was really small but quiet and clean. But we wouldn't recommend it if you'd like to have a proper breakfast before you start your days of adventure as their coffee shop opens really late (10am) and their service is really slow but with only one lady behind the counter it's understandable.There's a E-hotel nearby with a Tully Coffee Shop downstairs which looks better with their full coffee and breakfast service.

Don't be fooled by the photos on the web site and the wide-angle cameras: almost all of the rooms in this hotel are tiny - even by Tokyo business hotel standards. Many are also unnecessarily dark with brown interiors and narrow horizontal slits as windows. This hotel is only about a year old, yet it is already showing astounding signs or wear and tear. Floors are scratched, carpets stained, traces of the luggage visible on the walls. Like in the Shibuya branch, they forgot to plan in a luggage storage room, so it's just kept in a corner of the lobby under a net - not very elegant. On the positive side, the beds are very comfortable. Lighting inside the rooms is good, with plenty of options for a cozy indirect light. All the amenities one expects from and upscale business hotel are offered. Wireless is fast. And check-in/out was efficient. The hotel is in the middle of Kabuki-cho, about a 15 minute walk from main Shinjuku station, though only a few steps from the Higashi-Shinjuku station. With the Hotel Gracery set to open just around the corner in a few months, it will face some stiff competition. This should keep the prices down to 8000yen for a single - in which case the hotel offeres a reasonable value.

Although it's in the heart of the 'red light' district, this hotel was a class of its own. Many vending machines on the ground floor for a late night snack. With Tokyo being strict on smoking in public, they had a decent smoking room on the ground floor too. A nice cozy bar upstairs, of in case you didn't want to take the risk with the pubs outside. The first night we arrive at midnight and had the best Ramen on one of the streets which made us look forward to the rest of what we will be feasting on. The room was tiny, but for the price we paid, it was well worth it. I would surely stay here again.

Nestled south of Kabukicho, this hotel provides everything those wanting a city break could want. The rooms are small but cosy, the roof top bar is incredible with excellent service. The staff at the front desk looked after our suitcases as we went to Kyoto for a few days. I couldn't fault a thing.

Stayed here twice on our trip very good location, close to subway and shinjuku train station. Hotel was very clean, staff very friendly and helpful. Rooftop bar excellent open late serving food. Perfect for a comfortable stay in tokyo!

The hotel is situated about 3 minutes walk from tokyo metro. Overall, the hotel is nicely decorated, with full wifi access throughout the hotel. One major downside of the hotel is that it is located in the middle of the yellow district. Returning at night will be greeted with many prostitude along the way, so be warned!

This was one of the last stops on our honeymoon and I must say it was AMAZING. The hotel is brand new and I was really hesitant when I booked it. The are didn't convince me from what I remembered from my last time in Shinjuku. It also didn't convince me the fact that this hotel offers rooms at prices from very low budget to very high budget. Some rooms are worth it and probably some aren't. This also makes for a very diverse group of guests (could be good or bad). When we checked in Nana Hatsugai was there to help us with the process. She was truly amazing. I mentioned it was our honeymoon and she upgraded us to a club level room. With access to the club lounge and breakfast. I had previously requested a high floor and she granted us that, she gave us a room on floor 16 with floor to ceiling windows. A really nice room with an industrial feel to it (very brooklyn!). We got to enjoy the club lounge specially from 5-7 when they serve wine and beer. While it is quite different from most club lounges I have been to before it was very nice to have been given this as a compliment. Breakfast I must admit could be better. The offer is not quite four stars. I'm sure this is something they are working on. I got the impression it is more intended for the asian travelers than the westerners. For example, being Italian, the fact that there is no espresso in the morning is unacceptable; yet again, it was complimentary so I can't complain!During our stay we continued to see Nana Hatsugai at the front desk and she was amazing with everything we asked her about. She was very knowledgeable about tourist destinations, how to get to them, opening hours, etc. Also, I couldn't end this review without mentioning how great her english is, which is rare in Japan and even in this hotel, not everyone at the front desk. This makes things very easy since my Japanese is close to nothing. To end up my review, we had a wonderful stay at this hotel, all thanks to Nana Hatsugai who present from beginning to end. Maybe we were lucky or maybe that is how it is with everybody, that I cannot say. What I can say is, as long as she works there I will be coming back! Thank you Nana!
user_name:
Sebastian P
New York City, New York

review_body: True boutique; very small room; beyond clean; cool neighborhood; cool hotel; good area for nightlife but I didn't go out too late; I would definitely stay here again.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

If you're taking the subway, this hotel is easy to get to and near to the beating night-life heart of Shinjuku. If you're coming at it from the JR Railways (as we were) it's a bit more of a walk, but easily found if you've got Google Maps to hand. Staff have a fairly firm command on the requisite English, so if you're an international traveller you shouldn't struggle.We stayed in a modern/mature room on the 13th floor, fitted out in a hardwood and glass style that was very sleek. The room had all of the expected amenities and more - including some decidedly upmarket shampoo and personal care products. If you stay in a decent room here (Floor 13 and above) then you also get access to a complimentary exclusive lounge on the 13th floor where you can help yourself to free snacks and soft-drinks/tea and enjoy an amazing view.In terms of food, the 12th floor has a substantial dining area for the guests to have breakfast - which was a fairly wide and enjoyable buffet of eastern and western fare. There's a coffee shop on the ground floor near the lobby for brew-hunters and a bar that opens on 13th floor after 5pm, serving drinks and some hot snacks.It was intensely refreshing to have a bath after a long train ride from Hokkaido - and the centre-room all smoked glass shower is very well made. The large full size bathtub had a view overlooking Shinjuku that made relaxing even easier too.Will be back again, day after tomorrow - though we're going for an even nicer room next time.

it's been my first time in Tokyo and thus hotel was the right choice for me. great location, easy access to the train station. room weren't very big but for me as a single traveller more than enough, most important for me the room was spot on and clean. I will be for sure coming back. breakfast experience was so so but all available for a quick bite in the morning.

This was a very nice hotel with pretty good size rooms for Tokyo, the staff were very helpful and the food in the restaurant is pricey but really, really nice (especially when you are hungry and it is pouring with rain!).The design of the rooms and hotel is very modern and very comfortable, the area is really nice (for me especially as the room we were in looked out on to the Square Enix building *eeeee!!!* and the cafe there serves all sorts of Final Fantasy cocktails etc!!).It is a bit far from the station to drag a suitcase to be honest but personally I wouldn't have wanted to stay much closer to the station.The red light district is actually very safe and worth a walk through - if you like Whisky there is a bar near there called Zoetrope which has the most amazing selection of Japanese whiskies (it is a little hard to find, very small and on the 2nd floor if I remember right!).Shinjuku is very,very touristy, so worth a visit if you like shopping and nightlife etc but for staying in we found Hamamatsucho better for our personal needs.There is an amazing Tempura place around the back of Bic Camera (also worth a look for souvenirs etc!) which I highly recommend. If you aren't familiar with the customs for Tempura and all the different parts then I would say google it first ;) so worth it! They do have an English menu although from the outside it doesn't look like it. There is good Wi-Fi in the rooms too!Great hotel for the rooms and just the right distance away from main town for us!

Stayed for 3 nights. Great location with modern comfort and English speaking staff. Arrived at the hotel prior to check in time and were able to leave the bags with reception. Close enough to hustle and bustle of Shinjuku and the station on JR line, but far enough away also to enjoy.

We stayed 8 nights at this hotel and it was a nice surprise. It was good value for money, considering what we paid in one of the most expensive cities on the planet. We stayed in a very small room, but it was adequately distributed so to optimise space usage. The room was spotless, perfectly clean at even the smallest details (as you would expect in Japan). Very friendly staff, nice view of the Shibuya skyscrapers from the breakfast room, although the food it self could be better. A very nice stay, a recommendable hotel.

The hotel was everything you could expect from an international 4.5 star hotel. We had 2 rooms, the rooms were spacious (for Japanese standards), there is no closet, but we managed to cope with the clothes hangers provided. Even though breakfast was not included in our room rate, we did have breakfast at the 25th floor, infact we even had dinner there one night. Location was great, right in the middle of the entertainment and shopping district and close to Shinzuku station (the busiest train station in the world).

Location: In Shinjuku, surrounded by other ?love hotels. However, felt safe even late at night.Transport: Close to multiple train stations 1-2 blocks away. Easy to access to rest of Tokyo.Room: Standard Double. Very small. No walking space after luggage bags open. Has all the expected room amenities. Very clean. Vending machine on each floor. Wifi on each floor.Price: ¥13450 per night for 2 people. I thought pricey for such a small room, and friends said could get nicer accommodation for similar prices.No issues with our stay, was a good base to explore Tokyo, but probably wouldn't stay again.

We stayed for 2 nights as a family and had two rooms. The rooms (designer premium rooms), where excellent. Modern, large & clean. There was plenty of room, and the bathrooms were ultra modern and also huge. Taxi driver found it hard to find, so make sure you have the phone number with you. The breakfast was good, and there is a great view. The small bar was also very good. The location is great, to explore Shinjuku, which is a vibrant, lively area. Close by is the small bar area Golden Gai, highly recommended. I read some people were concerned the hotel is close to the red light area. But we did not find this a problem at all. I was happy to walk through with the family as there is nothing to openly see or on display. I think if you were single or 2 men, you will have people coming up to you to try to get you to go into the bars. But we were not bothered at all. We did visit the Robot Restaurant, walking distance from the hotel. Which is totally insane - it;s very Japanese,, crazy, neon, cheap, tacky, and brilliant. So we really enjoyed the hotel and exploring Shinjuku.

The Eastern side of Shinjuku station offers cheaper hotels than the Western side, but quality can be hard to find. The Granbell gives you a good quality at a fair price, and it's rooms are stylish. I went for the 'Luxury Designer Double - Mature' which was a lovely room with a semi open plan layout incorporating a double shower unit with rain shower and a fabulously high pressure hand held shower (excellent for hydro massages from/on your partner) and a free standing bath. We left the windows uncovered to enjoy the Tokyo cityscape at night, and to be woken in the morning with beautiful sunlight gently illuminating the sleepy city below. Our room and some others gives access to the Club lounge, which, though smaller than I was expecting, was a perfectly comfortable spot for the free wines and nibbles served each evening, or coffee and juice during the day.Breakfast was actually the best I had in Japan, because although it's a buffet, there's a good selection and I was able to eat light, healthy and recognisable items. All my other experiences of 'western style' breakfasts in Japan were nothing of the sort! The restaurant wasn't up to much for dinner, but on our first night we were too tired to explore outside.It only takes 7 mins to walk to Shinjuku station and Tokyo's metro can be accessed 3 mins walk away, so the location was good. As some reviewers have mentioned, there are several hotels in the area offering rooms for 'a rest' rather than a full night, and there are other businesses some might regard as seedy. But seedy in Japan is not scary or threatening, so don't let it put you off choosing the Granbell.

This was an excellent surprise in Tokyo. Not only the price is very reasonable, but also the location and the general amenities of the hotel are great and the design very nice. The rooms are small, but for a short stay (we stayed a week) you don't need more. And the location, 5 minutes walk from the subway, is perfect. Also, there are lots small cafes and restaurants around. I definitely recommend it.

The price is very good for the area. It is located in a quiet area of Shinjuku and from a 10 min walking distance from Shinjuku station. Considering the prices and the sizes of the rooms in Tokyo, I do recommend this hotel. Free Internet, Laundry can be made but it only has two machines for the whole hotel, so try to do it very early! At the top it has a nice bar, the views are worth it at any time of the day.

The comforts of home but just in Tokyo. No originality, nothing authentic Japanese, the sky lounge/bar serves very little local cuisine.The heated toilet seats are nice. The room/bed was small, but very comfortable, clean, nice. Location is amazing. 15 minute walk from shinjuku station, 2 minute walk for E2 oedo line station. At the right price, this place is awesome.

I booked this hotel mainly because of its location and price and also as we knew we would only be using the hotel as a base.The room itself was quite small but it was described as 'standard' so we were not shocked. The bed took up most of the room and the wardrobe was so tiny we lived out of our suitcases which wasn't a problem. This is a room where you cannot be shy with your partner because the bathroom has a see through glass panel so you can see EVERYTHING! Absolutely no privacy when doing daily ablutions.The room was cleaned daily and had coffee and tea facilities as well as a fridgeand free WiFi.The room serves it's purpose ands we were happy to stay here.Staff were friendly and very helpful.

This place was affordable and a great place to launch our two day Tokyo exploration. Smaller rooms but great facility. Clean. Clean. Clean (like all of Tokyo!).Very close to the subway. - note there are elevators to bring luggage over the cross walk!!

Stayed 9 nights at the Shinjuku Granbell with my girlfriend.Our room (Economy Double) was small, but well-designed and pretty much as comfortable they could make a room that small. Bed was comfortable. Bathroom was nice and it was nice there was a deep (but not long) bathtub in there. Our last stay in Tokyo at a more expensive hotel in Shibuya only had a shower. I extended my stay at the Granbell and the reception staff were easy to deal with and offered me a competitive rate for staying longer at the hotel.A few tips:- We stayed at the hotel with 4 other friends, both sharing similar Economy Double Rooms. Both of them were inititally placed into rooms that have a window seperating the bedroom from the bathroom, but there is no curtain between the bathroom and bedroom. So....whomever you are sharing the room with has to see you on the toilet/shower. Needless to say they asked to change rooms to a room with a curtain. Just something to consider. I really have no idea why the Granbell thought having rooms with a full window into the bathroom/toilet and no curtain was a good idea.-Our room keys became de-activated about 5 different times throughout our stay, we kept having to go to front-desk to re-active them. I eventually suspected that keeping the room key in my wallet besides my Pasmo/Suica tokyo transit cards might have been causing the hotel room cards to error out. If the same thing happens to you, keep your room card away from a Suica/Pasmo card.-There is no English language TV channels. I know that might seem like a small detail in such an exciting city but during downtime if you want to watch any English tv or movies be prepared to pay Y1,000 (approx $10) a day for a Video On Demand card from the vending machine. -The rooftop bar on the 13th floor is great. A bit expensive, but great. -The closest subway station to the hotel is Higashi-Shinjuku Station, if you are travelling to the hotel and can avoid the main Shinjuku Station I'd advise it. Shinjuky Station is the busiest train station in the World and it's a zoo in the station and all around it. It might be less daunting to visitors to head to Higashi-Shinjuku for a short 5 minute walk to the hotel rather than the 15 minute walk from the crazy area around Shinjuku Station. -Hotel WI-FI is a bit hit or miss. If you rent a "pocket wifi" unit while in Tokyo, you might end up using that rather than the hotel wi-fi. -The area around the hotel is great, it's a very short walk to the massively entertaining Kabukicho area and the bars in Golden Gai.

Great hotel! Stayed here for 4 days and enjoyed everything about this hotel. Clean, new, great staff, good western breakfast, 1 min walk to metro, close to Golden Gai (this is a must) and robot restaurant etc. we booked a 25m2 deluxe studio room with a king bed and was very comfortable with enough space for 2 people (and my mrs loves to spread her stuff out). This room was slightly more expensive but worth it with a massive bathroom and shower by Aussie standards. If your a tv person you'll be slightly disappointed as there is very limited English channels. Hotel is surrounded by love hotels but that's Shinjuku. If your a young couple looking for a hotel in the thick of the action with a dash of chic luxury.....book this hotel!

Don't be fooled by the photography on their site, the rooms are small, although fairly typical size for Japanese hotels. Like most hotels in Japan, they are religious about the 3pm check-in, so if you are arriving before this, make sure you have made some plans to kill time. We arrived on New Years Day, so the whole of Tokyo was dead. The hotel is nicely designed in contemporary artsy style, and a welcome differentiation from the 'bland-beige' style that predominates in many of the chains. Service was good, room-top bar would be great in summer, and location is great for Shinjuku area, metro etc.
