Clean and modern hotel in Shinjuku. Great location with subway nearby and close to central shinjuku.The staff was very helpful and spoke good english. The rooms are clean and we hade a great view from our room.

We stayed here for 8 nights over Christmas and would definitely stay here again. The hotel is in a great location, within walking distance of the train stations and a lot of Tokyo must-dos. The hotel staff was super helpful, though the receptionist that checked us in did not speak English very well. The room we had was a bit small (but we knew that this is what we would find pretty much anywhere in Tokyo) so 2 people can be a little cramped if you need to stay in the room for more than a short period of time.
user_name:
AvidTraveler1977
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here for six nights(over new year) and would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a great place to stay at while in Tokyo. The location is good, within walking disrance to metro and trains. Very helpful and friendly staff, at the reception, in the restaurant and house keeping. The rooms are big enought and contains everything you need. We stayed at the 10 th floor and had a nice view over Shinjuku. Rooms are clean and modern. We expected a continental breakfast but it was a buffé ☺ Would stay here again when in Tokyo.

Guys, stayed 5 nights at this hotel. A little difficult to find in the beginning but once you know where it is, its super convenient! Sort of middle between Shinjuku Station as well as Higashi Shinjuku station! In terms of transport, easy peasey! Excellent staff that speaks great english and hotel is less than 1 year old! Right in the heart of Shinjuku area, less that 10 mins walking distance to Robot Restaurant as well as food!!! No shortage here!! I will go back to stay again!

If I could give a rating of 4 and 3/4, I would, because it's not quite 5. Everything was excellent, except for the Wi-Fi which unfortunately was stuttery at times. Nevertheless, my stay was awesome. The location of the hotel, steps away from Golden Gai, one of my favourite spots in Tokyo, was prime. Public transport, shops, restos, are all within walking distance. Would stay there again. The rooftop bar and patio are unbeatable.

I love subway in Japan, very clean and fast, thats why i chose this hotel. My stay was excellent, breakfast is delicious, i stayed here for 4 nights and the room was clean and the staff was friendly and helpful. The room has big window to look out the view, the hotel also has nice decoration!i will be back here soon on next winter break and will recommend to all my friends.Really great value for money, thank you Shinjuku Granbell!

This was a great hotel with the rooms a little bigger than usual for Tokyo. It had a very hip vibe and was beautifully fitted out. The restaurant had a great breakfast buffet, typical of Tokyo and it was in a quieter area, tucked away from the main drag. This was a positive rather than a negative for us. My only complaint was that my leather gloves went missing from my room.....but s$#t happens... Would definitely stay here again.

We had a fine stay here. The rooms were clean, comfortable and mostly adequately equipped. Small compared to the rest of our trip but this is somewhat expected with the price. The location is interesting to say the least. This hotel is a boutique hotel. Self-styled as an "art-hotel". There are large art installations in the very stylishly designed lobby. The room itself was also rather stylish. Desk service was fine, staff spoke enough English to figure out the particulars. Unlike some more expensive hotels, there was no bell-captain but there was an elevator which is just as good in my opinion. The rooms themselves are very clean and comfortable. Good use is made of the limited space available. That said, this was one of our smallest rooms for our entire 3 week trip. Considering we only paid about 6800 yen each ($68 AUD~), we cannot really complain but it did feel a tad cramped. Dealing with large (30kg+) suitcases required some creativity. Otherwise, absolutely impeccable rooms with good views. The location may pose a challenge to certain travelers. It is located in a particular area of Shinjuku. Most of the neighboring buildings were "love hotels", host clubs or "massage" centres. I never felt unsafe. Australia is a very safe country but Japan is even safer still. The street feels a tad seedy but i see it as adding character rather than being a threat. By in large, it just feels like a neon bathed futuristic city. It really is like the Tokyo imagined in movies and the popular imagination, bathed in a neon glow along with many small bars, "hotels" and fashionable people. I quite enjoyed it's character but it is not for everyone. I usually give reviews in terms of the price paid. Considering what it cost, it is a very good hotel. I love the concept behind it. The room, even given the price, was a bit on the small side but it is one of our least expensive stays. The location may either prove challenging or interesting depending on how you feel.

PROS:1. Good location - While it's quite a walk from the subway, there's a lot going on in the area (not for kids though) that you wouldn't mind the walk itself. 2. Friendly staff - They're very accommodating and can communicate in English very well.3. Good freebies - They hand out pocket-size Shiseido products upon check-in (for female guests), which is great. Bathroom amenities were also nice.4. Above average bathroom fixtures5. Bed was comfy.6. Good internet speed in room. It's also free.CONS:1. Small room - While the interiors were well-designed and contemporary-looking, the room is very small and cramped. 2. Bathroom - While the bathroom itself was nice, I didn't like the glass window separating the bathroom and the bedroom -- with no option to cover it up. No curtains no nothing, which makes doing no. 2 uncomfortable in front of your new spouse. We had to make a deal that when someone's on the toilet, the other one shouldn't look.... which proved challenging in a very small room. But if you're comfortable with that setup, then great.

I absolutely loved staying here. Our room was very roomy and very nicely furnished. It's an "art" hotel, so if you like a boutique feel to your room, this is a good choice.Standouts: our room had a giant window with a city view. The bathroom was great; a full, free-standing bathtub in the middle of a very large bathroom with french doors. The separate shower had two heads (dreamy), and of course the toilet was fully equipped with all of the luxurious settings you could ever ask for.The bed was very comfortable, the room had a tiny closet with Shiseido clothing freshener (so tempted to accidentally pack it), and a couch with a coffee table. This was the "deluxe designer double," which I would happily do again.The neighborhood is garish/delightful, and it's any easy walk to Golden Gai, the Robot Restaurant, tons of restaurants and bars, and of course to a vast array of host and hostess bars. The Granbell is surrounded by "Love" hotels, which is amusing when walking to one of the four nearby/nearish Shinjuku stations.What I didn't love was the breakfast buffet - it was easy to give it a miss. Be careful also if you need a cab to get anywhere in a timely fashion (cabs don't pass by the hotel). Once called, it took about thirty minutes to arrive, and the ensuing panic and barely making our train to Narita (literally within seconds) was a somewhat stressful ending to a otherwise excellent stay.

Here's the rundown: it's a new, clean hotel with friendly and helpful staff. If you cheap out and get the cheapest room rate, you also get the smallest room in the hotel. 110 sq feet is perfect for me, but if your party travels with more than 2 suitcases, or if you're somewhat uncomfortable in small spaces (do you freak out when you're in a submarine?), then you may want to upgrade to a bigger room. Go ahead and get the breakfast-included rate. The breakfast is really good value, and consists of a full buffet with Asian and Western offerings. Shinjuku is nothing like Shibuya, and so breakfast offerings are somewhat limited. Thus, a hearty breakfast that's good value can't be a bad decision. This hotel is really better suited toward solo/couple travelers. Shinjuku is not a fun area for kids to explore - it's got some gritty parts (gritty for Japan, FYI, which is nothing). Keep this in mind when booking this hotel. That being said, it's another unique place in Tokyo to visit and experience.

We stayed for 3 nights. Location ok but still a bit of walk from Shinjuku. Really needed to use Metro to get around. Beds comfy and room very nice inside. Small but will designed. Breakfast was ok but nothing you would want to pay for. Staff were great. Hotel lobby is packed all day due to 3pm check in time. Suitcases and tired travellers scattered around. Would probably come back if got same rate $150 per night for 3 of us in a loft room with breakfast... but only if I could not find something closer to Shibuya or Shinjuku station of similar standard.

The Granbell is a very nice hotel, with great rooms, a nice lobby, and I quite enjoyed the upper floor bar. It was fine for a family stay, but be aware, the area is dodgy. It might be a bit uncomfortable to walk through the surrounding area with kids, and the cab driver refused at first to bring us there. However the Granbell itself is not part of the surrounding 'scene' and will not disappoint.

We stayed here 2 nights as a stopover for a ski holiday. There service was excellent, very efficient and thankfully they spoke good English as sadly I can't speak Japanese. The organised taxis and A friend arrived later then myself on a different flight, and there were no problems for her to get a key while I was out of the hotel. The rooms were very nice and clean, we even had a home cinema system with screen and projector. Shower/bath and bathroom were great, they had a frosted window to the bedroom area making a silhouette when yiu showered. However this didnt prove a big issue even as a group of friends, but we did only stay 2 nights. We had a loft lounge balcony area which was nice to chill.

The Shinjuku Granbell has been open about a year and we found it by mistake when looking for a bar to fill an hour in Shinjuku - the floor 13 rooftop bar, open to non-residents proves a fantastic view over the city and a great backdrop for a drink. It's also perfectly located for some of Shinjuku's top attractions - Golden Gai and the Robot Restaurant are minutes away, the shopping centres and mainline station are on the doorstep, and the gay area is under ten minutes walk away.As a result we decided to stay here for the final couple of days of our holiday, and treated ourselves to the top floor resort suite with outdoor bath to finish our trip in style. The room was completely out of this world - from the moment the blinds open as we walked in and the view extended out in front of us, we were in love with the place. A house entrance hall area with table and chairs, enormous bedroom with luxuriously comfortable bed and seating area, huge television, and then the steps up to the bathroom area with huge shower/bath and of course, the outdoor bath. Despite the temperature being 0 degrees Celsius we took advantage of this on both nights!The service however was somewhat lacking. No room service after 10pm, so no drinks to the room, and a very limited menu earlier in the day too. Only two illy coffee pods to go with the machine, and the cafe didn't open until ten in the morning. The breakfast was ok, but for a hotel of this standard I would expect more - the are so many delicious bakeries and patisseries in Tokyo is was a shame there were no examples of this at breakfast.Some very small improvements would make an enormous difference to this well positioned hotel, and make it a real competitor to the multinational chains in and around the area.

It can be difficult to find a nice, small, well located hotel in Tokyo that won't break the bank - this hotel is just that. A minute or two walk from the metro, so a train hop anyway from anywhere in Tokyo. If you want to walk, Shinjuku proper is only 5 minutes away.The hotel is tiny, as in common in Tokyo, but has been set up so you have everything in the room you expect just in a tighter space. If you are tourist, you won't be in the room much anyway right? My next trip to Tokyo this is the first hotel I will be looking at for a room. The price value/location is perfect.

I read the various mixed reviews on the hotel and location and would not have chosen this hotel in the first instance, however the normal places where I would normally stay were either fully booked, or just way too expensive, therefore I chose the Granbell because of the price and risked it.I took a taxi from Shinjiku Station as I had a suitcase and didn't want to be wondering the streets trying to find the hotel, however now that I have been there and got my bearings, next time I would be ok to walk.Check in was fast and efficient and I was nicely surprised when I walked into the room. I booked an Executive and Suite with Club Lounge Plan and found the room to be spacious and comfortable. Admittedly, it did not have a desk to do work on, but instead I got a sofa to sit on and used my laptop there... no problem.Breakfast was minimal, busy, but enough for me to be satisfied.There are some little things like when I rang for an Iron, they informed me to go to a level and collect the iron board and iron myself, which I did and the iron board was a half size one, so it took a little bit longer than normal, but I got a good size room, very modern clean, wifi, breakfast, etc for half the price of other hotels that I would typically stay at.I will stay here again on my next trip to Japan

Shinjuku is the prime location for massage services and it's full of restaurants. Granbell hotel is about 100 meters away from all the crowded narrow streets. (10-15 minutes walk from Shinjuku Train Station if your coming from the airport using Narita Express train)My room was on the 10th floor (double room) and comparing to other countries, it was small. No closet in the room but according to the friends there, it was considered a big room in Tokyo.Hotel is clean, staff speak English, Internet was free (and breakfast was free on my room).I asked for 110V to 240V adapters and they were available at reception at no cost (you should return them when you check-out)There was no Iron in my room so I asked and found out that on 9th floor there's a cabinet with some stuff in it shared with all guests (including Iron, Iron Pad, Heaters,...)The toilet in the room had 23 buttons!! TV only had Japanese channels.Breakfast was very simple and the same every day. No bellboy (which I like)I had a Hair dryer as well which was not mentioned in the facilities when I checked before.

I stayed here for 7 nights and was happy with this hotel. Location is key, and Granbell was close to lots of late night or 24/7 restaurants (nice when arriving late at night and hungry!) and convenience stores. Yes, it is in the middle of a cluster of love hotels in the red light district. Some of the neighbouring hotels look cheesy, but I never felt unsafe, even as a woman walking around alone after dark on a couple occasions. It was also surprisingly quiet, because it is on a side street. I slept really well each night! The walk to the main Shinjuku station is 10-15 mins. and there is a pleasant, tree-lined path just west of the hotel. I found it much more enjoyable to take the path vs. the crowded main roads. The hotel is also close to Higashi-Shinjuku station, a smaller station with access to less lines. Finally, the hotel borders the North Shinjuku area which is the Korean part of the city. Check it out if you're looking for some Korean food or saunas. The hotel itself is very modern and clean. The design is really nice and the lobby always smelled amazing! The lounge has a nice patio. In terms of service, everything was smooth and I have nothing to complain about. The standard rooms are tiny. It's pretty much the queen bed and then a desk and chair. There was very little storage, so I kind of lived out of my suitcase. I would recommend they have more hooks to hang things on the wall. There were just a few hangers on a bar to put your jacket and one or two other items. Still, they make efficient use of the small space. There is a bar fridge, which was helpful since we got a plan where breakfast was not included. So instead, we would go to the 7-11 and buy onigiri, juice, and yogurt and eat that for breakfast! There are nice details: the mirror is heated so it never fogs up, really nice bath products, comfy PJ's and slippers. A solid option for those who want to be close to shopping (Shinjuku station area has everything - Isetan, Takashimaya, Muji, Uniqlo, Marui etc.) and be able to access subway lines that go everywhere. Shinjuku station is the busiest station in the city -- you can go pretty much anywhere in less than 40 mins. Shinjuku is also a good choice because there is a lot of nightlife, and you can just walk back to the hotel afterwards (an important consideration as taxis are really expensive and the subway stops running around ~12am).

Nice hotel in Shinjuku area. Usually you get also good prices. We stayed at the economy small double room, which is really small for western standards but is very well furnished and practical. Bottom line, you get used to its size.Location is not that great. It is a red light district. Very safe and we were OK walking around it, but have that in mind when booking. Nobody will bother you but for a family with small kids I think it would not be nice (not our case).Internet was faulty and not so fast.Breakfast was 4 out of 10... Many choices but a bad mix of western and Japanese food. We stayed in Japan at several other places and this was the worst we had. Not that the food is bad, but the choices are weird.But, for the price and quality of the room, 4 stars!
user_name:
LucianoSR
Sao Jose Dos Campos, Brazil

review_body: The hotel is very big amid all the small surrounding hotels. Small room but very much expected. All the staff spoke English which is extremely nice. Two bad things though. Wifi keeps getting disconnected and it's in the middle of the red light district. Lots of yakuza here. Be careful of the neighborhood
user_name:
Chung-I C
New York City, New York

review_body: We recently stayed here for the entirety of our trip (10 nights) and I would stay here again ! We didn't find the walk from the station too bad and it was convenient to be located near a subway entrance. We stayed in the Superior Studio Double room on the 14th floor and while the view isn't anything spectacular, the room was really nice ! It was great to have a bunch of space to put our bags and belongings and still have room to walk around (previous hotels I've stayed in have been so small..). The decorating was really nice and the room was very clean. The house staff were very good with cleaning our room and changing our towels etc when needed, plus topping up our drinks and toiletries. The huge shower was really nice and I found myself having baths most night in the large tub ! A good selection of channels on the tv, a comfy bed and good air conditioning. The breakfast on level 12 was pretty good, with a selection of Western and Japanese foods (we also had dinner in the restaurant one night, also good !). We also really enjoyed the roof top bar and occasionally went into the club lounge for a drink and some nibbles before bed. The staff were very friendly and had great English. We would not hesitate to come here time and time again, a fantastic hotel !

This is a nice modern hotel. Within close proximity to 2 underground stations which is good for getting around the city. Quite a distance from the main shopping area of shinkuku. Theres nothing much around the hotel if you are looking for shopping options. Very near the Karaoke bars and love hotels if you are looking for this kind of surroundings.The hotel is clean although the rooms are small. Would not be my top of mind choice next time i plan a trip to tokyo only because of its location.

Efficient and helpful front desk staff, close to metro (Higashishinjuku station, turn left from the station and shortly left again, hotel is on the "diagonal" road).Minor issues with room cleanliness, but nothing to worry about. Decent room size and quality. Good breakfast (although only very minor changes daily).On the edge of Kabukichio. Batting cage around the corner, plenty of good food places around (check the map stand at the reception for printed list&map of ramen shops around - nice idea to provide it).

Shinjuku Granbell is perfectly located for nightlife, eating out, karaoke, and generally having fun in a popular area of Tokyo.Shopping and historical locations are conveniently nearby.Train station access is only a 3 minute stroll from the hotel (I timed the walk), making access so easy.The staff members here all speak English fluently, and I had no trouble discussing my needs and getting directions around the city.The rooms are modern, clean, and big by Tokyo standards.A coin operated laundry room is provided, although only two washers and a dryer were available so there was a line-up to use it. You'll need to be patient.The ground floor restaurant is great for barista coffee in the morning, but their food is expensive and lower quality than many nearby options, so I opted to eat outside of the hotel.A collection of vending machines on the ground flood adjacent to the lobby were handy for 24 hour snacks, drinks and toiletries.Shinjuku Granbell is a stylish, friendly hotel, and I would go back again in a heartbeat.

The hotel is quite new and the compact rooms are modern and 'cute '. Both bed and bathroom were great.I arrived early and wanted an early checkin... i was disappointed to find the fee to check in early was 80% of the nightly room rate. Its far too high and it put me in a bad mood although i reluctantly paid as I needed a nap. I think a 50% price is acceptable. The location is a little out of the way being a 15 to 20 min walk from jr shinjuku station. It is much closer to local subway stations though. It is in a seedy neighbourhood but I felt safe in the area.

It is a brand new hotel. Modern and stilish. The room was not so tiny, I mean, you have only to sleep in. Free wifi. Stunning roof bar on the 13th floor. English speaking staff. The hotel on the ground floor has some vending machines. You can make a coffee in your room every day. I suggest it.

Thanks to Typhoon Phanfone and a cancelled flight home we had the pleasure of an extra couple of nights at the Granbell back in October. In fact we were already checked out with our bags in the lobby and off for our final day of sightseeing when we learned about our "bonus Tokyo round". We called the Granbell and they organised for us to check back in to the same class of room for an additional couple of nights. First up, finding the hotel really wasn't that difficult. Maybe I was over prepared after reading lots of reviews prior to arriving but in the end, I was completely surprised at how easy it was to find. My tip - DON'T alight at Shinjuku station. The trek from there with luggage would be pretty horrible. Instead change at Shinjuku station to the subway line and travel to Higashi-Shinjuku station. It is literally 2-3 mins walk once you get to street level. For the life of me I cannot remember the exit number that puts you at the best spot but there are maps in the stations that help orient you towards where you need to go. In fact, on Google maps the hotel appears as a little wedge so once you remember that, look for the "wedge" on any map and you've got it! Too easy. As I did with all our hotels in Japan, I actually saved the coordinates in Google maps on my phone so wherever we ended up it was a simple "get directions to hotel". Highly recommend this approach. Anyway, we had spent a few days at Tokyo Disneyland Resort so were travelling from the other side of the city. We ended up catching the subway from Tokyo Station and it was all very straight forward. We arrived at the hotel in late afternoon and from Higashi-Shinjuku station we exited at street level, took two left turns and from the lane it was pretty easy to spot the hotel. Super simple. The lobby was pretty busy and lots of luggage around. We were promptly served and the staff were lovely. We booked a Superior Designer Double on the 16th floor. The elevators were really efficient and there is a bank of vending machines just before them in the lobby stocking soups, ice creams, soda and alcohol. The room was incredible. Super stylish and clean with a great layout. Even with two bags there was plenty of space to move around. The view was amazing- floor to ceiling windows along the entire length of the room. In room amenities were fantastic - bath salts, Shiseido and Paul Stuart toiletries were restocked daily, complementary water, soda, iced tea and water also restocked daily, slippers and robes, bluetooth speaker for playing our tunes. Thick curtains to shut out the city light at night, great air conditioning and what was my favourite bed during our time in Japan. The bathroom had a deep soaking tub and rain shower. A few floors down was the club lounge - we only visited this once - it was stoked with complimentary tea, coffee, drinks and snacks for guests staying on the upper floors. Location is great - actually the first night we stumbled onto the Robot Restaurant - wow - what a baptism of sensory overload! Be warned - once the show is over you exit into the heart of the red light area - and as two guys we were targeted by some, shall we say, persistent chaps who tried to offer us all manner of things to the point that we had to duck into a Don Quixote to get away from them. Turns out these guys are on most corners around the area and after a second encounter on the way home we managed to find some quieter routes back to the hotel every other night. Never felt threatened - just found them annoying and was surprised I didn't read about them in other reviews before we arrived. But back to location - about 15 mins walk down to the main action in Shinjuku with all of the shops etc. We used the subway near the hotel to get around the city easily - Shibuya, Harajuku, Roppongi, Nakano, Akihabara and all the way out to Tokyo Skytree and Sensoji Temple. If you have the time, take a trip down to Hakone - it's incredibly beautiful. We took the Romance Car from Shinjuku station. We had drinks and some snacks at the rooftop bar one evening - great view and vibe up there. Perfect for kicking off your night. Breakfast was included, and we tried it once but it wasn't really appealing to me. I think my only gripe with the Granbell would actually be that there is only one dryer and when we stayed there that thing was in high rotation. I ended up setting my alarm for 5am to actually try and get to use it - luckily a guy had just finished drying his stuff at that hour so I managed to get my stuff in to dry. So if management are reading this, maybe a couple more dryers and washing machines. When all is said and done, would I stay here again? Absolutely. The Granbell was boutique brilliance.

I enjoyed the stay at this hotel. Best bang for the bucks. Friendly staff and clean room and not small room like Vintage hotel Shinjuku which I stayed previously.I Will stay in this hotel again nest trip to Japan

I would have given this hotel an excellent rating if not for the fact that we got lost for almost two hours while locating it. Well, actually, we were almost there when a helping Japanese man pointed us to a wrong direction. But anyway, once we've found it, we were absolutely happy because it's close to everything and anything we need -- restaurants, train station, good view of Tokyo city. Plus, we liked how the hotel was artistically designed. Our room also came with a breakfast buffet for two, making our stay a lot more satisfying. Their CR also has that unique buttons you only experience in Japan :) It's also located in Shinjuku, which is lovely to walk around during day or night. Would definitely consider staying here again next time :)

I arrived at the hotel through a shuttle service. I'm glad I did as it might have been difficult to find walking from crazy Shinjuku station. But that said, once I walked around the neighborhood I had a very easy time finding the station and it was only about a ten minute walk. Shinjuku is a fabulous area to stay in: the shopping the restaurants and the energy is electric. Though this hotel is near the red light district, I didn't feel unsafe at all. Yes, a few men approached me because I am a single guy, but I politely said no.Check in was smooth. They didn't charge a huge deposit like most hotels do, and I appreciate that. In fact, I paid no deposit as I paid up front. The lobby is very inviting, the café looks comfortable, and there's a nice lavender smell.My room: I loved it. I had a double economic room. Yes it's not as large as American standards, but it was perfectly functional and they had thought of absolutely everything. The toilet is what you'd expect from Japan and the shower and soaps were lovely. The bed was very comfortable and the room had great climate control.I ate at the restaurant the first night and the views are breathtaking. The food wasn't bad at all, but nothing earth shattering. The service was good but the vibe was great.The lobby has all sorts of maps. Have the front desk mark on the map where the hotel is located and you're set. Explore! Tokyo is an amazing city. While I was only there for three nights, I can't wait to go back.

My husband and me spent 8 nights in this hotel, very modern, with free WiFi. We had very, very small room. It was uncomfortable, but in Japan it's common. The hotel has roof bar with beautiful view. Location is very good, only 5 min. to Higashi Station and 15 min. to Shinjuku Station. Kabukicho has bad reputation, but isn't dangerous. We came back every evening to our hotel through this district. There were a lot of lights and people. Nobody didn't catch us. Shinjuku is very good place because of lots of shops, restaurants, clubs. I recommend this hotel.

My stay was very pleasant. Great location. Very near to train station. Very close to the shops and market in the area. The staff were very helpful and friendly. 30% discount at restaurant, nice rooftop bar that stayed open late, clean rooms. Only negatives are that the room was pretty small, not much space to move around or spread out. No hanging rail for my clothes, and the breakfast food seemed to consist of leftovers from the dinner menu the day before. I wouldn't purchase breakfast there if I stayed again. There are plenty of places to eat outside the hotel and for cheaper. Positives far outweigh the negatives and I would definitely stay again.

The hotel is probably the best choice for travellers that value both price, location and design. The hotel interior is superior to any other hotels in its price category and the hotel staff is friendly, average proficient in English, but very helpful no matter the request. The standard rooms can feel a bit small compared to European standards, but that's what is to be expected from hotels in Tokyo. The only minor complaints I can think of is 1) that you might have to wait a while for clean knives and forks at the breakfast buffet and 2) the location in Kabukicho is considered the shady neighborhood and contains a lot of love hotels and host restaurants that can put somebody off, but it's very safe and rather fun to experience.

My initial concerns about the location were unfounded, if you are even "half way" fit you will be able to walk to Shinjuku Station east exit in ten minutes and there are heaps of eating places nearby (only a street away. The directions provided by trip adviser member (AntheaB972) were very helpful (spot on) and got us to the hotel without any problems at all (while not the quickest route they are easy directions to follow and the walk is scenic with shady tree lined pathway for about a third of the walk). Our hotel room was very clean and comfortable, the view (or lack of) was a disappointment (we overlooked air conditioning and fire exit stairs). Breakfast had lots of choices but was not fantastic, eggs scrambled (very mediocre) with no other egg choices. Still we ate sufficiently (rolls, cereal, yoghurt, salads, bacon, pasta etc). Hotel staff were helpful, polite and efficient. All did a great job (we had no problems with being understood in English at reception, roof top bar, breakfast or by cleaning staff in hallways. We definitely recommend the Granbell (Shinjuku) and would stay again (but probably pay a bit more for a higher grade room). Our room was queen size 'superior' with a comfortable bed (but it was pushed against one wall) so it was difficult to get in and out quickly for person sleeping near wall. We stacked our luggage (two backpacks) to keep the seating area free for use, there was also a chair and desk but with only just enough room to pull chair out and sit between bed and desk (i.e. not walking room between bed and desk, when someone was sitting at desk). All in all a "better than average" hotel that just scrapes in as 'very good' because of it's amenities, location and friendly staff.

the hotel is very good, no breakfast included and room a bit small(but that's the Japanese style). Good services for guest (tons of vending machines and a laundry room). Unfortunately in the middle of the worst part of Shinjuku, no nice restaurants close to the hotel, despite a lot of massage centers, which were not on our "to do" list. Hopefully you'll be able to find hotels better located. Crazy bathroom, with a big window instead of a wall. No privacy at all, if you travel with friends!

I stayed at the Granbell for one night in November 2014.This is a pleasant enough business hotel without being in anyway exceptional.Check in was impersonal, but fast and efficient. Don't expect a high standard of service here, but do expect to be processed and moving quickly.Rooms are small, even by Japanese standards, but are neat and clean. Bathrooms are not the pre-fab drop-in nightmares that some places still provide, but are still very small. Prepare to be picking dropped towels out of the toilet. Wifi was fast and free, and I had no problems with the connection.This hotel seems to be targetting the Chinese tour group market, which leads to a crowded lobby in the morning. Leave a couple of minutes longer for check out than you may elsewhere.The area around the Grandbell is made up exclusively of pay-by-the-hour love hotels, which can make for a slightly seedy scene late at night. If this is likely to be an issue for you, look elsewhere.Overall, and OK option but nothing that I'd rush back to.

I stayed in a "standard double room". It was relatively small as is usual in Tokyo but the layout was great, which made up for it. Great bathroom. The hotel was very clean and well maintained. Staff was friendly and competent. The location is very good if you want to explore Shinjuku by foot, Shibuya is not far. Easy access to several metro lines. Would definitely go there again.Not a big issue, but king size bed was actually not one mattress but two smaller ones.

Excellent location. The hotel is situated closer to the Shinjuku-nishiguchi metro station instead of the Shinjuku JR line station. You’re still within range to experience all the excitement and “stimulation” of Shinjuku, without having to say “no, thank you” to every second pimp in Kabuchi-cho. That being said, the red light district in Tokyo is safer than most suburban areas in western countries.As for the hotel itself, we were in awe of their service and facilities. The bed was huge, our view on the 11th floor was stunning, amenities were perfect and the toilet had a remote control – not a good thing if the person you’re sharing the room with can turn into a man-child who finds it hilarious to activate certain functions randomly while you’re inside.

Great place to stay, friendly staff they speak a little English. The rooms are very clean. The breakfast every day was great, there is a bar with a great view. I would defiantly stay again, it is in walking distance from shinkuju train station which was very handy and surrounded by heaps of restaurants

Great location,so clean ,friendly staff, perfect place to stay.i will surely come back to this Hotel. Thumbs up! More power Granbell Hotel Shinjuku. & to all the staff & management of Granbell. Godbless. from Philippines with love.

We had a deluxe twin room on the 9th floor. Not very spacious by Western standards, but roomy for a Japanese hotel. The bathroom was really clean, and the shower was lovely! The beds were comfortable and I loved the controls on the light stand which meant you could dim the lights from the comfort of your bed. But the main plus for this hotel is the location. It's off of the main road so nice and quiet at night, but less than a 5 minute walk to the metro station, Golden Gai (alley ways lined with bars and small yakatori restaurants), 15minute walk to the main Shinjuku railway station (JR line) and also 15 minutes to the main Shinjuku shopping district. You are also only a short walk to the Robot Restaurant (a must see!). The roof top bar has a great view of the city and a spacious terrace. I would definitely stay here again!!!

A very well run hotel, the front desk staff were very well trained, friendly and helpful.We had a Deluxe Triple with loft on the ground floor which although small was well planned and very clean.Having a vending machine and cafe was a good idea, the coffee was excellent. We didn't eat at the hotel but there are lots of places nearby. Dean & Deluca was a favourite for brunch in the mall next to main Shinjuku station.Washing machines on 2nd floor a plus, but only 1 dryer which was a problem sometimes.Don't be put off by the hotel being in a red light district, it really isn't a problem.I don't think we could have found a better good value hotel in central Tokyo.

Great location in Tokyo, less than 10 mins stroll from Shinjuku station and about 2 minutes from Higashishinjuku metro station. Couldn't be at a better station than Shinjuku, connects everywhere. Loved the hotel, best of the bunch we stayed in all across Japan in our 2 wk trip. Sparklingly clean rooms, lovely rooftop bar, great buffet all you can eat breakfast on 12th floor. The room we had was a Superior Double, it was a tight squeeze but we managed with our two large suitcases. The bathrooms are rooms rather than cubicles, great shower and all that jazz. Staff couldn't have been more helpful in shipping our big cases to Kyoto, ringing ahead to be sure the hotel would accept them as we were going to Hiroshima first and following cases to Kyoto 2 days later.... anyway they rang ahead to the hotel and organised it all easy peasy.Shinjuku is chockfull of things to do and places to eat and drink.Don't miss Golden Gai, little alleyways of bars. We loved Ace's Bar - nice fella. Would like to see him doing well, friendly and chatty and gets a good crowd in.Went to the Robot Restaurant - DON'T. Rubbish and it cost a fortune. Unless you like sci-fi and are about 8 years old it won't impress you.Its in a grand area, ok it was a few ladies bars, but to be honest we saw lots of them all over Japan, no hassle at all. Safe area and busy night and day which is good. Didn't feel as honky-tonk as Shibuya. Totally recommend Granbell Shinjuku for value for money (we found it on Booking.com and it included the breakfast for the superior double room), good location, very safe, compact but great staff and spotlessly clean and span new hotel.

We had a deluxe room in the 14th floor and the room was great. Spacious by Japan standards with excellent amenities including Bluetooth speaker and great bathroom features. The view over the city was really nice and the bed comfy. Breakfast was a little disappointing but I guess most hotel buffets are and wouldn't let this deter me from staying.

my favourite hotel among all others. Granbell provides the best services and comfort you could ever ask for, and also at a reasonable rate. I certainly enjoyed my stay at the place. But the sad thing would be that the bedrooms seem pretty small.

Hotel rooms are a bit small but hotel is very nice and clean. If you will not be spending most of the time in hotel, this room is already good. Lots of places to eat and go to nearby. 5 min away from Shinjuku station by taxi, Free wifi and restaurant upstairs have good food. Also has a roofdeck bar. Only down side is check in is at 3PM. a bit late than the usual 1PM.

Hotels in Tokyo can be outrageously expensive but this hotel was affordable and a great value. The rooms were modern and clean and quiet and the price was very good for a tokyo hotel in a trendy area. Yes it is surrounded by love motels but it's not seedy and we never felt uncomfortable walking around at night. We made a mistake booking and ended up in a larger room the first night which was very nice. We moved to a smaller room and it was probably made for solo business travelers as the bathroom had a glass wall overlooking the bed which was more than a little awkward trying to use the restroom! No complaints otherwise. Staff is very friendly and helpful.It was really hard to find this place based on the map provided. If you have never been to Tokyo or shinjuku be prepared to possibly be lost.

I like the hotel because it was well located in the craziness of Shinjuku. I wanted to be close to all the bars, restaurants, shows, etc while in Shinjuku so this worked great. Very close to the red light district, but that's fine because that area is also still safe and fun to walk around as well in case you had any concerns. The hotel is very modern looking, clean, and has a great rooftop bar for cocktails. The restaurant has also a great breakfast buffet and not expensive with lots of western options. I chose the smallest room when I booked with my wife, and it was pretty small, but that was my fault. The other room sizes looked better, but we didn't bother changing as we were not in room often at all.

We opted for a larger room after reading reviews that were not complimentary to the smaller rooms and we weren't disappointed (room 1608). A great view with a large bath and bathroom - the bath came in very handy after big days walking the surrounds. A colourful district edging red light district with many eating options nearby. Roof top bar also had great views.Breakfast proved limited after a week with a couple of dishes alternating every 2 days - not a great variety.

To cut to the short and sweet. The hotel is brand new, the rooms are great but a little small (but that's not unusual in Tokyo), you get everything you need in the room and irons/trouser press etc are available to collect. The staff all said hi to you and despite their levels of English always did their best even if it means getting someone who can fully understand you. It's well located near the shopping area in shinjuku, the station and for those that swing the other way 2chome is walking distance as well. If you need the metro there is higashi-shinjuku one Road up from the hotel as well, although taking the 10/15 min walk to the main station will yield better connections. CONS: I didn't mark the hotel down for this but, the hotel is located almost directly inside Kabukicho which is the famous red light district. While perfectly safe to walk around and at no time felt uneasy, being hassled by the Nigerians to come to their bars all the time was a little annoying. If you are visiting Tokyo, don't go into any bars that the Nigerians try to get you in. However, you are able to completely bypass this area by taking a couple of mins to walk around via the main road and walking to the hotel from the other side. It's still family suitable and inside kabukicho there are still a couple of great tourist sights including the famous robot Restaurant, all that no more than 5 mins walk from this hotel. All in all. Great location, great rooms, staff and decent value for money. PS - economy doubles have little to no storage for clothes. If you're staying a long time you will find yourself living out the suitcase or making use of the seat for storage!

The hotel is located in the heart of Kabukicho in an area which was not far ago exclusively planted of love hotel.Granbell is mainly a tourist hotel with bit of boutiqueness.It is a white 17 storey building with a high ceiling trendy lobby.The check in was prompt and we were soon at 17th floor in the room 1702.Lets put it simply: the room is amazing.After a little room with a table and 2 armchairs with a view and a beautiful illy expresso machine you push a heavy metal framed glass door to enter the bedroom:Huge window with a view on the townVery large bed with beautiful bedside lightsSmall hifiHuge plasma TVLarge sofa and a bench with a little marble table next to the bathroom doorThe bathroom is perfect with bath, rainforest shower and outside you have an other stone bath, open air.The breakfast served at 12 floor is nice and simple.Overall it was not a cheap room but it was a stunning room very well worth its price

I stayed here for three nights. The hotel is very modern and clean. The staff at the front desk were very friendly which is what you expect from anyone in hospitality in Japan. I stayed in the smallest room which was small but was very clean and comfortable. If you're going to Japan you probably don't want to be stuck in just your room anyways. The cleaning crew did a good job at restoring everything back to its new condition every night. The wifi worked really well. The location is about a 15 min walk from the Shinjuku train station. The neighborhood is pretty quiet which is great.The one big thing I care about in a hotel room is the bathroom. The bathroom at this hotel is nice, clean, and modern. It was small but had everything you need to be comfortable. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Great hotel, great view!Don quijote and uniqlo near . Only a few blocks.You can go walking to shinjuku station and easy to move to anywhere.Great service and people are so kind.Cofee and snack free card, restaurant discount / welcome kit!!

The hotel is centrally located only 10mins from Shinjuku station, very close to an area boasting with small bars, shops and restaurants. The room (small double bed) was very clean, modern with plenty power outlets and makes perfect use of the small space. It might take a moment getting used to the fact that the bathroom is divided from the bedroom by a panorama window but all in all the room was very comfortable. There is free wifi, a terrace bar with great city views and vending machines close to the front desk.

Stayed at the Granbell hotel in Shinjuku for 4 nights at the end of Sept. 2014. My wife and I stayed in standard double room. Bed wasn't the comfiest but the room was nice. It's walking distance to all the night life and walkable to a Shinjuku station. Probably 20 mins with our bags. Staff are all very nice and our room was cleaned daily. They give you free slippers, toothbrushes, razors and hair brushes. A free buffet breakfast was included. It was good. Had choices for everyone. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking to stay in Shinjuku. It has a very nice top floor restaurant with a great view of Tokyo. I saw pictures of bigger rooms and they look amazing.

This hotel is in a super location. Yes, there are hotels all around that advertise both "rest" rates as well as stay rates; but the Japanese are so discrete and my family were never out late so we never saw any love hotel activity!Only a couple of minutes walk to Higashi- Shinjuku station, this hotels location is very convenient and accessible. The rooms, while very small, are very clean and well equipped. I think you could probably ask concierge to hold your luggage if space became an issue, but my family managed okay. One down side was we needed to use 2 rooms, one triple and one double and they were no triples located next to doubles so we 2 floors between our rooms. Slightly inconvenient but not a deal breaker for us. There is a washing machine on the 2nd floor and plenty of vending machines which can supply the essentials, there are also numerous convenience stores located close by. Overall a very good hotel which I'd happily recommend to anyone.

As with most things in Japan, this put's most UK hotels to shame, the rooms are compact, however the bed is very comfortable, the shower/bath is fantastic and the ammenities provided cover all the basics in case you've left anything at home. The hotel itself has a lovely, albeit pricey, rooftop bar, and a reasonable coffee shop by reception. One word of advice, most taxi drivers do not instinctivley know where this place is, so do try to have a print out in Japanese of the address & phone number as it is somewhat off the beaten path. Also worth checking out, is the nearby Yakitori place, the cabbage and sesame salad will change your life !

I stayed at the Granbell Shinjuku recently for a few days.The hotel is very new, and nicely decorated.It's an easy 10-15 min walk to the JR Shinjuku station or closer to one of the Metro stations.As well as the main shopping area of Shinjuku which is basically next to the JR station.There are many shops and restaurants here.The hotel provides free wifi although not in the restaurant where breakfast was served.We had breakfast included in our room cost. It was a good substantial amount of food.Standard western style foods egg etc and some Japanese style things as well as a salad bar. We had a twin share room. Which is on the smaller side. But being Tokyo everything is small. The Air Con was very good, beds comfortable, tea and coffee and complimentary water as well.The bathroom is nice. Good size bath and shower.Overall I was very happy with the hotel and would stay there again.

Stayed here on a tour of Japan with my brother.Now first up, the rooms are very compact, if you like big palatial hotel rooms then this isn't the hotel for you. They are however really well designed with a decent sized bathroom, desk and a really good use of space. As previous reviewers have said if you have two suitcases open and two people in the room its probably a bit full..However the hotel is in an amazing location in the slightly sleazy but very safe part of Shinjuku an easy stroll to Golden Gai and Shinjuku station. The staff at this hotel are fantastic.What really makes this place though for me is the roof top bar, its very rare that the hotel bar is a cool and fun place to hang out but the bar at the Granbell is awesome, really well ran and very good value. Overall if you are looking for great value for money and a very convenient location to explore Shinjuku and Tokyo I highly recommend the Granbell.One word of warning, most of the taxi drivers we had struggled to find the hotel, keep the hotel phone number handy and pass it to the driver they will guide them in smoothly.

The Shinjuku Granbell Hotel is a great hotel, in a great location.It is clean, well maintained and has a very modern, fun ambiance. :)I will definitely be returning!Pros: Location, trendy, clean.The rooms are clean and well stocked with amenities (toiletries, coffee, tea, free wifi). Some of the rooms have a great view, and it's situated in a location that is close to the main Shinjuku train station, shops, department stores, restaurants, bars and nightlife.The ambiance is a good real feel of Tokyo and can be kind of romantic.Good amenities in the hotel: Comfortable lobby, café, good restaurant with a view, vending machine room and rooftop bar (city views). Cons: Can be a bit expensive for the cost. It's more worth it if you get a deal on Expedia, etc.The rooms are small - standard for Tokyo, but still pretty cramped. If you pay more you'll get a larger room, but may not feel the value of the hotel.The service staff was ok. A bit dreary and gave incorrect information/directions, but otherwise probably standard.Other Notes:Shinjuku can be a difficult area to navigate, and this hotel was hard to find. It's tucked in a little.I would memorize your map and get familiar.This area is near the red light district, but felt safer than you would think. Please note that the street maps all face North.You will be walking a lot.

We weren't sure what to expect since we had never been to Japan before. The hotel is walking distance from Shinjuku station (use the East Exit) it's about a 10-15 minute walk, I recommend taking a backpack or light suitcase in case you get lost trying to find the hotel like we did. We asked at 7/11 which is really close to the hotel and they had never heard of it, even when we provided the address in Japanese. Eventually we found it and once we knew where it was all was ok. Staff upon check in were friendly and helpful. Check in wasn't until 3pm, they said we could check in earlier however it would cost $70(AUD) so we waited until 2:30pm and they checked us in without paying. Free Wi-Fi is available in the lobby and in the rooms and works well. We booked a Moderate Hollywood Twin Omote room on Agoda. The room was nice and clean, small but that's ok since we were out a majority of the time. Japanese style Pajamas were provided and complimentary bottled water. There is a mini fridge in the room to keep food and drinks cool. The rooftop bar was nice, reasonably priced drinks, friendly staff and great view! The food was also nice. Breakfast in the hotel's restaurants was Western and Japanese and was great! Only thing was they had a toaster but we couldn't see any toast. They would also benefit from providing some fruit that isn't the canned fruit in syrup at the museli/cereal station. All in all I would recommend this hotel and would stay there again. If there was any possibility to have a pool there that would make the hotel just that little bit better!

very new and clean hotel. a very good location in shinjuku, walking distance to a subway. lots of places to eat nearby.the only negative comment is that the hotel staff cannot speak good english and the hotel does not have a concierge service where you can book day trips, activities or things to do etc.we will definitely stay there again

We stayed there in end July, for 5 nights. This is a very good hotel, in the heart of Shinjuku, very new and modern, but with small rooms (standard considering it's Tokyo). Positives: Very modern, Great Staff, plenty of amenities, good wifi connection and very clean. Negatives: Water temperature in the shower changing constantly, A/C in Japanese only. Overall it's a good hotel, with a very good price, which make sit a great value. I'd definitely go back if prices were the same and would recommend it to anyone wanting to stay in Shinjuku.

Great hotel in the middle of Shinjuku.It is in walking distance from the train station but if you are carrying suitcases I would recommend taking a taxi.The hotel is brand new. The room are Japanese small. But everything is available.We loved the roof terrace and bar. From there you have a great view over Shinjuku.If you are looking for a Japanese style hotel, this is not your place. The guests are mainly western people and therefor it has an international feel to it.

We got the studio room, spacious compared to other hotels.We had to pick a good hotel in Tokyo coz we are staying for 4 days.Not so close to Shinjuku station. At night all street looks the same.Hotel is really clean and staff speaks better English compared to other hotels.They are helpful and helped us to reserve a restaurant in Sapporo.They also helped me to book a taxi to visit tsukiji tuna auction, 03:30Shower head is fixed to the ceiling, something new to me, had not take a shower like this before.Had a chance to jump to jump into bathtub and they are providing you the salt.

Pros:The hotel is new. Steady free wifi. The staff is polite and speak good English. The mattress is firm. It takes about 15 mins to go to Shinjuku JR station on foot.Cons:There are many love hotels and bars nearby. I am not saying it's dangerous. I just feel a bit uncomfortable to the surrounding area. Another consideration is too many alleys in the district. Though it is only 15 mins walk from JR station to the hotel, it is easily getting lost.Additional comment:I cannot classify my below comment as pros or cons, depends on the guest preference. It is just a glass wall that separates the bathroom and the bed. While you are lying on bed, you can see your roommate sitting on the toilet and vice versa.

This hotel sits at the top of a pocket of little bars and alleyways that house love hotels and the like. It is actually in a very safe and central area though. Accessible and cheerful.Rooms were spotless and new. In my case I took one of the larger rooms but there was a slight youth hostel vibe in the lobby, with its various vending machines and the bearded backpackers sprawled on the sofas asleep as they waited to check-in.The hotel is a quick walk to the action in Shinjuku. The main station is a brisk 10 minute walk away but just behind the hotel is a smaller station which takes you straight to Shibuya without changing lines.Our room had a splendid bathtub which overlooked slightly lower rooftop bar on 13/F.I think this hotel is very much a young person-type hotel but don't be deterred. It is a great place and a real riposte to the stuffy old hotels that I have stayed in around Shinjuku station before.

In the heart of Shinjuku is this great little hotel. Was little bit hard to find with the taxi driver as it is quite new in the area but once there was very happy. The rooms were great, very clean as expected and had all the little things I enjoy that makes the overall experience of staying in a hotel that much more enjoyable. I had an amazing view of the city and enjoyed the little treats plus bits and pieces in my room. Would be happy to stay there again.

Nice design recent hotel in the heart of the exciting area of shinjuku. Perfect for nightlife.Standard room, small but functional and super clean. Amazing international breakfast with a wonderful view at the top of the hotel. I had great time here.

This hotel was great overall. Fantastic value and almost brand new when we stayed. Don't miss the great roof deck with cool Tokyo views. The major challenge, as exists with pretty much all of Japan, is space. Our room was tiny. This did create a fascinating design solution: a shower/tub with an all glass back wall that butted up against the bed on the other side. I know - wacky. It's Japan! This is most noteworthy if you're traveling with someone you're not cool getting naked with. The staff was as helpful as they could be (it's Japan!). We had a package delivered and they had it for us no problem when we checked in. Also, they facilitated the shipping of our larger luggage to Koyoto. Not sure if this issue has been fixed but our taxi driver's GPS didn't recognize the hotel because it was newer - so make sure if you're taking a taxi there you ensure the driver knows where to go. Although, it may not make a difference since....you guessed it...it's Japan!

Very nice looking hotel in the heart of Shinjuku with spectacular views of the city and mountain range behind it.Shinjuku is a must for any visitor to Tokyo and is where the best nightlife is. The Kabukicho area around the hotel has every kind of nightlife to suit any tastes as well as a huge selection of places to eat and shop.Taxis in Japan don't always like taking foreigners as there have been many problems with getting the fare owed, so several drivers said they didn't know where the hotel was, but if you keep asking different drivers you WILL find one who will take you (it's most difficult for single male travelers).There are 3 train/subway stations close to the hotel, nishi-Shinjuku is the closest (about 1 min on foot).
user_name:
Simon P
Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia

review_body: Only stayed the one night, nevertheless time enough to feel that the Granbell had a good "vibe".Although compact my room was modern, comfortable and quiet. I found the bathroom a notch or two above what greets you in standard Japanese hotels.Breakfast was a nice buffet on the upper floor of the hotel. Im sure weather permitting the views are normally very pleasant.The location seemed to be just round the corner from the Shinjuku nightlife, alongside the love hotels. About 10mins walk from Shinjuku JR station.

Nice hotel in the heart of Shinjuku district, very well connected to the metro station (just 5min walking). The rooms were modern and clean, a bit small if you compare with western countries, but no SO small... in my opinion. Staff was nice and helpfull. The hotel has a bar in the top floor, an Italian restaurant and a cafe in the ground floor. I really recomend it.

I am a female traveler on a solo trip when I stayed at the Shinjuku Granbell Hotel I Greatly enjoyed my stay for 3 nights in July, 2014. The # 1 reason? The staff. They replied to my email enquires in english in a timely manner including helping me reserve tickets to events I wanted to attend prior to my arrival and with shipping luggage to their location when I didn't want to carry all the gifts I bought in Kyoto on my adventures in Wakayama Prefecture. It was a great help to have someone at the hotel advise me through email on how to do this. Once at the hotel the staff continued to provide the best of service. On the first night I ate in the hotel restaurant and even though it was about 10pm the waitstaff was very friendly, described the meals to me in english and as a guest I got 30% off the bill which made the dinner very reasonable. After I went up to the terrace bar and had a drink. A fantastic view was at hand! I really want to thank the staff for assisting me in such a friendly and professional way throughout my visit.As for my room - as it was the last days of my trip I did upgrade to a queen size bed. AI splurge indeed and this was my most expensive stay in Japan, but even so, compared to prices I have paid in NYC it was very reasonable for me (and if traveling with a partner even a better deal. My cost was $120 USD a night plus tax. The room was typical for Tokyo - not spacious but it was well appointed, modern, had a view, (higher up the better) was clean (like new) had a hugh TV, a unit to plug my iPod into (or iPhone) to listen to some of my own music, a full bath/shower in the bathroom, coffee, tea etc in the room.The hotel is very clean, nice design, there are vending machines for food and drink, ice machine, a coin laundry and a cleaning service. Besides the restaurant there is also a small coffee place in the lobby. You can also rent bicycles from the Hotel.The hotel is in a great location to get out and see the sites, and even in Shinjuku's red-light district I felt safe. My one complaint is that it is hard to find the first time - you see Tokyo is a place all about getting lost. Many streets have no names and their address system is very different. Even the local tourist info place at Shinjuku Station did not know how to direct me properly, although they did give me a great map of the area, (so I advise stopping in to get that on your way to find the hotel). I would recommend that the hotel put a "walking" street map on their website, you cannot just follow the written directions once you get to Shinjuku. Fortunately people in Japan are friendly and want to help. It took asking three locals, but finally a nice young lady actually walked me to the hotel (it still took two wrong turns!) I advise you to not hold this against the hotel because it is actually the norm! Instead, know that getting lost can happen and be prepared. Or be willing on the first time to have a cab take you.Finally, I took the Narita Bus Shuttle form Shinjuku station to the airport - once again, the hotel staff helped book this for me, and I did the final treat of having them get me a cab from the hotel to the bus station at Shinjuku station (which was $13.50 USD) - It was raining, I had all those gifts plus some more I bought in Tokyo and I still had some yen to spend…. so why not. The bus took 1 hour and was a smooth and comfortable ride.I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Getting a room in Tokyo during Hanami is a mess, since everything is fully booked. And here "everything is fully booked" is not a figure of speech, we tried every online portal we could think of and spent together approximately 48 hours searching for ANY room which wasn't either 500 USD a night or an Unisex-Capsule. This said, book well in advance when you intend to visit Tokyo during cherry-blossom season, booking only three weeks in advance will definitely cause a headache.Anyway, since we didn't had much of a choice, we ended up in Shinjuku Granbell, even though our visit in Japan was part of an ongoing backpacker journey in Asia and this place exceeded our budget by far. But it retrospect in was worth every penny, we extremely enjoyed staying here. The room we had was rather small, but had every comfort needed. Especially the bathroom with its completely automatic toilet was totally awesome, giving you a fair impression of Japan's technological side. The view from our room was really good, even better sights can be enjoyed on the terrace on top of the building. The best part of staying at Granbell is probably it's location, as well as the service personnel, which was warm and helpful and helped us out with subway maps and detailed information about how to get to any place.Not cheap, but definitely a really good place to stay at!

Great and clean hotel. With a nice rooftop bar. Drinks have an ok price, but think you can get them cheaper elsewhere. We are two women in their 30s travelling and even though close to the red light district it isn't bad at all. Would recommend it to friends.

We stayed in this hotel in two different occasions on the same trip. Once in a simple room, then three nights in the 'deluxe' type. Clean, efficient, beautiful rooms, and pretty decent (if limited) western food at the lounge. The rooftop lounge is top notch. Great Mojitos (depending on who is at the bar) and everything feels stylish about the place. In the middle of the dodgy area of Shinjuku, surrounded by love hotels and massage parlours, it gives the place a lot of character. I might have a bit of a gripe with the reception area, not the willingness to help (they are very friendly) but do have a limited number of maps of the area with little English or other language labels. Reading the different Japanese characters can be a chore. Highly recommended.

Stayed here for three nights in July 14.Thought the hotel was modern, clean and bright. The front desk were really helpful with Taxi ordering and the like and the hotel is positioned for a 10 min walk to the station and a 5 min walk to the little bars of Golden Gai.The area is surrounded by "Love hotels" but feels very safe - like most of Japan.The room was small by UK standards but not tiny by any means.The gem of this hotel though is the amazing roof top bar, well worth a visit even if you 're not staying there. Great views and it's nice to be outside after time spent in smokey little Golden Gai bars.

I took a bus to the Shinjuku terminal east like their directions said online. I started to walk in the direction they said but couldn't find the place. It wasn't until 3 taxi drivers later that I was able to find it. After all of that, the place was actually really nice. In the lobby they have a cafe that I hung out in until it was time to check in. I had a sand which and a beer. Check in was easy. The room was very trendy and Japanese. Compact, yet very functional and visual pleasing. It rained a lot when I was here so I did spend a lot of time in the hotel. The restaurant on the top floor was good. It served western food though which was a bit of a let down. I had pizza. The hotel is a block away from a subway stop which was very convenient. So all of Tokyo is within reach. It's walking distance to a number of restaurants. I also was able to walk to The Robot Restaurant for a fun evening. I usually like walking around cities, but Tokyo is so huge and the streets so confusing that the subway system is the way to go here. Since the hotel is so close to the subway I highly recommend it. The staff was helpful and he aesthetics are quite nice.
user_name:
michaelahenry
New York City, New York

review_body: Great service and comfortable rooms. Got a room w a loft n it took me bak to my childhood days :) price is reasonable. Maid service is really great. Breakfast is also much appreciated before exploring tokyo. Also the hotel is situated about 5 min walk from shinjuku station which is one of the major stations in japan. Very convenient.

Touched down nearing mid night and check in was fast even though there was quite a que. The japanese lady whom spoke basic english still managed to give us valuable info on how to get to Disneyland and also to Tsujiki fish market. Room we got was on the 18th floor and the view is still spectacular. Maybe perhaps it was my first time in Shinjuku, but the clear dark blue skies and neon glowing lights really made a nice photo from the room. The bar in house was a lil bit disappointing in choices of drinks, but the local beer was a good try and very refreshing. What is worth heading to the bar is again the view of Shinjuku city and its nice cool breeze outside. Good to have a nice lil chat with your partner or just to unwind and play Clash of Clans, which I seem to notice tables around us were doing. haha. The italian french restaurant on the other hand wasn't bad and it wasn't that good either. The set of pizza, steak, ceaser salad and spaghetti was priced reasonably and feeds two people without a problem. On the side note, i'd still prefer to recommend people to try the local restaurants around the corner [about 5-10mins walking distance] as they are tasty and much much cheaper. Oh, again, Tsujiki Market is definitely worth going for the fresh sushi/sashimi/etc and it is really out of this world. All restaurant closes by 230pm and expect to que in line for about 15mins waiting time.Long story short, is this hotel worth staying? Rooms are great with a modern flair, cold air con, HD channels on a huge flat screen tv, hot powerfull showers and free wireless on cable internet. Yes it was worth the 14 nights stay with special promo from Agoda.

Stayed in 2 different hotels in 2 different areas in Tokyo at the start and end of our trip. Conrad was amazing but very expensive, the Granbell was also very good and value for money. 3 of us shared a loft room. It was well decorated and clean but quite small (difficult to fit luggage in). 16 year old thought the bed platform was great. We enjoyed the rooftop bar, good views. Staff were all pleasant. Great range of vending machines! Location was fine it was easy to get around. Interesting 'red light' area nearby but don't let that put you off, worth seeing.

I went to stay at the Granbell with really low expectations- 4 star hotel at really competitive rates- too good to be true I thought. I had originally booked to stay a total of 3 nights in an economy double and ended up extending my stay to five nights.Location- It’s in the northern park of Shinjuku. There are many Japanese love hotels in the surrounding streets and its nearest main road is the hub of the red light district. Please don’t let that turn you off this hotel. I’m a female traveller in her 20s who was travelling alone, so safety is my first priority. The red light district is timid. I walked down the main street late at night (some nights well past midnight) in a pair of short-shorts, and I did NOT ONCE feel threatened or unsafe. The hotel is in a quiet side street so noise isn’t a problem. There is a metro train station (Higishi Shinjuku) located on the same block- an easy 3 min walk. The room- an economy double- was perfectly adequate for a solo traveller. A basic but modern room. A large comfy double bed with a desk. It’s not a huge space but fit a large suitcase with room to spare. A small safe - big enough for an 18inch mac if in sideways, great aircon and reliable FREE wifi. The bathroom was sleek and spotless. Big bath with shower overhead, and modern toilet with a terrifying amount of buttons. The only criticism I have was that the windows don’t open, so there was no fresh air. The room was designated as non-smoking, but the smell of cigarettes still permeated the room. It was unnoticeable with the aircon on. There is only a glass window dividing the bathroom and the bedroom so there would be no privacy if there were a couple staying in the room. Also the walls are very thin meaning that noisy neighbors and cleaning staff can be heard easy. Facilities- an entire room of vending machines, a great coin laundry (Y200 for a load), bicycles to rent (Y2000 a day) and a laptop with printer in the foyer. Also the FOH sell stamps- which is useful to know as I spent hours looking for a post office. Staff- very helpful. Most spoke English very well.Food- I ate breakfast once and was pretty disappointed. I ended up having a Japanese breakfast, as the western style menu was pretty lackluster. The eggs were soupy, the bacon too sweet, only tiny rolls, no fruit. The Japanese breakfast was fine. I also had a coffee every morning in the reception area (y450). The coffee was hit and miss, sometimes excellent and other times undrinkable. The rooftop bar is not to be missed. It was a beautiful view over Shinjuku, which is especially stunning at night. I had a cocktail there; it wasn’t great, stick to beer. The hotel does have some teething problems but these issues are all minor details. I would happily stay there again and plan to do so later this month. For the price it’s an excellent place to stay.

Booked a standard modern double room for 4 nights.On arrival I knew things weren't great. Old worn couches and a worn out reception area.Booked in without trouble and staff overall have been very helpful, polite and trying hard to please. Very dark lifts and hallways and this might have been chic 15 years ago but now it's just dingy.Entered the room and went to the bathroom. Grabbed a towel and the towel rail fell off. Ok, no worries, advised them when I went downstairs and it was fixed on return with a handwritten apology.Stepped into the shower. Water good, hot and strong. Choice of two shower heads. But pet hate of mine are those clingy shower curtains and stepping over high bathtubs, and slippery when wet floors. To make it worse the water drained very slowly so by the end of the shower you are standing in it up to your ankles.The room was small but adequate and it was clean. Bed was good and on the 7th floor it was quiet. Airconditioning worked very well. Has a fridge but no minibar which is good and bad. Breakfast was abysmal. Tried it first morning and found it mostly inedible and didn't bother after that. Did look in to the first floor breakfast but kept going.Wifi was intermittent but they fixed it with one phone call and gave us an in room router that worked well.Great location, good value I guess by Tokyo standards and staff that try extremely hard. Our room was clean and the bed good.Bad though was a very average bathroom, dark, old, dingy and well worn public areas.If I return to Tokyo I will be looking elsewhere but in a pinch would probably return.

We spent our first holiday week in Tokyo and stayed at Granbell. The place was very nice and met our scandinavian expectations. Our superior level rooms were of good size (on japanese scale), well cleaned and very quiet. Hotel service was great, but they spoke however very little English. With no common language we still managed to get everything we hoped for.There's an awesome rooftop bar that we highly recommend. And also the beakfast was good. They serve mostly asian (miso, rice, salads...) with some western additions (croissant, eggs, bacon, yoghurt...). Fresh fruit cannot be found, but this goes in our experience for the whole Japan.The location of the hotel is somewhat strange, in between the "red light streets" of Shinjuku. Tokio is however so extremely safe that this should not intimidate anyone. It is after all in a good walking distance from Shinjuku shops and a metro station.

We selected the Grandbell Hotel because of the location and reasonable price. We expected a small room, but we were o.k. with that because we were there for only two nights. We found the staff to be very friendly (they even let us borrow umbrellas). The location is very close to a subway station. The best part of the stay was how quiet the room was (our room was on the 5th floor). No noise from neighbors, or from outside busy Tokyo. The room was very clean, bathroom had nice amenities, and the free bottled water and coffee was appreciated. As noted by other's reviews, the neighborhood is "colorful" and has many Korean restaurants to pick from, but we never felt unsafe even when arriving back late from a baseball game. A good pick.

New hotel with good-sized rooms with a view and nice decor. Very clean, comfortable bedding, best showers, friendly/helpful staff who speak English, very close to subway and a short walk (10 mins) to Shinjuku shopping district.This hotel is on the edge of the red-light district Kabukicho but walking en route through at night and early hours of morning as a caucasian female I felt safe and experienced no problems from the throngs of males lining the streets. Only complaint - minor - the western hot food offered at the hotel breakfast was stone cold and left exposed all morning. The selection of traditional breakfast however was extensive and looked fresh and tasty. Great rooftop bar and lots of goodies in vending machines. Easy check-in/out. Maps in foyer. Definitely a great stay for those wanting easy access to action, shopping, boutique bars - and then a clean, quiet place to rest.

We stayed here from 4th - 9th July. Check in was very efficient and the person we spoke was easy to communicate with in English. We stayed in a 'superior Hollywood twin' room. The room is compact, and I feel that the room can probably do without the 'egg chair' so there was more room for luggage. The beds were very comfortable and bathroom very nice (with a very substantial control for the toilet!)The first night we were there we watched a paid movie, but found the sound too soft. A quick call downstairs and we had two people come up to sort the problem out. Overall, we found the service excellent.I probably wouldn't recommend the restaurant. The carpaccio was just sashimi (not thinly sliced), and the pizza was ok, but nothing special. Still, the prices were quiet reasonable.Yes, some previous reviews have stated, it's a bit of a walk from the JR line, 10-15 min, but close to the Higashi-shinjuku station. The hotel is located close to plenty of restaurants and a 7-11 is very close by.My verdict? Definitely consider this hotel to stay in! I would stay here again.

Overall had a really good stay at the Granbell Shinjuku So first day i recommend getting a taxi from shinjuku station it only cost us 770yen which is no more than $10 (AUD). We looked for about an hour and couldn't find the hotel even with help of locals. But after finding it for the first time its easy to find again!
