Only 10mins from Shinjuku station and all the main areas. Many comments on here about walking through red light district but its fine! If anything a bit of fun! Also theres ways to avoid it by walking alternate streets! Staff at hotel all very nice, speak english pretty well. Its got everything you need! Rooms are a good size considering its Japan, bathroom also a good size! NIce clean and modern hotel. Would recommend for any type of stay whether it be holiday or business.WIll stay again!

Everything was great thus my high overall mark.Let me list minor disadvantages:- compact- bit far from the station (please note, that Shinjuku is located very strategically)- difficult to find however good maps are provided- close to red light district, but very very safe and unnoticeable

I stayed just 48 hours in Japan,so two nights at this hotel.As everywhere in Japan, the staff was most friendly. The room was manifestly spotless and also really comfortable. I did sleep really well without any kind of noise.Wifi was working well and the style of the hotel was a nice change compared to my previous trips to Japan (I stayed in real business hotels).Anyway, advice for the visitors:I highly suggest a very careful planning about how to get to the hotel if you use something else than the taxi (with streeview check and precise itinerary "study).It's actually less than 15 minutes on foot from Shinjuku station once you know the way... But before and with bags, it can be a real challenge to locate it! in particular if you take the wrong exit of the Shinjuku station!! Do NOT exit somewhere else than the central east exit.The Shinjuku Narita Express platform is far from this exit but you must avoid exiting via the south exit which is indicated on this platform.

Hotel is about 15 to 20 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, if you arrived from Narita Express. Check-in time is strictly at 3pm, but I could leave my bags there while I travelled around the area. Convenience stores and restaurants are everywhere around the area, and although it is located just one street away from the red district, it still feels pretty safe. The service was pretty good, and they helped me with finding locations of various places. Was really thankful that they spoke English! The room was for 1 person, but it was very very comfortable. A little small if you have too much luggage, but overall very good quality sleep. Rooftop bar was really pretty, and looked very affordable. Worth a stay if you are willing to spend about USD$100 per night.

Our room was amazing and we found the service to be very good. Others have mentioned lack of English with staff, but we didn't experience any difficulties being understood and receiving assistance. We booked a night out through the front desk and sought directions on a few occasions with no trouble. The rooftop bar was a great place to relax after a busy day, with terrific views and a nice selection of cocktails. Although we wouldn't recommend the restaurant for dinner (but I do love Italian food and can be a bit fussy with it - this was too oily and too sweet), there was a great selection of traditional and western breakfast choices. The bed was super comfortable and having a bath with one of many selections of bath salts while looking out on the city skyline incredible. Others have also mentioned having trouble locating the hotel - it's about a 2 minute walk from Higashi-Shinjuku station with one turn, a bit trickier from Shinjuku but only because the station itself is enormous and confusing. Once you get your bearings there, the hotel is easily located. We really enjoyed our stay here and would come back again in a heartbeat.

Good location in Kabukicho... At 10 minutes by walk from Shinjuku Station.We were stayed one night, and booked a room at 16th floor, with a beautiful view.Rooms are spacious, and clean.Wifi everywhere in the hotel (rooms, lobby...).Washing machine.There is a roof bar and lounge bar very nice to have a good time.

First off, I want to start by saying the location is bad, which is why this "4 star" hotel is so cheap. It's a 20-30 minute walk from shinjuku station and there is nothing in its near vicinity.Second, the real reason to avoid this hotel is they have zero value for customer service. I requested an early checkin since I had an overnight flight and just wanted to sleep, but when I arrived they tried to charge me approx $100 for checking in at 12pm and not 3pm!!! Absolutely ridiculous a full nights pay for 3 hours! After an argument they decided to offer me early check in at 1pm so I would have to wait one hour and pay $40. At that point I just said cancel the reservation and went to the nearby best western which is in a better location for the same price and they let me check in right away.Avoid this hotel, this type of service is unacceptable for a "4 star" hotel. They even tried convincing me other hotels won't let me check in at 12 if I left. I understand if rooms are occupied and must be cleaned but simply trying to bargain with me for extra cash to get into an already empty room is ludicrous for a hotel that is rated 4 stars, now I know why it's only $100 a night.
user_name:
Ash K
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here for 4 nights at the tail-end of a tour we participated in. It is a nice new hotel, but it is near the fringe of the red light district so if you are travelling with kids, may be best to avoid walking to or from the hotel, catch a taxi instead. We booked two rooms for our family of four, and despite being asked to have the rooms allocated together, this was not done so we had to sort it out at check-in time and we had to upgrade one of the rooms but they offered it to us at a discounted price. I was not able to get a response by email before our trip to confirm the room allocation, despite numerous attempts - their command of English is still quite poor but they were willing to help and accommodate our needs after our arrival. The hotel amenity kits were really good, but luggage space is lacking - and we booked into the Deluxe Suites which had their own Club Lounge and check-in/out facilities. The Club Lounge is lacking somewhat in food and drink variety and ambience. It is quite small but is better than sitting in the foyer. The location is a bit of a walk (at least a 15 minute brisk walk) from the main JR station, (closer to other non JR stations) and you will pass the red light areas, it's tucked in the back streets and we were pre-warned that taxis may find it hard to locate, so be prepared with the Japanese address when you hop into a taxi so they know where to take you. All in all, a really nice, new and modern hotel, location is ok but not the best and price was quite reasonable when we booked it (prior to opening).

Good location, new hotel with small but functional rooms with nothing really to miss. Nicely decorated and amicable staff. Rooftop bar lacks a bit of ambiance, as it is a bit small. Nevertheless nothing to complain really, all great.

My experience at the Granbell was excellent. It's tucked back just past the main red light area in Shinjuku to the North East of Shinjuku station near the Hotel Orion. It's a newer hotel, looks like it was built in the last 5 years. The room was clean and comfortable, but small as is typical for Tokyo. I stayed in a Standard Double room with a friend. The hotel has a bar terrace up on the 14th floor with great views of Shinjuku. The hotel restaurant had a good breakfast. The staff were great and I was glad they spoke English as my Japanese is terrible. I would stay again.

In summary: Service here leaves a lot to be desired, the room is small but adequate, breakfast is poor, location is not great but workable. You can get better located hotels for a lower cost elsewhere in Shinjuku.Expanded:We stayed in a total of 5 hotels in Japan (2 in Shinjuku - the other being the Century Southern Tower), and anyone who says this hotel is well located is quite wrong - it's about 20mins walk from Shinjuku station which if you have any intention of travelling around Tokyo, you want to be near.The actual facilities in the hotel are reasonable - the room was the smallest we received in Japan (which was surprising since it was the most expensive hotel we stayed in), but had all the mod cons. The air-con unit decided to switch itself off after 3 hours which was annoying in the warm nights, and with the room being so small it got very stuffy leading to a poor nights sleep on all of the four nights we were there.The biggest problem however was the service. Unlike most hotels - payment was requested up front rather than at checkout, which I believe gave them no reason to provide good service. We paid for the breakfast (which was sub-par compared to other breakfasts we had in Japan), but on the last morning had to check out at 6.45 to make our flight. Breakfast started at 7am. We asked if we could have an early breakfast and they said a flat no. This is fair enough - albeit I have always had some effort made to accommodate this request in the past. However, we decided to head up and see if there were at least some croissants laid out (which they had every morning) which we could grab before we left. As suspected, there were. But we were not allowed to take them (even though we had already paid). I planned to complain about this on checkout - but we didn't even receive the standard "was everything okay with your stay question".

The hotel can be a little tricky to find but keep in mind but you should be able to find it easily by using the maps in the subway station. It is a taller building which makes it easier to spot as well.The service here was fantastic.From the front desk, to the bartenders, everyone was very polite.The rooftop bar was a great place to wind down and have a drink.The room was clean, modern, and quiet. The location can't be beat and the price was very reasonable. I would highly recommend for staying in Shinjuku.Do not worry about the hotel being in the red light district. If you were not told it was in the district, you would not have a clue!

This hotel is perfectly located in Shinjuku. It is in the red-light district, but don't let that put you off. It's really close to lots of restaurants, bars, shops and transport. And the hotel itself is quite nice. The reception staff were helpful, but you will be charged to check in early or check out late and it can work out to be quite pricey. But if you don't mind waiting (and aren't desperate for sleep like we were) they are happy to hold your bags for you while you go sightseeing. The rooms are quite small (as I hear most in Tokyo are) but very well designed, so it didn't feel cramped. And the beds are really comfortable. Would definitely stay here again.

We arrived in Haneda in the wee hours of the morning 5-6am, fear of getting stuck in traffic jams we decided not to take the limousine bus, proceeded with the train. It took about 1hr 15mins before we finally reached the hotel, and that was with 3 changes of trains - lugging our baggage up and down flights of stairs at the stations. When we finally reached the hotel at about 9am, they told us that we could only check in at 3pm. Exhausted, we left our luggage with them and sat down on their comfy chairs in the lobby. The lobby is welcoming and had plenty of seats, you can tell that the hotel is very new. We were spent from the overnight flight and the tiring train transfer, and promptly dozed off on the seats. Nobody came to chase us for that one hour, and that was when I decided to try my luck for an early check-in. The staff was quick to tell me the rates for an early check-in at 12pm and I declined. SGD250/night for a double deluxe room and no early check-in? Ah well.Anyway, after that power nap we decided to explore the area around us on foot. Seemed like a pretty quiet neighbourhood and it was a comfortable walk to Isetan and Takashimaya Times Square - weather was lovely! Do take note however that the nearest exit from Higashi-Shinjuku has only escalators going up (stairs for going down), so if you wanna take the train to the airport, it's best if you walk further to the main exit with the elevator.Finally managed to check in at 430pm, and the room was small, which we expected! Even though we took the bigger 23sqm room, only one of us could have our luggage open all the time, my friend had to close hers whenever we wanted to walk around the room. It had a sofa where you could also place your belongings, and the TV was never switched on - they only had Japanese channels. The toilet was very white and clean, toiletries were provided and they were rather good quality too, and it had a bathtub and a separate standing shower area.The bed was pure comfort, pillows were plush and the blackout shades were such a delight! Every night was a deep and undisturbed sleep and we dragged ourselves out of bed every morning around 11am. The hotel also provides 2 sets of Japanese robes, very cute. The room was something we looked forward to coming back to every night, and it's really commendable how well the staff spoke English and assisted us whenever we had queries.At night, the surrounding area comes alive. Kabukicho is the nightlife hub of Tokyo but walking around as 2 girls, we never once got bothered by anyone. It is safe, and it is very near the Golden Gai (bars and very yummy Nagi Ramen open 24h)Going back, our flight was at night and we decided to take the airport limousine this time after struggling with our arrival leg via the train, what more with all the shopping we had already done in 6 days. However, we were unable to lug all our stuff to the train entrance with the elevator - too far and too much stuff, we decided to take our first cab ride to Shinjuku Main Station. Flag down rate is 730yen, but the metre doesn't jump for the first 2km, so it was a good call. Also, we got the reception to write down the directions/address for us to show the cab driver, easy peasy. The bus ride itself to Haneda airport took at mere 25mins (departed at 715pm).All in all, the hotel is marvelous, just wish that the location was a bit better.

Overall the hardware is good (room/ building/ location) however the software needs a bit of fine tuning (staff/ service/ price).PROS: Easy to find if you have a map handy and the location allows for you to visit a few places quite easily. The room is clean and the fixtures are stylish.CONS: Ladies at the front desk cannot work out the difference between night and day. You will struggle to book in despite this being the only request they get during their day. You can say there is no chicken in the katsu here.

Grandbell is, by far, the best hotel i know in Tokyo. The rooms are big, the bathrooms are western inspired and the beds are confortable. The location is also great if you plan to visit the robot restaurant. The only downside is the expensive prices.

Lovely hotel and superb service. Small rooms but to be expected in Tokyo. Very nicely appointed modern rooms, with plenty of amenities. There are a few comments about the hotel being in the red light district. I must say that you couldn't tell if it is and we felt safer than anywhere else we have ever stayed before. Cool place to stay and good value for money. Thank you.

Booked a deluxe room with a queen bed. Rooms are surprising small but very clean and modern with good interior design. The bed is amazingly comfortable. The bathroom is small but well-planned, with complete toiletries and equip with high-tech bidet systems and I just love it. The buffet breakfast is superb. Down side, no english channel on TV, all japanese channels and Taxi's find it a bit hard to locate hotel..

My wife and I stayed here on our visit to Tokyo and loved the hotel. The staff was very friendly and had all sorts of information for you if you needed it. It is close to Shinjuku station, shops and restaurants. a very good central location. When we first arrived in Shinjuku we could not figure out where to go but luckly an ederly man who spoke a little english walked us to the hotel. After that it was a piece of cake to get to and from the hotel. I read a few reviews about having to wak through "red light district" and did not think much of it. No one bothered us and like one reviewer wrote, it was more like PG rating than anything. The sky bar was very cool but we did not get to go on the balcony becaise it was raining. Still enjoyed a few drinks though. The hotel held our bags for us at checkout so we could venture off for a few hours on our last day. I would recommend this hotel and would definitely stay here again.

This place isnt too hard to find...its not on google maps but all you gotta do is goto their website and click on the access button and theres a link to the coordinates. Copy those into google maps app while your on a wifi. Then goto shinjuku station walk towards the east exit and go where it says "To kabukicho." walk out there and when you surface pull out your phone and open google maps which should still have the area and location cached. The GPS will find you (regardless if your on a network or not) then just walk towards the locationI had a deluxe room which was really nice. I loved the artwork around the hotel, i was wishing i had booked a more expensive room as mine was wonderful as it is. The only problem was that the TV turned on as soon as I entered the room and put the key in the holster...i didnt goto Tokyo to watch TV thats for sure!The Skybar was amazing. It was raining when i went there so I didnt sit outside which would have been cool. The restaruant was really good also, nice view! The breakfast..well..it was adequate, not anything to write home about but does the jobIt is basically in the so called 'red light' district of Tokyo but as far as red light districts go i think Tokyos is probably PG rated lol!

near shinjuku station. plenty of shops and restaurants in the area. staff are welcoming and accomodating even though it was very busy when we were there. loft room can be slightly cramped for 3 people, but pictures and descriptions were accurate. bar is ok and has great views over Tokyo. breakfast - i'm sure you can find better value elsewhere.

Booked Granbell shinjuku from Booking.com, and I'm reslly happy with my stay:- perfect location in Shinkiju Kabukicho, close to action, metros, not far from shibuya, and well connected to other parts of the city- hotel comfort is very good, higher value from miney than any western hotel- nice view from room- toom is small but neat, perfec set up, super clean and new, ton of accessories to play with :-)- nice view from rooftop, and ok breakfast for price

The best thing about this hotel is their breakfast, which has a variety of Western and Japanese foods such as miso soup, salads, chicken nuggets, curry rice, omelette, sausages, fish cakes and ratatouille, etc. The bed was very comfortable. There is very limited space to store luggages. The room is equipped with a safe, hair brush, tooth paste, tooth brushes, single use body towels, razors, hair tie and Q tips, etc. The bathtub is smaller than average. I am 165cm and I could not extend my legs while in the bathtub. Approx 7-8 min walk to Shinjuku station. We followed the direction according to the hotel website ( 4 min walk from exit A 1 at Higashi Shinjuku station) but we got lost for an hour and realized that there are several left and right turns in order to get there. Please make sure you have a map of the hotel location prior to arrival. Also, the wifi was extremely slow. If you need wifi, go to the lobby.

We stayed here 3 nights to explore Tokyo. Good location, about 10-15min walk from Shinjuku station, so in the centre of a lot of restaurants and activities. Hotel was new, comfortable and had a funky interior design. As with most Tokyo rooms, it was small- but well equipped. We were on 11th floor and had an excellent view. Rooftop had a nice open air bar but unfortunately we couldn't make use of it because it was raining. We had breakfast there also and it was great value and tasty (buffet, all you can eat). Hotel had a coin laundry which was helpful. Staff were friendly but not all spoke good English. Was a bit more on the pricey side but would stay here again.

Pros: clean rooms, friendly staff, nice breakfast spread, close to Golden Gai and kabuki-cho area of town, good design and bath products, quiet roomCons: rooms are very small, surrounding area is somewhat sketchy (never felt dangerous, just a bit seedy), 10-15 minute walk to Shinjuku station, bed had an extremely firm mattress, room was very smallUltimately, I was happy with the hotel, especially as it was a good value for Tokyo (paid approx. $180 per night). If I were to return to Tokyo, I'd try to stay somewhere a little closer to a JR-linked train station. We used our JR pass in Tokyo, and this hotel was a bit of a walk from Shinjuku station. Also, this side of Shinjuku has more bars and restaurants, but it also has some sketchy stip clubs and "love hotels" whereas the other side of Shinjuku has less personality and more office buildings.

Stayed 4 nights in April. Lovely breakfast with the best scrambled eggs ever. Very convenient for Shinjuku with all the clubs, bars and restaurants just a few minutes walk. If you're planning a late night out, it's the perfect location to be as you can walk everywhere what with public transport ending at midnight. Room was comfy, stylish albeit a little on the small side but as this is the standard in Japan, it didn't bother us at all.

Four of us stayed here for 3 nights on our first trip to Tokyo. From researching Tokyo hotels everything was really expensive and most places looked really run down but still cost $120-$150 a night. I was really pleased with the Granbell Hotel in Shinjuku. For $130 a night we had a really nice room that looked a lot like the images on the hotel website and we were in a location that allowed us to walk to a lot of the sight like Shibuya Gyoen National Park and Meiji Jingu. We also walked to Harijuku and the Imperial Palace, though that might be far for some people (an hour or two walking). Shinjuku was a great location too if you want to go out at night, it is a really bustling area with several 24 hour restaurants.One downside is that the hotel is quite close to Tokyo's red light district. There are several hotels by the hour (Love Hotels), prostitutes (although they aren't as obvious as in some cities) and bars apparently frequented by the Japanese mafia. We managed to get ourselves quite lost in this area at night when we were looking for the Granbell. A very kind local actually stopped and offered to walk us to our hotel and warned us that we had gone into a bad area. Although you could tell that there was something a bit seedy about the area we never really felt unsafe. I would stay at the Granbell again despite its proximity to the red light district. One tip would be to get really good directions on how to get to the hotel for when you arrive as it can be quite hard to find as it is down a bit of a side street.

Located about 12 min from Shinjuku Station, surrounded by so called love hotels. Friendly staff. Room is very small but stylish, clean and has a great view. Even if you don't go out in the area of Shinjiku it's absolutely worth to stay there to get one feeling of this great city.

Staff were nice but maybe a little inexperience. Near shinjuku station. Close to many restaurants. Free stuff for guests are always well stocked. Will definitely stay here again next time were in Japan.

I stayed in this hotel for one night in april in a single room. The staff were friendly on arrival. The room was clean and well stocked with razors, toothbrushes etc. I enjoyed my stay here and stayed a further twice during my travels in Japan in a loft style apartment room for three people.

Excellent value at this new hotel! Rooms were nicely finished and very clean. Decor felt like a high end hotel but the price was not. Bed was very comfortable (or maybe it just seemed that way after 20 hours of traveling...) Staff was nice but maybe still a little inexperienced. ~10 min walk to Shinjuku Station. The quickest direction to walk is through the "red light" district but this is not like the red light districts in the US - signs are G rated and relatively discrete. Male employees will try to recruit young males into their establishments but did not bother my husband and I walking together. Clean and safe.Breakfast was okay - probably worth it if you purchase it as part of your booking (I think we paid ~$5 extra per person per day) but not worth the $12 sticker price.

Hotel exceeded my expectations as per reading of Tokyo hotels you get what you pay for. However the Shinjuku Granbell was a great find in terms of location, price and amenities. Hotel was easy to find thanks to contributor AntheaB972 - the landmark directions were easy to follow after 20 hours of travelling. Once you get your bearings it's very easy to get to Shinjuku station (<10 min) or the Higashi-Shinjuku subway station (< 2 min). Forget anything you read about it being a "red light" neighborhood - whatever may happen stays behind closed doors and not in the street. Felt extremely safe at all times.The hotel itself is modern and clean. I stayed in a standard twin desk room. Beds were comfortable and bathroom amenities were nice. Room was tiny but not unbearably so for two people. However, if you are extra large people with extra large luggage you will not be happy in the standard room.I had a great Italian meal the first night at the hotel as well as a good snack at the bar another night (the two bartenders we encountered were great). Avoid breakfast - from a Westerner perspective it was awful and not worth $12. Thoroughly enjoyed getting snacks from the vending machines however it empties quickly.Only complaint would be if you needed to talk to the front desk for any reason it may prove difficult as at all times there seemed to be large groups checking in/out.

Rooms are new and come with a nice bathroom but small of course, as you expect when you travel here. Housekeeping standards were fine. The reception staff were courteous and very helpful about general directions, restaurants to visit, for calling taxis etc. Breakfast was reasonable. Gets very busy after 08.30hrs and you have to wait sometimes. Selection is average; think they could put a little more effort into this part of the operation and have a manager around to control service, table clearing etc. It's a little hard to find the hotel to begin with but its only 10 minutes to Shinjuku area and there's an MRT station just around the corner.

I think I had the smallest room in the hotel but the layout still made it OK. I can't really recommend it for 2 people. The bed/pillows were very comfortable and everything was brand new. The toilet amities’ was nice and I didn’t miss anything. Breakfast was served with a nice view of Tokyo. They had a good western selection. There is a subway station 3 minutes walk from the hotel and from Shinjuku station there is a 15 min walk. I took a taxi when I arrived and that was less than €10. Compared to what you pay for some accomodation in Tokyo this is a really good choice.

Location is relatively convenient. About 10-15 mins walk to Shinjuku Station and 5 mins walk to Higashi-Shinjuku Station. There are also several convenience stores around the hotel and it is absolutely safe walking past kabukicho at night. The hotel is new and with well designed furnishes, the bed and sofa are also very comfortable. It would be good if the hotel could provide a humidifier for Tokyo's dry weather in Spring (humidifier/ air purifier were provided in my hotels in other japan cities).

For those who don't know, kabuki is somewhat the red light district in Tokyo. They are known as the "entertainment district", but take a walk at night and you will realise the street reek of alcohol and smoke, with many standing outside host and hostess clubs touting for your business. It took me a long long time to find this hotel. I missed it soooo many times at first but I learnt my way fast. If you are coming from the JR Sapporo, take the kabuki cho exit and head straight out towards the main road. Turn right and walk until you see mister donut ( you can't miss this) and head all the way down. Once you see a baseball court, get ready to turn right and you will see the hotel snuck away off the streets. I checked into the club room on the fifteenth floor, which was bigger than the standard rooms. I knew Tokyo rooms were small, but this room was smaller than my expectation. The toilet had a bathtub but was cramped anyway. Though the room had a cozy feel, we barely had any walking space once we unpacked two luggages. However, the hotel did think of the guests staying in there. There were bath salts, combs, even hair tonic and a shisedo travel samples for females. The hotel was generally OK, but I would urge females to consider other granbell locations. Am returning to this hotel soon after my stay in hokkaido, hopeful that I can comment on another room this time.

Loved this hotel, quite new and stylishly done up. I had a small room which I loved- comfy bed, all the lobe,y complimentary goodies incl pj's, slippers etc. Very quiet. Great location 3 mins from the Higashi- Shinjuku metro and a 711 just opposite the station entrance. Very NB to take the A1 exit when getting off the train or else you'll get hopelessly lost if arriving the first time. The food offering in the restaurant was very average although the service Elic was my waiters name I think) was very good; also a poor food selection in the lobby bar/coffee shop, especially after 5pm. I think the reception staff could be warmer. Felt very unspecial checking in and whenever I had to ask about anything.
user_name:
AllisonF328
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Good: slightly more spacious than rest of the business hotels in tokyoSofa and desk provided which is really convenient New and clean roomFull glass toilet, u can watch tv while using and don't feel enclosedNearer to Higashi-Shinjuku station hence less crowded train to JR shinjukuDrinks and snacks vending machines in lobbyBad: If walking to/from JR shinjuku, need at least 15mins and have to pass through the red light district but this can be quite interesting if you are not alone as a lady. Quieter part of Shinjuku hence not much city scenery room view

We stayed Granbell Hotel Shinjuku from 20th March to 27th March, 2014.The hotel located in bad area, not good for family. Somewhat away from Shinjuku main area.Though we stayed at a suite room (17th floor), they don't even provide iron in the room. No foreign currency change. In the moring time, they don't pick up the phone. Most people tried to help, but couple of them were extremely extremely rude. They treated us like homeless people.I will never stay this hotel again. No wonder why people prefer 4-star or 5-star hotels.

After reading all reviews this hotel was as I expected. The room is well designed and just right for 1 person. I booked through Agoda.com and got the moderate single (ura) with the long seat against the window. This was where I placed my luggage otherwise I would have no space to walk in the room. I loved the hotel but felt that it was a bit of a walk from Shinjuku JR station. Walking past the clubs at night was an interesting experience and you just have to ignore the men standing outside the clubs. I was approached on two occasions as I walked by but I just ignored them. O er all I enjoyed my stay! As a female guest I was provided with some skincare samples at check in and I used them throughout my stay. Not all staff at reception spoke english but they were always willing to help. I had reception help me make a booking at a hair salon.

We stayed here a little apprehensive and not knowing what to expect due to some really varied reviews. However, we were pleasantly surprised with this new, modern, clean and well equipped hotel! Rooms were slightly on the small side, however we weren't spending a lot of time in the hotel room so not a problem. Toiletries provided of excellent quality. Bed was super comfy, nice feathered pillows and duvets. Bed was slightly on the small side, so if you would prefer more sleeping space for 2 maybe booking a twin room would be a better idea. Location wise, a 15 minute walk to shinjuku station and walking through the red light district was never a problem. Breakfast was of good quality with a large selection. Would highly recommend this hotel and if we return would definitely stay here again perhaps with an upgraded room type next time though!

The property was very new as it had opened for just a little over 2 months. It is situated about 10 minutes from the East Gate of Shinjuku JR Station in the middle of the cluster of love hotels. A Toyoko Inn is right across the street. If you don't mind walking through the red-light district, this is a good choice. Rooms are on the small side, but they've got everything you need. Would consider this place again on my next visit.

We stayed here for 2 nights for our short trip to Tokyo. My friends picked this hotel in the heart of Shinjuku cause of the location and the price. The hotel rooms were very tastefully decorated as the hotel is relatively new but were showing some signs of wear and tear cause of usage. All in all the rooms were decent just a little on the small size which is the norm for Japan so no complaints there. Storage in the rooms for medium or large suitcases might be a bit of a hassle but doable. The staff were very helpful and spoke good enough English. The hotel is smoke free so don't go there expecting a smoking room for all you smokers out there. My only concern during my stay there was that nobody from the hotel tried to clean the snow on the pathway leading to the lobby which was a little on the slippery side. All in all i would stay here again cause its convenient.

The hotel is conveniently located in Kabukicho, a short walk from JR Shinjuku Station and just around the block from Higashi Shinjuku Metro Station. I expected the hotel to be small, stuffy and smoky and was very surprised to find it lovely, clean and very friendly.It's an interesting place to experience the vibrancy and local colour of Japan. Having some Japanese skills will be very helpful; but the staff do have some English and French skills.I was visiting Tokyo for my birthday and to spend some time with friends in ni-chome, Shinjuku's gay distract which was just a 5 minute walk away.I'll certainly stay here again, and maybe try one of the more expensive room types.

I've stayed in few places in Tokyo before (mostly business hotels) and I must say Granbell Shinjuku is an excellent place. The price is about the same as what you'd pay for other hotels in the Higashi Shinjuku area. However, this hotel is new and modern and nothing like the typical tiny business hotel rooms that smell of stale cigarette smoke. The lobby was kinda classy and modern, which is very different from the other hotels. We had the standard double room. It was slightly more spacious than the usual Japanese business hotels, so was the bathroom. Excellent decor, with a really lovely painting (wallpaper?) on the ceiling. Love the booth seat by the window, that was a nice touch. All the usual amenities (kettle, fridge, hairdryer, towels) were available. The hotel is about 10-15 minutes walk to Shinjuku station, and about 5-10 minutes walk from the main Kabukicho area, which means there is easy access to various restaurants and shops. 7-eleven is just down the street, if you need anything. So glad we finally found such a lovely non-business-hotely place in Tokyo. Definitely coming back again!

Very good stay in Feb 2014! What did I like? Courteous and helpful staff; comfortable and stylish digs; central location near subway and train station; and a tasty and wide-ranging breakfast (approx $10 per person - decent value).I would be pleased to return.

This was my second time to stay in Shinjuku and the Granbell Hotel was great. My brother and I stayed on the 12th floor in a triple loft room (I booked this room thinking there would be a western style bed in the loft but it was Japanese style mats so we ended up sharing the main area, not a drama but just something to be aware of). - Staff: very polite and friendly- Breakfast: ok, a few western choices (cereals, croissants, eggs, bacon etc). I totally support trying new foods but first thing in the morning I'm happy to remain unadventurous :)- Rooms/Hotel: very slick as it only just opened, the room was nice and immaculately clean. There is a nice rooftop bar on the 13th floor with great views (good views also from breakfast room). - Location: great once you get your bearings. We had a transfer from the airport as our flight arrived late and we were very thankful for this because we might have struggled to find the hotel in the dark. The hotel is located about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. - My advice/directions would be: take the east exit from the station, turn left then cross at the pedestrian crossing. Walk through the park area (acts as a roundabout next to station) then cross the main road heading towards the ABC Mart down to the right (look for a red and yellow sign). Walk to the end of this street, you should pass a giant Citibank building on the right. When you reach the end you will be greeted by a busy street, turn right and walk along until you reach the Baskin Robbins (right hand side). Cross the busy road over to the Mister Donut on the corner. Just next to Mister Donut (on the main road) is a pathway lined with trees. Walk down the entire pathway (you will pass some public toilets and the Golden Gai lane ways). Once you reach the end of the pathway you should see a Subway Sandwich in front/a little to the right. Cross the road so Subway is behind you, head directly up the road away from Subway towards the Aramis Hotel. Continue walking up the street until you spot the Granbell hotel building (quite tall with a visible sign). Hopefully this makes it clear for you, my directions are not necessarily the best but this is how my brother and I made it to/from the hotel in the most straightforward manner. Overall we had a great stay at this hotel and will be returning before departing Japan. The location is excellent - lots of shops, restaurants and transport nearby.

Although the rooms are in good condition with comfortable furnishings, somehow this hotel disappoints. Things are just not well thought-out. The heating / cooling controls are electronic and all in Japanese, so very difficult to understand and no guide is provided. The taps are positioned so that one cannot fill the hot water pot, and the single dryer in the laundry is incredibly slow. A small hot coffee in the lobby cafe costs 400 yen. Some hallways are stacked with boxes of towels and amenities, partially blocking them and creating a hazard in case of fire.

Location:The Granbell Hotel Shinjuku is located relatively far away form Shinjuku station and is imho still located in the red-light district of Shinjuku. Because the hotel is relatively new, the location of the hotel is located at the wrong place on google maps so be careful and inform yourself well where to go otherwise you will find yourself in the run-down red-light building which was according to our research the address of the hotel when copy+paste the official address of the hotel. After walking around asking different people who could barely speak english, we finally found the hotel opposite of small boutique hotels offering all kind of services.Rooms: Be booked the economy room and I must say even though it is very efficiently designed, the room is very small and there was nearly no space to store the luggage. Be careful with the so far uploaded pictures here on tripadvisor, those are showing the more high-end rooms which are way more expensive. Nevertheless, the room has all amenities of a high-end hotel. The only thing I would immediately change is the "aggressive" sound of the television which should rather be relaxing and welcoming. The same applies for the elevators.Breakfast:Because the hotel was very full, the queue to have breakfast was approximately 15 meters. Overall the quality of the breakfast is very basic and the whole experience is more like canteen style. The view on the other hand is nice and the staff is very friendly.Overall the hotel is a good alternative, if you can accept the inconvenient location and the small rooms.

This hotel is lovely. New, chic, sound proof and in a great location. Leave the station out of the central East exit, walk 2mins down to the main street, turn right until next car traffic lights (there are small lane way lights) turn left until next lights, uphill and three streets on right. Rooms have iPod dock, toiletries, fridge and a terrific view. Roof top bar amazing. Breakfast provides a vast choice. The rooms are very small and the view and convenience makes up for it. Enjoy

The Shinjuku Granbell opened in mid-Decemeber. It is part of the Granbell chain which has a couple of other hotels in Tokyo (notably in Shibuya).We booked the brand new Granbell hoping that we would get the same service like in Shibuya. We were in for a big bad surprise. The reception staff had no English skills to communicate on the basics..like how to pay, check in-check out, practical arrangements etc. It was a nightmare explaining to them even in sign language what we wanted. So first advice to the hotel: get some people that speak a bit of English to welcome and help tourists. The rooms were fine for the small compact sizes of Japan. We had some problems with heating which were eventually resolved.The hotel is located in the red light district. The host clubs and love hotels are all around it. Not the best district to be located. Almost a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. Think again before you book. Breakfast was included but for some reason they run out of fruit. In order to make them understand that we wanted some apples or oranges if possible we had to liaise with three people and have someone interpreting.

Incredible hotel !! Rooms are modern, new, clean and well thought out. I absolutely fell in love with this place and made my unforgettable experience in Japan that much better. Staff were polite and helpful, not that you would expect anything else from the Japanese. We were lucky to stay on the 16 floor during our stay, rooms are a size you would expect in japan, and of a perfect size for the limited time you spend in there while traveling. If your spending all your time in a hotel you may as well of stayed at home. The location was great, just far enough from Shinjuku station to walk and to be nice a quite. And if your not in the mood to eat out in the hundreds of tiny restaurants in Shinjuku and surrounding neighbourhoods the restaurant was amazing as well. One of the best meal i had while in Japan. I will be returning to japan and will definitely be making this my home while away. Thank you so much Granbell Shinjuku

It's a new hotel so all the rooms were half-priced with free breakfast, which made it worth it but as a budget traveler, I don't think I'd stay here on full-price.Good things: The hotel has that fancy modern designer feeling so 1 of my travelmates liked it a lot. Breakfast spread was good with both Japanese & Western choices. Staff were very polite and fluent in English. Everything in the room was nice and new with well-thought designs. The breakfast restaurant has a very good view as it's on a high floor. Check-out is at 12pm, which is nice and late, especially if you have a late flight out.Bad things: I stayed in the smallest room (economy double) and it was the tiniest room I've ever stayed in of any hotel in the world (and I've stayed at a few business hotels in Japan). For 1 person, I think it'd be OK but it's tight for 2.Issue: This probably was only because we were there during a peak period (new years day) but there was a 30 minute queue to be seated for breakfast in the mornings and then another 10 minute queue for the buffet. We also had to wait 20 minutes for check-in and there was luggage all over the lobby (not enough space behind the counter), which was messy and a little unsafe since the staff couldn't watch all the luggage.Iffy things: It's on the fringe of Kabukicho, a red light district. We had no trouble and saw nothing more scandalous than the outside of love hotels but it may not be for everyone. The location is near to Higashi-Shinjuku station (2 lines) so it's a bit of a walk to get to some lines at Shinjuku Sanchome or Shinjuku station. I don't know if I'd want to attempt it with luggage.Pet peeve: I didn't like the video they kept playing in the elevator because it gave the lift the effect of flashing lights. I also didn't like that the TV would be turned on when you returned to your room showing the hotel page with annoying (to me) music. But this stuff only annoys me and not other people.

This new hotel in Shinjuku sits in the middle of Kabuki-cho. The location is a bit peculiar, surrounded by love hotels and a bit in the red light district of Tokyo, so it might not be for everyone. The regular rooms are small, but apart from that the rest was great in the stay: location is perfect to get to Shinjuku metro and train lines which makes it an easy place to visit Tokyo and around it; the breakfast buffet was nice and complete with wonderful views from the top floors. A cozy bar and a terrace in the top floor as well made a perfect spot to finish the day.I will no doubt come back again here next time I am in town, rather than the more expensive hotels as the Marriott which although nice would not stay in our minds later on.

Brand new property (as of Dec 2013), so the facility is in mint condition. Nice design touches. Very good beds. Open deck bar on a high floor offers a very nice view of the Shinjuku area. Breakfast buffet has a very decent selection, both Western and Japanese breakfast items. The rooms are tiny. Our room,definitely was not the smallest one,yet it had no closet and once the luggage was in there was practically no room to move around. Sound isolation is average and, although we stayed at a high floor we could hear partying activity on the street (the hotel is in a night entertainment/ love hotel area). We could also hear our neighbors, even as they talked on the phone. The staff attitude is great, for the most part. There were some communication issues and some staff members are slower than others (took us a long while to check in). Perhaps things get fine-tuned over time. The wi-fi quality was a major frustration, regardless of where in the hotel we tried using it. In general there was a feeling of a very well maintained student dorm, brought about by average age of the guests, the noise, tight space and a very high number of guests the hotel accommodates.

The Granbell Shinjuku is situated in Kabukicho, the night entertainment district, pretty much all the hotels nearby are love hotels, although the area is not dangerous.The hotel is not easy to find, the hotel should put some pictures on the website with directions (like the Shibuya branch), it is near Hotel Atlas.Because it's brand new, the facilities are great. However, the rooms are very small, so it may feel constraining after a few days.The staff are lovely, though the level of English varies.The nearest metro station is Higashi-shinjuku, which is not the main Shinjuku station.The Shibuya branch has a better location.There is a big selection at breakfast, the quality was slightly above average, and it is much better than the breakfast at Shibuya.The wifi had a tendency to drop off. Only Japanese channels are offered, although when I stayed at a higher floor, for some reason I could tune into cable channels such as CNN and BBC. The staff said that this might be because I picked up the signal from another building.
